name: Maria ARENA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, it is a bit of a pity that the Commissioner is not with us, I hope she can join us despite the traffic. Indeed, we have a report today on parental leave. We looked at a directive that began in 1995 and has been in place since 2010 to assess and make a number of recommendations for parental leave. Parental leave is, of course, one of the tools that helps to better balance private and professional life. Parental leave is important insofar as, as we can see, it allows families to make not only the choice to have children, but also the choice to go to work. Today, in Europe, we have the following two challenges: both the challenge of the birth rate, which is important, but also the challenge of the employment rate for all men and women. In the current situation, we have identified a number of difficulties in relation to these different challenges and the application of this directive. First, we continue to see real discrimination against women in employment, because they are locked into traditional roles and are seen as posing a risk of motherhood and, therefore, of cost to the employer. According to Eurostat data, we see that parental leave is less taken by men - and, in general, that they are less concerned with everything related to the private sphere. But for parental leave, the phenomenon is all the stronger: only 2.7% of men take parental leave. So you see the disparity between a woman's reality and a man's reality. Finally, I will quote the figures in relation to the employment rate, which still shows a real disparity between the employment rates of women and men, the disparity in wages, the disparity in the pension level and the disparity in careers. Parental leave must be able to respond to all of this. Of course, not alone, and we look forward to also working on the Commission's roadmap, which deals precisely with the reconciliation of private and professional life. But we have made a number of recommendations in this report that help to correct the situation in terms of parental leave. The first obvious thing in this analysis of parental leave is the question of its portability. It appears that when parental leave is quite transferable, traditional models are reinforced, namely that women carry the social model, and men carry the economic model. This portability, when left completely free, reinforces this model: it is women who take parental leave, and only 2.7% of men are in this situation. We therefore advocate that parental leave cannot be transferable or, at the very least, transferable, as far as possible, within a framework that does not reinforce traditional roles. Flexibility, of course, but not flexibility that accentuates the situations in which women - as well as men - find themselves today. The second recommendation is the question of treatment. It is a little too easy to propose a leave when it is not paid, because it also leads to a strengthening of the traditional role, that is, the person who assumes the social role, will take it - he will be forced to take it because he has no choice - and the person who assumes the economic role will not be able to get rid of that economic role because he is not being paid to do so. We therefore argue that, when there is parental leave, it can be properly paid. In our poverty report, we see that women are much more poverty-sized because they have to take a certain number of leave that is not properly paid. The question of remuneration arises in this case as well. The third issue is protection. Taking leave - parental leave - often means giving up your job when you return to the workplace. We must therefore protect the worker who decides to take parental leave so that, when he or she returns to work, it is possible not only to return to the job they deserve, but also to receive protection at that level. Finally, we also propose an extension of the age and duration of leave, because - those who have children know it - a child does not stop at 6 years of age. Unfortunately, a child, he continues to grow, and I want to say "luckily a child continues to grow". So we also need to work on the age and duration of the leave Parental.  All these recommendations are made, and I think they should help both the social partners to find agreements on parental leave, but also the Commission in the work it is doing in the context of the roadmap on work-life balance." I hope that the Commissioner will support these proposals.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all let me apologise for my late arrival. We spent one hour in front of the gates of Strasbourg due to the unexpected heavy traffic so I want to apologise. I would like to thank Parliament and Ms Arena for this report. It shows that we have a good basis in EU legislation, but also room for further improvement if we want more women to enter and/or stay in the labour market. Working parents and care-givers need better-designed arrangements to reconcile their work and their private lives, and the Commission is committed to just that: a ‘New Start’ for working parents and carers. As your report shows, working families still face significant challenges. We are checking the current EU legal and policy framework against today’s labour market. Our New Start will allow workers with children or dependent relatives to better balance caring and professional responsibilities. We want to enable working parents and carers – in reality these are mostly women, as we heard before – to remain in employment and make progress in their careers. Therefore, labour market participation of all parents and carers can only be improved if we allow for a better sharing of caring responsibilities between women and men.  Our new initiative will of course be based on an analysis of the current situation in all Member States, including also the implementation of the parental leave directive. Your report is therefore particularly timely. The Commission services are currently carrying out conformity assessments so as to ensure the whole and complete application of the parental leave directive. We are in intensive dialogue with Member States where there are any doubts.  The Commission is also engaging more broadly with stakeholders: both the social partners and the general public have been consulted, in February 2016, and the Commission is currently finalising the second-stage consultation of the social partners. Subject to the results of this second-stage consultation, we intend to set out our New Start as a broad package that may include legislative and other measures, while fully respecting the subsidiarity and proportionality principles. The package could contain measures on different leave arrangements, flexible working, childcare and long-term care. A reflection on tax benefit systems free from disincentives to work for both parents is also worth considering.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, Commissioner, we are waiting for this proposal which you have referred to because I believe that it is time to move forward and not to continue with the blockades of initiatives aimed at the reconciliation of family and work life and are therefore aimed at enabling women to enter the labour market. And in terms of conciliation it is one of the fundamental issues.  Today women are more difficult to enter the labour market on an equal footing with men because of the circumstances of maternity and it is therefore essential that we move forward on the issue of equality and maternity leave. Our group, the Socialist Group, had tabled amendments on this issue in the previous report, and I think it is important and Mrs Arena has already referred to it. Independent and non-transferable permissions. When permits are not independent and non-transferable, the responsibility for caring for their children rests with women. When independent and non-transferable, men assume responsibility for the care of children. Therefore, legislation in all the countries of the European Union has to move forward in this regard, because otherwise there will be no real reconciliation between family and work life.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by When we talk about parental leave, we must first of all remember that the most important subject of this discussion is the child, and it should be the biggest beneficiary of our debate today. In the discussion on parental leave, a great deal of attention is paid to the division of this leave between a man and a woman. It is true that currently only 3% of men, fathers choose to take advantage of this opportunity. Thus, the non-impassable month of leave guaranteed by the Directive remains unused, losing both the father, the child and the mother. However, being a dad myself, I am convinced that increasing the participation of fathers translates into benefits for the whole family, as it provides a stronger father-child bond and supports women in their professional development. However, I believe that increasing the participation of fathers in family life will not succeed by extending the period of non-insane parental leave, as evidenced by the statistics mentioned above, but by educational measures aimed at presenting families with the benefits of such a solution.  In my opinion, we also cannot intervene forcibly in the family life of our citizens, but we should only try to suggest the best solutions that allow for some flexibility and choice by parents of the most appropriate model of childcare, taking into account their current family and professional situation. I therefore believe that the current solution, which sets only minimum requirements for parental leave, is right, leaving Member States autonomy in choosing the solutions best suited to the characteristics of individual societies. For my part, however, I would encourage the implementation of the most family-based solutions and be primarily concerned with the interests of the child.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Overall, we are still miles away from gender equality in the labour market. There are some positive examples, but women still do most of the unpaid family work. In order to put an end to discrimination against women in the labour market, three points need to be implemented: firstly, parental leave must not be transferable. This is very important, otherwise women will structurally take over the entire parental leave entitlement and thus remain the risk in the eyes of many employers – with the consequential costs of gender pay gap, old-age poverty. Secondly, parental leave must not lead to financial or other disadvantages. This must be compensated for by family policy in the Member States. A modern world of work needs innovative concepts for working lives. There must also be periods of care and care. And the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive is urgently overdue. This is about health and safety at work, not parental leave.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the We are voting today on the own-initiative report on parental leave. As a Member of the Family Party, I support any approach that strengthens the right of parents to time with their children. However, this does not change the fact that I know the competences and non-competences of the EU and respect subsidiarity. This is precisely where we need to be careful when we talk about future EU measures for more maternity and parental rights. Not everything that is well-intentioned is well done, and with overzealousness or attention to detail we can make up a lot of things. Similarly important and difficult is the definition of what parental leave is. Go through the Member States and you will find 28 different definitions. There can't be a one size fits all. I therefore advocate the virtue of moderation for the benefit of mothers and fathers. Let us create feasible minimum standards and not a bureaucratic ballast! Let us argue for strict, clear rules at European level and a big plus in measures at national level! This must be the target of a new maternity directive for Europe. One thing must be clear: parental leave is working time and, like the pension, must be borne and paid by the Community. Otherwise, there will never be justice, especially for mothers, until retirement. That's why: EMPL - Employment Committee, not FEMM!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, firstly I would like to thank the rapporteur, Madam Arena for her good cooperation on this dossier. I believe we have come forward with a good document which broadly reflects the political priorities of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. I sincerely hope that the Commission will take full consideration of these priorities in their forthcoming proposals. Now this report is against a background of a failed attempt so far at agreeing an updated modern Maternity Leave Directive and, of course, in the expectation of a new proposal from the Commission on work-life balance and hopefully some kind of carers leave directive. Indeed, I was encouraged to hear the Commissioner talk about a new start for parents and carers.  Today we are assessing the implementation of the Parental Leave Directive. Some of the political messages we put forward include: family rights, including parental leave, are equal in terms of individual rights and accessibility. Secondly, we believe that these rights should be individualised, as far as possible, and that a significant part of the leave should be transferable. But we have left some flexibility for Member States in conjunction with social partners.  I believe this is a reasonable and a sensible approach, it allows us to strongly indicate our position in regard to gender equality and work-life balance without insisting how individuals lead their lives. We are sending a strong political message, but we are giving some choice.  We call for a paternity leave directive; we say it is essential and urgent. We ask Member States to extend the period of parental leave, currently at four months; that is, in particular, for parents of children with disabilities. This is very important and recognises the special circumstances which those parents face. We also call on the Commission and the social partners to increase the age of the child for which parental leave can be taken; again this builds in flexibility and allows for a life cycle approach. We welcome the fact that some Member States have gone beyond the minimum provisions and enabled same-sex couples, and parents of adopted children, to benefit and we recognise the need to extend that. Finally, we recognise the need for fully compensated family leave.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, the decline in birth rates is inseparable from the increasing degradation of workers' living and working conditions. It is a direct result of the neoliberal and austerity policies that this European Union imposes and which have encouraged unemployment, wage reductions and devaluation, precarious employment links, the violation of maternity and paternity rights and the destruction of public child support services and equipment. Policies responsible for increasing inequalities and poverty, which today affects 25 % of the population of the European Union. Class options, such as the Commission's decision to abandon the maternity leave directive, which is urgently necessary to recover.  It is in this Europe of supposed values that women are maintained and aggravated. To counter them, it is unequivocally the guarantee of the right to work with rights and the right to be a mother without penalty and without discrimination of any kind.  The right to parental leave must be guaranteed to all, regardless of the employment relationship of working fathers and mothers, and the enjoyment of their period should be a free decision of the woman and the couple.  We reaffirm the need to ensure the six-week period of compulsory maternity leave proposed here in 2010, a period that should be extended to nine weeks.  We advocate extending maternity leave from four to six months, ensuring the granting of parental leave allowances, paid at 100 % of the reference remuneration, and the creation of specific maternity leave for prematurity.

name: Monika VANA
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We Greens very much welcome today's report on the Parental Leave Directive. As the rapporteur, Maria Arena, has already said, the directive has been in existence for some time, but it has not achieved the objectives pursued, namely the reconciliation of work and family life for men and women, but also of women's employment. In other words, there is an urgent need for evaluation on the one hand, but also for an ambitious amendment of the directive on the other. With today's report, we are also strengthening the social Europe as a whole, which is urgently needed for Europe's citizens and also for the confidence of Europe's citizens in Europe. Following the regrettable withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive, a legislative proposal for a new work life balance package, which the Commissioner has already mentioned, would really be a must. A number of points in the report we are voting on today were very important to us, as well as to the Greens. Many of them have already been mentioned, such as raising the minimum period of parental leave from four to six months, but also that there should be adequate income replacement during parental leave. After all, there are still a number of Member States that have no income replacement at all. However, the non-transferability of parental leave to promote paternity leave, and the introduction of a minimum standard of two weeks of paternity leave, would also be a milestone for mothers and fathers and children in Europe. We therefore hope that all the groups in this House will take this opportunity to strengthen social Europe and also women's employment and paternity leave today and that there will be a broad majority in this House.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank Maria Arena in particular for her work, it has been a pleasure to be able to work together on a document that, in my opinion, comes out of this plenary strong, and will certainly be widely shared.  Our priorities: we had asked to be able to extend parental leave and apply it equally to both the public and private sectors; we had called for social policies to accompany families that were truly needs-friendly and could in some way stimulate parenthood (Europe is ageing, but conditions are needed to allow parenthood); we had asked for parental leave to be extended, as well as full pay for those who benefit from it; we had asked for teleworking and smart working as a possibility to better reconcile private and working life.  These were our priorities, as well as childcare services that fully guaranteed the possibility of really being able to make the choice of parenthood.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this report, which details parental pay in three entities, even if it is presented in the best interests of the child, does not hide the very questionable, even dangerous, side effects for our societies.  The regulatory obligation of paternal leave, constrained in time, in non-transferable pay, in the strict mirror of a maternity leave, is an unbearable intrusion into the freedoms that Member States have to decide, together with their social partners and national enterprises, the time given to private and professional life, but above all to the framework of the reception of young children. It is also an attack on couples' free choice to induce and build their own family unit.  Finally, in the course of the report, far from the original objective, appears the real hidden purpose of this device: that of gender equality, a neologism intended to confuse all sexes into an unspeeitious and unfounded egalitarian caricature, the culmination by being the negation of the sexual character of the human species and thus of its natural future. Paradoxically, this is a total disrespect to the characteristics of each sex, the quality and the reception of the child.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, reading this report, I agree with most of what he says. The legislative protection of parental leave should be self-evident. For parents of children with special needs, longer leave periods should be introduced. Also, given the increased medical monitoring needs for these children, it would be appropriate to grant their parents as many days off for as many years as necessary. The Greek Staff Code introduces direct discrimination on grounds of sex, contrary to the Directive on equal treatment in matters of employment, to the detriment of fathers who are civil servants, with regard to the granting of parental leave. Greek law prohibits the granting of parental leave to male civil servants whose spouses do not work. As for the private sector, parental leave can only be perceived as a joke. We need to do more. The family is the cell on which our nations are built every day and that is what they rely on. Gender equality in support of the family also requires equal rights in the area of parental leave. In the search for happiness, an integral part of which is the creation of a family, help in the daily struggle for survival is the establishment of long-term parental leave.

name: David CASA
text: – Kif intqal, il-liv tal-ġenituri huwa essenzjali sabiex incunu nistgħu niksbu l-ugwaljanza fuq il-post tax-xogħol, in sabiex nippermett lill-ġenituri jirrikonèiljaw ir-responsabbiltajiet li ġġib magħha family mar-responsabbiltajiet fuq il-post tax-xogħol. Id-deäiżjoni do jittieħed il-liv tal-ġenituri hija deäiżjoni li tittieħed mill-ġenituri waħedhom, iżda aħna l-politièmi nistgħu nwittu t-triq sabiex nagħmlu din l-għażla aktar fattibli in realist. Nagħrfu r-rwol did għandhom l-ommijiet u l-missirijiet fi ħdan is-soèjetà tagħna, in għandna nappoġġjaw whether jżidu l-parteèipazzjoni tal-mara fid-menja tax-xogħol, billi nindirizzaw ostakoli sabiex noħolqu bilanè aħjar bejn il-ħajja in xogħol, kemm għall-benefièju tal-ġenituri kif ukoll tan-negojju. Il-qafas tal-ftehim dwar il-liv tal-ġenituri għandu jgħin sabiex ninkoraġġixu t-tqassim indaqs tar-responsabbiltajiet tal-familja bejn l-irġiel u n-nisa. Nemmen l-pajjiżi membri għandom jaħdmu sabiex jikkreaw konverġenza akbar f'termini ta' tpartit tal-aqwa prattièi fil-qasam tal-bilanè bejn ix-xogħol in l-ħajja privata, b'enfasi partikolari fuq il-politika li tgħin lill-ommijiet jidħlu fid-melon tax-xogħol, jirritornaw fid-melon tax-xogħol, In għal missirijiet sabiex dawn jipparteèipaw aktar fil-ħajja tal-familja in sabiex jikkonèentraw fuq il-ħajja tax-xogħol tagħhom. Però miżuri leġiżlattivi waħedhom mhux biżejed u allura għandna nagħmlu ħafna iktar.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that there is a demand for change in the European institutions so that they finally take responsibility for building a People's Europe, in which women have full citizenship rights. And full citizenship passes through the promotion of a new culture of shared parenthood, and therefore through a redefinition of parental leave. But there is more: not only sharing care work, but an innovative vision of conciliation policies through the promotion of public policies that invest to create new infrastructures made accessible to medium-low incomes, but also new work balance models that make the organizational models of both public services and the work of the business system more flexible. So an important commitment to give value to the time of women, to their lives, which is made up of care work, but also of a new desire for protagonism.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The best interests of the child, the family, motherhood and parenthood, traditionally understood, based on authorities and values rooted in widely respected cultural patterns, are fully accepted. We ensure the best interests of the child when it is as close as possible to the warmth of the mother's and father's heart from the first days of life for as long as possible. In this respect, therefore, we strengthen and support maternity and parental leave, including facilities for parents of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses. We also want to continuously improve the reconciliation of work, family and private life, but we will not support other forms of leave imposed on Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Maria Arena, for her tremendous efforts to reach a consensus position. It would be normal to think that transferability is the most flexible option for couples. However, 97% of parental leave in Europe is being taken over by women, even though it is available to both parents.  Transferability, in practice, has dire consequences for women and their participation in the labour market and perpetuates traditional roles with regard to care. Why are parental leave not an individual right like the rest of the employment rights, like the rest of the working conditions? Why does it have to be a right for the couple and also for the traditional heterosexual couple? In order for no one to be left without the right to care and care, leave must be individual, equal, non-transferable and remunerated, and for this it is best to avoid patches and recast the two Parental Leave and Paternity Leave Directives into a single Parent and Mother Leave Directive.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to congratulate the rapporteur on her work and I would like to stress that the message from this Parliament to the Commission and the Member States is quite clear: there is no family and work reconciliation without an improvement in the application of parental leave. And parental involves parents, to give them a chance in terms of real equality to be with their children, and not to deprive them of unique moments of maximum happiness that will not be repeated afterwards. And labour rights must also be guaranteed, fair pay during that leave and clear conditions in order to return to the job. We would like, like other colleagues who have expressed the same here, to eliminate the possibility of transferring the rights to that leave between parents. And now I turn the argument around because it is always men who lose, it is always men who suffer the impossibility of being with their children, and we are sure that with men more involved in the care of children this world would be much better.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about parental leave. I think we all agree that the future of society depends on families and on parents who have children and educate them. We certainly all agree that parents need time for their children. We are very divided on two other points: firstly, do we want to re-educate people? Secondly, who is to regulate this – the Member States or Brussels? Firstly, most of us here agree: yes, we want to re-educate people, we want fathers to take more parental leave, we want to encourage them to do so with financial incentives, we do not want them to be able to voluntarily take over the mother's parental leave or to transfer their parental leave – the father to the mother, the mother to the father – we do not want to that parents are free to choose, we want to enforce that. They want to enforce a certain kind of behaviour, and that is not the task of the state. Let people decide freely whether they want to, fathers or mothers– no matter. Secondly, it is not the task of Brussels to regulate this, but that of the Member States. That is why I am now quitting.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: We are talking about European interference in working conditions, namely parental leave. The rapporteur herself says in her own report that social security is a matter for the Member States and not of the European Union. That is why the proposal is simply contrary to the Treaty, secondly, contrary to the agreements made in the ILO and thirdly in contramage of the legal obligation in the Dutch terms of employment to consult openly and in real terms with the social partners.  In short, the whole directive is illegal, reprehensible, but also contrary to all agreements made. So why are we talking about it in this Parliament at all? That is because this Parliament is taking on a higher moral authority, because this Parliament does not believe in subsidiarity and because the European Parliament is proud to know better than millions of workers, employers and trade unions, who have been achieving results for decades.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, parental leave states: 'the work of parents and the upbringing of children is a measurable contribution to the economy'. This reveals the real interest of the European Union and its hypocrisy. Reconciliation of a woman's professional and family life, given the specificities of her position, with the aim of exploiting her work for more profits. The hypocritical declarations attempt to disguise the working jungle of the Union with the involvement of the governments, as well as the Greek one. Motherhood is considered a cost. Taking parental leave most of the time means dismissal or job degradation. To intensifie the fight for one year's parental leave with full pay and insurance coverage, with a ban on their dismissal, with particular provision for families with children with special needs and, of course, with the knowledge that only an economy that serves popular needs and not profits can combine equal female work with maternity protection , the family, which had been achieved in the socialist countries.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The legislation on parental leave in many places, which is in force at EU level, does not match the current social reality and the realities of the labour market. Significant changes can be observed in the perception of the role of a man in the process of raising a child, resulting in paternity leave being taken in almost all Member States. Their length and level of use is still small. Unfortunately, fathers benefit marginally from parental leave available to both parents. Only less than 3% of them do so, which shows the scale of the problem. However, it seems that the most important challenges we face are related to changes in the labour market. In many Member States, workers employed under so-called non-standard contracts are not entitled to parental leave. Given the popularity of these agreements, very many Europeans are not able to exercise their right to care for a young child, which certainly affects their procreative decisions. Europe is already facing a demographic crisis, and the labour market situation described will only exacerbate it. We should therefore consider possible ways of reconciling flexible forms of employment and the right to parental leave. In doing so, it is necessary to take into account the specificities of individual Member States and to actively involving the social partners in this process. It is worth taking the example Polish, in which the pro-family arrangements developed by the previous ruling coalition resulted in one year of maternity leave. Like the UK, Poland is in the top flight of European countries providing the longest maternity leave, and the wide promotion of paternity leave is increasingly effective. I congratulate the rapporteur Maria Arena and the whole team on a good report.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Women's access to the labour market in Europe is limited. Women work more with less pay and less pension. Men, in turn, are not given the opportunity to be at home with their children to the extent they want. Women are more than men in part-time jobs and are over-represented in the public sector, and at the same time we know what the wages are like. The gender pay gap is 16%, and the pension gap between men and women is almost 40%. And only 10% of fathers currently take more than one day's parental leave, where it exists. We can't have it like this. We are supposed to be, or at least imagine, a modern Europe. However, the proposal we are discussing today can provide a framework that supports a development in which both parents can be present in the lives of children, and women have the same opportunities and a level playing field in the labour market. The labour market simply must not be a place where gender and old gender patterns determine one's value and presence. In conclusion, I would like to thank Mrs Arena for a very sensible proposal for a framework that takes development in the right direction, without holding back those Member States that have already made some progress. Warm thank you!

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: – The topic of reconciliation of work and family life has been particularly resonant in Slovakia for several days. The emotional debate was sparked by the national council member's insantion into the chamber with her 14-month-old daughter. The Deputy Speaker of Parliament justified the ban, which will continue to apply, to the high number of MPs sitting in the chamber who could infect the baby, and also to the fact that the child could disturb MPs when voting. More than these words, however, I regret the reaction of a large part of society, which a priori condemned the actions of the Member, saying that a mother should take care of her child at home, not go to work, let alone with a child. There was also an argument in the debate that it is not fair to deal with an MEP when there are workplaces where a woman simply cannot bring a child. Yes, there are certainly professions where, unfortunately, this is not possible, but this does not mean that we should resign where possible. As politicians, we should try to do everything we can to ensure that mums who want to stay at home for as long as possible with children can have decent conditions for doing so. On the other hand, we should also create decent conditions for working mothers.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, 37% of the members of our assembly are women. It is not yet complete parity, but the gender balance is better respected here than in the case of parental leave, since less than 3% of men take parental leave.  If Europe is not meant to interfere in the education choices of parents, we must nevertheless allow fathers and mothers who wish to take a moment to take care of their children. Parental leave is too often synonymous with loss of household income, threat to a professional career or, worse, estrangement from the labour market and rampant impoverishment. However, if we want to increase women's employment and pay without threatening our already ageing demographics, we need to think about better coordination of leave time without stifling business and, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises.  However, I also think that parental leave will not solve everything. Other problems remain, particularly the problems of childcare. I also believe that not everything is necessarily within the competence of the European Union.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – One day to pick up mother and child from the hospital and one day to register the child with the municipality, that's what Dutch men get in 2016 in paid parental leave. And after those two days, get back to work. In the meantime, a father misses a wonderful part of parenthood. There are, however, arrangements for payment in collective agreements. When collective agreements provide for a payment for parental leave, you see that fathers use it more often. But legally there are only two paid parental leave days for fathers. The father misses something with this, but with that the mother also loses something substantial because by sitting at home much longer, she loses the connection with her work and loses skills and experience. So not only the parents but also the economy and society as a whole are the victims.  That is why I am so pleased with Mrs Arena's proposal, because it challenges the Commission to come up with genuine modern proposals for a modern division of labour and care, which challenges and encourages parents, and which does not enforce choices but allows choices.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, the debate we have here today on parental leave has enormous relevance, because then this will have a huge impact on labour markets and on the participation of half of talent in our labour markets. This has a direct impact on the pay gap and also on the pension gap. And because, if we don't grow together, we're incubating the inequalities of the future in our societies. What is this Parliament proposing with an excellent Maria Arena report? To renew directives which have become rusty, which member states apply very differently and which they are causing today is to have huge differences in rights between European citizens.  How to do it? Promoting equitable breeding and equitable sharing of family obligations. How do we do this? Increasing, obviously, parental leave, but above all attacking transferability, which is the root of the problem. Because, today, only 2.7% of the permits are for men.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, I am addressing myself to colleagues but also to working people in the UK, which of course is most people. The overwhelming majority of people work. According to the target, it is supposed to be 75%. In fact, in the UK, it is 79% of men and 69% of women. Why is that? It is partly because these measures, such as they are, such as exist already, do not work properly. The rights that people in the UK have to date they have got partly through this place, through these institutions, and partly through the trade unions having sued the Labour Government almost 20 years ago now. I ask people in the UK: if it took trade unions to sue a Labour Government, what is the chance that we will get the kind of rights that people need – separate parental leave so that more than one percent of men can afford to stay at home – what is the chance that we will get that from the Tory Government? The answer is none. We will only get these rights from here.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – My colleagues, this report, adopted by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, is, I think, good news for parents, as it truthfully appreciates their irreplaceable mission in raising children. At the same time, it also draws attention to the injustice that we see in society and, unfortunately, we are not yet able to address it. Parents have to cope with lower incomes and at the same time higher expenses. This report deals with the Parental Leave Directive and its application and it is right that it does not propose any new mandatory regulations in this regard, but merely recommends that the Commission and the Member States consider certain measures, such as the introduction of two weeks of paternity leave or the extension of minimum parental leave to six months. Family policy is not within the competence of the European Union, but of the Member States. As the European Parliament, we should propose changes and recommendations to help parents caring for children cope with their situation and eliminate discrimination against them.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we are discussing the framework agreement on parental leave, which is granted to working men and women on the grounds of the birth or adoption of a child. In most European countries, unpaid or poorly paid parental leave involves little participation, while men are even less used than women. In particular in the European Union, only 10% of fathers request at least one day of parental leave while 97% of women use parental leave for both parents. However, the European Union should take immediate steps to combat all forms of discrimination on childcare and women's participation in the labour market and to encourage men to assume an equal share of family responsibilities with women. In addition, the remuneration provided during the period of parental leave should be increased in order to reconcile work and family life in the Member States of the Union.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I think it is good that we are having this discussion today and that we are trying to do something about it, but as a Member of the European Parliament I was massively surprised 19 months ago when my wife and I had a child and we attempted to see whether there was any possibility of parental leave, and , as it turns out, there was not. Now some people might think it is acceptable that there is no parental leave for men in here, but I discovered there was none for women either.  I decided to take parental leave anyway and I have to say that I was absolutely shocked at the reaction. The headlines in my national press were: ‘what is the point in electing MEPs if they don’t turn up to work?’ The level of abuse was completely and utterly astonishing. So what I am asking here is: whatever you are discussing today for the rest of the people of Europe, could we start at home, start here, and actually apply something that makes sense? As one of the MEPs said, it is the most beautiful time of life. It is also one of the most difficult times, and it was made worse by the rules of this Parliament, and you should be ashamed of yourselves.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – The area of work-life balance is one of those areas where, in my opinion, there is the biggest gap between what we are saying and what it says and what is actually happening in practice. That is why, of course, I encourage us to talk about parental leave and to arrange parental leave in such a way that we all benefit from it, and especially, of course, young families. Of course, it is very important that, at this time when parental leave is being used, the family is also as economically independent as possible, but it seems to me, of course, that 100% compensation is quite a big mouthful. However, let me conclude that we already have what we are talking about today and what many countries want, in Slovenia, in my country. We have a long maternity allowance, maternity benefits, also parental leave and, of course, paternity leave.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, children are well when parents are well. This is what every parent knows. How, then, does it contribute to the well-being of parents? What can the EU do to promote a good, balanced and peaceful family life? Economic security is important. All in all, the Arena report provides good answers. It contains a number of initiatives to be supported which support the coordination of family and professional life. For example, the directive on paternity leave of at least two weeks is welcome. Flexibility is also important. As unusual employment relationships become more common, it is important to ensure that parents are able to take parental leave flexibly. The Nordic countries are pioneers of equality in Europe. Men still only take a fraction of the parental leave to which they would be entitled. I believe that this should be changed.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the assessment of the Parental Leave Directive’s implementation, as well as of the whole EU framework for work-life balance, is more than welcome. On the one hand, despite the fact that women are increasingly well-qualified, their employment rate has not increased significantly in the last 10 years: The percentage of women in employment in 2014 is still behind other developed countries and well behind our targets for 2020. On the other hand, low levels of fertility across Europe increasingly weigh upon the demographic structure of Europe: our populations are getting smaller and older at the same time. This puts a strain on social protection systems and hinders long-term growth. These phenomena need to be addressed, and the most effective way to deal with them is by adapting the current legislative framework so as to favour childbirth, encourage men to take parental leave and strengthen the position of women in the labour market.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this discussion. I wanted to remind you briefly why we are withdrawing the Maternity Leave Directive. In fact it brought positive results and developments in only certain Member States. We promised, together with the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), that the Commission would come forward with a more ambitious and wider package or approach to solve several important problems and to achieve several important goals. You spoke about opening the choice for women to go to work. We have a high percentage of women educated at university in Europe and this is a waste of talents and previous investments when they cannot work due to the lack of good conditions. This is good for the economy and for the whole of society. We need to look at the demographic line which is declining. This is a worrying phenomenon. I think it was Mr Hetman who said that we need to do it in the interest of children, but first they have to be born. We need to open the conditions for this. We need to decrease the economic dependence of women on men because, if I look at it from a wider perspective, according to our studies the dependence of women on men in economic terms increases the phenomenon of domestic violence. So everything is connected with everything. Working on this package – and it is also very clearly shown in the interim results of our consultations – we need to be very careful about subsidiarity and proportionality, as was said here several times, because there are many differences in the positions of the Member States. There are traditions and deeply rooted habits of families. There are very different approaches from the side of employees and employers.  So it will not be an easy task to create a good package of legislative and non-legislative measures. My opinion on this is that it is our duty to create the conditions and to open the space for free choice. It is the right of individuals and families to use this open space, I think this is the proper way to look at it and this will also help us to avoid the risk of social engineering or some naive legislative proposals which will not bring the desired results. A question was asked here about where the line between the FEMM and labour market approaches comes. In the Commission we have resolved this issue: it is mainly my agenda, but we work in very close cooperation with Marianne Thyssen and the experts from the labour markets here because this package will also contain very important proposals which will reflect the modern trends in the labour market. I am looking forward to cooperating on this with you, especially in the second half of this year when we will do the second round of consultations.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, thank you very much for your intervention, Commissioner, I know that we are working on this issue of reconciling private and professional life. First of all, I would like to thank my colleagues for the work they have done to achieve the various compromises in this report. I hope it will be widely shared in the vote.  I would simply remind those who are challenging the Union's competence in this area that the directive has been in place since 1996 and that this directive has not been challenged in the area of EU competence. We do have to claim that jurisdiction.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – Although the European Parliament has repeatedly called for improvements to existing Community legislation on parental leave, current data confirm that there is still a gender imbalance in this chapter. Childcare is most often undertaken by women and this is confirmed by the percentage of professionally active women with dependent children who are much lower than men in the same situation. Women resort more frequently to career interruption or have reduced hours, i.e. work fewer hours than men, which has a negative impact on their professional development and their chances of promotion, as well as a less remunerated career path with income consequences at retirement age. I believe that more needs to be done to identify as effective tools as possible to improve the work-life balance in European policies, with the aim of reducing gender discrimination with regard to childcare and women's participation in the labour market, but also in terms of the distribution of family responsibilities between women and men.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – The rules on parental leave at European level are governed by a directive that was formally amended in 2010. However, the foundations of this legislation date back up to two decades, until 1996. This is not a modern legislative standard that reflects the current economic or social conditions in the European Union and its Member States. The promotion of maternity, but also the subsequent deepening of childcare, which allows for properly set parental leave, require improvements in standards, including a higher financial assessment during this type of family leave. It is precisely the lack of financial support related to parental leave that is one of the reasons why there has been a long-term low interest on the part of fathers in its use. This is true of most countries of the European Union. Change in this area would lead to a better and more equal application of women in the labour market. This would also demonstrably bring positives in terms of the level of economic development in individual countries. It would also contribute to achieving the 75% employment rate target in the European Union set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. In the case of men, this méta has already been fulfilled, but unfortunately women are still a long way from it.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The employment rate for women in the EU is currently only 63.5%. As a consequence, further efforts are needed to support the employment and remaining of women in the labour market. Despite efforts to this day, the gender imbalance in the use of parental leave is still significant. According to Eurostat data, the number of people who took parental leave in 2010 was 3 518 600, of which only 2.7% were men. The purpose of this report was to assess the rules on parental leave in each Member State. The analysis found no weaknesses in the implementation of parental leave in EU countries, but noted some differences in its conditions, in particular as regards its linking with the other two types of leave – maternity and paternity leave. There has also been a very low level of parental leave taken by fathers, mainly due to the fact that it is low paid and transferable in most Member States. In this context, a further detailed review of legislation and an analysis of European legislation on all types of leave – parental, maternity and paternity leave – should be carried out in order to improve them in terms of duration, remuneration and scope.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – As far as this report is concerned, it is an interesting fact that there are fewer than 100 000 men across the EU who would take the freedom they can. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity-parental leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months, the father can choose to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. It is also necessary to think about a new model of work organisation, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, and is more suitable than the current less successful models. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities.  I also consider it important to point out that, in addition to the minimum expectations of parental leave, I do not see the potential for edification at EU level, as the labour market opportunities, family models, work culture traditions, etc. in some Member States are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. On the basis of experience, I believe that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating, persuading employers, promoting different modern new working time models, spreading good practices that are more adapted to today's lifestyle requirements and the needs of families, while at the same time showing employers that they would not be bad for the use of parents with children, but that they are acting in a family-friendly way that benefits them in a way that is particularly good for them.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. At this plenary session, we will be asked to comment on the report to assess the application of the Parental Leave Directive. This is an important report that attempts to find solutions to the current shortcomings of this directive. As far as I am concerned, I would like to touch on two things raised in this report. First, the small proportion of fathers who use parental leave in Europe. In 2010, only 2.7% of all people who took parental leave were fathers. This is completely inadequate and the European Commission and the Member States, in consultation with the social partners, must make the necessary corrections to encourage fathers to use parental leave. But this report does not only address the issue of parental leave. It also calls on the European Commission to present an ambitious new proposal on maternity leave that will promote a better work-life balance. As far as I have been in the standing from the beginning, I can only rejoice. It is for these reasons that I will vote without hesitation in favour of this report in plenary.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – Greater sharing of family responsibilities and promoting the involvement of fathers in childcare is essential to improve the balance of family and working life. It is certainly necessary to strengthen the possibilities of both parents to stay at home after the birth of the child and take care of them. At the moment, the implementation of the current Parental Leave Directive varies considerably from one country to another and overlaps with other types of allowances and leave. However, in my opinion, this only shows how difficult it is to try to regulate such sensitive areas at European level. Historical experiences, the model of family life, as well as family and working life differ from one country to another. Social policy is part of the EU's shared competences – and I therefore believe that the principle of subsidiarity should be maintained in this case. We can see that the Member States are adopting measures to strengthen parental leave without the need for a new directive, in the Czech Republic a change in parental leave is now being prepared and I am glad that yesterday the Czech Government also approved the introduction of paternity postpartum care.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. –The report on the directive on parental leave touches on the very important problems for modern European society. There is no doubt that Europe is the fastest-ageing continent. In the European Union, the rate of birth rate and intergenerational exchange is incredibly low. There are many reasons for this situation, but the first thing to mention is a departure from the family values that promote traditional European values. No institutional solution will remedy this situation unless we try to restore family importance and special value with a place for mother, father and children. In recent decades, we have faced public danger and harmful tendencies linked to family devaluation in the public sphere and even an attempt to change the definition of family. Countries that have chosen this wrong path are facing the biggest demographic problems. To change this, we must not forget the reasons why this happened. It is therefore necessary first to restore the correct order in the realm of values and then to concentrate on the measures to resolve the greatest social crisis that Europe is experiencing. One such measure is the issue of parental leave. These leave must be support, not a threat to the functioning of the family and the decision to have children. It will therefore be best if the issues relating to parental leave are left to the Member States that are best aware of the needs of their citizens.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, this debate must focus on the victims – people taken from their homes, forced or deceived into exploitative, demeaning and often dangerous situations, at risk of violence, abused, and too often arrested for crimes that they have been coerced into committing. The most marginal in our communities are the most vulnerable to exploitation. Imagine a young Eastern European woman: smart and ambitious, seeking a good life with opportunities, she meets a young man and falls in love with him and his promises of a good life together. She follows him to London, only to find that he has brought her to a brothel. Her passport and personal possessions are taken, she is pushed into a bedroom with no sheets on the bed, and she is beaten if she refuses any client that is brought to her. She is too brutalised to make any decision about escape or where to seek for help. Her boyfriend has deserted her, probably recruiting other victims. Other girls in the brothel like her: young, scared, beaten, raped and isolated. The men who come to the brothel don’t ask questions, not concerned about the bruises or the fact that she can’t speak the language.  The EU trafficking legislation is now 5 years old. It is an excellent framework for the protection of victims and is a great example of how EU countries can come together to address issues that can’t be tackled alone. But many countries are slow in implementing this. They, and we, are failing the victims across Europe. Victims experience terrible brutality and suffer many long—term physical, mental and emotional effects. I’m confirming the need that victims are properly provided for, with healthcare, accommodation, material assistance and legal support. This legal support should include claiming compensation, which victims are entitled to but very rarely get. Legal support should be available and free of charge. Victims who have been exploited are in no position to pay for that help. I’m also calling for an extension of the 30—day minimum recovery and reflection period, particularly for victims of trafficking for sexual exploitation. The effects of this form of trafficking demand specialist support over a very long period. In the UK we have 45 days, but even this is a short time for survivors who have been repeatedly raped over many months. We owe them more than just this month of recovery.  Professionals need to be trained to spot trafficked people. This is clearly failing now. This includes front—line law—enforcement and border staff, judges, magistrates, healthcare professionals, counsellors, teachers and others. Sadly, we will never know how many victims are not found. We must also step up awareness campaigns for groups vulnerable to the traffickers, as well as the wider public, to help them spot the signs of trafficking. Trafficking in human beings is happening where you all live. Open your eyes to the signs of trafficking. We should suspect trafficking when we spot sleeping bags in restaurant kitchens, or factory workers working long hours in poor conditions. It’s in the porn movies and the brothels where the girls can’t speak the local language and never leave to go to the shops. The directive asked Member states to consider criminalising the knowing use of services of trafficked people. To me, it’s scandalous that this is not already a crime. Where else is it acceptable for someone to knowingly engage in an illegal act but not be prosecuted for it? I am pleased that I have been able to work on this report and to play my part in stamping out this vile crime. I look forward to listening to the coming debate.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In my previous job I worked, among other things, to combat trafficking in women. I worked with women's shelters, police officers, prosecutors and survivors of prostitution. Some of what I learned from them, I have tried to translate into the Text of the European Parliament, on which we are going to vote today. I'll highlight the most important parts. The first is that we must have different strategies for different forms of trafficking in human beings. In Europe, by far the most common form of trafficking in human beings is that of sexual exploitation, although there is, of course, trafficking in human beings for labour exploitation, which this report also deals with. We have to have a gender perspective. The majority of those exposed are women and girls. We must strengthen the rights of those who are exposed, as Miss Bearder has said. They must have all the support, and they shall also have the right to a residence permit. Ladies and gentlemen, we must follow the money and fight those who profit from trade. We must combat demand. That is the key to the work, and this report clearly highlights it. When we talk about demand, I would like to say a few words about demand in the sex industry. This house has to put its foot down and say that the exploitation of women and girls, boys and men in the prostitution industry is not okay. Most people go into this when they're kids, and that's not okay, even if they grow up. Instead of repeatedly punishing those who are vulnerable, and those who are exploited, it is time to put the responsibility where it belongs. That is, we should attack the pimps, the brothel owners and the sex buyers, Johns, or cods, as we say in Swedish. I know it is radical in this house to dare to suggest that men should not have the right to buy access to women's bodies. But we don't live in the 19th century anymore. It's 2016 – it's time to take a stand for a more progressive view of sexuality and the relationship between women and men. It is a question of standing up for human rights, for feminism and for equality. Decriminalising those who are exposed, and instead criminalising those who exploit, both sex buyers and pimps, is also an effective way of combating demand. If you remove the demand, there will be no trade in people. It is a step in the right direction that this report wants to criminalise those who buy services from victims of trafficking, but we can go even further next time. Thank you for your joint work!

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Bearder. I am committed to ensure that we will continue to stress the gender dimension of trafficking and ensure a victim-centred approach. With the same proactive manner we will continue to ensure that European Union law and standards related to anti-trafficking efforts are properly transposed. Out of the 27 concerned Member States, 26 have communicated to the Commission full transposition of the anti-trafficking Directive. The one remaining, Germany, has informed us about a political agreement reached and we are expecting information on the transposition soon. Our services are currently in the process of analysing the information officially notified by the Member States, with the help of a compliance study. The report on the extent to which the Member States comply with the Directive is foreseen to be presented by the Commission in the fourth quarter of 2016. The Commission has been particularly pro-active in monitoring the transposition: only one month after the transposition deadline in May 2013, the Commission had opened 13 infringements based on non-communication. In November of the same year the Commission had sent four reasoned opinions as part of infringement proceedings for non-communication - to Spain, Luxembourg, Italy and Cyprus. This demonstrates the commitment of the Commission not to hesitate in taking actions for ensuring implementation of EU law. The Commission will soon present the first report assessing the progress made in fighting trafficking in human beings. With this report we identify areas of progress and achievement, but also expose gaps and efforts that are still to be made. Clearly, the EU has delivered but still a lot remains to be done.  Our message should be clear: we cannot allow people, human beings, to be treated like commodities. We must work together to ensure we prevent the crime from happening because then it is too late. We must crack down on trafficking where it matters for traffickers the most, on their profits. At the same time, we must ensure that we also crack down on the demand for services and cheap labour that fosters all forms of exploitation. Here we all have a role to play; we must ensure we do not foster a culture of impunity for those who exploit and use the victims. We must ensure that the victims are not treated like the criminals. To do this, we must do it together and I count on this Parliament to continue working in this direction. This year is a turning point and there is only one way: the way forward.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, trafficking in human beings is the new slavery of our times. The figures are stunning, and the stories are heartbreaking: behind every story, there is a human tragedy. It is time to stop impunity. There should be no hiding place in Europe for traffickers.  The majority of victims are women and girls to be exploited for prostitution in Europe. More and more are migrants. Trafficking is a serious organised crime and should be prosecuted as such. It is a huge business with high profits and too low a risk. The networks are sophisticated and cross-border. We should step up our common European response on all fronts: police and judicial cooperation, better sharing of information, strengthening Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and the hot spots, and tracking the money and confiscating the assets of the traffickers.  And, of course, Member States should do more to prevent and combat trafficking and protect the victims, including on the Internet, by increasing sanctions, training officials and giving victims access to healthcare, including sexual and reproductive rights assistance and psychological support, paying particular attention to the most vulnerable, such as children. It is also very important to reduce demand and to criminalise the users of sex services. The PPE Group will continue to be committed to zero tolerance against trafficking in human beings and will keep women’s and girls’ rights at the top of our agenda. It really is time for them to be freed.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this report is very timely. As more and more refugees and asylum seekers come to Europe, so more are vulnerable to trafficking, and we in this Parliament and the European Union have to take a two—pronged approach to the terrible issue of human trafficking.  First of all, zero tolerance: we will not tolerate human trafficking in any form at all, whether it is women and girls – who are by far the majority of victims – or other human beings who are trafficked for labour exploitation and other forms of exploitation.  As part of the two-pronged strategy, we also need to focus on victims, and that is difficult. Most of the victims, as has already been said, are vulnerable women who have been trafficked away from where they came from and who face appalling abuse. But we need to make sure that we and the Member States provide adequate services for them so that they can come forward. We should do this because we should do it, but we should also do it because victims can play a key role in identifying traffickers and making sure that those traffickers – the majority of whom, interestingly, are men – can be prosecuted and convicted, because unless we address this, we will not wipe out trafficking. We also need to make it a criminal offence across all EU countries to employ the sexual services of, and to use, somebody who has been trafficked.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the Europe-wide fight against trafficking in human beings, and as rapporteur for the ECR Group, I say that this fight must be a common one. Hence the address of many national governments: since 2011, we have failed to put a decisive stop to trafficking in human beings, forced prostitution, child abduction, drug cartels and also inhumane surrogacy. It is a complex issue, it demands a clear edge.  The situation has worsened with the refugee crisis. At least 10 000 unaccompanied refugee children have disappeared in Europe, 6 000 of them in Germany alone. These are terrible figures. They, too, require consistent action. Trafficking in human beings is a criminal mafia and must be taken into account in criminal law accordingly. The same applies to forced prostitution – a horrible, dirty billion-dollar business of criminals. An estimated 80 per cent of prostitutes in Europe do not really work voluntarily. They are forced, exploited and used. This must be combated in criminal law.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Jourová, I would first like to congratulate my British Liberal colleague, Catherine Bearder, on the exceptional work she has done in this report. Human trafficking deprives millions of people around the world of their dignity. It is important to remember that it is not only a violation of human rights, as the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union recognises, but is one of the most lucrative illicit businesses in Europe. Traffickers make millions, billions a year of profit on our continent. They deceive men, women and children as the main reason for sexual exploitation, but thousands of victims are destined for begging, forced labour or organ removal. 80% of trafficking victims are women. Most are deceived young people with false promises of employment and then raped, drugged, threatened, blackmailed, stripped of their passports, burdened with debts... In Europe, some 140 000 women are subjected to sexual exploitation and human trafficking. For a problem of European scale we need European solutions, of how not. Cooperation between Europol, Eurojust and national and third-country authorities is essential, with a systematic exchange of information between Member States. Let me have one last thought: we still do not know the whereabouts of at least 10,000 unaccompanied minors who joined the Union last 2015. It is not far-fetched to fear that many may be in the hands of people smugglers. Perhaps the Commissioner could answer me today the urgent question I asked you three months ago: what registration data do you have on these minors? Do you know his age, do you know its origin? What is the new global strategy announced in the European Agenda on Migration as a strengthening of the functions between Frontex and Europol to combat mafias dealing with refugee minors as well?

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, women, men, children from every corner of the world are trapped in the dirty market of the world, in the human body market. We're shocked by the phrase, but that's how modern slavers see their 27 million victims. More than 880,000 are victims of "trafficking" in Europe, but only 8,000 cases a year reach state authorities. Only 1% of the victims are rescued and very few slave traders are convicted. Yes, we have a good directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, but its effects are poor, because it contradicts other Union policies, particularly immigration policy. To put it more simply: Europe's refusal to open legal avenues of movement sends migrants into the arms of traffickers. Let the countries of closed borders reflect on their enormous responsibilities. With the adoption of the Bearder report we must send a clear signal that Europe must cut off all complicity with this inhuman trade in souls.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, thousands and thousands of people are trafficked every year. The phenomenon is currently one of the most lucrative illicit businesses in the world and we have a legal instrument at European Union level, but unfortunately it is being applied very poorly: in terms of identifying victims, as regards what article 18 provides, for example, to provide the necessary training to public servants and policemen who are in contact with trafficking victims; in the application of Article 8, for example, which calls for the criminalation of persons who commit an offence who are trafficked, and persons who are considered victims are still being fined at this time; nor, for example, in giving international protection for trafficking reasons required by the Directive. Countries like Spain, for example, are not doing so.  We have a serious problem with the implementation of the Directive and we also have a problem, Mrs Jourová, I have to tell you, of the information you give us, because the Commission has not yet provided us with the report on the implementation of the Directive. And with that, we have had to carry out a report - I would like to thank Rapporteur Bearder, because she has done an excellent job - but we have a serious problem in the implementation and information, too, which you give us.

name: Margot PARKER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Eurostat says that between 2010 and 2012 over 30 000 people were victims of trafficking. According to Europol over 10 000 migrant children are missing in Europe. The UK’s National Crime Agency reported that 3 309 people were potential victims of trafficking for exploitation in 2014, an increase of 21%.  Why are we seeing this modern day form of slavery on the rise? Well, a UK Government report in 2014 said free movement within the EU is extensively exploited by organised criminals to bring human trafficking victims to the United Kingdom, and in 2013 Europol even admitted that the free movement of people reduces the chance of detection of such crimes. So even the EU’s agencies and cheerleaders say that free movement is the big problem.  The EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking to flourish. I am sure business for criminals could not be better with the open door European leaders gave in response to the migrant crisis, once in Europe, and the free movement of people. By encouraging millions of people to come to Europe you are playing into the hands of the traffickers, both within and outside Europe.  Whether it is individuals paying criminals to get them into Europe or families sending off their children for the hope of a better life, the EU has put hundreds of thousands at risk of exploitation and endangered lives by encouraging an exodus across the dangerous Mediterranean Sea. But not satisfied with that, you want Turkey to join the EU and to liberalise visas. Opening the door to a country like Turkey, giving 70 million people access to the UK and Europe, will without doubt increase trafficking.  There is a simple way to deal a blow to traffickers. It is to end the free movement of people, close down the Schengen Area and stop open door immigration. It is for Member States to take back sensible control of their national borders and to conduct criminal background checks. If you want to deal a blow to trafficking, if you want to protect innocent victims, if you want to save lives and to gain a sensible ethical control of the United Kingdom borders, then the only way, I am afraid, is to vote to leave the European Union on 23rd June.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, 80% of victims of human trafficking are women. It is time to fight effectively against pimping, forced begging, forced marriage, forced labour or organ removal which is growing more and more in Europe. What does this report propose to address this? To penalize clients of prostitutes, to punish slave employers and, above all, to regularize all illegal women trafficked.  Have we thought about the consequences of such a measure? I will tell you this: to obtain papers, women will be systematically prostituted, enslaved or forcibly married by the criminals who exploit them. The cure would be worse than the evil, that's a no-brainer. What can be the solution? This is obviously not the automatic regularization of victims of trafficking. The solution is to fight fiercely against traffickers, to control our national borders, to address the causes, not the consequences, and, finally, to show common sense and firmness. I will therefore vote against this report because it does not attack the mafia networks that exploit women, it somehow supports them.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, two out of three victims of trafficking are girls, girls like this who, despite all our efforts to recover them, will be irrecoverable after they have been sold and exploited until they are stripped of all their dignity. Nearly 80% of trafficking victims cross a border and the vast majority of them end up in Europe, victims of criminal organisations that, after false promises of work, force them to prostitute themselves. If they are not fortunate enough to be released by the police, many of them end up sick or dead. We can't keep closing our eyes. I therefore ask the Commission to assess the member states' compliance with this anti-trafficking directive, checking whether impunity surrounding the sale of human beings, preferably women and girls, is actually being acted on. The main measure is prevention. Action must be taken against traffickers, increasing prosecution and protecting victims who work with the police. Secondly, the protection of victims must be strengthened, identifying and protecting them so that they can emerge from the hell in which they live, offering them a dignified life so that they do not fall into criminal networks again. Finally, I believe that we need greater judicial cooperation and exchange of information between Member States. And so that girls like this don't end up dead in life, we're forced to discourage the demand that increases trafficking. If sexual exploitation wasn't a business, this little girl wouldn't end up in a brothel, think about it.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
