text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we have spoken in this House on many occasions about gender-based violence, and it is obviously closely linked to trafficking in human beings and trafficking in women: a violation of human rights; a great way to see how in this unequal society women are being used as if they were goods.  There has been talk here of concepts such as 'buying and selling', such as 'goods' such as 'use', and I believe that all instruments need to be put in place in order for countries to be forced to establish legislative, legal and police cooperation measures to combat trafficking in human beings. Because we talk mostly about women.  We have dealt a lot with the refugee issue and seen how, also in this case, these organized groups are using women to do business on this issue. And so, if we talk about avoiding business, if we are talking about avoiding prostitution, let us be aware that demand must be suppressed, that anti-prostitution measures must be put in place to prevent it from being bought and sold to women as if they were a commodity.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her Trafficking in human beings is not only a crime, but it is also a disgusting business model in the European Union. This business model is used to make millions of euros every year, and we must finally put an end to these criminals. But one thing is clear: as long as the victims of trafficking in human beings must be afraid that when they testify against the perpetrators in court, nothing will move. That is why, including with this directive, we must put more pressure on the Member States to finally implement existing legislation. That this gives victims of trafficking the right to stay, that they receive psychological and legal advice, and that we can finally put a stop to the criminals behind this business model.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we will be supporting this report, even though, in our opinion, it is in many parts outside the competence of the FEMM Committee. We are satisfied, however, at the heart of the dossier because it focuses mainly on two factors: on the one hand, the strong sanctions and punishments desired for criminal organisations, but also for individuals who commit the horrendous crime of trafficking in human beings; on the other hand, on the attention and protection of the victims of trafficking itself, which are mainly women, who are shamefully exploited because of their social and economic despair in their countries of origin.  However, I am sorry that I have not seen any reference to a form of trafficking in human beings, particularly babies, which needs to be talked about much more: I am talking about surrogacy. Let us remember that last March the Council of Europe spoke out against this practice and that we also adopted an amendment condemning it in this House last December. I therefore hope that there will be other opportunities to address this issue, which sees women, as well as children, as the main victims.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, when we want to tackle the exploitation of human beings, we must look on the right side. The thousands of illegal immigrant children who have been missing for more than a year have unfortunately had to fuel the networks of prostitution and modern slavery. This is a direct consequence of the Union's irresponsible migration policy. This air call to the flow of stowaways is the infusion of mafia systems. Another fundamental point, but which is the subject of only a timid article in this report: the exploitation of women for surrogacy (GPA) and other methods of reproduction. These GPA techniques are forms of marketing of catalogued women and children. The Union must not open any path in European law that could promote or recognise such a horror, a real regression. All forms of exploitation of human beings must be tackled and the causes of these evils must be addressed- massive immigration and libertarian liberalism are part of it. Sorry to disappoint some idealists!

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, Commissioner, you know that exploiting people for profit is now the most common, dangerous and abhorrent organised transnational crime, not least because we know that there is a turnover of billions: EUR 3 billion is turnover per year. European legislation is sufficient both to guarantee rights and to prevent and suppress and to protect victims, but there are problems in implementation and above all in identifying potential future victims, because complaints are not sufficient. They run into taboos, weak structures, victim self-victimisation, so the statistics are incomplete. We must incentivise them to denounce, and especially young girls and women, this heinous crime. To focus on strengthening the social role of women and weak social structures, on removing inequalities, which are falsely strong against the weak, and above all on raising public awareness. Human dignity cannot be the subject of agreement, transaction, commercialisation or negotiation, because this is a disgrace to humanity and an affront to European culture and our values.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We are once again talking today about trafficking in human beings, not about trafficking in human beings somewhere, but about trafficking in human beings right here in Europe. Let us be a little more specific linguistically: it is a slave trade! We must face up to the fact that we have more slaves in Europe than ever before, that so many people live here in a disenfranchised, degraded, without freedom and without human rights. Many of the previous speakers have already described it: they live in kitchens, in cellars, they live in prostitution, they live in exploitation. As the European Parliament, we are the representative of the citizens here, and as citizens' representatives we have three clear announcements to make: a clear message to the slave traders and to the slave users. Statistically, slave users also sit here in Parliament – statistically. This clear message means that we will not tolerate it and we will protect the victims. To the victims must be our message: You are not lost. We see your suffering, even if it happens behind closed doors. And to society, our message must be very clear that we must enlighten, enlighten, enlighten! Too many people in Europe have not yet recognised the dimension of slavery in Europe.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur on the remarkable work. Full implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings is key in our fight against slavery in the 21st century. I want to draw attention to four points: First of all, we will not tire of repeating it – prevention. Extensive information campaigns on the issue of trafficking in human beings are needed, including on the issue of gender equality at an early school age. Education and training are a cornerstone for reducing the risk of human trafficking.  Secondly, early identification, appropriate assistance and protection of victims. Member States need to improve their victim identification systems. It is necessary to increase the number of crisis centres to accommodate them and strengthen their reintegration programmes into society.  Third, tracking money is a key strategy for investigating and prosecuting organised crime networks that profit from trafficking in human beings. The role of Europol and Eurojust is important here.  Last but not least: enhanced cooperation with third countries. Neither Europe alone nor the Member States individually are able to cope with this global challenge. Only with a coordinated approach at international, national and interinstitutional level can we give a decent response.  Finally, I want to congratulate Milia Vasiliadou, the European Coordinator for Combating Trafficking in Human Beings, for her strong commitment and dedication and to congratulate her and her team on the good work.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament's research is startling. What is it – we have all the legislative conditions, measures have been taken by the security agencies, and there are no real results to reduce the trafficking of women and children. Moreover, the high percentage of victims and criminals is precisely from European countries. The number of human rights guarantee documents is proving to be inversely proportional to the actual results. How else to explain that it is in European countries in the 21st century that "white slaves" can be talked about, about trade and exploitation of children?  We also have new challenges. We are busy making policies to curb migration and the refugee crisis, but we are doing nothing about well-developed sewer networks that literally sell women for sexual exploitation or labour on the black labour market.  Mrs Jourová, the European Commission needs to strengthen member states' control over the implementation of this Directive, because almost nothing is done to prevent and protect victims. We also need better coordination between the security services and European agencies to dismantle transnational criminal organisations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, I condemn every form of human trafficking and I believe we must do everything in our power to protect human dignity. Given that surrogacy is a modern form of human trafficking that is not adequately regulated in many EU countries and the surrogacy industry and surrogacy industry are taking off, I think this report should have condemned the practice of surrogacy. All the more so because we have already done so in the 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World. We must not agree to children being bought and sold, and the reproductive functions of a woman to order are rented. What do you call it than human trafficking? Women and children are not objects and goods, but human beings who have their dignity. The Council of Europe has refused to legitimize surrogacy and we must push for its ban, as it is human trafficking.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings are top priorities for the European Union. The strategies adopted so far in the field of crime control, trafficking and victim assistance have been manifold, but the results, alas, are by no means reassuring.  An extraordinary effort is needed on the part of the international community to prevent inhuman and degrading situations. The intolerable phenomenon of trafficking in human beings is not only the result of economic and social inequalities: it is also the result of gender inequality. Structural discrimination means that 80 % of the victims are women: women and girls, and often girls. Finally, I would point out that migrant trafficking and trafficking in human beings, while representing different phenomena, often tend to overlap. An adequate and well-calibrated response could therefore come from a thorough analysis of the latest trends, including the influence that the current migration crisis is exerting on the phenomenon of trafficking in human beings.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, trafficking in human beings is considered one of the most serious crimes in the world and is a serious violation of human rights. Worldwide, 70% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women, especially young girls, while in the European Union between 2010 and 2012, this figure reached around 80%. Of course trafficking in human beings can take on many dimensions, such as sexual exploitation, forced labour, organ removal and forced begging. Moreover, the number of victims of trafficking in human beings from minority groups is disproportionately high because of the marginalisation of these citizens. Huge refugee and migration flows are intensifying the problem of trafficking in human beings, especially children. It is therefore necessary for each Member State of the Union to have appropriate mechanisms in place to prevent and, at the same time, identify victims and provide them with assistance in cooperation with specific support groups. At the same time, gender inequality should be addressed and the independence of women, especially young girls, promoted to make them less vulnerable to trafficking in human beings.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, estimates suggest that over 10,000 people a year are victims of human trafficking. Of these, 70% are EU nationals. We're not pointing that out enough here. Of these, 80% are unfortunately women and more than 16% are minors and minors.  It is said to be a business worth more than 1 billion euros a year. Gentlemen, those who are now here are in some way shedding tears over this problem and when we spoke about Europol the other day, they did not want to talk about a stronger deepening of all that Europol can do, about europol's stronger powers. We will not be able to fight these criminals working in a particular country on our own because it is a cross-border trafficking of people. So I'm all for punishing all criminals, but we also need to strengthen Europol.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, indeed, we are dealing here with one of the new forms of slavery of the 21st century, one of the most shameful crimes that exist. This is not just a criminal issue; it is also an attack on human dignity and also an attack on fundamental freedoms, undoubtedly a full-rule violation of human rights. Victims are often invisible out of fear, out of fear for possible revenge. And it encompasses not only sexual exploitation, but also forced begging, forced labour, organ trade. It therefore requires an immediate response from all Member States, and especially from the Commission. Millions of men and women from all corners of the planet are deceived. That is why the responsibility is for the authorities and society. We need awareness for all services involved in research. We need civil society cooperation, but also open cooperation and dialogue between all health, judicial, police sectors, and we also need cross-border cooperation. I would ask the Commission for an immediate response and involvement so that it can give the answer which takes a delay of one year and we can prioritise this issue as one of the most important on the Commission's own agenda.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened to the speakers with great attention and I want to reassure you that this is a priority for the Commission. Personally, sitting here and listening to the honourable Members, I fully share the sense of urgency. We see and we hear these cases: each individual story, of a woman, a young girl, a child, is a human tragedy, and we need to combat these awful crimes against human dignity by all possible means. As I said before, we will continue to address trafficking in human beings and work towards its eradication.  We are now developing a post-2016 policy, and elements raised in this report will be considered very carefully. I count on this Parliament’s commitment and cooperation as a long-standing institutional partner in advancing our ambitious legal and policy framework to eradicate this scourge in our society.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her commitment to this issue and it is very good to hear that Germany is now coming on board. I would also like to thank my colleagues and the shadows, and the Secretariat of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) and ALDE, for all their support and work on this, including those in my own office.  Just a few points. Prostitution: not all those in prostitution have been trafficked and controlling prostitution is not an EU competence. It has been a very fine line to talk about this in the report, but it is part of the market demand and so that is how it has been addressed. Surrogacy is not trafficking. Forced surrogacy is a crime in anybody’s language and also needs to be tackled.  Migrants: migrants are not always victims of trafficking but their vulnerability and the lack of care that we are affording them make them very easy prey for the traffickers.  Organised crime: yes, this is the fourth largest organised crime. It is much easier to traffic human beings than it is drugs. Police dogs do not smell out trafficked people and for the lady who said that we should get out because it is free movement of people that causes it, the UK is not in Schengen and yet it is still one of Europe’s biggest markets for trafficking people. Traffickers do not care what sort of border control is there; they will work a way around it. We have all to be vigilant on this issue.  I look forward to building on the progress that has been achieved by the Office of the Anti-Trafficking Coordinator, Madam Vassiliadou, and for all those who tonight and for the next who knows how long, face heaven knows what, we need all of us to be committed and vigilant and to work to make sure that we catch the traffickers and rescue those who are held in in slavery.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Author. – Thank you President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable colleagues, we are discussing Parliament's resolution on the Crimean Tatars today, the least that can be done to help this unique community. I have no doubt that all the like-minded Members of this House condemn the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula last year. However, it seems that the occupiers are not limited to seizing territory. They sought to fulfill what could be seen as signs of ethnic cleansing. You must have heard that the Crimean Tatars were one of the first nations declared criminals. It is true that if similar actions by Nazi Germany resulted in an international verdict, the activities of the Soviet Union in 1944, declaring all Crimean Tatars as criminals and deporting them from their birthplaces, are still not assessed. Since 2014, the Soviet Union's successor has been trying to repeat this barbaric practice, so far Russia has confined itself to declaring criminals the main Crimean Tatar organization Mejlisa, restricting the rights of Crimean Tatars, with accusations of persecuting prominent Crimean Tatar public figures, forcing several tens of thousands of Tatars to leave their homes. Your vote has been accompanied by an excellent resolution. It gives a detailed account of Crimea, condemns russia's repression, and expresses our support for the fundamental principles of human rights democracy and international law, including the Ukrainian Tatars ... (Language timed out)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the mass deportation of Crimean Tatars began in 1944 involving more than 230 000 people. Discrimination against this minority continued over the following decades by both the Soviet and Ukrainian Governments, which succeeded each other in the administration of Crimea. Even today, very serious reports of persecution of political leaders and activists belonging to the Tatar minority in Crimea are still coming to our ears. What I am calling for, loudly, is for Parliament and the European institutions to close the shameful page of silence that has been maintained for too long on these events, but to do so without pursuing double political and strategic aims.  It is shameful that Europe has for years forgotten about the Crimean minorities, but it is even more shameful that it should only remember it for ulterior motives. I call for these serious events to be taken into account and dealt with for what they are: human rights violations, which must stop as soon as possible. All other political and strategic considerations must take second place.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, Crimea, and more widely, the situation in occupied eastern Ukraine must not be allowed to fall into the realms of frozen conflicts. The EU and Member States must keep up the pressure and remain resolved in applying the sanctions against Russia over the annexation of Crimea. Beyond the geostrategic picture, however, are the people living in Crimea: minority communities are facing persecution, including notably the Crimean Tatars and ethnic Ukrainians. Already 20 000 have fled to mainland Ukraine and the object of the current policy is to force the rest of the Tatar population to do the same; the 21st century version of the forced deportation in 1944 under Stalin.  The EU and Member States must remain vigilant to these issues and we must encourage Turkey to be as strong in defending their ethnic kinsmen in Crimea as they are in defending their ethnic kinsmen, the Turkmen, in Syria. Forced territorial annexation of territory at the point of a gun is totally unacceptable in the modern world.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second time in a few months that we have intervened on the issue of the Tatars, demonstrating the European Parliament's commitment to this minority, which, since the beginning of the Ukrainian crisis, has expressed its opposition to Russia's annexation of the peninsula and which is under great pressure and discrimination. I am also deeply concerned about the decision taken by the Sinferopoli Court to declare mejlis, the local Tatars' parliament in Crimea, an extremist organisation, and to ban its activity. This ban indicates a new level of repression against the community as a whole, and that is why there must be a strong appeal from us. Our commitment is to take the necessary measures to repeal this measure quickly, and above all we want to avoid, in essence, an intervention that silences political dissent and removes the voice of this minority that has already suffered great harassment in its history.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Author. – Madam President, I think that the essence of the problem, the Crimean Tatars, does not need to be explained. We have all heard about the boycott of the referendum in March 2014, but also about the emigration of some Crimean Tatars after it. This is what we all want, while respecting the rights of the majority, to protect the rights of minorities. The new government's promotion of the Crimean Tatar language to the official language is a step in the right direction. It is natural that even in this situation, not everyone is satisfied. Our task should be to demand from all the disgruntled, even if they consider to be the only representatives of the Tatar minority, not to abuse violence. The Minsk Convention must remain the basis for a solution. Secondly, in order to avoid being subject to the emotions generated by emigrants, who often have bad information and private interests, as was the case, for example, in Washington when intervening in Iraq, I propose to send a group of MePs to Crimea, along the lines of the Council of Europe, to find out on the ground the state of democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Developer. – Madam Vice-President, first of all I would like to express my satisfaction that we have reached an overall consensus on this resolution on the position of the Crimean Tatars, a minority in Ukraine, a minority that has remained loyal to the Ukrainian state, which has opposed illegal annexation and aggression by Russia on Ukrainian territory. We have also very clearly condemned the ban on the Medjlis - crimean Tatars and the proclamation of their work as an extremist organization from the so-called local institutions, what the Supreme Court, what the chief prosecutors.  We find this unacceptable, we stand for respect for their human rights, for avoiding any violence and intimidating the position of the Crimean Tatars. We want the overall political process of reintegration of this part of the territory of Ukraine to continue through the Geneva format and we feel that the policy of the sanctions regime towards Russia because of Crimea must be maintained because there is no obvious progress in this process. In this regard, we also advocate the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, in 1738 Crimea was occupied by the then Tsarist Russia. It was the first attempt at the Novorossiya project. In reality, it meant the quick and ruthless Russification of neighbouring lands. In May 1944, upon the order of Stalin, 240 000 Crimean Tatars, the whole nation, were deported, mainly to Central Asia. Thousands of people died on the way or in exile. Total deportation was accomplished.  Today in Crimea we observe a zealous continuation of ethnic cleansing policies. Tatar leaders are banned from entering the peninsula. The Mejlis, the local parliament, is declared to be unlawful, dozens of its activists are prosecuted, religion and culture are suppressed, TV and other media are closed down. The target of the occupation authorities is clear: that the Crimean Tatars shall not come into the future plans of Putin’s Crimea, and all this is happening in the Europe of the 21st century.  The banning of the Mejlis is a violation of many international laws. I am more than convinced that those who stand behind this shameful court ruling, namely the so-called prosecutor-general and judges, must face very restrictive measures from the EU side. Not doing so will be a mistake. Crimea belongs to Ukraine. There is no Crimea without the Crimean Tatars.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, our group has proposed on several occasions to discuss this subject. I'm glad that, for the second time in the last three months, we're talking about crimean Tatars. The human rights situation has worsened since February. Since the last discussion, we have witnessed the abusive prohibition of the Tatar Mejlis, the classification of this institution as an extremist organisation. During the same period, censorship and discrimination continued to flourish in Crimea, this Ukrainian territory which Russia illegally annexed - I recall that we do not recognise this abusive act. I think it is essential that negotiations on Russia's departure from Crimea begin. It is also important that international institutions have access to the territory of Crimea to monitor the human rights situation.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the decision to suspend the Mejlis in Crimea is quite simply a breach of the right to freedom of association, and it follows the enforced disappearance of at least six Crimean Tatars and the forcible detention of Tatars in Pionerske, with the taking of fingerprints and DNA. This represents a new wave of repression against the Crimean Tatar people since the Russian annexation, and it has an historic echo four decades after their entire population was deported to remote parts of the then Soviet Union. My Group draws attention to the long-standing discrimination against Tatars, documented by the Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organisation (UNPO). We remain convinced that we should diplomatically engage with Russia and we believe Tatars should be protected under the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. On behalf of the Foreign Affairs Committee, I met, in Kyiv, Refat Chubarov, one of the two banned Tatar leaders who continue to campaign for their people from outside Crimea. We told them we would not forget them, and today we remind the whole of Europe of their plight.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – What is a "home"? This is the definition of the American writer Gladys M. Hunt: "home" is a safe place, where you do not have to fear an attack, a place of familiar relationships and affirmation. Unfortunately for the Crimean Tatars, their homeland is no longer that safe place. They've known deportation, genocide, lawlessness in exile. They fought against one of the most brutal regimes of the 20th century for their return and their national rights and they returned. No one expected that in the 21st century a state, a permanent member of the UN Security Council, would in such a blatant way violate international law.  Today, the Crimean Tatars are once again the victims of discrimination and lawlessness, kidnapping and murder, forced recruitment in the Russian army. The lack of democratic freedoms is forcing many to leave their homes again: 20 000 from Crimea, almost 5 000 from Sevastopol. In the resolution, we point to the kremlin's crushing responsibility, but we also ask our own institutions and Member States not to weaken the pressure and therefore sanctions. This proud people are counting on us.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia has also led to a growth in violations of the rights of minorities such as the indigenous Crimean Tatars, who are increasingly identified as terrorists and who are facing violence, forced disappearance and even killings, and the so—called authorities are not investigating or prosecuting the perpetrators. What is more, the Mejlis is now banned, and we call on the EU to help and assist so that they can meet in exile. The restrictions to access to the OSCE, the UN, the Council of Europe and human rights NGOs are another bad sign, and so are the restrictions on freedom of the press and freedom of expression. All these restrictions of rights – and particularly the persecution of minorities of the Crimean Tatars, which actually seem politically motivated – must end, and so should the illegal annexation of Crimea altogether.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again a consensus in error. The Tatars are one of 101 ethnic groups that make up the population of Crimea. In the name of a so-called status of indigenous peoples, they would be more equal than the others. Admittedly, they were persecuted by Stalin, but all the Ukrainian people were persecuted.  The Majlis, an Islamic consultative assembly, believes that Tatars have more rights on Crimean soil than Russians, Germans, Greeks, Armenians and all other ethnic minorities, in the name of questionable historical precedence, in particular, because the Greeks were the first to build the cities on this peninsula. Contrary to what the joint resolution text says, the Majlis was never recognized by any Ukrainian power before the annexation of Crimea to Russia. The Ukrainian Minister of Justice, Mr Golovati, in his reply to a parliamentary question, dated 14 March 1997, stated that the Majlis' action was illegal in Ukraine.  The Majlis has become a terrorist organization that hosts terrorists from the Turkish organization "Grey Wolves" in Kherson territory. (Protests at the end of the speech. Mr Demesmaeker shouts "shame")

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Unlike my colleagues, I was in Crimea and talked to several Tatar organizations in Crimea and with people on the streets. Well, the Tatars initially supported the Anszlus crimea to Russia, persuaded by the Tatars of Tatarstan, where they were pretty good; now they are deeply disappointed because they hoped that they would improve, but they did not improve, on the contrary. Crimea is ruled by the same people who used to rule, only now they call themselves Russians, and before that they called themselves Ukrainians, and they use the fact that to Moscow for justice is further than to Kiev. The Mujalis, on the other hand, does not enjoy the support of all Tatars in Crimea at all, and especially since it supported the terrorist attack, which was the blow-up of a power plant that supplied electricity to Crimea and in the winter Crimea was deprived of electricity, and this was supported by the Mjlis – which is why it was considered a terrorist organization. The matter is very complicated and I would ask you to approach it with great care. Thank you for your attention, and besides, I think that the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, in May 1944 Stalin had two hundred and fifty thousand Crimean Tatars deported to Uzbekistan. More than 100,000 Tatars have died as a result of this forced resettlement.  After Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea two years ago, the Tatars became inferior citizens again. The ban on their parliament – Medjlis – and its inclusion on the list of extremist organizations and the overall gross violations of their human rights by Russian occupiers must be seen as yet another attempt to drive the Tatars out of Crimea.  We must not allow a repeat of the tragic history of the twentieth century and the advent of new Stalinist methods. Next week, I will attend a commemorary rally in Kiev to mark the 72nd anniversary of the Tatar genocide. On this occasion, I will be honoured to present to Mr Chubarov, President of Medjlis, the resolution of the European Parliament on which we will be voting today.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Crimea is home to the Crimean Tatars. They were subject to barbaric Russian politics, a policy of ethnic cleansing: during the tsar's time, during Stalin's time and now, especially after the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation. Ethnic cleansing continues, people are killed. The same is true of other minorities, but the scale of barbarism towards crimean Tatars is unprecedented. Their leader Mustafa Dżemilew calls for increased, tougher sanctions against Russia over aggression in Ukraine.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, the Russian annexation of Crimea is illegal and needs to stop. Crimea must be returned to Ukraine, but until this is the case, Russia is obliged to protect the Crimean people from any form of discrimination and to protect their human rights. Sadly, we are witnessing the opposite. The banning of the Mejlis and the persecution of its members is deplorable and has to stop.  We are soon going to discuss again the Sakharov Prize nominees. Looking at the situation of the Crimean Tatars, I would suggest we consider as one of the Sakharov Prize nominees Mustafa Dzhemilev, a leader of the Crimean Tatars, who has been banned from entering Crimea for his activities in promoting the human rights of the Crimean Tatars in Crimea. The EU needs to send a clear message that we do not tolerate the current occupation of Crimea or the repression of the Crimean Tatars.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the ban on mejlis, the representative body of crimean Tatars, shows more than anything how Russian realpolitik works. The public benefit association was banned by the Russian Ministry of Justice on the grounds of the Anti-Extremism Act, i.e. the entire Crimean Tatar minority was collectively branded as extremist and dangerous to Russia. This is happening with the Russian leadership demanding municipal powers for Russians living in the eastern half of Ukraine. Russia's crackdown on Crimean Tatars discredits its stand with Russians in Ukraine. There are also large numbers of indigenous national minorities in the European Union, so let us not allow one member state or another to declare them collectively extremist and unreliable using the same technique, because unfortunately there are trials. It is not a good message for a state to see indigenous peoples living on its territory as foreign bodies, as this causes mistrust and tensions.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, the Council of Tatars of the Crimean peninsula, annexed by Russia in 2014, was banned after it was falsely classified as a terrorist organisation. Many Tatars are in closed, dozens of young Tatars have disappeared, and some have been found dead. Why all this? Because the Tatars are the only minority, the only population in Crimea that is organizedly opposed to the Russian Federation, the threat and the occupation of the Russian Federation. I call on the Member States, I call on the European Union to extend the freezing of the assets of those who contributed to the annexation of Crimea and to tighten the actions against the Russian Federation. We are talking here about three aspects: 1) a European minority is threatened with extinction; 2) Ukraine has lost over fifteen billion euros through the annexation of Crimea and 3) Is threatened European security. Russia is militarizing the peninsula, the most modern air defense systems are located on the territory of Crimea that endanger the entire southern flank of NATO.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Colleagues, I support this resolution, which clearly names the situation in Crimea as an annexation by the Russian Federation and a violation of international law. The resolution gives concrete examples of violations of human rights and the rights of national minorities, such as the ban on Medjlis. This representative body of Crimean Tatars has been operating in Crimea since 1991 and 1999 respectively and has been banned by a self-proclaimed court for alleged extremist acts and sabotage. The European Parliament calls for support for Medjlis and for the restoration of freedom of speech and the media. We consider it important to be able to monitor the situation through non-profit organisations and human rights organisations. I have personally met with such representatives, I have met with journalists who had to leave crimea. For me, their testimonies are one of the main reasons why I can support this resolution. It is right that the European Parliament should not be silent on the situation in Crimea.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, the debate on the state of crimean Tatars is extremely timely and the resolution openly presents discriminatory actions against the population of the Crimea peninsula. Authorities on the peninsula continue to implement crackdowns on the population, including arbitrary arrests and a travel ban.  In recent days, the Ministry of Justice has banned in practice the representative body of the Tatars – Mezhlysa, whose activity was absurdly defined as "extremist", and community leaders Refat Chobarov and Mustafa Dzhemilev continue to live in exile with a ban on entering the territory of the peninsula.  These events have unleashed yet another wave of discontent towards crimea's ruling government and the international community cannot be ineminent. Otherwise, we will remain observers and passive participants in the systematic violation of human rights in the region.  I therefore call on all parties ruling on the Crimean Peninsula to immediately cease any practices of repression against civilians. Crimean Tatars are an integral part of the population of Crimea and their cultural heritage should be respected.

name: Věra Jourová
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, in March, two years after the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by the Russian Federation, the EU and its Member States reaffirmed their deep concern at the worsening of the human rights situation in the Crimean peninsula. This includes the denial of freedom of expression, freedom of peaceful assembly, freedom of religion and belief, and the persecution of persons belonging to minorities, in particular the Crimean Tatars.  High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini discussed these issues in person with the leaders of the Mejlis of Crimean Tatars during her last visit to Kiev in November 2015. The decision of 26 April by the so-called Supreme Court of Crimea to prohibit the activities of the Mejlis, which is a self-governing body of the Crimean Tatars, and labelling it an extremist organisation, represents a grave attack on the rights of the Crimean Tatars as a whole. Furthermore, it constitutes an additional very negative deterioration in the human rights situation on the Crimean peninsula since its illegal annexation by the Russian Federation in 2014.  Let me reiterate once again the EU’s long-standing call for full, free and unrestricted access for international human rights actors to the whole territory of Ukraine, including Crimea and Sevastopol. In the light of recent developments this remains absolutely vital.  In less than one week, 18 May will mark the anniversary of the deportation of Crimean Tatars in 1944. Last year the Crimean Tatar community was not allowed to hold peaceful public events on the peninsula to commemorate this historic tragedy. The occasion is a stark reminder to all of us that the Crimean Tatar people have suffered too much in their history and their persecution must stop immediately.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this resolution in support of the Crimean Tatars, which I have personally co-signed. We demand the immediate lifting of the ban on their assembly by the authorities of the peninsula annexed in 2014 by Russia. This decision constitutes a direct persecution of the Crimean Tatar community and a politically motivated measure designed to further intimidate its legitimate representatives. The ban on the Tatar assembly, a legitimate, representative and recognized body of the indigenous population of Crimea, is unacceptable! It risks serving as a precedent for the continuation of discrimination and violations of human rights and fundamental civil liberties against this population, at the same time as it constitutes an attempt to expel it from the territory that is its historic homeland. We call on the EU to provide financial support for the activities of the Tatar Assembly and to increase funding for human rights organisations in Crimea.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, I think we should congratulate ourselves on the fact that such a broadly supported resolution has arrived in this Parliament today. The terrible human rights situation in The Gambia, the lack of democracy, the risk of persecution, illegal detention and torture in which many of its citizens live because they are critical or simply different, such as LGTBI groups, justifies this Parliament taking a clear position of denunciation and condemnation.  But we need to go a little further, and that is why we think it is essential that the call to action of the Delegation of the European Union in The Gambia, the African Union and the Economic Community of West African States should be included in this Resolution. To act on the ground, to report and monitor any violations of human rights.  Of course, the freezing of all European support for President Jammeh's regime, which has crossed all tolerable limits , is also of course essential, because the people of The Gambia cannot suffer because of the behaviour of their rulers.  Nearly 15,000 asylum seekers have arrived from The Gambia to the European Union since 2015. From The Gambia! Imagine the distance and suffering of these people so you can get here. No more data is needed. To tackle that human indentation, we must act there.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, power in The Gambia is being brutally exercised by a dictator who has wiped out freedom and democracy. It has been 22 years since 1994 when Yahya Jammeh, who came to power at just 29 years old in a military coup, promised an end to the corruption, nepotism and poverty of the Dawda Jawara regime. Since then, however, only fear has reigned in Gambia: members of the press, human rights activists, homosexuals and more generally opponents of the regime, in any capacity, are under attack, even if only perceived as such. Meanwhile, the president proudly shows his picture at the White House with Barack and Michelle Obama, nodding at whether journalists and opponents disappear or are imprisoned and tortured in his country. Through this resolution, we call on the Gambian authorities to release all those illegally detained. We call on Gambia to ratify the UNITED Nations Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment and to take all necessary measures to put an end to discrimination, attacks and criminalisation of the LGBTI community.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – Gambia, which promotes itself as "the land of the smiling coast", also has a grim face that the tourist rarely sees. Under President Jammeh, probably the worst dictator you have never heard of, the people do not dare to talk about politics out loud. They whisper better. The Gambian secret service sows fear to the smallest villages and farthest corners of the country. Journalists, political opponents and even close associates of the president are hunted wild. And while the president is wasting his time in his luxurious retreat in the United States, many Gambians are fleeing their country. They risk their lives at sea in rickety boats.  The fact that the president declared his country an Islamic republic at the end of last year, thus raping the constitution, is very worrying. We are looking at the Gambian government but also at the EU. This small African country deserves much more attention. The organisation of fair and free elections is a first crucial step towards restoring democracy and re-ensuring that the people have a future prospect.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a climate of terror in The Gambia which is driving a large part of the population to emigrate. According to Frontex, gambia, despite its small population, is among the top six countries in terms of the number of immigrants reaching Europe. As I said, in this former British colony journalists, human rights defenders and members of opposition parties and civil society are continually intimidated and persecuted for their ideas. Arbitrary and unre charged detentions are the order of the day, as is torture and other inhumane treatment that is carried out during the period of custody.  There is no doubt that the European Union must make all economic aid conditional on respect for human rights, and it is also necessary for the European Union, together with the African Union, to undertake to monitor prisons and the conditions of prisoners. A legislative change that decriminals the crime of homosexuality and tightens the government's grip on information control is also essential.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Author. – Madam President, The Gambia is one of the smallest and poorest countries in Africa. Poverty is widespread and predominantly rural and it is women who suffer most often and severely. Women are also responsible for 40% of total agricultural production. However, they do not own or control the land and their role in decision-making is totally limited. Ebola also caused enormous damage to the population and the local economy. The European Union suspended aid of $14.2 million in 2014 and this fiscal year 31% of the country's revenue will go to pay the interest on the debt. We believe that the Government of The Gambia must end repression and respect human rights, and we demand it, and also that the European Union must contribute to getting the people of The Gambia and especially women out of chronic poverty.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, Gambia is not the only West African country in which security and stability are an increasing problem. In particular, the situation in this country is deteriorating and even the most basic human rights, such as freedom of religion, especially of christians there, are being violated. There are regular unauthorised arrests, rough treatment, torture and abuse. And we can't even talk about freedom of expression or assembly in this country. I therefore completely agree with the European Union's move, which has therefore reduced financial assistance to The Gambia and is constantly putting pressure on the Gambian regime to start addressing this serious situation.  Not only should the European Union and its delegation there oversee respect for human rights, but really strive to establish a dialogue with the opposition here. If there are still fundamental shortcomings and human rights violations, we must move on to concrete steps in the form of sanctions or the freezing of further financial assistance.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author. – Gambia is full of contradictions. Many members have already said this here today. It wants to attract tourists but it repels its own citizens. As one of the 15 poorest countries in the world, it has little to offer its young people. Without perspectives and with hunger in the belly, they seek happiness elsewhere.  Unfortunately, the brutal repression of a demonstration adds to a long list of abuses. The protesters used a fundamental right to protest, but it ended in carnage. The demonstration was yet another proof that freedom of expression in Gambia is not going well. Journalists, human rights activists, student leaders and LGBT people are arbitrarily arrested, detained and tortured. The government creates a climate of fear and oppression.  That is why the country must absolutely be kept on the map. We must cooperate with civil society and with the African Union. Give Gambia a peaceful and democratic process. The country lures tourists to dream, but for the population it is a nightmare. We liberals want freedom and respect for human rights.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Gambia , one of the 15 poorest countries in the world, is heavily dependent on international aid, including eu aid. As a result of the lack of respect for human rights, the Union has drastically reduced the amount of this aid, which means that a quarter of the population is at risk of starvation there. The current President Jammeh, who came to power 22 years ago following a military coup, will run in the Gambia's presidential election scheduled for december this year for the fifth year in a row. The authorities are already intimidating the opposition and its potential voters by arresting and torturing journalists, human rights defenders and political opponents, exempled by the tragic events of the Serekund peaceful demonstration in Serekund and the mysterious death of Solo Sandeng, leader of the main opposition party. The right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly must not be restricted. The Gambia needs immediate electoral reform, including the creation of an independent electoral commission, and equal access to public media.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, a number of Gambians live in my constituency, forced out of their country by the appalling regime that exists there. It is not widely realised, but Gambia creates more migrants per capita than any other country in the world, including Syria. That is how desperate the situation is in the country. We do not notice it because Gambia is such a small country, and so in absolute numbers it is small, but relative to the population it is enormous. We have to do more as a European Union. Like other speakers, I welcome the fact that we withdrew GBP 13 million worth of aid in 2014, but we now need an Article 96 consultation and we have to send a clear message to the Gambians that if they do not release the April activists who were arrested for peacefully demonstrating, if they do not stop arbitrary detention, and if the police and the national intelligence agency do not bring to an end their brutality and torture , the European Union would consider cutting all relations with them. We have to send a very, very clear message. This is a brutal regime and it needs a brutal response.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Jourová, I would like to thank my colleagues for this urgent resolution so comprehensive and concise that we are going to vote on The Gambia today. However, I find it hard to believe that a dictator who has been in power for more than twenty years, who threatens to cut off homosexuals' heads or presumes that he can cure AIDS through medicinal herbs, can meet some of our demands.  However, I would like to examine what possibilities we, the European Union, have of helping one of the worst-spending populations in Africa. To one country, Gambia, which is in the "top 15" of the poorest countries, one of the main issuers of emigration. Torture, arbitrary arrests, dead opposition leaders, all while their shores have become one of the great paradises of sex tourism.  But The Gambia also has a strong civil society, and this year's presidential election will be an opportunity for thousands of Gambians to take to the streets.  We, as the European Union, must use all the tools at our disposal, such as the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, or by sending an election observation mission from this Parliament.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I too am deeply alarmed by the situation in Gambia, where last month peaceful protesters were brutally arrested, with reports of torture, and one opposition activist, Solo Sandeng, has died in custody. All of this, as we have heard, is happening against a backdrop of grave harassment of human rights defenders, journalists and LGBTI people. The EU was right in its action when it blocked some EUR 8 million in aid because of the poor human rights record and anti—gay legislation, but what this has led to is the Gambian authorities expelling our representatives, and it means that ties are cut. Therefore, I think it is really important that we continue to support those who are taking the lead in standing up for reform, but we also need to work closely with the African Union on this. I am also concerned about the implications for elections in December: against this backdrop, can they really be free and fair? So we have to urge the government of Gambia to ratify the African Charter on Democracy ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I identify with my pre-speaker, we really should be supporting the African Union, and we should be supporting those particular actors who deserve some kind of opposition voice in this country. Even after the European Union's restrictions on support for the country, it is $33 million in 2015 and 2016. The European Union is the largest aid provider to this country, and I ask whether it is acceptable for us to support the government of the country with such sums. Of the $900 million of their annual gross domestic product, thirty-three million are relatively high. I think that we should not support precisely a government that treats its people so disgracefully, but precisely selected members of the opposition movement and, of course, the West African Union.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after the death of Only Sandeng, we can no longer tolerate the arrogance and arrogance with which the security forces in The Gambia systematically suppress all voices of dissent in the country. With this resolution, we want to put an end to the rhetoric of hatred, disappearances and arbitrary killings, accompanied by constant attempts at coup d'state. We are faced with a lack of democracy in a country that has to go to elections in a few months' time, to the attack on fundamental freedoms, to reforms within the criminal code, to the violent criminalisation of the LGBT community, as well as arbitrary murder and torture. That is why we are calling in this vote for consultation with the Gambian Government to be launched as soon as possible in accordance with the Cotonou Agreements and for action such as the freezing of non-humanitarian funds to Banjul to be assessed, leading to targeted sanctions such as travel restrictions for those responsible for these human rights violations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the systematic violation of human rights in The Gambia is a daily occurrence. Peaceful demonstrations began in the capital Banjul in April, calling for transparency for the December 2016 elections. During these protests, opposition leader Solo Sandeng was arrested and died while in prison. Then there was a second wave of protests that led to a new round of repression. These cases are not new for Gambia, which is one of the 15 poorest countries in the world and a quarter of its population faces chronic food insecurity. Moreover, under the regime of Granny Jammeh, who has been in power since 1994, there have been many disappearances, murders for political reasons and security forces and paramilitary groups have been accused of human rights violations. The European Union must take immediate measures to stop the repression of human rights in The Gambia.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about Gambia, one of the poorest countries in Africa and in the world, where even more than a third of the population is now below the poverty line of EUR 1.25 per day. Freedom of association and expression is completely suppressed by the brutality of the regime of Yahya Jammeh, who has in fact been in government for more than twenty years and has even come to prevent the treatment of AIDS, imposing a method of traditional herbs – in his opinion the only solution in the world – which is condemning a few thousand people to death. Moreover, it is also one of the most homophobic countries in the world, having the crime of aggravated homosexuality, which even provides for life imprisonment. Unfortunately, the death penalty is applied very extensively. The demonstrations in April 2016 were completely suppressed by the police, and we must therefore intervene by freezing all aid – even the remaining remnants – that goes not to the people of The Gambia, but to the dictatorship, and by imposing immediate sanctions on the president's family and his entourage.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, indeed, the European Union cannot, of course, tolerate the violation of human and citizen rights, but it can even less tolerate torture and persecution, in The Gambia as elsewhere. President Yahya Jammeh violated the Constitution by establishing an Islamic republic, thus imposing a state religion. This is not acceptable and the European Union must be respected and impose democratic developments in this small country of less than 2 million inhabitants, which is emptying its substance by driving away its youth. To do so, it must freeze aid to the Gambian state. This does not, of course, exclude humanitarian interventions, which is what the region of which I have been president for several years is doing. Support for the people, but by no means to dictators!

name: Věra Jourová
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the situation regarding human rights in Gambia gives rise to serious concern, notably in the areas of freedom of expression, rights of LGBTI persons, arbitrary arrests, torture and isolated detention. We use every opportunity to address these issues with our Gambian interlocutors and to push for improvements. These subjects are regularly on the agenda of the Article 8 political dialogue meetings, the most recent of which took place on 26 April in Banjul. Human rights concerns were also raised on 11 April when the Gambian Minister of Foreign Affairs held talks with high-level EU officials in Brussels. Unfortunately the crackdown on the two rare and peaceful political protests on 14 and 16 April 2016 confirmed our concerns. Protesters were arrested, some were mistreated and one person died in custody. Thirty-seven persons, including the leaders of the strongest opposition party, the United Democratic Party, are currently on trial on charges including conspiracy to commit a felony. This is particularly worrying as it occurs in the run-up to presidential and parliamentary elections in December 2016 and, respectively, April 2017. The EU has issued a statement voicing our concern at the crackdown and demanding an investigation. We are part of a common front, as similar statements were issued by the United States, the United Nations and the United Kingdom, as well as the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights. The United Nations, the African Union and ECOWAS deployed a joint high—level mission to Gambia last week, which renewed calls on the Government to respect freedom of expression, assembly and political participation, to allow due process of law and to conduct an investigation into the death of the Opposition member. In the most recent Article 8 political dialogue meeting in Banjul on 26 April, the EU raised the crackdown on the protests among other human rights concerns. According to the Gambian Government, an investigation was underway and the results would be shared with the EU. The EU delegation to Gambia continues to monitor the situation closely in contact with all stakeholders and strongly encourages the Gambian Government to follow the rule of law. We think that it is important to remain engaged in dialogue with the authorities, as this provides the best possible platform from which to address our concerns and to influence the situation concerning human rights and governance. The EU remains committed to supporting the Gambian people in strengthening democracy, human rights and the rule of law and in building sustainable and inclusive development on the basis of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. Since 2009, the EU has been engaged in an international dialogue aimed at combating the continuing violations of human rights and the rule of law on Gambian territory. Torture and other forms of ill-treatment are now on the agenda. Human rights defenders and journalists are constantly victims of abusive practices, harassment and intimidation. The Gambian Government must shed light on the continuing disappearances and arbitrary detentions and must also take all necessary measures to stop discrimination and attacks against LGBTI people. I trust in the commitment and joint action of Member States and international organisations to protect fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a joint draft resolution on human rights in The Gambia, particularly in the context of the planned parliamentary and presidential elections. The resolution also draws attention to critical poverty in a country where one quarter of the population is facing chronic food shortages and the country is thus dependent on international aid. We also recall the violence and unlawful arrests that accompanied the last elections and call for the release of political prisoners, expressing concern about the deteriorating security situation in the country and, in particular, in the area of human rights. We want to have a targeted dialogue with the leaders on the basis of the Cotonou Agreement. I supported the resolution.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Author. Madam President, what has been happening in Djibouti for years is very worrying, and recent events are not reassuring. After revising the Constitution to run for the fourth time in the presidential elections, President Guelleh established a state of emergency: a murderous repression of the opposition, self-censorship of the only government press, extreme poverty, violence against women, and a lack of respect for human rights. The only thing that would remind us that Djibouti is supposed to be a democracy is the regular holding of elections - elections so manipulated that President Guelleh's scores no longer even create a democratic illusion. Moreover, European election observation missions are still expected to be carried out. The African Union, following these observation missions, recommends the establishment of an independent electoral commission to end the democratic charade. Djibouti's geography makes it a strategic point that France has been enjoying for years, leaving it with its main military base abroad. I have no doubt that my country is partly responsible for the political situation in Djibouti, but so are other foreign powers: Germany, China, Japan and the United States also have military bases there. That is why I call on not only Europe to act, but also the countries involved militarily, so that they may play the best of roles and not the one they have always confined themselves to - that is, defending their own interests. It is time to stop hypocrisy.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we can say that Djibouti is the perfect example of the European Union's enormous weakness in terms of development cooperation and respect for human rights. The emergency resolution is the only weapon the European Parliament has in asking the High Representative for a major diplomatic engagement in Djibouti. We would like to remind you here in this House that Djibouti's gold is its strategic position, which attracts a large number of Western military investments, but also China, which has invested more than $8 billion in the country's infrastructure and will now have its military base of 10 000 soldiers and exerts increasing influence in terms of diplomacy and development cooperation.  In Djibouti, despite this massive presence of foreign soldiers, many of whom are Europeans, there is one violation of human rights per 100 inhabitants. We believe that the time has come to forcefully ask the Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court to monitor the situation in Djibouti to see whether attacks on the population are crimes against humanity. We want those responsible to be investigated and punished under international law.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, as Somalia continues to battle against piracy and jihadist insurgency and Eritrea nears the 30-year mark of the barbarous regime under Isaias Afwerki, Djibouti sadly completes its tale of tragedy in the Horn of Africa. With President Guelleh winning his fourth mandate last month with an implausible 87% share of the popular vote, hopes of reform seem very unlikely under his authoritarian regime. Only last year, we saw the police raid of opposition leader Ahmed Houmed, who was hospitalised alongside his party’s secretary-general in the ensuing police shootout. The massacre at Buldhuquo, in which government forces killed 37 people on the same day, is another great tragedy and blight on the record of the Government of Djibouti.  Such incidents only attest to the brutal culture of repression against human rights activists, journalists and the political opposition of Djibouti. We in the European Union must put more pressure on the Government of Djibouti to implement the framework on political reform signed in 2015 as a starting point for the future and improvement in human rights in that small country.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many cases of political regimes in Africa in which the transfer of power and public office takes place according to family dinastic criteria, and Djibouti is an example of this. The current president has assigned weight ministries to children, grandchildren and genders. The result is a kind of nepotism that excludes the people from management and participation in national wealth. The majority of the population is in serious poverty and the situation is aggravated by the presence of Somali, Eritrean and Yemeni refugees fleeing the surrounding conflicts. The human rights situation is of great concern, in particular the legal inferiority of women in many areas and the state monopoly on information.  So denouncing President Guelleh's responsibilities for human rights violations and repression of those who oppose it is a duty for the international community and for the European Union, and the European Union must move as quickly as possible.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, according to many diplomats and, of course, those of countries with military bases, and there are more and more of them, Djibouti would be an anchor of stability. The reality is very different.  Despite significant assets, Djibouti is ravaged by economic underdevelopment, widespread social misery and a marked political lockdown, and the word is weak.  This resolution is, in itself, a revolution. I thank everyone who has contributed to this. In this resolution, we denounce in particular the increasing repression in that country and, in particular, the one that followed the Buldhoqo massacre on 22 December 2015, particularly against those who dared to denounce the facts. We denounce the electoral masquerade of the presidential election of April 8. Yes, all scores over 80% are generally tainted by irregularities. Moreover, even the African Union has acknowledged a number of irregularities, that is to say!  Finally, here we echo the voices of these courageous Djiboutian women, who have begun a hunger strike to denounce the rapes of them by members of the army, with impunity.  We call for an independent international investigation. Yes, there is an urgent need to lift the lead that is hanging over this country and which the people of Djibouti are paying the price.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Author. Madam President, the European Union's partnership with Djibouti is important, particularly in the regional context of the Horn of Africa, for the promotion of peace, security and the fight against piracy. This is precisely why we are particularly concerned about a deterioration in the political climate, which can potentially destabilize the country and then the region. I have three points to make. The European Union must, first of all, encourage the Djiboutian authorities in order to ensure respect for human rights, the rule of law and democratisation, in particular by paying greater attention to these aspects within the framework of the national indicative programme. Secondly, for the sake of the credibility of this House, it is important to focus on the most problematic elements at present and not to get lost in too many different considerations. In Djibouti, efforts have been made to promote women's rights. The role of women in society is recognized as important, more than in other countries in the region. Let's not lose sight of the priorities - the urgency is not there. Finally, I encourage colleagues to maintain a factual and documented approach to the allegations. We can alert, ask for investigations and justice to do its job, but we do not have the authority to deliver verdicts. Thank you all for the constructive work on this resolution!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I welcome this motion for a resolution, which responds to the elections held in this country in April this year, in which President Guelleh won for the fourth time, whom I personally consider to be one of the key persons in the problems and tragedies that are happening today in Djibouti. It is therefore right that we have a resolution on the table in which we want and ask, as well as the international community, to examine how this election, where the president won 87% and, according to all the documents, celebrated victory before the elections were over and the votes were counted. Pressure must be put on this president, who has repeatedly extended his mandate in this way thanks to changes to the constitution, to address the problems of this small state, namely the problems mentioned here: the huge poverty, the position of women in society, the suppression of political opposition, the fundamental impossibility of women to emancipate. So I support the resolution.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. – Madam President, statements and condemnations, usually rhetorical, are usually made from this Parliament on the violation of human rights in so many parts of the world. Djibouti, in addition to being a place where human rights violations are commonplace, it turns out that it has a European military presence that contributes to the budget of the Government of Djibouti. And from these bases we say defend human rights, and we really do, especially with Operation Atalanta. It is absolutely necessary that in addition to the rhetoric we move on to the facts. And the facts are Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement and therefore require effective pressure measures on djibouti's un democratic government.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the group, Madam President, I will only speak of those women whom I have had the opportunity to meet and who have been raped, who were allegedly perpetrated by Djiboutian soldiers, those women who are only demanding their rights: the right to access justice, to an independent justice. My colleagues have talked about the situation in Djibouti. It is true that, if Djibouti is a partner in this part of Africa, as our colleague said, the acts committed against these women and anyone else who fights for their rights cannot be allowed to go unpunished: political rights, freedom of expression rights, rights to dignity, simply rights to live.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, faraor an scéal céanna go deo, go deo! An rud atá ag tarlú in Djibouti, tá sé feicthe againn ina lán tíortha eile. Tagann duine éigin i gcumhacht mar uachtarán; is maith leis an chumhacht; teastaíonn uaidh fanacht ann; aistríonn sé na dlíthe; úsáideann sé an t-arm chun a réim a chur i bhfeidhm; tagann siad anuas go dian ar lucht an fhreasúra; ní thugann siad cearta sibhialta nó cearta daonna, go háirithe do mhná agus mar sin de.  Seo díreach atá tar éis tarlú in Djibouti ó tháinig Guelleh i réim i 1999. Agus é seo ar siúl, cad a fheicimid? Táimidne ón Aontas ag tabhairt EUR 105 mhilliún dóibh mar chabhair. Tá sé in am dúinn athbhreithniú a dhéanamh air sin, agus b’fhéidir stad a chur leis go dtí go mbíonn ar a laghad tréimhse faoi leith ag an uachtarán agus toghchán oscailte, féaráilte acu.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Republic of Djibouti is located in a crisis-ridden region. What happens in the Horn of Africa has a direct impact on Europe. Terrorism, repression, material hardship and a lack of state structures are the triggers for large-scale flight movements. The Republic of Djibouti is a small country and could thus also be an island of stability – perhaps even a model for the region.  Europe supports the country to a relevant extent. This support is important, but the developments already under discussion today are a matter of great concern. Human rights, the situation of elections and freedom of the press are all things that we must take a very critical view of, and I believe that we should not only talk about developments in that country, but we must also draw conclusions from them at long last.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, as in the previous case with Gambia, and in the case of Djibouti, of course, it is necessary to protest against human rights violations. However, it must be said here that the current president may have followed up his electoral masquerades with the last president, who ruled Djibouti for twenty-two years. Maybe it's a certain political tradition in this state. However, the role of the European Union is not to promote this tradition. And I agree with what my colleague Mr Kelly said. As in the case of Gambia, we should really look at the development aid provided by the European Union to this very country. I think that the one hundred and five million is a relatively high amount, and in a situation where this country is not respecting fundamental human rights and is rather using the fight against poverty as its significant enrichment, we should also reconsider these amounts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, Djibouti, despite being inhabited by some 864,000 inhabitants and with little land and no natural resources, is an important base for foreign military forces. Djibouti is characterised by high unemployment and widespread poverty, and is also a transit point for thousands of African migrants. At the same time, the country's government is responsible for many cases of human rights violations. In particular, in the 2013 elections the government violently suppressed the protests of the opposition parties resulting in several deaths. The protesters questioned the legitimacy of the elections resulting in mass arrests and then complaints of suspected deaths, torture and disappearances. Given that women in Djibouti are faced with various forms of violence and there are enough cases of freedom of speech, there should be pressure from the European Union to stop them suppressing rights in the country. Djibouti has signed the UN's International Convention on Economic and Cultural Rights and should abide by it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the small state of Djibouti, President Guelleh has now effectively established a real dictatorship based on violence, nepotism and corruption. The elections are now reduced to a mere farce between repression, intimidation, arrests, enforced disappearances, torture and violence of all kinds. France, China, Japan and the United States: many understand its geostrategic importance and have military bases there, and the situation is clearly even more serious when one considers the presence of refugees from Yemen and Somalia, in an increasingly deteriorated regional context. Is that enough to close our eyes? No, we don't think so. If this resolution is an important first step, we reiterate that the Attorney-General of the International Criminal Court must investigate the violence and that Article 8 of Cotonou must be applied, just as the EUR 105 million must be suspended, because it is inconceivable to help a regime that is harassing its people in this way. Djibouti's position cannot be a justification for our silence.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that once again we are not going to get to the heart of the matter. We are talking about countries, and every country has its own dictator, there are misfortunes, there is no democracy. Was it better in Libya before, when Gaddafi was there, or now?  It is obvious that then those who have the money – Europe, Japan, China – exploit the situations, but the end result, what is it? What is the end result of this situation? The end result of this situation is that it's okay. The Arab Spring, of which so many have filled their mouths, was a crazy shit. What was the Arab Spring? Crazy shit! In the end, Africans want dictators, because democracy in Africa does not work.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with this vote we are expressing our deep concern for the safety of those who, fleeing war or hunger, try every year through Djibouti to reach the Arabian Peninsula, risking their lives at sea or by land to North Africa.  We need strong and democratic institutions.
