We call on the Government of Djibouti to guarantee the safety of those fleeing, bringing to justice those death traffickers who have built real fortunes on the lives of thousands of desperate people fleeing. Tragedies similar to those we are witnessing in the Mediterranean all too often occur in silence, thousands of kilometres south of Europe, in the Gulf of Aden.  Refugees must be protected through the dismantling of the criminal network, through the fight against trafficking in human beings, the traceability of financial resources, but also by combating the racket of local exploitation to which refugees are easily at risk of falling victim.

name: Věra Jourová
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, the EU and Djibouti have a long-standing relationship and the EU remains an important partner. Djibouti has actively supported regional initiatives and continues to provide troops to AMISOM, the African Union Mission to Somalia, which is key in the fight against Al-Shabaab and to securing Somalia’s political process. At the domestic level, the development of the political and human rights situation in Djibouti is a matter of concern. Human rights activists and opponents are subject to harassment and the political space of the opposition is narrowing, especially since the run—up to the presidential elections of 8 April 2016. Throughout the pre-electoral period, members and supporters of the opposition have been arrested and detained without charges. The EU has followed these worrying cases closely and expressed its apprehension at different levels.  On 21 December 2015, the police broke up a traditional religious ceremony that took place close to the capital of Djibouti. The intervention of the police and security forces resulted in several deaths. The EU issued a statement on that occasion, demanding clarification on the events and that the perpetrators be punished. The EU condemns the violent action and considers that an international inquiry into these matters is of utmost importance and therefore welcomes the mission of the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, which will be in Djibouti this week, and hopes it will allow clarification of the issues. With regard to the recent presidential elections, the release of full and detailed results broken down by polling station would have increased the transparency and credibility of the process. The EU notes with regret that the dialogue on the implementation of the framework agreement on political and institutional reforms, concluded between the Government of Djibouti and the coalition of opposition parties at the end of 2014, came to a standstill last year. This is a missed opportunity for engaging in a democratisation process in Djibouti.  Democratisation and governance efforts, as well as greater respect for human rights, are needed to ensure Djibouti’s internal stability in a region marked by conflict and poverty. Therefore, the EU will continue encouraging all political forces in Djibouti to restart the political dialogue in view of engaging in political reforms, improving good governance and putting an end to the tensions the country has experienced in the last years. On the question raised by Madam Arena – what is the EU’s position with regard to the Djiboutian women who went on hunger strike to denounce the rapes perpetrated by the Djiboutian army – I want to assure you that the EU has followed the issue very closely. The EU considers that an investigation should establish the facts and the perpetrators be brought to justice. The EU stands ready to work together with all relevant stakeholders to improve the human rights situation in the country.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Rapporteur. "I don't think there's any need for an explanation, it'll go faster.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Yes, I can also speak – and explain the vote – in this atmosphere. So, the fact is that the problems of cross-border tax evasion have escalated in recent years, in principle harmful tax competition, aggressive tax planning, etc. The main problem with transparency is that the exchange of tax returns for each country between Member States does not yet take place, and these changes require the introduction of appropriate rules requiring mandatory automatic exchange of information in relation to country-by-country accounts, which is a good thing. The Commission will be actively involved in this process, that is to be welcomed, I support it. And these changes, it should be noted, will take effect as early as next year and will affect the amount of revenue and profit before income taxes, pay savings, from accrued income and taxes respectively. And that's right, and that's why I voted in favour.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, we need the mandatory automatic exchange of information on taxation, and I am glad that we have adopted this report today. The latest information from the Panama document scandal shows the involvement of more than 200,000 offshores, 200 states and 21 different tax havens. It's an unprecedented situation. Member States are still not automatically exchanging data, which is why we need to oblige them, and that is what we did today with this report.  The Commission announced the publication of the country-by-country impact assessment in April 2016. Let's come down to earth! We do not have time for impact assessments, but we must immediately proceed to this mandatory automatic exchange of information. It has been said that competitiveness will decrease if this information is available. Not. Transparency will also lead to competition for companies that pay their taxes and citizens... (The president interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We do have a single internal market, but we still have an economic policy that is determined by the Member States. Above all, we also have a tax policy which is determined by the Member States and which, as a colleague has already said, is defined and fails in very different ways. Of course, if there are differences, the company simply takes advantage of tax advantages and eventually become a criminal. This, of course, leads many companies to think that tax justice is not there. We have now drawn some important conclusions. The best conclusion, by the way, would be that we would have tax harmonisation in the European Union, then there would automatically be tax justice. But the first step is to exchange information. We have taken a decision on this today. I simply expect that we will discuss this decision again at some point. How has it had an impact, and is it really improving tax justice in the European Union?

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I voted in favour of the report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, as it introduces a very important instrument to counter the unfair practices of multinational corporations, which, through aggressive tax planning, seek to minimise the taxes paid. The main cost of such activity is not only less revenue to the Budget of the Member States, but also a weakening of the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. The mandatory exchange of information on reports among countries will increase the transparency of the functioning of international companies and thus eliminate tax fraud. I agree with the rapporteur that the European Commission has very modestly outlined its role in the proposed amendment. Some amendments to this legislative proposal are therefore necessary, in particular those concerning the Commission's inclusion in the information exchange process, so that it has access to the tax returns transmitted. This would allow it not only to keep an eye on the interest of the Union as a whole, but also to prepare annual reports to Parliament and the Council setting out the main conclusions of the actions observed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm labhairt ar an ábhar seo go déanach aréir, chomh maith le mo chomhghleacaí Brian Hayes ó Éirinn. Dar ndóigh, fáiltím roimh na moltaí seo.  Bíonn ar gach oibrí – bíodh sé ag obair sa chóras príobháideach nó sa chóras poiblí – a chuid fhéaráilte den cháin a íoc. Cén fáth nach mbeadh ar na comhlachtaí móra, ach go háirithe, an rud céanna a dhéanamh? Ach trí chlisteacht, bhíodar in ann gan a lán den cháin ba chóir dóibh a íoc a íoc. Dá bhrí sin, bhí sé in am dúinn rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi.  Molaim an Coimisiún agus an OECD as ucht rud éigin a dhéanamh faoi. Tá daoine nach bhfuil sásta go bhfuil an t-uasphointe ag EUR 750 milliún. Ach caithfidh an OECD dul níos faide ná sin sula dtéann an Coimisiún.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to say that I am against harmonisation in the area of direct taxation, but as regards the issue of the exchange of information within the framework of the tax obligations of tax entities, I strongly support this proposal and voted in favour. It is not just reporting issues or cross-border problems related to tax payments. I think that the Panama Papers case has clearly shown the need to share information. It is important that even the most large enterprises are effectively deterd from tax evasion by this method, because this is precisely the result of the affected or undermined competitiveness of SMEs, which cannot use the routes known to large corporations to the biggest tax evasion caused by the largest concerns.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, multinationals receive significant tax advantages or tax exemptions in several Member States, resulting in many local small and medium-sized enterprises suffering or being destroyed by significant competitive disadvantages. Another consequence is that the Member State, the citizens, the economy, is lost to significant revenue. The European Union has not discovered spanish wax, that it has said so and has finally condemned it. But how far did he get? To the point where the relevant data and information need to be exchanged. That's not enough. This type of economic policy must be completed and local small and medium-sized enterprises supported. And you can't have a Juncker at the head of the European Commission and represent the European Union, including at the head of the immigration policy that's been famous for this whole tax avoidance policy. You can't drink wine at the same time... (The President shall withdraw the floor from the Member.)

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, please inform me of the point in the procedure under which the President may overrule the content of the opposition. When has there been a change in the European Parliament that the institution of censorship has been introduced? I'd like your information. Thank you!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution has among its objectives the fight against tax evasion and fair tax competition. Information on the tax sector should, to this end, be transparent and public. In our opinion, the Commission should have strong powers that go beyond the limits of confidentiality set by banks. These points of ours have not been accepted by the other political groups, and for these reasons I have chosen to abstain.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite a clear improvement in the area of the exchange of tax information between EU Member States, the limit laid down excludes most companies from such obligations. This report falls within the framework of the many tax scandals that the European Parliament has been working on during the last few years. It proposes very important measures for the control of the tax activity of multinational companies that must be integrated into the European regulatory framework. However, the limit of EUR 750 million (as consolidated turnover) excludes the majority of such undertakings which may continue to operate without being subject to this regulation. It is because of this great failure that I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field.  This text proposes the implementation of country-by-country reporting with the aim of combating aggressive tax optimisation. The purpose of this reporting will be to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. This reporting is therefore a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It should also be noted that it is the Member States that will be required to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach and who will benefit from it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The Rosati report is a first step that I welcome. However, in another text voted by the European Parliament, we have already obtained a similar public accounting report which is being blocked in a scandalous way by the Council.  Then there is the question of the threshold: this country-by-country reporting will only apply to multinationals with more than 750 million euros in annual net sales. We have struggled to change this threshold, which de facto exempts 90% of multinationals. In this sense, we have tabled an amendment to reduce it to EUR 40 million, which corresponds to the definition of a 'big business' in European law. It is incomprehensible that part of the Chamber, the Conservative and Liberal groups, refused to vote for transparency for all multinationals in excess of EUR 40 million. They spoke in favour of this threshold last July; meanwhile, the Panama Papers confirmed, if necessary, the need to act forcefully. This was not the time to hold europe back in the fight against tax evasion and optimisation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, because tax transparency is a key element in the fight against tax evasion.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Currently, SMEs pay a proportional ly 30% more tax than multinationals (MNCs). This is because MNCs operate in different states and use it in their favour. Of course, a distinction should be made between tax avoidance, which is clearly illegal, and aggressive tax planning, which is legal but contrary to the meaning of the law. It is particularly in the case of tax avoidance, where the current legal framework is no longer sufficient. At present, the Member States lack the necessary transparency to enforce the principle of paying taxes where profits are made. The draft law calls for more transparency. This not only leads to the effective enforcement of the national tax framework, but is also in favour of the competitiveness of SMEs. However, this increased transparency will only help if Member States have easier access to this information from other Member States. Only if MNCs are transparent to national tax authorities can they meet their obligations with regard to the mandatory exchange of tax information. I also see the automatic exchange of tax information as a positive step in the fight against aggressive tax planning. Consequently, I also support this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach and which will benefit from it. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that European countries must unite to fight tax evasion, particularly that carried out by multinationals. Lack of coordination in tax matters benefits large companies and prevents Europe from taking action. I welcome this resolution, which obliges companies with a total turnover of EUR 750,000,000 to file a country-by-country tax return on their total turnover of EUR 750,000.000.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report requiring automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field for companies with more than 750 million euros in turnover. This report is a first step in the fight against tax optimisation or tax evasion. This is the translation into European law of an OECD agreement approved at the G20 last November. It requires multinationals to declare to tax authorities only, country by country, their main tax information: nature of activity, employees, turnover, profit before taxes, total taxes due, corporate taxes paid.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to make a binding exchange of tax reports between corporations in the EU. The new rules provide that, in order to combat tax avoidance and aggressive planning, EU countries will have to automatically exchange information on the income, profits or number of large multinational corporations. I agree that the exchange of information between EU countries must also involve the European Commission and provide for penalties for companies that do not provide the information they require. I agree that tax reports should be submitted to tax authorities by groups of multinational companies with annual revenues in excess of EUR 750 million. Euro.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The problem of cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has become an increasingly serious challenge for EU Member States in recent years. Under the current legal framework (Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation), Member States do not yet share their country-by-country reports, but there is an urgent need to increase tax transparency in order to prevent tax evasion. According to the amendment, multinational groups of companies located in the Union or operating in the Union with a consolidated aggregate revenue of at least EUR 750 million will be required to submit a country-by-country report.  The Member State which has received the country-by-country report shall communicate the report by automatic exchange to all other Member States in which one or more companies in the MNN group are resident for tax. The country-by-country report shall include information such as the amount of revenue, profit before tax, income tax paid and still due, number of employees, size of subscribed capital, profit or loss reserves and tangible assets. As MNEs are required to submit country-by-country reports for the reporting financial year each year from 2017 onwards, and as the amendment curbs tax avoidance, I voted in favour of the amendment.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report sets out Parliament's position on the Council's proposed directive imposing country-specific "reporting" as part of the fight against aggressive tax optimisation. The purpose of this provision is to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made.  Thus, the proposed directive would make it mandatory to report turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, etc., by country, in each jurisdiction where multinational groups operate.  I voted for this measure, which makes the automatic and compulsory exchange of information a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles, especially since the text provides that it is the Member States that will be required to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and who will benefit from it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this crucial text in the fight against the aggressive tax evasion and optimization of large groups. This is an essential step in transparency to give ourselves the means to restore tax fairness. Country-by-country reporting requires multinationals to report to the states their economic and tax information in each state or tax jurisdiction: activity, turnover, pre-tax profits, taxes paid, etc.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has for years been engaged in combating cross-border tax avoidance, tax competition and aggressive business tax planning. These issues have become increasingly important not only in Europe but also in the world and therefore require more effective legislation, in line with the increased importance of the challenges to be faced. The Rosati report, which I supported with my vote, identifies the compulsory automatic exchange of tax information as the main way to stem the phenomena of tax avoidance and competition. Under the new legislation, multinational companies will be obliged to provide country-by-country reporting from 2017, in accordance with a standard model, if their total consolidated results in more than EUR 750 million. Member States will have a duty to make this report available to other EU countries through an automatic exchange procedure. A crucial role should also be played by the Commission, which, thanks to full access to shared information, could assess whether or not tax practices comply with Community state aid rules.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. This report amends the commission's proposal for the exchange of information on the profits and taxes of multinationals, aimed at reducing tax avoidance. We consider that the report is clearly insufficient, and we have opted because the information is not only exchanged between Member States, but is regularly communicated to the Commission and above all made public. Unfortunately, this last point has been rejected by large groups.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which carries the proposal for a directive to impose country reporting. This directive will help to combat the abusive tax optimization practices of some multinationals, while protecting SMEs. Indeed, it will give Member States the opportunity to ensure that the profits of large companies (the proposed threshold is 750 million euros of turnover for the group's parent entity, a threshold high enough to avoid imposing new constraints on SMEs) will be imposed where they are made. Thus, multinationals would be required to report in each country their turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, salaried staff, assets, or subsidies received. If necessary, Member States will be empowered to take deterrent sanctions. Finally, it would also constitute a certain tax benefit. The only downside to this proposed directive is that it is the European Commission that is the preferred recipient of the information and can determine whether or not reporting should be advertised. This could potentially compromise the secrecy of business.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax sector, which I supported with my vote, is acceptable and does not present any particular critical issues.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and fiscal competition has been considerably exacerbated, and today creates enormous concern both in the Union and globally. We believe that multinationals should be required to publish country-by-country reports under the Cofferati report. The proposal to exchange information between tax administrations between countries is only the first step. However, the establishment of an arbitrary billing threshold for the implementation of the Directive is not yet understood, as it does not cover all the undertakings that should be covered, so we request that it be reviewed.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the provisions of the Council Directive on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The problem posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased significantly and is of great concern in the European Union and at global level. In its reports prepared by the European Parliament's Economic Affairs and Monetary Affairs and Tax Committees, Parliament called for greater transparency in relation to information on tax issues to combat aggressive tax planning, in particular by imposing a country-by-country reporting obligation on multinational enterprise groups. Member States do not share country-by-country reports between Member States in applying the current rules of law (Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation – now in its third version). There is therefore an urgent need to increase transparency. To that end, it is necessary to improve the instruments and mechanisms established by Council Directive 2011/16/EU. The European Parliament therefore welcomes the Commission's proposal as a positive step towards greater transparency. Considers, however, that the proposal would be more effective by adopting the proposed amendments establishing the exchange of information with the European Commission, and calls on the Commission to assess, on the basis of this information, member states' compliance with EU State aid rules.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ i also supported the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased significantly in the EU and is of great concern at global level. It is therefore essential to increase transparency in tax liabilities, which has also been pointed out by the Lux Leaks affair. We simply have to insist that taxes are paid in the country where profits are made. The proposed directive exacerbates the tools and mechanisms established by Council Directive 2011/16/EU, and I was therefore happy to support it.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The problems of cross-border tax avoidance and evasion, which generate harmful tax competition and distorting effects on competitiveness, have taken on considerable proportions, becoming one of the main sources of concern at world and European level. To address this, the European Parliament and the other EU institutions have repeatedly come out in favour of greater transparency and the automatic exchange of information on tax matters, and have also called for measures and mechanisms to stem this phenomenon, such as country-by-country reporting for certain multinational companies. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted today, as it calls for the strengthening of existing instruments in this area and supports the need to identify new mechanisms to combat unfair or aggressive tax practices, and thus to reduce the incidence of this phenomenon within the Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report on automatic information sharing in the field of taxation. I am sorry that the proposal to lower the threshold was not supported, as the threshold of 750 million euros in turnover will allow only 10% of multinationals, or about 1900 companies, to be tackled. I believe that in the near future, the threshold should be considered once again to achieve greater transasparentity in the fight against aggressive tax planning.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report because while it contains several important and positive aspects aimed at tackling tax evasion and avoidance, and aggressive tax planning, it also has several limitations. The report was the first legislative proposal in the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package aimed at obliging multinational enterprises (MNEs) with total revenue of €750 million or more to file a country-by-country report in the Member State where the ultimate parent company is resident for tax purposes and for this data to be automatically exchanged between Member States. I fully support measures aimed at tackling tax avoidance but believe Member States should have primary competence over tax policy, and this report proposed that the Commission should be associated with the automatic exchange of information between Member States. Another problem with the report was that I believe the threshold for MNEs’ revenue should be lower than $750m in order for them to be obliged to file country-by-country reports. The report also does not introduce a public disclosure obligation for the MNEs to make their country-by-country reports public. I voted in favour of an amendment calling for such public disclosure.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is important, in order to combat the increasingly frequent phenomena of tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition, to establish a system of compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field between all Member States. This system has the advantage of making the control of the tax authorities more effective, and this will benefit the whole community.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is unacceptable that some Eu ropean Union Member States or certain territories dependent on them do not share the EU's fight for tax justice and against evasion and corruption. The automatic sharing of information between The Member States of the Union is a necessary and fundamental step towards harmonisation and tax justice within the Union and in the fight against the evasion of large-capital owners. That is why we must wholely support this decision, as must any effort to combat tax injustice within the European Union and its Member States.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Rosati report sets out the European Parliament's position on the proposed directive imposing country reporting, as part of the fight against aggressive tax optimisation. This reporting allows Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. The proposed directive would make it mandatory for the country to report turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, salaried staff, assets, subsidies received in each jurisdiction where multinational groups operate. For this main reason, I voted, through this report, for the continuation of the legislative process.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a directive aims to strengthen cooperation between Member States' tax authorities to combat tax evasion in the context of the importance of aggressive tax planning. The need for all taxpayers to pay their taxes fairly derives from the ultimate purpose of collecting these taxes, namely to obtain higher tax revenues, which leads to a reduction in public sector deficits, which benefits citizens. It is therefore necessary for the tax authorities to have complete and relevant information on the structure of multinational business groups, in particular information on their transfer pricing policy. It is also necessary to increase the transparency with which these groups operate, in particular, since multinational undertakings need to provide annually and for each tax jurisdiction in which they operate information on the amount of income, profit prior to income taxation, income taxes paid and accrued, number of employees, share capital, capital gains withheld and tangible assets. I have expressed myself in favour of this proposal because I believe that close cooperation between tax authorities based on increased transparency generates a good functioning of internal markets and a significant reduction in tax evasion.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has taken on considerable proportions and has become a major concern in the Union and around the world. Specifically, the Commission's proposal clarifies the way in which multinational companies report country by country and calls on the information collection centre. I would point out that, on the one hand, a greater role for the Commission in tax matters affects one of the last prerogatives of the Ms, but on the other hand it is plausible that the supervision of tax practices at Community level, by large multinational companies, will find central coordination of the information provided by the national authorities. In view of the possible political importance that the vote may have in the light of recent events involving several multinational companies on EU territory, I voted in favour.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Directive on the Automatic and Mandatory Exchange of Information in the Tax Field is part of the European Commission's legislative package to improve tax transparency in the wake of the revelations of the Luxleaks scandal. The European Parliament has been consulted on this text. The European Commission proposes that multinational companies with a turnover of EUR 750,000,000 or more should provide the tax authority of the Member State in which they operate with a country-by-country declaration. This statement contains the turnover, pre-tax profits, income taxes, number of employees and the social capital of the multinational company. This information will then be exchanged automatically and obligatoryly with the other authorities of the Member States concerned by the multinational. This directive is a major step in the fight against tax optimisation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of amending the Directive on administrative cooperation in the tax field, which defines the scope and conditions for the compulsory automatic exchange of country-by-country reporting information. The proposal aims to put a stop to cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax competition harmful to the Eu ropean Union by introducing a transparency obligation that will require groups of multinational companies located in the EU or with operations in the EU, whose total consolidated revenues amount to or greater than EUR 750 000 000, to submit country-by-country reporting.  It will then be the competent authority of the Member State which received the report that will communicate, by means of an automatic exchange, such reporting to any other Member State in which one or more constituent entities of the multinational group of undertakings are resident for tax purposes or are subject to tax for activities carried out through a permanent establishment. I welcome the criteria introduced for the information to be exchanged and the imposition of a reporting deadline of 12 months from the last day of the reference tax period of the group of multinational companies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report because while it contains several important and positive aspects aimed at tackling tax evasion and avoidance, and aggressive tax planning, it also has several limitations. The report was the first legislative proposal in the Anti-Tax Avoidance Package aimed at obliging multinational enterprises (MNEs) with total revenue of €750 million or more to file a country-by-country report in the Member State where the ultimate parent company is resident for tax purposes and for this data to be automatically exchanged between Member States. I fully support measures aimed at tackling tax avoidance but believe Member States should have primary competence over tax policy, and this report proposed that the Commission should be associated with the automatic exchange of information between Member States. Another problem with the report was that I believe the threshold for MNEs’ revenue should be lower than $750m in order for them to be obliged to file country-by-country reports. The report also does not introduce a public disclosure obligation for the MNEs to make their country-by-country reports public. I voted in favour of an amendment calling for such public disclosure.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which recommends introduction of a number of amendments to the directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. This will help us deal more effectively with tax evasion and fraud.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, although the final text for the plenary presented some critical issues, our requests to increase the level of publicity and transparency of the data collected by the Commission were subsequently accepted.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report as we consider it a positive step to enhance transparency.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a Council directive on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. I believe that this issue is particularly important for streamlining the functioning of the Union and better controlling economic activities within its territory. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I therefore voted in favour of this report because I think it highlights the basic prerequisites for effectively combating tax fraud, which is a dangerously growing phenomenon.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years, the challenge posed by tax fraud and tax evasion has increased considerably and has become a major focus of concern within the Union and at global level. The automatic exchange of information constitutes an important tool in this regard and the Commission, in its Communication of 6 December 2012, containing an Action plan to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, highlighted the need to promote vigorously the automatic exchange of information as the future European and international standard for transparency and exchange of information in tax matters. This Directive amending Council Directive 2011/16/EU as part of the Commission’s Anti- Tax Avoidance Package, addresses the political priority of fighting tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. It also responds to the demands of the European Parliament outlined in its resolution of 21 May 2013.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy in the collection and dissemination of tax information, UKIP accordingly voted against.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – The EU is an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy in the collection and dissemination of tax information, UKIP accordingly voted against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite a clear improvement in the area of the exchange of tax information between EU Member States, the limit laid down excludes most companies from such obligations. This report falls within the framework of the many tax scandals that the European Parliament has been working on during the last few years. It proposes very important measures for the control of the tax activity of multinational companies that must be integrated into the European regulatory framework. However, the limit of EUR 750 million (as consolidated turnover) excludes the majority of such undertakings which may continue to operate without being subject to this regulation. It is because of this great failure that I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of recent news of the global scale of fraud, tax evasion and avoidance, European solutions to solving this problem have become a priority. That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution strengthening the European Commission's proposal on the automatic exchange of information in the tax field. By voting in favour, I wanted to support greater transparency in the tax sector throughout the European Union. Indeed, I believe that the automatic exchange of tax information between multinationals and national authorities is an important step in facilitating the work of national tax administrations in controlling the profits of multinationals, to verify that taxes are paid in the country where these profits are made. To this end, it is important that member states' tax authorities have access to complete and relevant information and that such information is exchanged both between the tax authorities of the Member States and with the European Commission.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the topics of major concern within the Union, but also at global level, is the problems arising from cross-border tax evasion, which have worsened considerably. Groups of multinational enterprises located in the EU or operating in the Union, with a consolidated total income equal to or greater than EUR 750 000 000, will be required to submit the country-by-country report. The country-by-country report shall be submitted in the Member State in which the parent company is a subsidiary of the group of multinational undertakings or any other reporting entity has its tax residence. I voted for this first step towards resolving these problems by increasing transparency.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The problem of cross-border tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning is becoming increasingly challenging. Under the current EU legal framework, Member States do not share tax information on companies. This is one of the Commission's measures to prevent tax evasion, a tangible proposal; transparency by strengthening European cooperation. New provisions will be introduced into the Directive specifying the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic exchange of information on country-by-country reports. The ECON and TAXE committees of the EP called for the introduction of country-by-country reporting obligations for multinational groups in order to combat aggressive tax planning.  MNEs with aggregate consolidated revenue of at least EUR 750 million will be required to submit a country-by-country report in the Member State in which the final parent company of the MNM group or any other reporting entity has tax jurisdiction. The competent authority of the Member State which has received the country-by-country report shall communicate the report by means of an automatic exchange of information to all other Member States in which one or more of the economic units of the MNN Group are resident for tax. The country-by-country report will contain a wide range of information on the group's business, including revenue, profit before tax, income tax paid and still due, number of employees, subscribed capital, profit and loss reserves and tangible assets.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The proposal proposes amendments to the Directive on administrative cooperation, consisting in the introduction of specific requirements for the automatic exchange of information on country-by-country reports. These amendments concern, inter alia, the scope of information provided by multinational companies in respect of each tax jurisdiction, the threshold from which the reporting obligation arises, the rules for the automatic exchange of information between national tax authorities, as well as other practical issues. This consultation shall not require information to be made public. The proposal aims to involve the European Commission more in the process of exchanging information on country-by-country reports, but it has been pointed out that the European Commission must comply with confidentiality rules. I agree with these provisions and with the amendments made to the earlier directive, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This consultation report focuses on the revision of the rules on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. This exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States would become compulsory and automatic. The text proposes that multinational business groups provide certain information (revenue amount; pre-tax profits; number of employees; social capital; tangible assets) every year, and for each tax jurisdiction in which they operate. All groups of multinational companies with a turnover of more than 150 million euros (OECD standard) must complete this country-by-country declaration. Considering that multinational business groups must be transparent with European tax jurisdictions, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy in the collection and dissemination of tax information, UKIP accordingly voted against.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. Ending fraud and tax evasion requires the establishment of country-by-country accounting reporting. With the Rosati report, a step has been taken, as this text provides for the automatic and compulsory exchange of information between the administrations of the Member States, and aims to impose on multinationals the declaration, country by country and tax administrations only, of their main information. I welcome this progress, which will currently only be applied to multinationals with more than 750 million euros in annual net sales. We have struggled to change this threshold, which de facto exempts 90% of multinationals, without being heard at this time, even though the Panama Papers scandal shows a general awareness. That is why I am concerned about the provisions introduced by the Council to the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, which weaken the general scope of the text.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I welcome the Commission's proposal for an automatic exchange of information on corporate taxation between national tax authorities. This is another step towards tax transparency and an important step forward in the fight against unfair tax practices, particularly aggressive corporate tax planning. However, I believe that this type of progress cannot be made by member states on an individual basis. This requires joint action. The European Commission should therefore participate in the exchange of country-by-country reports and have access to information exchanged between Member States' tax authorities, which would enable it to assess whether Member States' tax practices are in line with state aid rules. This is particularly important for SMEs operating in one country. Available data show that, in general, these companies are subject to an effective tax rate much closer to legal rates than that offered to multinationals. For me, domestic companies cannot be systematically disadvantaged because of their size or the absence of cross-border trade.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text deals with country reporting, which is intended to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. This is one of the flagship measures of the OECD's Base Erosion Profit Shifting (BEPS) plan, i.e. the fight against base erosion and profit shifting. Thus, the proposed directive would make it mandatory to report by country the turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, employees, assets, subsidies received, this in each jurisdiction where multinational groups operate. Although the Commission is the recipient of the information and whether it considers whether it is necessary to publish it or not, these measures are a tool to combat "letterbox" companies and fictitious or abusive domiciles. Since Member States are obliged to take deterrent sanctions in the event of default and will benefit from it, I voted for this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Rosati's report as it represents an amendment to the Administrative Cooperation Directive which introduces, in particular, the additional requirement for automatic exchange of information by country. I support the establishment of a system of single standards according to those introduced by the OECD in order to avoid the creation of different levels of standards, reporting requirements, as well as the creation of a burden on small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's amendments to the Commission's proposal to the Council on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation propose that Member States should also give access to the information exchanged (between the tax authorities of the Member States). This situation will result in the Commission's monitoring, supervision and unacceptable involvement in this area as well. For these reasons I voted against the report.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The aim of this review is to strengthen transparency on taxes paid by companies by making it mandatory to automatically exchange information on the country reports of multinationals between national tax authorities. Groups of multinational companies based or operating in the EU, the total of which is eur 750 million or more, will be required to submit a report by country which should include information on the amount of revenue, profits before the incidence of income tax, income tax paid and deferred , the number of workers, the declared capital, the undistributed profits and the tangible assets.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. The fight against tax evasion and avoidance is one of the main challenges that we, as legislators, are facing. Aggressive tax planning and tax competition have called for increasing transparency regarding information through the introduction of country by country reporting for multinationals. As a delegation of the 5 Star Movement, we wanted more publicity and transparency of information, as well as the online publication of information. The failure to accept our amendments in this regard makes this report imperfect and to some extent diminishes Parliament's appreciable commitment to a more effective fight against tax evasion and avoidance.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We are facing an attempt to respond to what became known as the Luxleaks scandal, which directly involved the current President of the European Commission, when he was still finance minister and later Prime Minister of Luxembourg. The discovery that not only this, but also several other governments of EU countries have concluded secret agreements with multinational companies to save them from paying taxes, opening the door to tax avoidance and depriving states of huge revenues that would result from the due collection of taxes, generated just and understandable outrage across Europe. For those in charge of the EU, we had to make sure that something changed in appearance so that everything stays the same.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on administrative cooperation because I believe that greater transparency is needed in the area of the exchange of information in the field of taxation. I welcome the introduction of specific requirements for the automatic exchange of country-by-country reporting information between national tax authorities, as well as the classification of information to be communicated by multinational companies for each tax jurisdiction. I also consider it appropriate to provide for a threshold for the identification of companies obliged to make the report.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is no longer aware of advice from tax avoiders in a targeted and thoughtful way. This state of aggressive tax planning and harmful tax burdens will continue if we do not succeed in increasing transparency together, which we can only achieve by adopting improved instruments and mechanisms in the forthcoming legislation. I therefore welcome the European Commission's initiative to introduce into the existing directive a new article defining the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on country-by-country reporting. The adoption of this legislation will mean that multinational groups established or operating in the European Union, whose total consolidated income amounts to or exceeds EUR 750 000 000, will be forced to report on a country-by-country basis.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I believe we need more control against tax avoidance.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's amendments to the Commission's proposal to the Council on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation propose that Member States should also give access to the information exchanged (between the tax authorities of the Member States). This situation will result in the Commission's monitoring, supervision and unacceptable involvement in this area as well. For these reasons my vote is against the report.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recent revision of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC 4). The Directive encourages better cooperation between tax administrations in the EU and will ensure that tax authorities have the necessary information to act in a coordinated manner to fight against tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In order to counter the aggressive tax planning we need increased transparency with regard to tax information, notably by introducing country-by-country reporting (CbCR) for Multinational Groups. Because under the current legal framework Member States do not share CbCR with one another, I welcome the proposal to set out a mandatory exchange of information of country-by-country information between tax authorities, taking into consideration that tax transparency is only a first step to fight tax avoidance. However, the Commission’s proposal regarding a threshold will only make it possible to tackle 10% of multinationals, about 1 900 companies. I would like to underline that I am in favour of lowering the threshold to EUR 40 million, the threshold of the Accounting Directive and CDR IV, in order to target about 20 000 multinational companies. In parallel, I believe that the Commission should also have access to the information exchanged between Member States’ tax authorities in order to ensure compliance with the relevant competition rules. I support the publishing of the country-by-country reports by the Commission, based on the information contained in the centralised register of country-by-country reports. In doing so, the Commission shall comply with the provisions on confidentiality.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, the problem of cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has become increasingly challenging. In the reports of the ECON and TAXE Committees, we have stepped up the legal framework for the transparency of tax information, notably by introducing country-by-country reporting to multinational groups of companies. The Panama Papers scandal has shown the great need to increase transparency. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that the proposal is heading in the right direction, in particular with regard to the need to increase transparency and the threshold for groups of multinational companies subject to country-by-country reporting. It is to be welcomed that the report imposes transparency requirements on multinational groups of companies.  Increased transparency may also encourage MNNSs to meet their tax obligations at a higher rate in the country where they operate. The introduction of automatic exchange of information between national tax authorities is more important than ever. The competitiveness of European businesses and the performance of the economy are at stake. I congratulate my colleague Rosati on the excellent report, which I supported with a positive vote.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal as it will introduce a much needed directive to combat major tax evasion and avoidance; the proposals aim to focus on multi-national enterprises with large assets in several countries. I think this is a good and important part of the proposal as it is the multi-national enterprises that have the means and infrastructure to avoid taxes on a grand scale. It is important that we keep red-tape and bureaucracy for medium and smaller-sized companies as well as individual citizens to minimum and in this regard I welcome the proposal’s focus and restriction on the ‘country by country’ reports to major multi-national enterprises with assets over EUR 750 000 000.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution amending the proposal for a Council directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, because I strongly supported first of all the explicit extension of the scope of the automatic exchange of information to combat not only tax fraud but also the equally important phenomenon of tax avoidance. It is essential for the Union that tax rules are designed in such a way as not to jeopardise growth or investment or to constitute a competitive disadvantage for companies in the Union, nor to increase the risk of double taxation; it is also essential that these rules are designed to minimise costs and administrative burdens for companies. In accordance with the important investigation work on the phenomenon of early decisions in tax matters, I supported the reference to the EP resolution of 25 November 2015 on tax ruling and other similar measures by nature or effect, to Parliament's report on the proposal for a directive on the encouragement of long-term shareholder engagement and to Directive 2013/34/EU on corporate governance. The Member States are now in a chance to tax the profits of large multinational groups and make sure that they are taxed where they are produced.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the obligation to automatically exchange information in the field of taxation. Anyone who wants to prevent tax evasion, curb tax tricks and achieve greater tax justice across Europe in the interests of citizens, families and small and medium-sized enterprises must cooperate well and transparently. This directive is a good basis for this.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The outcome of today's vote reflects the need for greater transparency with regard to tax information in order to combat cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition. Automatic exchange of information is an important tool in this regard as a future European and international standard for transparency and exchange of information in tax matters.  The proposal also sets out the threshold from which MNEs are required to report by country, the scope of information exchanged, the timetable for implementation and the frequency of reporting. Following the entry into force of the new rules, multinational groups of companies established in or operating in the EU with revenues of at least EUR 750 000 000 will be required to submit such reports. The European Commission should participate in the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation and, like national tax authorities, should have access to reports in compliance with confidentiality rules.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. New scandals on tax avoidance, tax evasion and tax avoidance are becoming known time and again. It was recently about the Panama Papers. We are facing significant challenges in this area. I support the country-specific report that multinationals will have to submit to the relevant authority from 2017. This creates greater transparency with regard to tax information on individual companies.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for country-by-country reporting. If we are ever to tackle tax dodging it is vital that we make companies report exactly where they make their money and where they pay their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, although it still does not go far enough: many more companies should be required to submit these reports and the reports should be made public. Only then will we have true tax transparency. While Labour MEPs have consistently voted in favour of increased transparency, it is lamentable that Conservative MEPs have talked a good game but when it comes to the crunch have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world of tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This text proposes country-by-country reporting, i.e. the ability for the tax authorities of the various Member States to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they have been made. This business strategy is already being applied to banking institutions. Once implemented, this directive would require multinational groups to report their turnover by country, pre-tax profits, taxes paid, wage headcount and all subsidies received. This could be more effective in combating fictitious, abusive domiciles, but also against so-called "mailboxes" companies. Member States will retain the right to sanction abuses for breaches by multinational groups. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, which I believe is in the direction of greater transparency.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. In a different context than the financialized globalization we are experiencing, where capital flows freely from one end of the world to the other, we would not even ask ourselves the question of tax optimisation, its morality, its legality and its harmful consequences. But in reality, and even if the European level of decision-making is not satisfactory, we must do the right thing. That is why I voted for Mr Rosati's report, which is part of the fight against tax evasion or against the aggressive tax planning of multinationals. It is no longer acceptable - it has never been - for large groups to make considerable profits, aided by armies of lawyers, to evade tax, when captive taxpayers, SMEs and citizens, are crushed. The so-called "country reporting" is the obligation to report to the tax authorities the profits made country by country, taxes paid or due, turnover, staff, etc. and the automatic exchange of this information between administrations should be used to detect suspicious behaviour.  There are many negative points in this report, such as the role of the Commission. But since Parliament's opinion was only advisory, this did not justify another position.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. – This report amends the commission's proposal for the exchange of information on the profits and taxes of multinationals, aimed at reducing tax avoidance. We consider that the report is clearly insufficient, and we have opted because the information is not only exchanged between Member States, but is regularly communicated to the Commission and above all made public. Unfortunately, this last point has been rejected by large groups.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report because there needs to be a mandatory exchange of information in the tax field. The Panama case adds to many other cases of tax avoidance, economic crime. I have been and am a supporter of SMEs and in this area of tax evasion they are the ones who suffer the most. Cooperation is needed to reduce cross-border tax evasion, and that is why I supported this report. An adequate level of information provided to the tax authorities of the Member States and the Commission responsibly will discourage those who have become accustomed to running for profit by circumventing tax regulations and business ethics.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. This proposal calls for country-by-country reporting, which I believe is vital. It is vital because, if we are to ever tackle tax dodging, we need to make companies report exactly where they are making their money and where they are paying their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, in my view, although it – as is often the case – does not go far enough. Much more can be done, such as expanding the number of companies that should be required to submit such reports, and such reports need to be made public. It is a shame that the Tories do not understand this and have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world that is tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. After the Panama Papers revelations, a strong message must be sent to tax evasion candidates. It is a question of social justice that matters most to me. That is why I supported this text, which is one of three proposed in the "Moscovici package" against tax evasion presented last January, and which aims to impose on multinationals the declaration, country by country, to tax administrations only, of their main tax information: nature of the activity, employees, turnover, pre-tax profits, total taxes due, corporate taxes, etc. For the Socialists, the aim was to lower the threshold currently set to exempt multinationals below 40 million, not 750 million as proposed by the Commission, thus exempting 90% of multinationals. We will continue to fight to change this threshold and achieve a country-by-country ratio. Conservatives and Liberals must stop being deaf to our citizens' calls for a firmness that now seems more necessary than ever; going in any other direction is purely unacceptable.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report. The matter of transparency and its instruments should be increased in the directive. Therefore, the Parliament encourages the Commission to focus and review the mechanism of transparency in this regard.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – Country-by-country reports are central to the Commission's anti-avoidance package following the LuxLeaks scandal (and now PanaLeaks), as it allows to know where multinationals generate their profits and where they actually pay their taxes. The European Parliament has already positioned itself in favour of imposing an obligation on multinationals to publish country-by-country reports under the Shareholders' Rights Directive (Cofferati report) although the Council has strongly opposed it. Recently, the Commission has put forward a legislative proposal on the mandatory publication of country-by-country reports, so this proposal on exchanging country-by-country reports of multinationals between tax administrations, which I have supported, is only a first step, if only important and positive. However, I do not share the relatively arbitrary billing threshold for the implementation of the Directive (EUR 750 million per year) which means that only 1,900 merchants would be covered, when the Accounting Directive indicates a lower threshold for identifying large companies and that if implemented, the new rule would cover 20,000 undertakings.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as I had no objections to its contents.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of improved cooperation between tax authorities. The report presented by the rapporteur is balanced by improving the exchange of information between tax authorities, but not ignoring the data protection of taxpayers. The measures proposed by the Commission and adopted by the Council are likely to help tax authorities to be better informed about the activities of taxpayers. This will help make tax avoidance more difficult and pay taxes to international corporations where profits are made. I support this concern and voted in favour of the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Tax transparency is crucial in fighting tax avoidance. I voted in favour of this report because this is a necessary first step, however CBCR (country-by-country reporting) is needed.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, as this increases the transparency of tax information.  It is of utmost importance to address cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition in an efficient way, and to establish a System at European level that is in line with current global challenges.  The Commission proposal is good especially when it comes to the threshold for groups of multinationals that have to submit country-by-country reports and the scope of information exchanged. Therefore, I support this report and the principle of mandatory automatic exchange of information.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Country reporting will be a tool to combat mailboxes or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it. Finding these measures positive, I voted in favour of the text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The EU is an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy in the collection and dissemination of tax information, Diane James MEP accordingly voted against.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this directive, which concerns the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. It allows for better cooperation between EU tax administrations with a view to more effective tax collection and a better fight against fraud in Europe. There is an urgent need for the various tax authorities in Member States to exchange information so that multinationals cannot evade tax with regard to their activities in Member States.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report aims to ensure more effective cooperation between the managing authorities of each Member State in order to counteract harmful tax practices. The collaboration of Member States through the exchange of country-by-country reports enables national tax authorities to intervene more effectively in the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning by multinational groups of companies. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Taxation policy in the European Union is a very important and at the same time complex system, as there are 28 different national tax policies with differences in them. It is very important that, in future, in matters of tax law and application in the European Union, Member States retain the existing exclusive national competence. However, the European Union needs greater transparency and cooperation between Member States on tax rulings and tax planning. Greater transparency and coordination could prevent tax revenues from one country from being unfairly reduced as a result of the tax policy applied by another Member State. I believe that the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation between the competent authorities of the Member States will facilitate fair tax competition in the European Union. I support greater coordination between EU Member States in matters of tax rulings, which is why I voted in favour of this advisory report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for country-by-country reporting because I believe that it is vital, if we are ever to tackle tax dodging, that we make companies report exactly where they make their money and where they pay their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, although it still does not go far enough: many more companies should be required to submit these reports, and the reports should be made public, if we are to have true tax transparency. The Labour Party understands that; it is just a shame that the Tories do not and have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world of tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of improved cooperation between tax authorities. The report presented by the rapporteur is balanced by improving the exchange of information between tax authorities, but not ignoring the data protection of taxpayers. The measures proposed by the Commission and adopted by the Council are likely to help tax authorities to be better informed about the activities of taxpayers. This will help make tax avoidance more difficult and pay taxes to international corporations where profits are made. I support this concern and voted in favour of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the amendment of the directive on administrative cooperation, with regard to tax information, by introducing country-by-country reporting for Multinational Groups. The proposal reflects an ambitious aim to improve the existing framework towards transparency. Even if it contains some limitations, given the fact that only multinationals with a total consolidated revenue equal or above EUR 750 million will be obliged to submit the country-by-country reports, it is a positive step forward, in order to counter aggressive tax planning. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the text because in the wake of the Panama Papers tax avoidance scandal, it is vital to end tax secrecy and abuses. Within the EU almost EUR 1 trillion is being lost due to tax evasion and avoidance. The problem knows no borders and affects every European citizen, so we should join efforts to stop it. In this context, we should support the extension of automatic information exchange at EU and global level. The amended directive 2011/16/EU is the first step towards more transparency and the effective fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I support the report before us. With regard to its ECON and TAXE reports, the EP has called for greater transparency regarding tax information in order to counter aggressive tax planning, and for country-by-country reporting (CBCR) to be introduced for multinational business groups. The draft in question provides for the amendment of Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in which Member States do not provide for reciprocal country-by-country trade; directive recently amended by Council Directive 2376/2015 precisely in order to achieve these objectives, namely the mandatory automatic exchange of country-by-country reporting information.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. The purpose of country reporting is to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. Thus, the proposed directive would make it mandatory to report by country the turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, salaried workforce, assets, subsidies received, this in each jurisdiction where multinational groups operate. Country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Country reporting is a measure that enables Member States to combat fraud and abuse by multinationals. This tool gives national governments the ability to ensure that corporate profits are actually subject to tax. Reporting already exists for banking institutions and the text therefore proposes to extend it to multinationals. Although the Commission is among the recipients of this information, Member States will be the only ones able to apply sanctions to outlawed companies, and will benefit from it. I expressed my support for this text by voting FOR.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe that country-by-country reports are fundamental within the Commission's anti-avoidance package following scandals such as LuxLeaks (and now PanaLeaks) as it allows to know where multinationals generate their profits and where they actually pay their taxes. The European Parliament has already positioned itself in favour of imposing an obligation on multinationals to publish country-by-country reports under the Shareholders' Rights Directive (Cofferati report) although the Council has strongly opposed it, as well as in the non-legislative report adopted by the TAXE special committee.  Recently, the Commission has proposed a legislative proposal on the publication of country-by-country reports, so the proposal to exchange country-by-country information between tax administrations is positive but only a first step.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. U2012 Country-by-country reports are central to the Commission's anti-avoidance package following the LuxLeaks scandal (and now PanaLeaks), as it lets multinationals know where their profits generate and where they actually pay their taxes. The European Parliament has already positioned itself in favour of imposing an obligation on multinationals to publish country-by-country reports under the Shareholders' Rights Directive (Cofferati report) although the Council has strongly opposed it. Recently, the Commission has put forward a legislative proposal on the mandatory publication of country-by-country reports, so this proposal on exchanging country-by-country reports of multinationals between tax administrations, which I have supported, is only a first step, if only important and positive. However, I do not share the relatively arbitrary billing threshold for the implementation of the Directive (EUR 750 million per year) which means that only 1,900 merchants would be covered, when the Accounting Directive indicates a lower threshold for identifying large companies and that if implemented, the new rule would cover 20,000 undertakings.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing.
