I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite a clear improvement in the area of the exchange of tax information between EU Member States, the limit laid down excludes most companies from such obligations. This report falls within the framework of the many tax scandals that the European Parliament has been working on during the last few years. It proposes very important measures for the control of the tax activity of multinational companies that must be integrated into the European regulatory framework. However, the limit of EUR 750 million (as consolidated turnover) excludes the majority of such undertakings which will still be able to operate without being subject to this regulation, while limiting public access to information, which is vital to effectively control the tax activity of large companies.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. We are faced with numerous cases of cross-border tax evasion, against which greater transparency is urgently needed.  In order to achieve such transparency, it is intended to increase the exchange of information between Member States. This information will include different items of a company, such as the amount of income from the company, the benefits before tax, the income tax paid and accrued, the number of employees as well as the accumulated profits, among other items.  It is also considered appropriate that there should first be an automatic exchange of information between national tax authorities on country-disaggregated information in which the European Commission plays an important role. Once this exchange has taken place, the exchange will be responsible for transmitting the conclusions of its study to the European Parliament and the Council. I consider that any control measures in areas of taxation are welcome to ensure compliance with the tax obligations of the Member States. That is why I support this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of improved cooperation between tax authorities. The report presented by the rapporteur is balanced by improving the exchange of information between tax authorities, but not ignoring the data protection of taxpayers. The measures proposed by the Commission and adopted by the Council are likely to help tax authorities to be better informed about the activities of taxpayers. This will help make tax avoidance more difficult and pay taxes to international corporations where profits are made.  I support this concern and voted in favour of the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. The Committee's proposal does not ener a major change in the opoti of the Commission's proposal. I voted against it because I do not agree with the extent of the exchange of company accounting data between the Member States and the Commission.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The problem of cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased in recent years and has become a focus within the Union and globally. Member States should increase the level of human, technical and financial resources dedicated to the automatic exchange of information between tax administrations, as it constitutes an important instrument in the fight against tax fraud, evasion and aggressive tax planning. Groups of multinationals (MNEPs) can engage in aggressive tax planning practices, the thus distorting internal market conditions and competition to the detriment of SMEs. Providing an adequate level of information to Member States' tax authorities and the Commission and sharing this information between them could encourage groups of MNEPs to abandon certain practices and pay taxes in the country where the value was created. By amending this directive, MNE, which is located in or operating in the EU, with total consolidated revenue equivalent to or higher than eur 750 000 000, will be obliged to report by country, which is further subject to automatic data exchange. Increasing the transparency of MNE groups without undermining the Union's competitiveness is an important part of countering base erosion and profit shifting and ultimately tax avoidance, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The proposal for a directive on the table defines the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of country-by-country reporting information, the application of which will help to detect tax avoidance in cross-border activities.  An obligation is introduced for multinational groups established or operating in the EU, whose total consolidated income amounts to or exceeds EUR 750 000 000, to report annually from 2017 in the Member State where the ultimate parent entity of the multinational group or any notifying entity is resident for tax purposes. The report shall be within the scope of information on the amount of income, profit before income tax, income tax paid and incurred, number of employees, declared capital, retained earnings and tangible assets. The exchange of this information between the Member States concerned will help to increase the monitoring, control and detection of tax fraud and evasion.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text.  As part of the fight against aggressive tax optimisation, Dariusz Rosati's report determines the European Parliament's position on the proposed directive requiring country reporting. This would allow Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 As the world economy is increasingly interconnected, it is necessary to have more capacity to control groups of multinational companies in the single market. So it is time for a unified system for the exchange of information in the Union so that businesses and Member States can work more efficiently. I supported this report because I believe that everyone will benefit from its initiatives.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. The automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation is a major step in combating tax evasion and avoidance. However, I cannot fail to mention my displeasure at the lack of ambition of this proposal, in which only large multinationals such as Google, Apple and IKEA will be included in the obligation to exchange information, as they are multinationals such as those which receive revenues of EUR 750 000,000 or more. In this sense, out will be all other large companies, including Portuguese companies, which may continue to enjoy tax avoidance maneuvers to escape their tax obligations, burdening the ordinary citizen and SMEs with the payment of taxes. I voted in favour, but I hope that this is only a first step and that it will soon be possible to present more comprehensive and effective legislation on this matter.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the amendments to the directive proposed by the EP on mandatory automatic exchange of information, which will help to collect taxes more effectively and combat their evasion.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I support the proposal to encourage the automatic exchange of tax information between Member States. It is a positive step in the fight against aggressive business tax planning practices. In addition, we believe that additional safeguards need to be established to avoid distortions of the internal market by the tax arrangements of some multinationals with the authorities of the countries.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. This initiative, which did not wait for the Panama Papers to be put on the table by the Commission, is good news in the immense jungle of tax evasion and optimization of large transnational firms. Country-by-country reporting requires multinationals to report their economic and tax information to states in each state or tax jurisdiction.  But the European Parliament's report, which is only consulted for opinion on this tax matter on the purview of the Member States, remains quite limited due to the resistance of right-wing groups; who refused to extend the measure to more than ... 10% of multinationals.  Although these transparency measures will not restore a level playing field between all taxpayers, SMEs and large groups, with only an extreme minority of companies engaged in international tax optimisation, the fact remains that, for the first time in Europe, we will be able to ensure the traceability of the profits of multinationals. These statements, which they are to make, could even be made public in the near future. The Commission's new proposal in this regard is an interesting basis for validating and extending the achievements of this text, which I voted for.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that seeks to modify administrative cooperation in the area of taxation, with a requirement for an automatic exchange of information in a form of non-public country-by-country reports for MNE Groups with revenue of €750 million or above.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The current legal framework for tax cooperation does not provide for the exchange of tax returns of companies country by country between Member States. In light of the latest tax evasion scandals, the report that is before us seeks to remedy them. It thereby requires an automatic and compulsory exchange of country-by-country tax information for multinationals located in the EU or operating in the EU. However, only multinationals with an income of more than 750 million euros are affected and these reports will not be made public. I abstain to encourage these efforts at transparency, without any illusions as to the arrangements that multinationals will be able to put in place to circumvent this still weak system, given the precautions of "protection" initially provided by this so timid text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The content of this amended proposal is comprehensive and will enable countries to be more effective in combating excessively optimal taxation. If the Commission recovers information as a result of certain amendments, it has no power. In short, this report is an important step forward in the fight against the fictitious or abusive offshoring of profits. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal amending the Directive on the automatic exchange of mandatory information in the field of taxation. With this legislative change, another step is taken in the fight against tax evasion and in favour of strengthening transparency on taxes paid by companies, making it mandatory to automatically exchange information on the country reports of multinationals between national tax authorities.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as its main goal is to tackle the problem of tax fraud and evasion. The proposal is aimed at multinational enterprises with revenues equal to or over EUR 750 million to submit country-by country reports, therefore SMEs will not be adversely affected or overburdened.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The automatic exchange of corporate tax information between national tax authorities is an important and necessary step. Member States retain their prerogatives in terms of taxation, but in a common area such as the European Union, it is essential to avoid national policies that are harmful to other Member States. By increasing transparency, we will better combat unfair tax practices between Member States and reduce harmful tax competition. With this in mind, the European Parliament has adopted a proposal that obliges multinational companies (holding at least EUR 750 million) to submit a country-by-country report in the Member State in which the parent entity resides for tax purposes. This Member State will then have to communicate with all other Member States the following information: turnover, profit, taxes paid, capital, un distributed profits, tangible assets and the number of employees.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Cross-border tax avoidance, harmful tax competition and aggressive tax planning is not only a problem within the European Union, but has already reached global dimensions. The European Parliament is seeking greater transparency of tax information, in particular by introducing a country-by-country reporting obligation for multinational groups. Under Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, Member States do not yet exchange country-by-country reports. Multinational groups established or operating in the EU, with a total consolidated income of or above EUR 750 000 000, will be forced to report on a country-by-country basis. The competent authority of the Member State in which the country-by-country report has been adopted shall, by automatic exchange, communicate the content of the report to all other Member States in which one or more individual entities of a given MNE Group are either resident for tax purposes or subject to tax in respect of an activity carried out through a permanent establishment. A country-by-country report must be submitted in the Member State where the ultimate parent entity of the mne mne group or any notifying entity is resident for tax purposes. I welcome this proposal when it comes to setting a lower limit for multinational groups, and I also believe that it will contribute to greater transparency as a whole. He's got my support.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, which overall is a positive step in the fight against unfair tax practices and aggressive corporate tax planning. The report should enhance tax transparency by obliging big multinational firms with total consolidated revenues of €750 million or more to file a country-by-country report in the EU member state in which the ultimate parent entity of the group is resident for tax purposes.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has adopted a directive to the Council amending Directive 2011/16/EU, which concerns mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The Council consulted Parliament on the proposal. The Swedish Parliament has tabled a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the Commission's proposal with 34 amendments and requests the Commission to amend its proposal to the Council accordingly. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose of country reporting is to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. This is one of the flagship measures of the OECD's BEPS plan (No. 13), which clearly needs to be supported, as have the automatic exchange of scripts or the final report of the TAXE 1 Commission. The scope of Parliament's opinion is complete and will help to restore a fair estimate of tax revenues due. Among the critics, it should be noted that the Commission is the recipient of the information, it is not a simple exchange between the administrations of the Member States. It will also determine whether or not to advertise the reporting, which is not desirable given the stakes in terms of the benefit that this could give to competitors not subject to such regulations. In the end, despite these remarks, country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft Directive amends Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, with the last wording given to it by Directive (EU) 2015/2376. This draft directive introduces a new article in the existing Directive, which sets out the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic exchange of report information by country. I believe that this proposal is already an important step in the fight against cross-border tax avoidance, which has been increasing and has become one of the main reasons for concern in the Union and globally. It is important to note that, following the reports submitted by the ECON and TAXE committees, the European Parliament has called for increased transparency on tax information in order to combat aggressive tax planning, including by introducing country reports for multinational groups of companies. I support the rapporteur's position that this proposal would improve in efficiency with the proposed amendments, which extend the exchange of information to the European Commission and request that, on the basis of this information, the Commission assess member states' compliance with EU state aid rules.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles.  It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it. That is why I voted for it.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, because it allows the Union to move forward in standardising the regulatory framework necessary to achieve uniform tax regulation in the near future. This report focuses in particular on the tax status of multinationals and the need for greater transparency. The starting document for the parliamentary debate is the BEPS text drawn up by the OECD, which identify the legislative procedures necessary to strengthen the tax union and the exchange of tax information between the countries of the Union. The report advocates the use and sharing of country-by-country reports (CBCr) for multinationals. The BEPS plan is a strategy that aims to reduce and in some cases even eliminate the inconsistencies in European tax systems that allow some companies to artificially shift profits where there is only a small part of the company, which often does not generate output, simply because there are facilities that allow it to reduce its tax contribution to the European economy. The BEPS plan has gained worldwide relevance as it was signed by the finance ministers of the G20 countries at the Shanghai conference last February.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The report aims to reduce cross-border tax avoidance and tax competition. This means submitting a country-by-country annual report on the part of multinationals. Member States receiving these reports shall forward the report to all other Member States where the multinational company submitting the report operates. This automatic exchange of information helps transparency and thus reduces the risk of tax fraud.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The challenge posed by aggressive tax planning, cross-border tax avoidance and harmful tax competition has increased considerably and has become a major focus of concern within the European Union and at global level. I have voted for this report that will oblige Multinational Groups in the EU that have a revenue equal or higher than EUR 750 million to file a country-by-country report that will include every tax jurisdiction where the group has its activities.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is of vital importance for the Union that tax rules are designed in such a way as not to adversely affect growth or investment, not to subject Union undertakings to competitive disadvantages or to increase the risk of double taxation, and that those rules are designed in such a way as to minimise costs and administrative burdens for businesses. The Directive on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation lays down the rules and procedures under which Member States cooperate with each other and with the Commission with a view to carrying out an exchange of information which is predictably relevant for the administration and application of Member States' national laws on taxes and charges.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report by vote because I believe that at European level there is a need to step up the fight against tax evasion. Due to the economic crisis of recent years, the population of the European community has become increasingly aware of the need to create a healthy fiscal environment, in which all taxpayers must pay their taxes in a fair way. In this respect, the report voted on today encourages the exchange of information between the tax authorities of each Member State, with multinationals obliged to transmit all information about the company's activity. Last but not least, this transparency will increase the state budget, not only by absorbing more taxes, but also by reducing administrative costs.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the regulation, which newly obliges multinational enterprises with revenues above CZK 20 billion per year to inform the tax authorities, inter alia, of their revenues and earnings, of income taxes paid or of the number of employees paid in each Member State in which they do business. The tax office to which this information will be delivered shall then transfer it to the other States in which the company does business or is liable to pay taxes. I consider the automatic exchange of information to be one of the first steps to make it easier for tax administrators to assess the taxation of large multinational supranational firms. The approved very limited range of reporting information will not lead to excessive burdens on companies, while establishing fair conditions in the area of tax collection. I welcome the fact that the debate on disclosure is separate from the approval itself, which must take place quickly. I would remind you that the benefits of this step also depend heavily on the ability of national tax authorities to work with data.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at this vote, I would have voted in favour of this report. It is a very positive step to counteract aggressive corporate tax planning. Further security guarantees are also advocated in order to give the EU Commission access to the information concerned.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported, the aim is to make the sharing of tax information more transparent between countries.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The EU must have effective measures in place to prevent aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance and with which. In particular, EU countries must automatically exchange information on the income, profits earned or the number of employees of large multinational corporations. It is also essential that the European Commission also involve the exchange of information between EU countries. In order to ensure an efficient exchange of information, all information must be publicly accessible and transparent. The Commission shall make the reports received from the competent public authority publicly available. The information should be made available on the Internet. In addition, an effective control and surveillance mechanism should be applied. Appropriate penalties should be provided for those undertakings which do not provide the required information.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The position of the explanatory memorandum to the Directive that 'tax rules must be designed in such a way as not to create barriers to growth or investment, not to create competitive disadvantages for Union businesses (...) as well as (...) minimise the costs and administrative burden on undertakings' reveals the substance of the Directive. EU and government tax policy serves precisely the fundamental strategy of strengthening the profitability of capital in every way. The fact that the directive concerns a very small part of transnational monopolies, those with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million, also reveals the extent of the mockery of the declarations on combating tax evasion and avoidance of businesses. The EU and the civil governments of its Member States, at the same time as legislating with the help of the civil law the exemption of capital from taxes and obligations with "development" and a plethora of other laws challenging tax exemptions, subsidies and aid to business groups, such as the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government in Greece, plunder the meager popular income with unbearable direct and indirect taxation, reduction of wages and pensions , abolition of social rights. The working people must get away with the mockery of "fair burden-sharing" in capitalism, claiming the socialisation of the monopolies and wealth that they themselves produce.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is an unnecessary layer of bureaucracy in the collection and dissemination of tax information, UKIP accordingly voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On my colleague's proposal, I would like to vote in favour. Tax planning and competition are currently particularly aggressive and harmful to the European Union. Therefore, greater transparency in this area, through the exchange of information on the revenues, profits and capital of multinational companies, is perceived as indispensable. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Surely economic policies are always frowned upon from the business world, but nevertheless they are needed to enable a functioning relationship between individuals and firms in the business world and national governments. There has been much controversy about taxation lately, so perhaps it is time to rethink the rules concerning the exchange of information in the field of taxation. I vote for the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation to enable a more transparent and fair taxation process concerning EU citizens and businesses.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Automatic exchange of information and access to country-by-country reports should be provided to all Member States (national tax administrations) and the Commission. Compliance with confidentiality rules must be taken into account. I support the proposed scope of information sharing that will contain information on the amount of income, pre-tax profits, income tax paid and incurred, number of employees, declared capital, retained profits and tangible assets for each tax jurisdiction in which the MNE group operates. Information on received public subsidies, property values and future European tax identification number should also be part of the country-by-country report. I am pleased with the announcement to increase the Commission's transparency towards citizens by publishing country-by-country reports based on information from the centralised register of reports, and I also support the proposal to submit an annual report to Parliament and the Council, where the Commission will summarise the main points of member states' national assessments.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a priority for the Union and its Member States to act resolutely in the face of the challenge of fraud and tax evasion, which have now assumed intolerable proportions. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to combat aggressive tax planning, there is an urgent need for greater transparency with regard to tax information, and in this respect the automatic exchange of information is an important step. The instruments and mechanisms set out in Directive 2011/16/EU need to be strengthened in order to achieve this objective and to combat unfair tax practices in the field of corporate taxation: it is a question of promoting a European and international standard for transparency in tax matters. This directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation already provides for the compulsory automatic exchange of information in a number of areas, but its scope needs to be broadened in order to achieve the compulsory automatic exchange of reports between Member States, which is not yet provided for in the current legal framework. The Commission should also have access to the information exchanged in order to ensure compliance with the relevant competition rules.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. We are facing an attempt to respond to what became known as the Luxleaks scandal, which directly involved the current President of the European Commission, when he was still finance minister and later Prime Minister of Luxembourg. The discovery that not only this, but also several other governments of EU countries have concluded secret agreements with multinational companies to save them from paying taxes, opening the door to tax avoidance and depriving states of huge revenues that would result from the due collection of taxes, generated just and understandable outrage across Europe.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. Tax fraud, avoidance and tax evasion have posed increasing challenges for the European Union in recent years. It is of utmost importance that tax rules are created in a way that will not prevent growth or investment, put companies in the Union at a competitive disadvantage or increase the risk of double taxation, and minimise costs and administrative burdens for companies. Reports for taxation purposes must be ented in the Member State where the parent company or any other entity is resident and must include relevant information. I supported MeP Rosati's report as a positive step in which it contains an action plan to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion with a view to ensuring the proper functioning of the Union internal market.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the past and now, I have supported the reporting of tax-relevant information of multinational supranational companies by country. I consider it the right move to pay taxes where profits are made. In another case, it's a financial robbery. Robbery on SMEs and other taxpayers who have to bear the tax burden instead. I also voted in favour of extending the country-by-country tax reporting obligation to several companies. The proposed legislation to enhance tax transparency would have a very limited scope. It concerned only a few percent of multinational supranational companies, and only those with an annual turnover of more than EUR 750 million. I find it very unfortunate that we have not been supported in this fight for greater tax fairness by colleagues from the conservative and liberal factions and have therefore, in my opinion, sided with tax cheats and their intermediaries. I also voted in favour of the proposal that the European Commission should have access to information that will be shared between the various tax authorities of the Member States. Furthermore, in order to expand the range of information to which the public will have access. We will never achieve full transparency unless all the necessary information is publicly available.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal will oblige multinationals with consolidated total revenues of €750 million or more to submit the "country by country" reporting in the Member State where the group's main parent is resident for tax purposes. That Member State will therefore have to share this information with the other Member States in which the company operates. The Directive will also set deadlines of 12 months for reporting after the tax closure of the financial year and a further three months for the automatic exchange of information. In order to ensure that the reporting obligation is applied, Parliament calls on the Member States to introduce sanctions to be imposed on multinationals that do not comply with their obligations under European legislation. I believe that, in order to assess whether tax practices comply with Community state aid rules, the Commission should have full access to information shared between the different national tax authorities. At European level, we must promote virtuous tax behaviour in order to ensure fairness and social justice. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The draft proposes amendments to the Directive on administrative cooperation consisting in the introduction of specific requirements for the automatic exchange of information on country-by-country reports. These amendments concern, inter alia, the scope of information provided by multinational companies in respect of each tax jurisdiction (pre-tax profit, output and paid tax, number of employees, etc.), the threshold from which the reporting obligation arises (consolidated total group revenues of at least 750 000 000), the rules for the automatic exchange of information between national tax authorities after receiving a country-by-country report from the multinational company, as well as other practical issues. This consultation shall not require information to be made public. The proposed amendments aim to involve the European Commission more in the process of exchanging information on country-by-country reports, but it is noted that the European Commission must comply with confidentiality rules. The compromise reached is balanced compared to earlier versions of the Administrative Cooperation Directive. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which welcomes the European Commission's proposal to introduce an automatic exchange of information on corporate taxation between national tax authorities. The main objective of this text is to effectively combat aggressive corporate tax planning. However, safeguards must be provided so that competition in the European single market is not respected by not being undermined, in particular, sometimes by tax agreements advantageous to multinational firms decided in certain Member States.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. This text aims to establish an automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field in order to reduce the aggressive tax planning practices used by multinational companies, which distort competition to the detriment of SMEs in particular. Also covered are the practices of tax competition between Member States to attract multinational companies or the shortfall in revenue for them. More broadly, this text is part of the EU's political will to combat tax evasion and evasion.  While we can welcome the progress proposed, we regret, however, that this text falls under the consultation procedure, thus limiting the role that European parliamentarians can play in this regard. However, Parliament's ECON Committee strengthened the original proposal, by further involving the Commission or by broadening the information involved in this exchange. In line with the political lines presented, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal makes it mandatory to exchange information between member states' tax authorities to identify aggressive tax planning practices by large enterprises and ensure fair tax competition. Companies with revenues of 750 million or more are required to submit country reports (including the amount of revenues, profits before the tax, number of employees, declared capital, undistributed profits, etc.). The 750 million ceiling covers only 105 of multinationals. S&D was in favor of this amount going down to 40 million, allowing it to oversee about 20,000 companies. There was no agreement and S&D tried to get an amendment to this effect passed in plenary, but it failed to get it approved. Still, this is a good principle on the path of transparency and tax justice.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and fiscal competition has been considerably exacerbated, and today creates enormous concern both in the Union and globally. Parliament considers that multinationals should be required to publish country-by-country reports under the Cofferati report. The proposal for an exchange of information between countries through their tax administrations is only the first step. However, the establishment of an arbitrary billing threshold for the implementation of the Directive is not yet understood, as it does not cover all the undertakings that should be filled, so we request that it be revised.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament was asked to give its opinion on the Council's proposal to amend the 2011/16/EU directive on automatic and compulsory exchange in the tax field. I have supported this report at the same time, but I cannot but regret the European Parliament's lack of ambition in this regard. A lack of ambition that concerns two elements in particular. First of all, I regret that the European Parliament has not voted in favour of a country-by-country declaration whose information could be accessible to all. In view of the recent revelations in tax matters, I think it is indeed important to play the card of transparency towards our European citizens. Second, I voted in favour of lowering the threshold to determine whether or not a group should submit a country-by-country declaration to the tax authorities. Unfortunately, the majority of the European Chamber has chosen to maintain the threshold of EUR 750,000,000 in consolidated turnover in order to determine whether or not a group of multinational companies is required to pass on to the tax authorities the information required by the country-by-country declaration.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 As long as member states' tax systems remain separate, there will be a need to ensure that different Member States exchange information on tax operations effectively. Information technology gives us this opportunity to achieve a high quality of information exchange, and it is therefore our duty to do everything in order to achieve effective tax collection and the fight against tax evasion, so that the exchange of tax information takes place quickly and to the fullest extent.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. It aims to tax a country-by-country declaration of the tax information of large multinationals: the nature of the activity, number of employees, turnover, profits, taxes, etc. These declarations will be made to the tax administrations of the various Member States. The European Commission will also have access to it, a possibility that the Socialist and Democratic Group has managed to introduce into the text. This text, which is part of the "Moscovici package" to combat tax evasion, is therefore a further step, but it does not go far enough. While Parliament has already voted several times for a country-by-country, public reporting, which would affect companies with a turnover of 40 million euros, due to the reluctance of the right, this text provides for a threshold of 750 million, which effectively excludes many companies from its scope. This is an unsatisfactory situation that will have to be corrected while new proposals are on the table. The battle must therefore continue in order to put an end to tax evasion practices.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the automatic exchange of mandatory information in the field of taxation.  In the current legal framework of Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, Member States do not yet share country-by-country reports, so in the current cross-border tax avoidance scenario it is essential to promote transparency and strengthen the tools and mechanisms set up by the Directive. I am in favour of the proposal put forward by the Commission, which establishs the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic exchange of information contained in the country-by-country report, and I endorse overall the more specific details on the mandatory reporting of multinational companies, taking into account the volume of revenue in commercial transactions. In the name of greater transparency and a more effective fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and avoidance, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the revision of the 2011 directive, which had already been updated in 2014 and which establishes all the procedures for better cooperation between the tax administrations of the European Union. These are technical measures aimed at more effective tax collection and the fight against fraud in Europe. The text states that multinational companies with total consolidated revenues equivalent to a minimum of EUR 750 million will be required to submit a country-by-country report in the Member State in which the group's ultimate parent entity resides for tax purposes. The fight against cross-border tax evasion is fundamental and in this sense we must strengthen transparency and cooperation so that they are maximised between the tax authorities of the European Union. The adoption of this text is a step forward and will reduce any harmful and unfair tax competition.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft directive on which this report focuses concerns administrative cooperation and the exchange of information on taxation within the Union. I voted in favour of a number of amendments to the original report, which aim to make the exchange of information between Member States' administrations compulsory and to promote the need not to jeopardise the competitiveness of EU businesses through the risk of double taxation or additional administrative costs.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. This report amends the commission's proposal for the exchange of information on the profits and taxes of multinationals, aimed at reducing tax avoidance. We consider that the report is clearly insufficient, and we have opted because the information is not only exchanged between Member States, but is regularly communicated to the Commission and above all made public. Unfortunately, this last point has been rejected by large groups.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ LuxLeaks, Swiss Leaks and now the Panama Papers scandal have highlighted the need for much greater transparency in reporting on profits, fund formations and transfers across frontiers, and tax liabilities by companies large and small, as well as individuals. I support all measures meant to ensure this transparency. Such measures must fully respect the need to allow a wide legitimate space for the financial services industry to function effectively, as well as the need for European corporations to compete on global markets against players which do not play by European rules. Nevertheless, transparency measures should not serve as a pretext to introduce tax harmonisation or to reduce the sovereignty of EU Member States in organising their taxation systems in line with their endowments. The latter point is especially crucial for smaller, peripheral economies in the EU system which have seen their flexibility eroded over the years by rules applied in a one-size-fits-all mode on a continental basis. I am sure that robust systems that combat tax evasion, aggressive tax planning, money laundering and related issues can be set up on a European basis, and globally, while respecting the above principles.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the revised directive on the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, as it will allow us to significantly improve cooperation between European tax authorities and make it easier to detect and punish tax offences.  The report provides that all companies with locations in more than one Member State – with total revenues of at least EUR 750 000 000 – are obliged to pass on information to each country in which they operate a site to the relevant tax authorities. The relevant Member States then exchange information with each other through these companies in order to verify that the taxes have been paid correctly.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax evasion, which the Social Democrats have long pointed out, has finally become a relevant topic of public debate in the EU and around the world. The huge scale of tax evasion, on the one hand, and the lack of funding in public budgets are indisputable facts, yet mechanisms for effective and fair taxation of multinational supranational companies are still lacking. I agree that the automatic exchange of information between the Member States and the Commission introduced by the proposal is an important instrument in this regard with regard to the fight against tax fraud, evasion and aggressive tax planning. Member States' tax authorities need comprehensive and relevant information on MNE groups in order to respond in a timely manner to undesirable tax practices. In the vote, the Social Democrats also supported lowering the consolidated income threshold for the inclusion of multinational supranational enterprises in the scope of the proposal in order to cover 10 times the number of companies than in the original proposal. However, this is still a partial step, not a sufficient step towards setting up tax transparency and fair taxation of multinational supranational companies.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote on this report because, despite a clear improvement in the area of the exchange of tax information between EU Member States, the limit laid down excludes most companies from such obligations. This report falls within the framework of the many tax scandals that the European Parliament has been working on during the last few years. It proposes very important measures for the control of the tax activity of multinational companies that must be integrated into the European regulatory framework. However, the limit of EUR 750 million (as consolidated turnover) excludes the majority of such undertakings which may continue to operate without being subject to this regulation. It is because of this great failure that I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal. This proposal calls for country-by-country reporting, which I believe is vital. It is vital because, if we are to ever tackle tax dodging, we need to make companies report exactly where they are making their money and where they are paying their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, in my view, although it – as is often the case – does not go far enough. Much more can be done, such as expanding the number of companies that should be required to submit such reports, and such reports need to be made public. It is a shame that the Tories do not understand this and have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world that is tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution amending the Directive on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, I voted in favour of its adoption. The tax 'optimisations' of multinationals and their efforts not to tax billions in revenue require us to introduce an exchange of information between tax administrations and to demand information on what profits they make and where they tax them. However, this effort to stop profits spilling over into tax havens must not be linked to tax harmonisation in the EU.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the increase in tax fraud and evasion in recent years and their serious impact on Member States' tax revenues, which are thus losing billions of euros. Tax evasion and fraud are a global problem and cannot be combated only at EU level. The EESC believes that, in the interests of simplicity and efficiency, as well as cost savings and for the benefit of all stakeholders, it is essential to harmonise the different systems for exchanging information resulting from individual initiatives and to transform them into a single system. This should be done at least at European level. Moreover, the related rules should be clear, unambiguous and proportionate in the light of the objectives required. I supported the resolution because the proposal for a directive is one of the measures of the action plan to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. I believe that these changes will help in the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. As there are currently considerable differences within tax systems and these differences can be an obstacle to the implementation of automatic exchange of information, I expect the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to simplify and harmonise tax legislation.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition pose an increasing challenge for the EU. We need more transparency on tax information to prevent aggressive tax planning, especially by introducing country-specific reporting for MNE Groups. The current legal framework does not yet oblige Member States to submit reports to other EU members, which would require greater transparency. Multinationals established or operating in the EU with total consolidated revenues of EUR 750 million or more will have to submit a country-by-country report. The competent authority of the Member State receiving this report will forward it, on the basis of an automatic exchange, to all other Member States in which one or more constituent entities of the MNE Group are resident for tax purposes or taxed in respect of activities carried out through a permanent establishment of the group. The Greens have been critical of limiting the reporting obligation only to the largest companies, which generate more than EUR 750 million in revenue per year, as this has greatly reduced the volume of companies covered by the measures. Although our proposals to reduce this threshold have not been adopted, it is still a step forward compared to the previous situation, which is why I supported the report at the meeting.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of improved cooperation between tax authorities. The report presented by the rapporteur is balanced by improving the exchange of information between tax authorities, but not ignoring the data protection of taxpayers. The measures proposed by the Commission and adopted by the Council are likely to help tax authorities to be better informed about the activities of taxpayers. This will help make tax avoidance more difficult and pay taxes to international corporations where profits are made.  I support this concern and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation between Member States' tax authorities is essential in the fight against tax avoidance. In recent years, business tax planning has become a way of using legislation to reduce tax liabilities. I therefore see the proposed directive as a positive step towards greater transparency, which will greatly strengthen international cooperation to combat tax evasion.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ In the last few years we have encountered an increase in the number of problems in the field of taxation at european union level, but also globally. These include cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition. Such a situation requires increased transparency regarding tax information in order to counter aggressive tax planning, in particular by introducing country-by-country reporting for groups of multinationals (MNP) as member states do not yet do so under the current legal framework. I support this report because I believe that it is essential to strengthen the tools and mechanisms of the council's already existing Directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation to address transparency and report sharing. Member States' tax authorities need comprehensive and relevant information on MNP groups in order to respond in time to harmful tax practices through changes in legislation or appropriate risk assessments and tax audits, and to determine whether companies have engaged in practices that have the effect of fictitiously shifting significant amounts of revenue to a more tax-advantaged environment.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for country-by-country reporting because I believe that it is vital, if we are ever to tackle tax dodging, that we make companies report exactly where they make their money and where they pay their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, although it still does not go far enough: many more companies should be required to submit these reports, and the reports should be made public, if we are to have true tax transparency. The Labour Party understands that; it is just a shame that the Tories do not, and have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world of tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Unfortunately, in recent years we have encountered an increase in the number of problems in the field of taxation at european union level, but also globally. These include cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition. Such a situation requires increased transparency regarding tax information in order to counter aggressive tax planning, in particular by introducing country-by-country reporting for groups of multinationals (MNP) as member states do not yet do so under the current legal framework.  I support this report because I believe that it is essential to strengthen the tools and mechanisms of the council's already existing Directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation to address transparency and report sharing. Member States' tax authorities need comprehensive and relevant information on MNP groups in order to respond in time to harmful tax practices through changes in legislation or appropriate risk assessments and tax audits, and to determine whether companies have engaged in practices that have the effect of fictitiously shifting significant amounts of revenue to a more tax-advantaged environment.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending the Directive on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. I support the amendment of the Directive, which, inter alia, regards the application of the practice of aggressive tax planning by multinational companies, but which is not available to domestic companies, emphasises that, in addition to the significant damage to SMEs, it also distorts and distorts the functioning of the internal market and distorts competition to the detriment of SMEs. I also welcome the amendment, which adds to the Directive that it is essential for the EU to make tax rules so that they do not jeopardise growth or investment, do not put businesses in the Union at a competitive disadvantage and do not increase the risk of double taxation of companies.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I and the ECR Group voted in favour of the recent revision of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC 4). The DAC4 covers all the necessary procedures for better cooperation between tax administrations in the European Union – such as exchanges of information on request; spontaneous exchanges; automatic exchanges; participation in administrative enquiries; simultaneous controls; and notifications to each other of tax decisions. It also provided for the necessary practical tools, such as a secure electronic system for the information exchange. This will ensure that tax authorities have the necessary information to act in a coordinated manner to fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. This Directive must be treated separately to the recently released proposal by the Commission on the Accounting Directive that introduces country-by-country reporting by large multinational entities to the public. The contents of the DAC4 and the level of granularity in the exchanges of information has been agreed internationally, therefore I do not support the amendments that have deviated from this international agreement, which would attempt to implement public country-by-country reporting via tax authorities instead of directly by the companies concerned.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The ECON and TAXE committees have been pushing for a more transparent taxation of large multinationals for some time, which would be greatly facilitated by country-by-country reporting. The Commission proposal to include a new article in Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation setting out the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic exchange of information on country-by-country reports is to be welcomed. However, I approve of the report's amendments concerning the extension of the exchange of information to the European Commission, which calls on the Commission to assess, on the basis of this information, whether Member States are indeed complying with EU state aid rules.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We did not vote in favour of the latest draft directive presented by the European Commission because it is still very critical. We have asked for the data to be made public and transparent, but the majority still preferred to keep it confidential. In fact, multinationals subject to reporting (less than 10%) they will have to submit only a limited number of tax data, leaving out important information (e.g. where subsidiaries, public subsidies, assets, etc.) are located, making the calculation of taxation distorted. The key issue, that of banks, is not being addressed. The banks are not mentioned in the draft resolution. There is no form of regulation for banks that are crucial in ensuring effective tax transparency. Recent Panama Papers and Swissleaks scandals teach, who are the real carousel of the machine of great tax avoidance and evasion. With this proposal, it is clear that the European Commission wants to protect large tax evaders and strong powers instead of contributing to the creation of a fair and transparent tax system.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ I support the resolution for mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation because I believe that public authorities in Member States need to better communicate and cooperate with each other in order to increase tax transparency. Although such information is not available to the public, CBCR is necessary in order to fight tax avoidance. The Lux Leaks and the Panama Papers revelations have brought momentum on tax evasion and have given the European Union opportunities to further push for the regulation of taxation at the EU level. The EU does not need to wait for a third leak in the area of taxation before finding solutions to the issues that we are confronted with.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's proposal for a directive amending the 2011/16/EU directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. In recent years, the challenge of tax evasion, tax avoidance and tax evasion has increased considerably and has become a major concern within the Union and globally. Automatic exchange of information is an indispensable tool.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Commission proposal on the mandatory and automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. In the midst of the Panama Papers scandal it has become even clearer that we need to drastically reduce the scope for aggressive tax planning, tax evasion and tax avoidance if we want to allow all businesses to compete more fairly in the EU and achieve better fiscal standards at an international level. The proposal will improve administrative cooperation between national authorities and increase tax transparency across the EU. I specifically welcome the balance found between necessary reporting and the administrative burden which will provide incentives for multinational groups to pay a fair share of tax where the profits are made without hampering their competitiveness. The country-by-country reporting is required only for multinational groups with annual consolidated revenue higher than EUR 750 million and it will be communicated to the Commission in a confidential way so that the internal market is not distorted.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, as it represents a positive step towards combating an aggressive tax planning system. Further safeguards will have to be adopted in the future to ensure that competition in the single market is not disrupted by favourable national tax transactions with multinationals. The proposal is an important step in the fight against unfair tax practices in EU countries, as it aims to increase transparency and reduce harmful tax competition. The European Commission must have full access to the information exchanged between the tax authorities of the Member States in order to assess whether their tax practices comply with European rules.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. This report amends the commission's proposal for the exchange of information on the profits and taxes of multinationals, aimed at reducing tax avoidance. We consider that the report is clearly insufficient, and we have opted because the information is not only exchanged between Member States, but is regularly communicated to the Commission and above all made public. Unfortunately, this last point has been rejected by large groups.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of improved cooperation between tax authorities. The report presented by the rapporteur is balanced by improving the exchange of information between tax authorities, but not ignoring the data protection of taxpayers. The measures proposed by the Commission and adopted by the Council are likely to help tax authorities to be better informed about the activities of taxpayers. This will help make tax avoidance more difficult and pay taxes to international corporations where profits are made.  I support this concern and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report. Mandatory and automatic exchange should be welcome. Full transparency is the best way to show that people and companies have nothing to hide. The challenge posed by tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax evasion has increased considerably and has become a major focus of concern within the European Union and at global level. The automatic exchange of information constitutes an important tool in this regard and the Commission in its Communication of 6 December 2012 containing an Action plan to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion highlighted the need to promote vigorously the automatic exchange of information as the future European and international standard for transparency and exchange of information in tax matters.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The Rosati report sets out Parliament's position on the proposed directive imposing country reporting, as part of the fight against aggressive tax optimisation. The purpose of country reporting is to enable Member States' tax administrations to ensure that the profits of multinationals are taxed where they are made. This is one of the flagship measures of the OECD's PLAN against BEPS. Thus, this proposal for a directive would make it mandatory to report by country the turnover, pre-tax profit, tax paid, salaried workforce, assets, subsidies received, this in each jurisdiction where multinational groups operate. In the end, despite some negatives, country reporting will be a tool to combat mailbox companies or fictitious or abusive domiciles. It is the Member States that are obliged to take the deterrent sanctions in the event of a breach, and which will benefit from it. I voted for this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information provides for the automatic exchange of information on the tax returns of multinational companies between Member States from April 2017. Thus, groups of multinational enterprises located in the EU or operating in the EU, with a total consolidated income equal to or greater than EUR 750 000 000, will be required to submit a country-by-country report. This report proposes that the Commission be associated with the automatic exchange of information and that it should have access to each country's statements, while respecting the rules of confidentiality. Furthermore, the Commission should have equal access to information exchanged between the tax administrations of the Member States in order to ensure compliance with the provisions of competition law. The Commission shall submit equally each year to the European Parliament and the Council a report on the annual evaluations carried out by the Member States on the effectiveness of the automatic exchange of information and the practical results achieved. This practice could be a first step in the fight against cross-border tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In the field of corporate taxation, unfair tax practices also have a state aid dimension. Therefore, in order to ensure compliance with the relevant competition rules, the Commission should also have access to the information provided between the tax authorities of the Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. This report amends the commission's proposal for the exchange of information on the profits and taxes of multinationals, aimed at reducing tax avoidance. We consider that the report is clearly insufficient, and we have opted because the information is not only exchanged between Member States, but is regularly communicated to the Commission and above all made public. Unfortunately, this last point has been rejected by large groups.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it gives consent on legislation which is slowly progressing in the direction of higher transparency to fight tax fraud and avoidance in the EU.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The problem posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased significantly and is of great concern at Union and global level. In its reports prepared by the ECON and TAXE Committees of the European Parliament, Parliament called for greater transparency in relation to information on tax matters to combat aggressive tax planning, in particular by imposing a country-by-country reporting obligation on multinational enterprise groups (MNDs). In applying the current rules of law (Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation – now in its third version – it is now in force), Member States do not share country-by-country reports among themselves. There is therefore an urgent need to increase transparency. To that end, it is necessary to improve the instruments and mechanisms established by Council Directive 2011/16/EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This legislation amends Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of appraisal, forcing multinationals with consolidated turnover of EUR 750 million to report on their country-by-country tax return to the authorities of the Member State in which the parent company is domiciled. That country will have to share the information with the countries in which the company operates. The company must report on income, profits, taxes paid, capital, material assets and number of employees. We are therefore talking about an essential step in combating unfair tax practices, as it will boost transparency and reduce unfair competition. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this text.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. U2012 Country-by-country reports are central to the Commission's anti-avoidance package following the LuxLeaks scandal (and now PanaLeaks), as it lets multinationals know where their profits generate and where they actually pay their taxes. The European Parliament has already positioned itself in favour of imposing an obligation on multinationals to publish country-by-country reports under the Shareholders' Rights Directive (Cofferati report) although the Council has strongly opposed it. Recently, the Commission has put forward a legislative proposal on the mandatory publication of country-by-country reports, so this proposal on exchanging country-by-country reports of multinationals between tax administrations, which I have supported, is only a first step, if only important and positive. However, I do not share the relatively arbitrary billing threshold for the implementation of the Directive (EUR 750 million per year) which means that only 1,900 merchants would be covered, when the Accounting Directive indicates a lower threshold for identifying large companies and that if implemented, the new rule would cover 20,000 undertakings.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. This proposal for a directive unfortunately represents a timid step towards real transparency and a tough fight against the avoidance promised in words by the Commission following the recent tax scandals. The creation of an automatic mechanism for the exchange of information is an essential element, but it is clearly not enough to put an end to the opacity, inefficiency and iniquity of the current system. The proposal lacks truly strong and credible measures: there is no question of banks - through which all lawfully and unlawful financial flows pass - which, as the Swissleaks and Panama Papers have shown, have played a central role in supporting great circumvention, and of course there are no sanctions. In addition, the rules on transparency on the information that multinational companies are required to report, with regard to the activities carried out in the individual countries in which they operate, the so-called country-by-country-reporting, will apply exclusively to companies with revenues of more than EUR 750 million, that is, only 10% of all multinationals operating in Europe, and these companies will also be able to benefit from exemptions that allow some confidential information to be maintained. It is scandalous, given the scale of tax avoidance and the companies involved. For these reasons, I was unable to support this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, which aims to make the tax exchange of information between Member States more transparent. This is a step in the right direction in the fight against tax fraud.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As we see the realisation of all these tax packages, it is clear that ambitions have been revised down, with the adoption of minimalist measures and far below what is necessary. It is ironic that this negotiation is being made under the Dutch PRESIDENCY of the EU, and the Netherlands is one of the most important tax havens in existence, as demonstrated by the starbucks scandals, among others. What the European Commission proposes is to follow OECD rules by proposing a confidential country-by-country report in which multinational companies will provide tax administrations with information about their activity and their taxes. As is acknowledged, the confidentiality of this information takes away all the effectiveness of the measure and in particular its deterrent effect. We therefore call on the Commission to make it compulsory to advertise this information, as is the case with banks. We do not understand the 750 million euro limit, which exempts the vast majority of multinational companies from this measure. In a sense, we demand from the European Union coherence and consequent actions in the fight against this social iniquity, which is inseparable from the capitalist system that promotes the concentration of wealth and social inequalities.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report, which commits to the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, focuses on cooperation between the managing authorities of each Member State in order to counter harmful tax practices. Cooperation between Member States is intended to facilitate the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field. At the moment, the Member States do not share information on the taxes paid by multinational groups. The report suggests a mandatory report for each Member State on the taxes paid by multinationals. I am convinced that this report lay the foundations for a more transparent taxation system and that transparency is the first weapon in combating tax evasion.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the obligation to automatically exchange information in the field of taxation. This proposal for a directive is part of an overall package of tax measures put on the agenda by the Commission, the full implementation of which will represent a significant increase in tax powers for the EU. I reject this package as a whole and its individual components. It is essential for me not to move sovereign rights in the tax area from the Member States to the EU. Any postponement undermines the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States. However, this is essential in order to avoid further steps towards political union.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for country-by-country reporting because I believe that it is vital, if we are ever to tackle tax dodging, that we make companies report exactly where they make their money and where they pay their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, although it still does not go far enough: many more companies should be required to submit these reports, and the reports should be made public, if we are to have true tax transparency. As Labour MEPs we understand the importance of tax transparency; it is a shame that the Tories do not share our values, and have consistently voted against any attempts to shine more light on the murky world of tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – The fight against tax avoidance and evasion has been put high on the agenda by the Panama Papers. The ones who are most affected by this are the individual citizens and the SMEs who do follow the rules. I therefore think it is important that we try to avoid such situations in the future. The only way to achieve this is transparency and cooperation between Member States. I therefore support the resolution, which aims at an automatic exchange of information on taxation.  Moreover, it is important that the European Commission should also have better access to this information. New legislation will provide Member States with tools and means to achieve the above objectives. I believe that this will ultimately lead to fairer competition between companies, markets and Member States.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for country-by-country reporting because I believe that it is vital, if we are ever to tackle tax dodging, that we make companies report exactly where they make their money and where they pay their taxes. The Commission’s proposal is a step in the right direction, although it still does not go far enough: many more companies should be required to submit these reports, and the reports should be made public, if we are to have true tax transparency.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – This proposal introduces an interesting novelty in the area of taxation and against tax evasion. There are unfair tax practices in the EU that need to be changed in order to increase transparency and reduce harmful tax competition. The report was prepared in response to the EP's so-called 'green card'. Panama Papers – lists of companies and individuals who circumvented tax laws or exploited their shortcomings. We demand that the Commission have unrestricted access to information circulating between member states' tax authorities in order to assess whether member states' tax practices comply with State aid rules. This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises operating in one country and which should not be disadvantaged in view of their size. Multinationals are also called for greater transparency in the management and submission of annual reports.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Mr Rosati's report covers a major issue, not only for the EU but also worldwide, which is why it received the broadest positive response in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Similarly, I approved it with my vote in favour.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU with regard to the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, known as DAC4, was voted on today. The challenges posed by tax evasion and avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax competition have required increasing transparency regarding information through the introduction of Country by country reporting for multinationals. The existing legislative framework (Directive 2011/16/EU) was revised with the entry into force of the recent Directive 2015/2376/EU which introduced the automatic and mandatory exchange of information from 2017. Although the final text sees the Role of the Commission increased, there are still major shortcomings in terms of openness and transparency.
