In fact, the reference to the online publication of information was not accepted by the other political groups. Another critical point is that sensitive data can benefit from confidentiality. Unfortunately, the amendment calling for the application of the public CBCR to all large companies and not just to multinationals with revenues of more than EUR 750 million, or only 10-15% of all multinationals operating in Europe, has not passed.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The position of the explanatory memorandum to the Directive that 'tax rules must be designed in such a way as not to create barriers to growth or investment, not to create competitive disadvantages for Union businesses (...) as well as (...) minimise the costs and administrative burden on undertakings' reveals the substance of the Directive. EU and government tax policy serves precisely the fundamental strategy of strengthening the profitability of capital in every way. The fact that the directive concerns a very small part of transnational monopolies, those with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million, also reveals the extent of the mockery of the declarations on combating tax evasion and avoidance of businesses. The EU and the civil governments of its Member States, at the same time as legislating with the help of the civil law the exemption of capital from taxes and obligations with "development" and a plethora of other laws, provocative tax exemptions, subsidies and aid to business groups, such as the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government in Greece, plunder the meager popular income with unbearable direct and indirect taxation, reduction of wages and pensions , abolition of social rights. The working people must get away with the mockery of "fair burden-sharing" in capitalism, claiming the socialisation of the monopolies and wealth that they themselves produce.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support this report, as the problems caused by tax avoidance have increased significantly and have come under the spotlight in the European Union and around the world. In my opinion, it is crucial to increase transparency and strengthen the instruments and mechanisms established by Council Directive 2011/16/EU. I therefore very much appreciate that the present proposal introduces a new article into the current Directive, which sets out the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information from country-by-country reports. I welcome this report as a positive step towards achieving greater transparency, in particular as regards the need for greater transparency, the threshold for MNE groups that are required to report disaggregated by country.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. In recent years, the challenge posed by tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax evasion has been significantly higher and is of great concern to the Union and at global level. I supported the report as I agree that automatic exchange of information is an important tool for ensuring a future European and international standard of transparency and exchange of information in tax matters. However, I believe that it is essential for the Union to establish tax rules in such a way as not to jeopardise growth or investment, not to put companies in the Union at an uneasy competitive position and not to increase the risk of double taxation of companies, and to minimise their costs and administrative burden.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent The right of consumers to know what we buy in shops and restaurants is the most sacred right and one of the most principled rights, and for various reasons, however, these rights are not exercised in practice in a number of cases. Even if we are talking about what is being sold in the European institutions, namely the dishes sold. This is not only about the fact that the consumer is actually being lied to, deliberately, inadvertently, but that there are still certain health concerns. Let's say a person can eat one fish, but someone else is already allergic. In contrast, both appearance and taste are similar to the two species. And mis-labelling can in theory lead to a rather sad result. This is why this document is extremely important for all consumers, including in my country, Latvia. And here financial fraud due to incorrect labelling, thus a negative impact on taxation, this is another additional argument why I voted in favour.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I voted in favour of the motion, but I have to admit that there are two souls living in my chest, because, on the one hand, I naturally want to agree with the previous speaker, who said that the consumer has a right to know where what is on the plate comes from. That's right. On the other hand, of course, we must be careful not to overbureaucratise the procedure, that there are too many costs in the system. Good if you know where the fish comes from. What is much more important to me is that the food is healthy and that it has been produced according to European standards. This question has not yet been answered with a simple origin marking. Unfortunately, i believe that the question of the costs incurred is not adequately answered. There is still some catching up to do. Above all, we must also see whether we are really effectively preventing food scandals. Not that we turn to the wrong people in the big game, as always.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: We want to know what we're eating. A third of the fish we eat in Brussels is labelled incorrectly. In other words, we don't know what we eat and where we eat. A recent study published by the non-governmental organisation Oceana showed that a third of the 280 samples of fish taken from restaurants in Brussels, including European institutions, are mislabeled. It is serious and once again there is a wake-up call that we do not know what we are feeding on. I call on the European Commission to investigate where the errors in the fish production and distribution chain are and to use the DNA-based barcode as a tool to identify the origin and route of fishery products.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the European Union is the world’s largest seafood market and this market is supported not only by EU fisheries but also by imports from third countries. In a sector so vast, it is important that the standards and rules of the European Union regarding fisheries, and the labelling of fish products, are adhered to by all, including producers and importers from third countries. European consumers should be able to rely on the supply chain that provides fishery products all across Europe. They should be protected from fraudulent acts such as the mis-labelling of fishery products. It is vital that we improve the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products across the European Union. The fisheries industry is of great importance to my state, Ireland. The industry contributes about EUR 700 million annually to national income and employs 11 000 people. A European-wide traceability label, as proposed here, would be of benefit to the fisheries industry both in Ireland and across the EU.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the largest market for fish products in the world. The proposal recognises that consumers have the right to be informed in an understandable way. In this respect, the Commission is considering the creation of an external structure for the certification of fishery products. Attention is drawn to the need to indicate information on the origin of fishery products in a clear and transparent manner, and the Commission is encouraged to publicise more effectively with citizens its action to protect marine resources and combat illegal fishing. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a motion for a resolution, based on an oral question put to the Commission in the light of a study published by the NGO Oceana which highlighted the inaccuracy of fish labelling. This entails a fundamental problem with regard to the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the Union. In these seemingly widespread cases of mislabeling, misleading information is provided to consumers. I would also like to point out that the Commission's request to act to correct FAO labelling of certain fishing areas was incorporated on my proposal in the amendments process. Since, as far as Spain is concerned, there is a great deal of unease in the sector because the fishing of Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz, is labeled as "Portuguese Waters".

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the catering and retail sector. The text is going in the right direction even though I think it falls short of its demands on the Member States and the Commission. It is noteworthy that there are significant levels of mislabeling in fisheries products sold on the Union market, support for a robust traceability system from landing to consumption, the call for the creation of an EU-wide eco-label and the explicit mention of catches in Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz labelled as "Portuguese waters".

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I abstained on the vote on the oral question in the Commission on the traceability of fish and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. A study by the NGO Oceana revealed a problem with labelling fish served in restaurants in Brussels (including in European institutions). One-third of the fish studied were mislabeled, demonstrating a problem with the traceability of fish products.  This oral question therefore asked the Commission for explanations to understand at what level the error was being made, what measures would be taken to counter the problem and, above all, where the establishment of a European eco-label was at. While I am obviously in favour of measures to ensure the traceability of fishing products and to inform consumers as accurately as possible, I am strongly opposed to the introduction of a single label which would deprive Member States of the opportunity to create their own, more comprehensive national labels.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This was a very important resolution which I voted in favour of and which aims to challenge ‘food fraud’. I have actively worked on the issue of food fraud in my capacity as an MEP since 2013. This resolution will benefit both consumers and fishing communities across Ireland. It highlights the importance of traceability through all stages of production, processing and distribution and proper legal labelling. This is of particular importance as my country is an island and the fishing industry is a key industry. In recent years, there has been a proliferation of seafood which has been unlabelled or mislabelled. This threatens the livelihoods of fishermen and seafood traders and it facilitates illegal and unregulated fishing practices. It is also clearly not in consumers’ interests. It threatens the livelihoods of fishermen and seafood traders and it facilitates illegal and unregulated fishing practices. Moreover, it is also not in the consumers’ interests. Sinn Fein will continue to ensure that criminal activity in the Food Processing industry is combatted.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Through this vote, we demand a robust traceability system for all fishing products sold in EU restaurants and shops. This would help prevent cases of incorrect labelling. More generally, it seems to me that a reliable European fish labelling policy would strengthen consumer confidence and the economic development of the European fishing sector.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The above motion for a resolution refers to the importance of the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in focus and retail trade. Incorrect or inappropriate labelling of fishery products is a clear violation of the rules of the Common Fisheries Policy by misleading consumers and their health and making it difficult for fishery producers to position themselves. That is why I supported this motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission and the Member States to act decisively to improve information, traceability and controls in the interests of consumer protection.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Labelling and labeling, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is moving in the right direction. But it is unacceptable that a single European label can effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This appears innocuous and even helpful to the consumer and it does offer some benefits. However the bureaucracy and record-keeping potentially involved is disproportionate and it probably represents a massive additional intrusion by officials into restaurants, cafes, supermarkets, shops and market stalls. They cannot be trusted to keep it proportionate – they constantly crack nuts with sledgehammers – and it also represents in consequence, a further power grab.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the traceability of fishery products in the catering and retail sectors. The EU is the largest market for marine products in the world, with products supplied from the EU fisheries sector and imported from third countries. Consumers have the right to information provided in a comprehensible manner, including coastal and geographical information from catch areas, and should be able to have full confidence in the whole chain in which fishery products are placed on the EU market. Unfortunately, there is a significant increase in the level of labelling of fishery products sold in the EU market, including restaurants by the EU institutions. I support calls on Member States to strengthen national controls, including controls on raw fish for restaurants and the catering sector, in order to address fraud and to identify the stage in the supply chain where fish has been mislabeled. I agree with the need to establish a strong system of traceability from landing to consumers, which ensures that consumers gain confidence in it and, in turn, reduces commercial dependence on imports of fishery and aquaculture products, thus strengthening the EU market.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I was unable to vote in favour of this oral question, which, based on a study by the NGO Oceana, reveals, according to surveys carried out in Brussels restaurants, that one third of fish are not labelled and that traceability of fish products is not assured. For if the question put to the Commission is how these errors have occurred and what measures the Commission and the Member States intend to take to ensure the adoption of European eco-labelling in order to facilitate the traceability of fish products, I cannot vote in favour of a single European labelling that could oust Member States' labels and effectively deprive them of their right to create stricter and more stringent labels. protectors for consumers.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this joint resolution which calls for stronger state controls and better traceability of fish and aquaculture products from fisherman to consumer in order to avoid as much fraud or deception as much as possible about the nature of fish and aquaculture products sold or consumed.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's largest fish market, but a number of studies have confirmed the presence of a very high rate of incorrectly labelled fish, largely directed towards the gastronomy and catering sector. Limiting cases of food fraud and mislabelling must be a priority, which is why I have today chosen to vote in favour of the joint resolution before the European Parliament on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. Clear, transparent and comprehensible information on fishery products must be ensured for all consumers by activating mechanisms that make it possible to identify species with certainty, including by using methods such as dna barcodes. The Commission should focus on the creation of an eco-labelling system at European level, financed through the European Maritime Affairs and Fisheries Fund, correcting the confusion caused by the current labelling requirement based on the zones and sub-zones defined by the FAO.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution so that there can be follow-up of products with the aim of improving consumer information and in turn for the achievement of the food security we are advocating for the EU. With the growth of Aquaculture in the search for sustainable means to supply the growing demand for fish in the diet, controls are needed to verify that labelling is met and to be able to find that the corresponding health criteria are maintained. Labelling is also important so that the consumer can have maximum information when buying their food. It can in turn reduce dependence on import fisheries and aquaculture products by strengthening trade in local products.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this oral question, which, while it is well-intentioned , namely to investigate the problems of mislabelling of fish products and to ensure that these products are traceable from a food safety perspective, does not propose an effective solution. I welcome the work of the NGO Oceana, which has revealed these shortcomings in seafood labelling and, in particular, to lift the veil on the unreliability of this labelling within the restaurants of the European institutions. It seems to me, thereby, common sense to require answers as to how these errors may have occurred and what steps can be taken to remedy them. However, I question the relevance of the creation of a single European public label, as proposed in the oral question. Such a measure, which in theory would allow for some visibility, would in fact lead to the abolition of national labels, which often carry higher environmental and health standards: we cannot afford to take the risk of harmonization that would lower the level of French health security.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution being voted on aims to improve the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retailing. I believe that this text is balanced and acceptable. Whatever efforts we can make to ensure maximum transparency for our citizens on products that end up on their tables is necessary and worthy of support, which is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The fraud of the European fish consumer is highlighted. These are not isolated cases. The same is produced in Brussels as in Spain, Ireland, Greece or Great Britain. And it always involves selling lower value fish instead of the most expensive varieties. We could resolve this situation by requiring precise information about the species and place of origin of the products. Something relatively simple, for example, in the case of canned products. In favour of the consumer, but also of sustainable European production, case of the mussel of Galicia. I therefore support the call for this resolution, for greater clarity and transparency in information on the origin of fishery products. As well as correcting FAO labelling with regard to Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz, labelled as "Portuguese Waters." If we want to protect our quality productions and protect consumers, we must clarify the origin in labelling.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because consumers have the right to receive information provided in a comprehensible manner, including coastal and geographical information in catch zones, and should be able to have full confidence in the whole chain in which fishery products are placed on the EU market. The European Union and the Member States must protect EU citizens from unfair practices and all imported products must comply with EU rules and standards. The European Parliament is concerned and dissatisfied with the results of various studies, which show the high level of mislabelling of fishery products sold in the EU market, including restaurants in the EU institutions. Parliament therefore reiterates that intentional drug fraud is a violation of EU regulations, including the common fisheries policy, and can be considered a criminal offence under national law. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to regularly monitor the extent to which the necessary information is provided on labels. In addition, labels must contain comprehensible, verifiable and accurate information, and therefore calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up awareness-raising campaigns on labelling requirements for fishery and aquaculture products.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒Since December 2014, with new food labelling, consumers have hoped that food sold to them in fast restaurants, restaurants with ethnic cuisine and similar establishments will be more tightly controlled. Unfortunately, the study shows that customer deception continued. Positive examples from the world show that the cost of adjusting to more detailed menu labeling is not great. Traders often say that they write all the information somewhere, but the truth is that the buyer usually does not know it at the time of the order when making a decision.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Labelling and labeling, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what we are asking for. On the other hand, I cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive States of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. I therefore abstained.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – This was a very important resolution which I voted in favour of and which aims to challenge ‘food fraud’. I have actively worked on the issue of food fraud in my capacity as an MEP since 2013. The resolution concerned the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants. This is of particular importance as my country is an island and the fishing industry is a key economic industry. Moreover, in recent years, there has been a proliferation of seafood which has been unlabelled or mislabelled. This threatens the livelihoods of fishermen and seafood traders and it facilitates illegal and unregulated fishing practices. Furthermore, it is also not in the consumers’ interests. This resolution highlights the importance of traceability through all stages of production, processing and distribution and proper legal labelling. This will benefit both consumers and fishing communities across Ireland. Sinn Féin will further continue to ensure that criminal activity in the food processing industry is combatted.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important that a robust traceability system is put in place, from landing to consumption, that instires consumer confidence and, at the same time, reduces the dependence of trade on imports of fishery and aquaculture products, thereby strengthening the EU market. I also believe that, in order to improve traceability, the Commission should make full use of the potential of the DNA barcode, which could help to identify a species through DNA sequencing.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. A study by the NGO Oceana found cases of mislabelling of fish served in restaurants in Brussels, including in European institutions. In particular, this study shows that the traceability of fish products is not properly assured due to the lack of reliable labelling. However, we must be vigilant about European eco-labelling which could supplant national labels. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the resolution is largely acceptable and notes the need to put in place an essential instrument, such as origin labelling, to combat the abuses and scams (at different levels of the fish distribution chain) affecting the fisheries and aquaculture market. Vote.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. This resolution was adopted on the basis that labelling is wrong in 6% of cases. These figures may be more alarming for some noble species that are substituted by common species. For example, the rate of labelling fraud on bluefin tuna is 80% according to some NGOs. We must demand that Member States enforce EU legislation, including the control of fish products but also deterrent sanctions for fraud. Mandatory information must be available to the consumer. It is up to the Member States to ensure that this information is accurate and available. I have been advocating since 2010 for the creation of a single European label of fisheries products that would concentrate voluntary information (ethical, social, environmental.) Such a label would be readable, impartial and transparent and would provide reliable consumer information.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this motion for a resolution to express serious concerns about the alarming cases of fish labelling errors that have given misleading information to European consumers. The replacement of one species of fish by another, which is cheaper and less valuable, is not too difficult today: the large number of intermediaries between capture and sale, the increasing processing of the product, clearly not impeccable traceability and the fact that 65 % of the fish consumed in Europe are imported with fewer quality controls have made the trap simple. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to step up controls and to review both the operation of the fish chain and the legislation on the labelling of fish. The effectiveness of the genetic barcode as a tool for the traceability of fishery products must also be better exploited. This innovative method allows the identification of fish species with a degree of reliability far greater than all the other diagnostic methods already used.  It is therefore essential to create a European network against food fraud in the fisheries sector, proposing a wider use of DNA testing to prevent any kind of fraud.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to tackle ‘food fraud’. In recent years, there has been a proliferation of seafood which has been unlabelled or mislabelled. This threatens the livelihoods of fishermen and seafood traders and it facilitates illegal and unregulated fishing practices. It is also clearly not in consumers’ interests. This resolution highlights the importance of traceability through all stages of production, processing and distribution and proper legal labelling. This will benefit both consumers and fishing communities across Ireland.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the fishery products should be more traceable than they have been until now. Consumers should be able to know the origin of the food they are eating, especially given that most of such products come from outside the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retail as I did not find any particular problems in the text.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and express our deep concern, as well as our dissatisfaction, with the results of various studies showing high levels of misleading labelling for fishery products sold on the EU market.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in focus and retail trade is clearly an attempt to strengthen quality controls aimed at protecting citizens' health and improving food and trade structures. As I believe that such actions work for the benefit of European citizens, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 A strong political position is needed on the part of the European Parliament to respond to the problem of fraudulent and incorrect international labelling in the fish market and which is obviously a crime for EU rules. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which seeks both to improve traceability and to introduce a sound European policy on labelling in the fisheries sector. I believe that these elements would be fundamental points for boosting the economic development of coastal communities and would be available to consumers for better and more transparent product information. I believe that it is necessary to indicate information on the origin of fishery products in a clear and transparent manner, and this report, in my opinion, moves in precisely this direction. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I support a strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, which would give confidence to consumers and, in turn, decrease commercial dependency on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thereby strengthening the EU market. The Commission should exploit the potential of DNA barcoding, which could assist in the identification of species by DNA sequencing, in order to enhance traceability.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is the world’s largest seafood market, which is supplied by both the EU fisheries sector and imports from third countries. It is worrying to note that significant levels of mislabelling on fish products sold on the EU market, including in the restaurants of the EU institutions are in breach of EU regulations. Such may constitute a criminal offence under national law. I support the call towards creating a working group to harmonise the implementation of traceability in all Member States and the setting-up of an external structure enabling the certification of voluntary claims for fishery and aquaculture products on the EU market. Consumers should be assured that there is adequate traceability from landing to consumption, which would give them confidence, together with an effective awareness-raising campaign on labelling requirements for fishery and aquaculture products. For this reason, I agree that an EU-wide ecolabel for fisheries and aquaculture products criteria should be further discussed at EU level within the context of Fisheries and Maritime Policy.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Resolution on the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the catering and retail sector. The text is going in the right direction even though I think it falls short of its demands on the Member States and the Commission. It is noteworthy that there are significant levels of mislabeling in fisheries products sold on the Union market, support for a solid traceability system from landing to consumption, the call for the creation of an EU-wide eco-label and the explicit mention of catches in Galicia (for plural Izq to include "in Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz") labelled as "Portuguese waters".

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In recent years, a large number of cases of mis-labelling of fish and fish products sold in supermarkets, cafeterias and restaurants across the Union have been demonstrated. When it comes to incorrect labelling, high-quality species are deliberately replaced by lower-quality species, mistakenly named and sold to the consumer at a price they would pay for high-quality grades. This is unfair to fishermen and consumers. Member States have therefore been called upon to step up their national controls in order to detect and prevent cases of incorrect labelling. The same was advocated for a robust and robust traceability system: from landing to consumption. On labelling, the motion for a resolution will support the Commission's idea of exploring the possibility of introducing a system of eco-signs for fishery and aquaculture products within the CMO, and the draft states that a robust EU labelling policy in the fisheries sector is a key driver of the economic development of coastal communities. I agree with and fully support the above-mentioned proposals, which is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I can support this because it is vital consumers are able to make informed decisions when buying fish and aquaculture products. This is important both for those who buy the products and also for fishermen themselves, who want the fish they catch to be correctly labelled, so that they are not unfairly hindered by the mislabelling of cheaper alternatives. Legislation already exists for Member States themselves to ensure that there is a robust control of fish and aquaculture products and they therefore have a responsibility to enforce quality control checks. I note caution on the call for the Commission to examine the feasibility of an eco-label scheme for fishery and aquaculture products, something which could add additional and unnecessary red-tape burdens for fishermen.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Pangasio del Mekong, caught in some of the most polluted waters in the world, on the tables of restaurants becomes grouper or cod, or the Senegalese linguata, which easily turns into sole for unsuspecting European consumers who sit at the table. This is revealed by recent studies, which report numerous cases of 'fish fraud': a threat, that of adulterated products, which absolutely cannot be tolerated. These are obvious cases of incorrect labelling, which are apparently widespread in Europe, caused by misleading information and an ineffective system of control over product traceability. Now, as the resolution that I have fully supported points out, we need a strong commitment from the Member States and the Union to put in place a better and more effective labelling system that ensures full traceability of fish products from the moment they are caught to when they arrive on our citizens' tables. Responsible and, above all, conscious consumption is a social and food choice that every European citizen has the right to exercise, which is why the Union must ensure that clear, transparent and complete information is provided on the origins and species of all food products, including fish products.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution looks at a recently published study that reveals worrying cases of incorrect labelling of fish served in restaurants in Brussels. According to the study, about one-third of the fish tested were incorrectly labelled. In this context, the resolution expresses its concern about the results of several studies which have shown that fish products sold in EU markets are often incorrectly labelled. For example, it advocates a traceability system to ensure consumer confidence and a European labelling strategy. Considering that consumer protection is an essential condition for the proper functioning of the internal market, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on the traceability of fishing and aquaculture products in catering and retail. In order to improve the traceability of these products, a robust European labelling strategy is needed to counter fraud and avoid incorrect labelling.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the traceability of fish and aquaculture products in catering and retail because I want the labelling of these products to be more transparent. 70% of fishing or aquaculture products sold on the European market come from imports. It is therefore necessary that they be subject to the same traceability standards as products from the European Union. Indeed, in voting in favour of this resolution, I would like to reaffirm that any mislabelling must be punished, thanks to a greater firmness of national controls, for example. Furthermore, I support the idea that a single European label would benefit the consumer and the producer by establishing compliance with a number of environmental and health standards and by giving greater transparency and visibility of the traceability of products from fisheries or aquaculture.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution as it provides for the creation of a strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, which will inspire confidence in consumers and thus reduce commercial dependence on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thus strengthening the EU market.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. Some worrying cases of fish labelling errors, revealed by DNA analysis of 280 fish samples by some NGOs, have shown that around a third of the fish analysed were mislabelled. This is a highly incorrect practice which needs to be properly addressed, both in the case of errors in the production chain and, clearly, more forcefully, in the case of real fraud against consumers. I voted in favour of this resolution, which lists a number of recommendations and actions to be implemented at European and Member State level in order to achieve better control of fish products, for consumer protection and for the protection of our seas, which are increasingly at risk due to illegal fishing practices and over-exploitation of resources. The introduction of a Union eco-label for fishery and aquaculture products could be a first step towards improving traceability and making transparent information available to consumers.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Consumers have the right to information communicated in an understandable manner, including coastal and geographical information on catch areas, and should be able to rely fully on the entire chain of supply of fishery products to the EU market. However, the results of several studies indicate significant levels of incorrect labelling of fish products sold on the EU market, which is a violation of EU regulations. Member States should therefore strengthen national controls, in particular of unprocessed fish intended for restaurants and the restaurant sector, in an effort to combat fraud and identify the stage of the supply chain where fish is incorrectly labelled.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: labelling and the creation of labels, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what we are asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Recent cases of identification, in various restaurants and hotel and commercial equipment, of fish which do not correspond to labelling (the fish version of selling cat by hare) justify the development of measures that promote not only a correct identification of the species concerned, but also their origin and processing conditions. In the name of the quality of the products, the improvement of the conditions of fishermen and producers of fish products, but also the confidence of consumers, we support this measure. Indeed, the certification of the origin and quality of products is a claim of Portuguese producers and fishermen, as a way of affirming national products and protecting against adulteration and a kind of commercial dumping. Such certification should be ensured by a public entity, exempt and free of charge, thereby avoiding the obligation of producers to pay such certification to private entities, which are often unjudicious. The example of the canning industry deserves a special reference. We have repeatedly questioned the European Commission on this subject. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Several studies show a very poor level of labelling of fishery and aquaculture products sold on markets in the European Union. Individual Member States must also strengthen national controls, with a focus on unprocessed fish in restaurants and catering establishments, thus seeking to combat fraud more effectively. The European Commission should regularly monitor the extent to which the required information for consumers is labelled and published. Member States should provide, as part of voluntary labelling, all available information to enable the consumer to make a qualified choice.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution which stresses the need to put in place an essential instrument, such as origin labelling, to combat abuse and fraud.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution as it provides for the creation of a strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, which will inspire confidence in consumers and thus reduce commercial dependence on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thus strengthening the EU market.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission and Member States are urged to improve traceability and controls. Non-traceable seafood may include illegal fish which causes economic damage and constitutes a risk to the protection of marine resources as well as a health risk due to a possible lack of sanitary and health checks. Imports from third countries must fully comply with EU rules and standards. Improved traceability can boost the economic situation of coastal communities as well as fair competition for producers of high-quality EU seafood. Awareness-raising campaigns should be strengthened. Labelling requirements must guarantee the right of the consumer to accurate, reliable and understandable information and avoid any confusion. In the context of voluntary labelling, Member States are asked to state all available information that enables the consumer to make an informed choice.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I adopted Parliament's resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in hospitality and retail. The EU fisheries sector provides third countries with the world's largest seafood market. We must ensure that consumers are properly informed and monitored so that they can have confidence in EU fishery products and throughout the sector. The aim is to protect consumers from fraud and there is therefore a need for greater transparency, which can be achieved through a stronger monitoring system and greater national control. Mislabeling of products is significant and we need to remedy these errors as soon as possible, as deliberate mislabeling of fish species is a breach of EU legislation, including the Common Fisheries Policy. We need an appropriate European labelling policy, which would be a key factor in acknowledging fishermen's best practices and the quality of their products for consumers.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The commitment to promoting the right to health of citizens is an objective that requires the utmost scrupulousness on the part of Europe. That is why we regard food safety policies, such as consumer protection policies, as worthy of particular attention in our parliamentary work.  Providing precise information on the real traceability of food, and fish in particular, in shops, supermarkets and restaurants means investing in transparency and security of supply, in guaranteeing minimum safety standards respected, on a more effective control system for customers. I therefore agree with the proposal raised in the oral question 'Traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retailing', which I fully support.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution, which the Committee on Fisheries has interpreted, on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retailing, because I believe it is necessary to react to the recent food fraud scandals in the retail and trade in fishery products for the gastronomy and catering sectors. , which highlighted the unfortunate practice of replacing high-quality species with lower-quality specimens. I believe, in fact, that action by the European Commission is necessary in the face of a practice, that of fraudulent labelling, which is not only dangerous to human health and violates the elementary commercial and consumer protection rules, but is also linked to the problem of illegal fishing and is, consequently, a violation of the rules of the common fisheries policy. I therefore support the request to the Commission to examine possible measures to achieve a robust system of product traceability, which will give consumers confidence and also reduce dependence on imports from third countries. We therefore await the legislative proposal for a labelling system that guarantees the transparency and credibility of the certification process and protects consumers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. As much as I would like to see real tracability and transparency in the food sector, and as good as the measures already taken at EU level are, an additional award of products in restaurants and retailers overwhelms small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. – Traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail outlets is very important. European standards must not simply be undermined. Traceability is also an important issue in terms of human health and environmental protection, which is why I support the motion.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. A study by the NGO Oceana found cases of mislabelling of fish served in restaurants in Brussels, including in European institutions. About one-third of the fish tested were mislabeled. This study shows that the traceability of fish products is not assured due to the lack of reliable labelling.  Labelling and the creation of labels, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, are in line with what we are asking for.  However, we must be vigilant about European eco-labelling which could oust the Labels of the Member States. It is thereby not secret that some want to remove all existing labels in favour of a single European label. However, it is important for the future that Member States can create stricter and more consumer-protective labels.  All the more so because if the transatlantic treaty were signed, the European Union will, as always, comply with the demands of the United States, which is particularly hostile to labels and other consumer information and protection measures.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution so that there can be follow-up of products with the aim of improving consumer information and in turn for the achievement of the food security we are advocating for the EU. With the growth of Aquaculture in the search for sustainable means to supply the growing demand for fish in the diet, controls are needed to verify that labelling is met and to be able to find that the corresponding health criteria are maintained. Labelling is also important so that the consumer can have maximum information when buying their food. It can in turn reduce dependence on import fisheries and aquaculture products by strengthening trade in local products.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Fraudulent mislabelling constitutes a clear breach of common fisheries policy rules. It misleads consumers, represents a threat to marine resources as well as consumer health, disadvantages honest producers and distorts (fair) competition. The Commission and the Member States are urged to act decisively to improve information, traceability and controls, not least in the interest of consumer protection.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution, which aims to provide consumers with greater legibility and transparency about the products they buy on a daily basis. The introduction of stronger Member States' controls on the labelling of fisheries products should enable a more effective fight against labelling errors and fraud and thus contribute to increasing consumer confidence in the fisheries product chain. Finally, this resolution, by providing specific geographical indications to consumers, will encourage consumers to prefer European products to their imported counterparts and the result will the most effectiveness of European fisheries products.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support the resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retail. A strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, would give confidence to consumers and, in turn, decrease commercial dependency on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thereby strengthening the EU market. A sound European label policy in the fisheries sector would be a key factor in boosting the economic development of coastal communities, in recognising the best practices of fishermen and in underlining the quality of the products they supply to consumers.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support for this report as I had no objections with its contents.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. Investigations found that in 6% of cases, the labelling of fish products was incorrect. This is even more alarming for noble species such as tuna, where labelling fraud amounts to 80%. After the food scandals that have rocked the agri-food industry in recent years, these figures can no longer be tolerated. They reveal flaws, or at least persistent inadequacies, in the control of the manufacture of the products we consume and in the deterrents used by the competent authorities to curb this trend. That is why I welcome the adoption of the resolution of my colleague Alain Cadec, which calls for the creation of a single European label for fisheries and aquaculture products. This label could provide consumers with the assurance that the products consumed are in line with ethical, social and environmental commitments and restore lost confidence.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. I voted for the proposal for a Resolution on traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail, as I think it is good for the European market for fish products and for hospitality, as well as for consumers.  The motions in the Resolution go towards reducing the opportunities for fraud and mislalasting of products. In this way, a greater degree of safety and trust is achieved in consumers. The traceability system should be standardised at European level, transparent, clear and independent in implementation. It is important to establish a simple system that would not jeopardise the economic sectors concerned by administrative and other barriers.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Labelling and labeling, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what we are asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which will enable the establishment of a robust traceability system for all fish products sold in EU restaurants and shops to help prevent cases of mislabelling, strengthen consumer confidence and support the economic development of the EU fishing sector.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This decision expresses serious concern that fishery products sold on the European market are often mislabelled and calls on member states to tighten national controls. It calls for better traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. There is nothing to counter this demand. I therefore agree with this resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Fraudulent mislabelling constitutes a clear breach of common fisheries policy rules. It misleads consumers, represents a threat to marine resources as well as consumer health, disadvantages honest producers and distorts (fair) competition. The Commission and the Member States are urged to act decisively to improve information, traceability and controls, not least in the interest of consumer protection.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – European citizens deserve to consume fishery and aquaculture products of good quality and clear origin. Unfortunately, nowadays fish products that are being sold on the EU market are not labelled and have unclear origin. In fact, this practice is a breach of EU regulations, in particular the Common Fisheries Policy, and may constitute a criminal offence under national law. In order to tackle successfully this illegal practice, we should promote an EU wide ecolabel for fisheries and aquaculture products in order to provide transparent information to consumers. Should we manage to implement an EU ecolabel then we will guarantee the health of EU citizens, development of the EU fishing industry, protection of EU marine resources from illegal fishing. Therefore, it is our duty to support and improve traceability of fishery and aquaculture products on the EU market.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the traceability of fish and aquaculture products in catering and retail. A study has revealed cases of mislabelling of fish served in restaurants in Brussels, including in European institutions. About one-third of the fish tested were mislabeled. This study shows that the traceability of fish products is not assured due to the lack of reliable labelling. Labelling and the creation of labels, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what the Front National is asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The Committee on Fisheries asked the Commission about the mislabelling of fish. Indeed, a study carried out in the catering services of the European institutions and Brussels shows that about a third of the fish were mislabeled. The question asked on this subject is twofold, it asks the causes of these errors and the progress of the dossier on European ecological labelling. I believe that traceability and labelling of products are paramount, but I strongly oppose the creation of a single European label. Member States must retain the freedom to create their own labels according to their own assessment criteria. Between good and bad proposal, I abstained.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the catering and retail sector. The text is going in the right direction even though I think it falls short of its demands on the Member States and the Commission. It is noteworthy that there are significant levels of mislabeling in fisheries products sold on the Union market, support for a solid traceability system from landing to consumption, the call for the creation of an EU-wide eco-label and the explicit mention of catches in Galicia (for plural Izq to include "in Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz") labelled as "Portuguese waters".

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the tightening of fish labelling. Mandatory information is already extensive, let us leave the additional information to voluntary use. When customers request additional information, it's an opportunity for businesses to provide it to customers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The proposal for this resolution speaks to the problem of traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the EU. A study published recently by an NGO points to worrying cases of mislaging of fish served in Restaurants in Brussels. The backbone of this study was DNA analysis of more than 280 samples of fish served in restaurants, including restaurants of the European institutions. The results showed that a third of that fish was mislabeled. In these cases, misleading information was provided to consumers by wrongly labelling them. I supported the proposal for this resolution because it underlines the necessity of the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail, as this is necessary in order to fully respect consumer rights.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – I support a system of consistent tracing and control of the origin of fish products from catch to consumption. The spread of poor quality and unhealthy food shall be avoided, the responsibility of producers for quality at all stages of production and processing shall be increased and the consumer's protection and the right to full information on the product, its composition and its origin shall be promoted.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in focus and retail trade for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 9/5/2016 and because this motion for a resolution is complete and well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. A study by the NGO Oceana found cases of mislabelling of fish served in the foodservice industry. This study demonstrates that the traceability of fish products is not assured, or unsure, due to the lack of reliable labelling. We welcomed the desire to ensure better traceability and product quality, but we oppose a single European label that would de facto deprive states of their ability to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is necessary to address the fraud problems encountered in the marketing of fish and its products. According to the study, 6% of fish dishes sold in EU restaurants are misrepresented in terms of type and origin of fish, and high-quality species are replaced by lower quality equivalents. I therefore support the ep resolution's calls for the Commission to present a plan of measures to improve the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that looks at the possible mislabelling of fish and fish products sold in the EU market. I support traceability of aquaculture products.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This resolution calls for greater traceability of fish products. Indeed, studies have shown that fish products sold on EU markets, including in restaurants in the European Parliament and the Commission, are often incorrectly labelled. The resolution stresses the need for European eco-labelling for fisheries and aquaculture products. I vote for this text which defends the quality of products sold to consumers as well as better fishing practices.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report follows a study by an NGO reporting mislabelling of fish. That is where the idea of introducing a European label comes from, which we cannot approve, even if the principle of labelling is a good thing. States should have the opportunity to create specific, more restrictive and consumer-protective labelling. As a result, I abstained.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in catering and retail. Consumers have the right to understandable and non-fraudulent information in compliance with Community regulations and standards, so incorrect, fraudulent and intentional labelling of fish species will be a violation of EU regulations, in particular the common fisheries policy.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal as European consumers have a right to receive understandable, verifiable and accurate information on the origin of their food.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Europe has a rich culinary tradition. Good food and quality ingredients are part of our cultural life. The European also likes to know what he gets on his plate at home or at a restaurant. Therefore, a correct label on food products is good for consumer confidence. Unambiguous information supports a conscious purchase. Openness about the origin of food also provides a competitive advantage for our European fish farming and benefits the economic development of coastal regions. Moreover, a clear label has already proven its usefulness in preventing and addressing food incidents in the past. An efficient label has the advantage that in the event of a food incident, a rapid traceability of the contamination and appropriate measures to contain the incident are guaranteed.  This report calls for closer monitoring by Member States on the supply chain of fish and aquaculture products. A plea for an EU label for fish and aquaculture products offers openness about the origin of fishery products and on their quality and specificity. Moreover, with an EU label for fisheries and aquaculture, we can set up a dam against illegal fishing.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The European Union is the largest seafood market in the world, supplied by both the Union's fisheries sector and imports from third countries. Consumers have the right to information on coastal and geographical catch zones and should be able to rely fully on the entire chain that provides fishery products on the market, as the Union and the Member States have a duty to protect their citizens from fraudulent activity. All products imported must comply with european Union rules and standards. The results of the various studies confirmed the high level of mis-labelling of fish products sold on the Union market, including in restaurants of the Union institutions. It should be stressed that the deliberate and fraudulent mis-labelling of fish species constitutes a breach of Union rules, including the Common Fisheries Policy, and may even constitute a criminal offence under national law. National controls should therefore be strengthened, including checks on unprocessed fish in restaurants and the catering sector. It is also necessary to support the establishment of a working group in order to harmonise the application of traceability systems in all Member States and the establishment of an external structure for the certification of voluntary information on fishery and aquaculture products on the Union market. In view of the above, I fully support the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ A strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, would give consumers confidence and strengthen the EU market. Fraudulent mislabelling constitutes a clear breach of CFP rules and misleads consumers, represents a threat to marine resources as well as consumer health, disadvantages honest producers and distorts (fair) competition. Therefore, I support the report on traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail which calls on the Commission to assess the benefits of setting up an EU-wide labelling system to ensure transparency and credibility of the certification process and provide understandable, verifiable and accurate information.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The largest market for seafood in the world is the EU, which is supported by the EU fisheries sector and imports from third countries. According to various studies, a significant proportion of fishery products sold on the EU market are mislabeled, and deliberate and fraudulent mislabeling of fish species constitutes a breach of EU legislation, including the Common Fisheries Policy, and can be considered a criminal offence. It therefore calls on the European Commission and the Member States to strengthen controls and to study measures to improve the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. It draws attention to the importance of transparency and clarity of information on the origin of fishery products and welcomes the Commission's launch of a project to introduce a public database providing information on trade names in all official EU languages. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The question relates to labelling and the creation of labels, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, following a study by an NGO showing that one third of fish sold in Brussels would be mislabeled, raising the question of the effectiveness of traceability and labelling. That is in line with what we are asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. Forbearance.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is the world's largest market for fishery products, which is supplied both by the EU fisheries sector and by imports from third countries. I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because there are still significant levels of incorrect labelling of fish products sold on the EU market. It is also important to stress the need to solve this problem also in the Iberian Peninsula, and measures should be taken to address the confusion generated by the current labelling requirements based on the areas and sub-areas identified by the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Labelling and labeling, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what we are asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. That is why I abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the traceability of fish and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. While the Commission's 2015 control plan has detected cases of fraud in the labelling of fish products on the European market, it is essential to strengthen our anti-fraud and sanctions measures. In this context, I supported this resolution, which calls for consumers to have access to mandatory labelling information, as well as the strengthening of national anti-fraud controls.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution. Consumers of fishery products have the right to be informed in a clear way. Several studies have shown that mislabeling is common in the European Union. As most of these mislabelings are intentional, national controls on products intended for restaurants and catering sectors need to be strengthened. The motion proposes monitoring from unloading to consumption, thus ensuring consumer confidence.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Various studies have expressed concerns showing significant levels of mislabelling on fish products sold on the EU market, including in the restaurants of the EU institutions. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that will strengthen national controls in an effort to tackle fraud and identify the stage in the supply chain where fish is mislabelled.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in food and retail establishments, because I strongly believe that consumers have the right to informed choice and access to proper information. However, observations from recent years have found that there are high levels of false labelling of fishery products sold on the EU market. Deliberate and deceptively mis-labelling of fish species is a breach of EU rules, including the Common Fisheries Policy, and may constitute a criminal offence under national law. Labelling is not a luxury, but information that should give access to sufficiently comprehensive and correct information due to the increasingly frequent problems arising from consuming unhealthy foods. In this regard, I also share the view that the EU-wide eco-label for fishery and aquaculture products can improve traceability and the provision of transparent information to consumers.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is the world's largest market for fishery products, which is supplied by both the EU fisheries sector and imports from third countries. A good European fisheries labelling policy would help to stimulate the economic development of coastal communities as it would recognise fishermen's best practices and the quality of their products to consumers. Consumers also have the right to be informed, with easy-to-understand explanations, including information on the geographical and coastal areas where the fish were caught, and should be able to rely entirely on the entire chain offering fishery products on the EU market.  The EU and its Member States have a duty to protect EU citizens from deception and all imported products must comply with EU rules and standards.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Regrettably, fish products sold on the EU market are often mislabelled, even deliberately, and higher quality fish species are replaced by less quality. Action must be taken to put an end to this practice.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. In particular, it is necessary to ensure a high level of consumer protection and to establish a strong system of traceability from unloading to consumers.  The capacity to track the tour of fishery products will be ensured at various stages of production, processing and distribution from field to table. It should be noted that the extension of the supply chain has facilitated the loss of quality of fishery products and the potential harm to consumer health. It is therefore essential that an effective control mechanism involving all responsible authorities and bodies is applied. In addition, the Commission and the Member States should examine what measures could be taken to improve the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products and to reduce commercial dependence on imports of fishery and aquaculture products.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the European Union's global leadership position as a market for fish products. Given that consumers have every right to know the geographical origin of the fish products they consume and the entire supply chain.  Given that the European Union has a duty to protect its citizens from the risk of fraud. Furthermore, given that, despite europe's commitment to traceability, data on the labelling of fish products for certain species are not fully compliant and the risk of fraud is still high to date, I believe that greater traceability is also necessary in order to reduce Europe's dependence on imports of aquaculture and fishery products. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is the largest fish market in the world, supplied with fish caught on the territory of Member States and third countries. Several studies have pointed to the frequent worrying occurrence of mis-labelling of fish products, with low quality fish presented as of high quality. In my view, in addition to the right of consumers to be informed in an understandable way about the fish they are buying and the place where they catch them, it also states the Union's duty to protect its citizens from fraudulent treatment by producers, as all products on the European market must comply with European standards. I therefore support the proposal for a resolution that aims to protect consumer confidence. I consider it a positive step to set up a working group to level the implementation of European legislation in the Member States and support the strengthening of national controls on the production chain, from fish catch site to table. In terms of the regulation of the market for fishery products, the Republic of Croatia is facing major challenges. In the future, emphasis will be placed on improving the traceability of products by labelling products, since fishing significantly participates in the export of food products of the Republic of Croatia to the territory of the Union.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that a sound European fisheries labelling policy would be a key element in boosting the economic development of coastal communities and would highlight the quality of products supplied to consumers. The need for such a policy comes from discouraging labelling results with significant levels of incorrect labelling of fish products sold on the EU market, despite the fact that this is a breach of EU regulations as well as common fisheries policy rules. It is therefore necessary for the Commission and the Member States to work to combat fraud and to identify the stage within the supply chain at which fish are mislabelled. National controls must be strengthened, including for un processed fish products intended for the gastronomy and catering sector, and the information on labels must be monitored at regular intervals, because labelling must provide comprehensible, verifiable and accurate information enabling the consumer to make an informed choice. It would also be important for the Commission and the Member States to promote awareness-raising campaigns on requirements for the labelling of fishery products.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The EU is the world's largest market for marine products supplied with products from the EU fishing sector as well as from imports of marine products from third countries. In such a large market, unfortunately, there is the possibility of false product labels, so e.g. there are labels with false names of fish as well as false geographical indications of origin. Therefore, I am committed to protecting consumers' right to information, and I call on the EU and the Member States to protect citizens from fraudulent product labels and ensure that all products meet all EU requirements and standards. I express serious concern and dissatisfaction with the results of the survey so far on the amount of false seafood labels in the EU, and stresses that such false label procedures are not only against EU law, but may also constitute criminal offences in accordance with the relevant national laws. In the name of the fight to protect consumer rights, I support the system of traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. I believe that such a traceability system would strengthen consumer confidence in EU products, and consequently reduce dependence on imported fisheries and aquaculture products, which would not only strengthen the EU market, but could also lead to the growth of the EU economy and job creation.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. Recent cases of identification, in various restaurants and hotel and commercial equipment, of fish that do not correspond to the labelling deserve the development of measures that promote not only a correct identification of the species concerned, but also their origin and processing conditions. In the name of the quality of the products, the improvement of the conditions of fishermen and producers of fish products, but also the confidence of consumers, we support this measure. Indeed, the certification of the origin and quality of products is a claim of Portuguese producers and fishermen, as a way of affirming national products and protecting against adulteration and a kind of commercial dumping. Such certification should be ensured by a public entity, exempt and free of charge, thereby avoiding the obligation of producers to pay such certification to private entities, which are often unjudicious.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Food control in many countries is hampered by fragmented legislation, multiple jurisdictions and ineffective oversight, monitoring and implementation of laws. Effective national food control systems and legislation are crucial for ensuring the health and safety of the domestic population as well as ensuring the safety and quality of food in international trade. I supported Cadec's resolution on behalf of the Fisheries Committee, which raises concerns about the mislaging of fish products and calls on Member States to strengthen national food control legislation and control systems for transparency and respect for consumer rights. I welcome the creation of a public database of information on fish products of all Member States so as not to be confused, and in this context a single eco-label for products across the Union would also help.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which aims to provide solutions to the many cases of fraud detected in the labelling of fish in retail sales. It is essential that consumers be able to know the commercial name of the species (as well as its scientific name), the production method as well as the gear used for fishing, the catch area and finally whether the product has been frozen beforehand. The text therefore provides for measures to enhance the transparency and traceability of products, such as the implementation of a public database showing all trade names for each species or the creation of an external structure that will certify information (voluntarily transmitted) related to fishing and aquaculture products.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution calling for a reliable European fish labelling policy. Several studies have shown that fish products sold in EU markets are often incorrectly labelled. Such deception against consumers cannot be tolerated. They should be able to fully trust the whole chain supplying fishing products to the EU market and it is our duty to protect them from these fraudulent practices.  We call on the European Commission to assess the benefits and feasibility of a robust EU-wide labelling system and to consider measures to improve the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products. Labelling must include understandable, verifiable and accurate information to enable consumers to make an informed choice.  Such a system would benefit the development of coastal communities as it would highlight the best practices of fishermen as well as the quality of the products. This would also reduce dependence on trade in imported fish products and aquaculture, thereby consolidating the European market.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. Several studies show significant levels of poor labelling of fishery products sold in the EU, including restaurants in their institutions. Such intentional and fraudulent practice is a failure in european union regulations and may constitute an offence under national law. It is necessary to establish minimum standards of information to the consumer about the origin of these products in a simple and transparent way. The same goes for eco-labeling patterns. Member States should strengthen control, including unprocessed fish for restaurants and catering.
