A European labelling policy will be a key point in boosting the development of coastal communities, recognising best practices and underlining the quality of their products.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The fraud of the European fish consumer is highlighted. These are not isolated cases. The same is produced in Brussels as in Spain, Ireland, Greece or Great Britain. And it always involves selling lower value fish instead of the most expensive varieties. We could resolve this situation by requiring precise information about the species and place of origin of the products. Something relatively simple, for example, in the case of canned products. In favour of the consumer, but also of sustainable European production, case of the mussel of Galicia. I therefore support the call for this resolution, for greater clarity and transparency in information on the origin of fishery products. As well as correcting FAO labelling with regard to Galicia and the Gulf of Cadiz, labelled as "Portuguese Waters." If we want to protect our quality productions and protect consumers, we must clarify the origin in labelling.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament today called for stronger measures on traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in catering and retail. The text of the resolution aims to draw lessons from the results of several studies showing that fish products sold in EU markets, including in restaurants in EU institutions, "are often incorrectly labelled".  The intentional and fraudulent mislabelling of fish species is a violation of European regulations, including the common fisheries policy, and is likely to constitute a criminal offence. The voted text therefore calls on Member States to strengthen national controls, including unprocessed fish in the food and food services sector, in order to "counter fraud and identify the stage in the supply chain at which fish are mislabelling". The adopted text also calls on the Commission, in order to improve traceability, to exploit the potential of the application of a DNA barcode, which could help identify a species through DNA sequencing.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent Brussels restaurant scandal, which showed that a larger proportion of fish products in the European capital do not comply with neither the rules of origin nor, at times, even its name, have shown that the fisheries sector is facing huge problems. I am therefore in favour of strengthening the rules on origin and traceability in the fisheries sector. European citizens have a right to know what they are eating! The EU institutions have a duty to guarantee citizens the right to know what they are eating!

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As the world's largest market for fishery (aquaculture) products, the European Union must strive for demanding and effective regulation for this sector, from extraction and production to retail/catering. However, several studies have shown that there are a significant number of cases of incorrect – and sometimes even fraudulent – labelling of fishery (and aquaculture) products sold on the European market. It is imperative that Member States should be taken into account as a violation of Community principles (and regulations), it is imperative to alert Member States to the need to strengthen their national controls and to require them and the European Commission to take measures to improve traceability of fishery and aquaculture products. With greater monitoring and traceability of these products, not only consumers, but also agents of the sector, gain, for the greater confidence placed in the system of extraction, production and sale of fishery and aquaculture products. I am also in favour of the proposal to set up an eco-labelling system for fishery/aquaculture products, welcoming feasibility studies to this end. In the sake of rigour, transparency and confidence in the fish sales system, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Studies by the European Commission and non-governmental organisations have identified worrying cases of incorrect labelling of fish; I have therefore supported this report which calls for greater consumer confidence in the product they consume and access to solid and reliable information. Fishing and aquaculture products sold on the European market come from more than 70% of imports; in this sense, it is important that they meet traceability standards identical to European products and therefore are perfectly traceable. For example, a traceability system for all fish products sold in SHOPS or restaurants in the European Union would prevent cases of fraud and provide consumers with access to solid and reliable information.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly urges the Commission to take note of and intervene in the traceability of fishery products as the most efficient source of food fraud and perpetuated fraud in consumer information. As the report itself points out, the adoption by the Union of high standards of quality and guarantee will strengthen the single market, increasing consumer confidence and reducing dependence on imports.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the motion for a resolution so that there can be follow-up of products with the aim of improving consumer information and in turn for the achievement of the food security we are advocating for the EU. With the growth of Aquaculture in the search for sustainable means to supply the growing demand for fish in the diet, controls are needed to verify that labelling is met and to be able to find that the corresponding health criteria are maintained. Labelling is also important so that the consumer can have maximum information when buying their food.  It can in turn reduce dependence on import fisheries and aquaculture products by strengthening trade in local products.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the traceability of fishery products. Traceability is essential, especially when fish and seafood are perishable products. I hope that both the European Commission and the Belgian authorities will take steps to eliminate irregularities in the labelling of fishery products.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in the catering and retail sector. The text is going in the right direction even though I think it falls short of its demands on the Member States and the Commission. It is noteworthy that there are significant levels of mislabeling in fisheries products sold on the Union market, support for a solid traceability system from landing to consumption, the call for the creation of an EU-wide eco-label and the explicit mention of catches in Galicia labelled as "Portuguese waters".

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recently a study commissioned by an NGO revealed that in restaurants in Brussels almost a third of the fish analyzed were not the one promised on the menu. Unfortunately, complaints have been abounding in the EU for many years about cases of incorrect labelling of fish products: for example, a pangasio is passed off as grouper or fish are bleached with oxygenated water. Intentional and fraudulent mislabeling not only constitutes a violation of the common fisheries policy and harms those who work honestly, but can also pose a serious risk to the health of the consumer. I therefore supported Parliament's resolution calling for a strong traceability system from landing to consumption for all fish products sold in EU restaurants and shops. Finally, I hope that controls will be strengthened to combat fraud and to identify in good time the stage of the supply chain, where fish are mislabelled.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. I am concerned that several studies have indicated that there are significant levels of incorrect labelling of fish products in Europe. I am sure that incorrect, fraudulent and intentional labelling of fish species is a violation of Union regulations. It seems to me that genetic barcode techniques should be effectively followed up, which facilitate the identification of species by DNA sequencing and, I would stress, these techniques have been developed on the basis of funding from the European Union itself. In other words, once again, it is necessary to effectively transfer scientific and technological developments to the world of industry and, in this case, regulation. I believe that it is necessary to ensure that future Union-wide eco-labels and the certification and eco-labelling schemes of seafood in European and third countries are consistent with fao guidelines for the eco-labelling of fish and fishery products caught at sea. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report and I hope it will have consequences for establishing a certification method. In my view, this method can only be in the European Union.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion which wants to improve the traceability of products derived from fisheries and aquaculture in restaurants and retail. All too often we see fraudulent mislabelling; this constitutes a clear breach of CFP rules. It misleads consumers, represents a threat to marine resources as well as consumer health, disadvantages honest producers and distorts competition. I’m joining the voices from this place to call on the European Commission and the Member States to act decisively and improve controls, traceability and distribution of information on these products – not least in the interest of consumer protection, but it also goes some way to protect the credibility of the fisheries industry as well as the catering industries which buy such products.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome this resolution, which calls for the monitoring and fight against fraud in the area of origin marking and mis-labelling of fish and fish products. The results of various studies show a high level of mis-labelling of fish products sold on the EU market, including in restaurants of the EU institutions. It is necessary to identify in which part of the supply chain fish is misrepresented and to strengthen national controls, including controls on unprocessed fish in restaurants and the catering sector.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the end of last year, a study by OCEANA was published which pointed out that up to a third of all fish served in restaurants in Brussels is not correctly labelled. The revelation that sellers, instead of declared quality fish species, are actually offering their lower-quality substitutes (cod, for example, is to be substituted for pangasia) has caused public outrage. I therefore agreed with the resolution which aims to describe this problem and to put pressure on the Commission to come up with options for redress. Nevertheless, it is unacceptable for the consumer to be misled in such a straightforward way. Each seller must comply with certain minimum standards for the labelling of fish and seafood. In order for the consumer to have confidence in the products he consumes, the seller must act transparently and responsibly. The competent authorities, on the other hand, need to be able to trace the origin of fish, as illegal imported fish harm the economy, have an impact on the conservation of fishery resources and may also pose a health risk. That is why we are asking the Commission to come up with a proposal for an accurate, credible and understandable way of labelling fish and seafood for the consumer. Misleading the consumer is unfair and I therefore hope that such practices will be prevented.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Last year, a survey was carried out in Brussels, including in restaurants within the European institutions, on the adequacy of the labelling of fish dishes. Using DNA testing, the International NGO Oceana identified fish prepared in restaurants and compared the findings with the suppliers' claims about the dishes offered. More than 30 per cent of the dishes analysed did not match the DNA research findings of the fish used in the preparation of the dish. NGOs have come to similar findings elsewhere. Despite the fact that Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 contains a provision on consumer information regarding food, including restaurant sales, Member States shall postpone their responsibility in requesting proper enforcement of the provision by food providers elsewhere. I believe that the debate on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail sales would contribute to ensuring proper labelling in restaurants in the future, which is why I also voted in favour of the resolution at the meeting.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ A recently published study by an NGO has highlighted worrying cases of fish mislaging served in Brussels restaurants. DNA results from an analysis of more than 280 samples of fish served in restaurants, including restaurants of European institutions, showed that a third of that fish was mislabeled. This study thus proved that the key problem in the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail in the European Union is the disinformation of consumers on fishery and aquaculture products. I support this motion for a resolution, as I believe it is necessary to identify traceability deficiencies in the production chain and to ensure traceability of products in restaurants and retail, the way to provide consumers with access to complete and accurate information on the products they use and consume.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution to the oral question on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. Some studies point to the significant prevalence of incorrect labelling of fishery products sold on the EU market, including in the restaurants of the EU institutions, in breach of EU regulations, including the rules of the common fisheries policy, which can be considered a criminal offence under national law. I support enhanced supervision by the Member States and an effective fight against fraud.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution provides for the creation of a strong traceability system, from landing to consumption, that will inspire consumer confidence and thus reduce commercial dependence on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thus strengthening the EU market.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, mainly because of its consumer protection aspect. As is known, the European Union is the world's largest market for seafood, with a significant third-country import share. I think it is important that consumers are informed of the place of catch and that imported products comply with EU rules and standards. I share the concern that significant mislabeling and abuse in the EU market could lead to serious problems. I therefore agree with the need to strengthen member states' controls, to step up the fight against fraud and to make use of the system of voluntary or compulsory certificates.  Designation of origin and tools such as eco-labelling provide an opportunity for consumers to choose healthier food and to strengthen the internal market. This also means that they are not only important from the consumer side, but can also be effective tools from the producer side. I believe that, like different food VAT, the system of fish trade licences in different Member States can lead to misunderstandings and abuses, which is why I welcome their approximation and their release in all official EU languages. I also think it is important that marine resources are exploited in a sustainable manner and that we combat illegal fishing.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 European citizens have the right to enjoy quality food and whose origin is clearly mentioned. Unfortunately, this is not always the case at Member State level, particularly with regard to marine foods. There are many cases where the labels of certain products misinform the true origin or quality of the product, offering a lower quality at the price of a higher one. This has already happened for the various tuna species marketed at European level and is very serious. It is the duty of the European institutions to eliminate these reprehensible practices by establishing much stricter controls, both on the quality and elimination of risks to public health and with regard to the accurate determination of the origin of marine products. Often, the provenance of third countries is hidden, which translates into avoiding the payment of related taxes and falsifying real prices, with negative effects on European producers and workers in the field. The consumer must have all the information necessary to be able to make the decision to purchase the product in full knowledge of the facts. In this respect, I support the adoption of the current resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With this resolution, we express our strong concern and dissatisfaction with the results of several studies which have shown that fish products sold in EU markets, including in restaurants in EU institutions, are often labelled incorrectly. The intentional and fraudulent mislabelling of fish species is a violation of European regulations, including the common fisheries policy, and is likely, under national law, to constitute a criminal offence! Member States controls need to be strengthened!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Various studies have shown that there have been significant levels of mislabelling on fish products sold on the EU market, including inside the EU institutions. This is a clear breach of EU regulations and of consumers’ trust and therefore I voted in favour of this resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail.  It is necessary to strengthen national controls and develop a traceability system to reinforce the EU market. Increased monitoring by the Commission of the information provided on labels should help overcome the confusion created by existing different denomination within Member States. Eventually it will contribute to boost the economic development of coastal communities while encouraging more ethical and environmental production of fishery and aquaculture products.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I have partnered with my colleagues on the Committee on Fisheries to have an oral question and resolution adopted on the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products in catering and retail. A few months ago, a new scandal broke over labelling; far less shocking than that of the horse, it concerned the fraudulent naming of certain species labelled as more "noble" species. However, this scandal has revealed existing shortcomings in terms of traceability and consumer information. Today, the labels must include the FAO area where the fish was caught. But is it really clear to a consumer that a fish caught in the "Gascony Gulf" can come from Brittany? In addition, labelling must be a traceability tool. On the occasion of my initiative report on fisheries control, which is being discussed at the moment, I insist that the fish be controlled from the net to the plate. Finally, I would like to see the creation of a European eco-label, based on criteria formulated in a democratic and objective way.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the identification of traceability of fishery products in restaurants and retail. Proper labelling of goods is the basis for fair trade and services. Consumers have the right to reliable information and, most importantly, understandable information about composition, expiration date, origin or price of the product. The requirements for manufacturers and traders contribute to the protection of the rights of consumers of EU citizens in this respect. For this reason, we should increase our requirements, especially with regard to suppliers from third countries, in order to reach the European market from so-called aquaculture that meets our standards.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has become the world's leading market for fishing and aquaculture products and this market is growing continuously and new products are being added daily coming from member states as well as third countries.  The results of various studies show a low level of labelling of fish products sold in the internal market, including those sold in restaurants, indicating deliberate avoidance and violation of European Union rules.  Given that consumers are entitled to information on the origin of food, including geographical data on catch zones, I believe that the Commission and the Member States must improve the traceability of fisheries and aquaculture products. I believe that a strong traceability system would increase consumer confidence and reduce dependence on imports, and this would also strengthen the Union market.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the resolutions - Traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail, as greater transparency and traceability is needed in the labelling of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. 70% of fishery and aquaculture products on the European market are imported, so it is important that they meet the same standards as European products. The European People's Party has for many years advocated a single European food label that would ensure respect for environmental, social and health standards.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution so that there can be follow-up of products with the aim of improving consumer information and in turn for the achievement of the food security we are advocating for the EU. With the growth of Aquaculture in the search for sustainable means to supply the growing demand for fish in the diet, controls are needed to verify that labelling is met and to be able to find that the corresponding health criteria are maintained. Labelling is also important so that the consumer can have maximum information when buying their food.  It can in turn reduce dependence on import fisheries and aquaculture products by strengthening trade in local products.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. A study by the NGO Oceana found cases of mislabelling of fish served in restaurants in Brussels, including in European institutions. About one-third of the fish tested were mislabeled. This study shows that the traceability of fish products is not assured due to the lack of reliable labelling. We must remain vigilant about European eco-labelling which could oust the labels of the Member States. Labelling and the creation of labels, with the aim of improving traceability and product quality, is in line with what we are asking for. But we cannot accept a single European label that would effectively deprive states of their right to create stricter and more consumer-protective labels. I chose abstention.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to provide information to consumers on the geographical and coastal areas where the fish have been caught, while the EU is the largest market for fishery products in the world, being supplied by both the European fisheries sector and imports from third countries. In 2015, as part of a control plan aimed at determining the extent to which mislabelled fish spread on the market, the European Commission found that the declared species were confirmed in 94% of the samples taken. However, the results of several studies show significant levels of mislabelling for fish products sold on the European market. That is why there is a need to create a robust traceability system that gives consumers confidence, thereby strengthening the European market for fishery products and stimulating the economic development of coastal communities. In addition to the fact that the motion for a resolution underlines the need for Member States to strengthen their national controls, it also calls on the Commission to analyse the potential of DNA bar codes that could help identify species. I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and in retail.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Consumers have the right to clearly worded information, including coastal and geographical information on catch areas, and should be able to have full confidence in the whole chain supplying fishery products to the UNION market. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution so that there can be follow-up of products with the aim of improving consumer information and in turn for the achievement of the food security we are advocating for the EU. With the growth of Aquaculture in the search for sustainable means to supply the growing demand for fish in the diet, controls are needed to verify that labelling is met and to be able to find that the corresponding health criteria are maintained. Labelling is also important so that the consumer can have maximum information when buying their food. It can in turn reduce dependence on import fisheries and aquaculture products by strengthening trade in local products.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it puts pressure on the Commission to ensure that labelling in restaurants and canteens is reliable. Last year, an NGO (Oceana) did a survey of a number of eating establishments and found out that, in over 30% of the cases, the label on the menu (or verbal information) appears to have been wrong.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted for this resolution. Fraudulent and mislabelling constitutes a clear violation of European fisheries policy and is misleading to consumers. The Commission and the Member States are encouraged to take strong action in order to better protect European consumers.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution of the Parliamentary Committee on Fisheries focuses on the traceability of fishing and aquaculture products in catering and retail. Studies have shown that products from fisheries in EU markets, restaurants and even in the canteens of Parliament and the Commission are often mislabeled. The labelling policy would better recognize fishermen's best practices and the quality of products sold to consumers, and could enhance traceability and transparency of information for consumers.  The EU's maritime and fisheries fund is in a position to finance it and could, in particular, enable the establishment of an independent structure certifying information on the labels of fish products.  This report, the main provisions of which remain optional, seems to me to be a good thing for both fishermen and consumers. I voted for it.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – The European Union is the world's largest market for the consumption of fish products. It is therefore important that this market is regulated accordingly. To date, there are still breaches of existing legislation. Mainly the incorrect labeling of fish is a frequent problem. Taking this into account, I support this resolution and also call on the Member States to take action against it. To achieve this, a unified, transparent and harmonised system is needed. It is very important that any form of label, clear, correct, and consumer-understandable information is displayed. Such a system, which would give a better picture of the quality of the products purchased, could also have a stimulating effect on the coastal areas and economies that depend on them.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Recent cases of identification, in several restaurants and hotel and commercial equipment, of fish that do not correspond to the labelling (the fish version of selling cat by hare!) deserve the development of measures that promote not only a correct identification of the species concerned, but also their origin and processing conditions. In the name of the quality of the products, the improvement of the conditions of fishermen and producers of fish products, but also the confidence of consumers, we support this measure. Indeed, the certification of the origin and quality of products is a claim of Portuguese producers and fishermen, as a way of affirming national products and protecting against adulteration and a kind of commercial dumping. Such certification should be ensured by a public entity, exempt and free of charge, thereby avoiding the obligation of producers to pay such certification to private entities, which are often unjudicious.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this critical resolution, as it also advocates stronger controls, for example in the case of unprocessed fish for catering and restaurants, in order to be able, above all, to counter fraud.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the oral question on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods. I am firmly in favour of an honest and functional labelling system. Consumers have a right to know where the food they buy comes from. The labelling of certain types of meat, such as pork and goats, was already compulsory, but Parliament is calling for the obligation to be extended to all types of meat, to meat in processed foods and to all dairy products. I am convinced that this will give citizens a better understanding of the environmental impact of the food they buy and that it will help to increase consumer confidence. In addition, producers will be forced to better control the supply chain and the number of frauds will consequently be reduced.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail. There is no need to establish monitoring measures along the supply and value chain for fish and similar products. Moreover, it would not be the eu's job.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – As regards the labelling of fishery and aquaculture products (purposeful, planned management of water bodies) in gastronomy and retail, we voted in favour of introducing a sound labelling system from unloading (landing) to a consumer who could gain consumer confidence and consolidate the EU market. With this resolution, we are asking the Commission to assess the benefits of introducing a European labelling system that should ensure the transparency and credibility of the certification process, such as the application of a DNA barcode that could help identify species.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Cadec's resolution, which strengthens both the internal market in fisheries and aquaculture and consumer confidence.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I was happy to support the European Parliament resolution based on an oral question. As consumers, we are often misrepresented about what kind of fish we buy, from what area and whether it has been caught or comes from farming. In doing so, incorrect information prevents us as consumers from opting for information and sometimes borders on misleading. It is not exceptional that we buy stained cod instead of salmon, or compressed protein instead of crab sticks or lobster. Not to mention that such tactics are not only wrong towards consumers, but also towards fishermen who are loss-making to them. That is why we have called on the Member States to strengthen controls at national level and also to establish a system for monitoring the origin of fish and the mandatory labelling of established data. I therefore believe that this resolution will also help to change the conditions soon, and we will always learn the right information about what we are ad.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Cadec report because I believe that fraudulent labelling of fishery products is not only a breach of EU rules, in particular the common fisheries policy, but also misleads consumers, calling into question their food security and the stability of marine resources and also distorting the internal market. I believe that European consumers can fully trust the entire supply chain of fishery products on the European market, and that the EU and the Member States have a duty to protect their citizens from fraudulent acts. The result of several studies indicating significant levels of incorrect labelling of fish products sold on the EU market is regrettable. I would like to point out the call on Member States to strengthen national controls in an effort to combat fraud to identify the stage of the supply chain where fish is incorrectly labelled, and to take measures to improve traceability of fishery and aquaculture products from landing to consumption.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. The EU is the world's largest seafood market, stocking up on products from its fisheries sector and imports from third countries. However, various studies find that there is often a intentional and fraudulent incorrect labelling of fishery products sold on the EU market. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the traceability of fishery and aquaculture products in restaurants and retail sale and the introduction of a reliable traceability system from landing to consumption, thereby ensuring consumer confidence and, consequently, reducing dependence on imported fishery and aquaculture products, thereby strengthening the EU market.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, trouble has been looming for 15 years and for 15 years our governments did nothing. Now we are being put under pressure to decide whether the EU should grant China market economy status in December, risking the tools we currently have to deal with Chinese trade dumping. The situation in the steel, ceramics, and other manufacturing industries demonstrates that these tools are not sufficient today to fully protect jobs and businesses against unfair competition. We need the long-overdue reform of EU trade defence instruments. The Commission proposed it, Parliament amended and adopted it. We now need trade ministers to do their part and to stop blocking it. Tomorrow they have an opportunity to make a key decision for our manufacturing industries. On their side, China must deal with their massive overcapacity; without real reforms in China there cannot be any recognition of what would really be a fictional market economy status. I supported today’s resolution for these reasons.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, it is probably an ordinary topic of debate among people in several Member States: is it a good thing that I can go out to the Chinese market to shop, to the Chinese store, and that the other malls are also full of Chinese dumping and mass goods. It is a very good thing, because it is cheap, say many, for example, mothers with several children, who can buy shoes, clothes, school supplies, etc. for their children there. Yes, but we should just put this particular cheapness in context and why so many people, for example in Hungary, need to buy cheap, low-quality goods. That is because, precisely because of global free trade, the structure of the economy has become such that they are forced to do very low-wage and labour-law-vulnerable work, and paradoxically this creates demand for cheap, often useless, low-quality goods.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: (beginning of off-mic intervention) because I am in favour of in-depth cooperation with China. Here, cooperation is negotiation. Free trade that is the framework of this agreement is simply the balance of power. And the balance of power is not because of China, but because of the rules that the European Union has imposed on the rest of the world on free trade. That is why I am against this agreement, but above all I want to denounce the hypocrisy of those who are calling for anti-dumping measures, especially on the issues of Chinese steel, when they themselves import it into Europe. I am talking about Mr Mittal, the great great european steel industry. I do this denunciation on the basis of the facts revealed by the CGT of ArcelorMittal and Florange, and my comrade Lionel Burriello, head of the CGT. This is all a comedy. We must have cooperation with China, a frank dialogue that confronts the advantages of each country and not the balance of power. You imposed them on China and now you are the first to suffer and you dare to protest!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I did not support China having market economy status. I agree with what has been said here by some of my pre-speaking ers. I believe that if we were to grant China this status, then Chinese products, which are often dumped or sold at dumped prices, would overwhelm the European market, and some of those analyses clearly show that this would have a major impact on unemployment in Europe. For example, in my country, the Czech Republic, this could lead to major problems in the Czech steel industry and could result in the redundancies of up to tens of thousands of people. This means that it is good to have good trade relations with China, although I have great reservations about the political regime that is in place in China, on the other hand, the European market must be protected if China is taking advantage of unfair practices. China's use of these practices is clearly demonstrated. That is why I think that, at the moment, Europe and its economy should not be opened up to Chinese imports.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, today’s vote gives a clear signal that firm action must be taken against practices that are far removed from the fair competition and open trade that this House should champion. Steel dumping has damaged our industry unfairly and if China wants to be regarded as a reliable and trusted partner on equal terms with us, it must act like one. The real question though is: why has the Commission seemingly been sitting on its hands, doing nothing to anticipate a situation that has been 15 years in the making? Where is the reform on trade defence instruments, for instance? A potential turning point in global trade is just a few months away and we have no idea how the Commission will tackle a situation that could cause irreversible damage to our industry and jobs.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, China is not a market economy: it subsidises companies and meddles in the way in which they are run, and its export prices are not determined by the rules of supply and demand. In addition it dumps its overcapacity production in other countries, where it creates severe economic and social damage, putting at risk hundreds of thousands of jobs in the EU alone. It has happened in the case of solar panels, tyres and shoes, and now it is happening in the steel sector. This is why I believe that, just like the USA, we should not automatically grant market economy status to China. Instead we should opt for a criteria-based assessment of this status, involving a case-by-case definition of dumping margins, and prepare in advance strong trade defence instruments that can protect our industries against global unfair practices.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Well, by exiting the criteria set by the European Union, the People's Republic of China could be considered a market economy country if, as we know, five criteria are met. First, a low degree of government influence on resource allocation. Secondly, the absence of distortions of privatised economic activity. Thirdly, the implementation of company law with appropriate corporate governance rules. Fourth, effective legal framework. And the fifth, the existence of a real financial sector. By transferring all these criteria, it is clear that, despite the fact that China is undoubtedly a very important partner for the European Union, these criteria are not met. And so I do not really see an opportunity to grant This Status to China in the near future. This does not mean that this status will never be granted, but it only means that, at the moment, China must meet these five criteria.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think that if you study the press and see how economists define the Chinese economy, many terms appear – some say it is a planned capitalist economy, others say it is a socialist market economy. But I too find it difficult to give the Chinese the status of a market economy, because it is simply not. That is why I was unable to vote in favour of the report. On the other hand, of course, our lawyers say that, especially if we give China this status, it would be much easier to combat unfair practices. At this point I have to say: I hear the message, but I lack faith. But what is left and what I call on the Commission to do is to take more action more closely against unfair practices. We have had various crises – the steel crisis is currently under discussion, where the Chinese economy or the Chinese Communist Party is simply destroying the European steel industry through dumping prices.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, this is truly absurd. If we were to grant China market economy status, we could better combat its unfair practices. However, this cannot entitle us to grant such status in order to better combat its unfair practices to this economy. I was against it, I think that China did not meet all the criteria, the five basic areas simply were not met and for this reason it is not possible to grant it this status. On the contrary, the Commission should be called upon to prepare better tools to combat precisely these unfair practices. This is not only an anti-dumping issue, but also, of course, an environmental issue, an environmental damage that has far-reaching consequences for the global state of the environment. I think that these issues are very much linked to this status as well, and we cannot rule out that China will ever come to this status. But certainly not in the current situation.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 China is currently the European Union's second largest economic partner. The Member States have always sought to establish economic relations based on mutual respect and fair and fair cooperation, including in the economic field. The proposal to grant China market economy status has, however, raised many concerns. The main doubts concerned the likely harmful consequences for the European market and, secondly, the strong state influence on prices and products that characterises the Chinese economy. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution in which Parliament urges the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed in this regard.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. As I have highlighted with the vote in the amendments, I consider it necessary to have a firm position against the Commission's intention to proceed, after 2016, with further liberalisation of trade with China. The joint motion submitted to the vote, despite recognising that the current situation would not support such a procedure, merely repeats the Commission's argument. It thus endorses poor public consultation and leaves the door fully open to eliminating anti-dumping protection in exchange for privatizations and deregulations in the Chinese economy. We cannot defend economic interference in China, nor an intensification of global competition that would seriously harm social and environmental standards in industry and the jobs it generates in Europe. That's why I voted against it.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I objected to china's granting market economy status. China is not a market economy, but it meets only one of the five criteria expected for this. Granting this status to China would be catastrophic: it would potentially reduce anti-dumping duties from 44% to about 10%. According to experts, the EU would be deprived of 90% of its anti-dumping measures and according to the Institute for Economic Policy (EPI), an affiliate of the trade union world and based in Washington, European production could be reduced by 2% of gross domestic product (GDP) per year. Finally, between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs could be at risk in Europe as early as 2020, of which 183,300 to 366,800 in France. A motion for a resolution from the ENF group has been tabled, asking not to grant this status to China and to strengthen our trade defence mechanisms.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Our vote is a very clear signal to the Member States as well as to the European Commission. China must not achieve market economy status. Granting China market economy status would prevent the European Commission from opposing anti-dumping measures against Chinese products. The situation is already critical in some areas. The most telling example is steel: because of its massive overcapacity, China is flooding the world market with products that it sells at prices below the cost of the raw material. It is a certain idea of Europe that is at stake. Employees and consumers will turn away from the EU even further if it proves unable to protect them. More than ever, Europe must impose the rules of fair trade in international trade. This debate is not technical, it is eminently political.  I and my colleagues would like to draw on this debate to work towards a strengthening of the European anti-dumping arsenal. This means strengthening trade defence instruments (IDCs) to increase applicable anti-dumping taxes, drastically shortening the time of investigations and simplifying complaints by opening up this possibility to trade union organisations. It is time for Europe to stop behaving like an idiot of the global village.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. When the People's Republic of China joined the World Trade Organisation (WTO) in 2001, it was classified as a non-market economy, thus restricting full access to the markets of other WTO members. However, the Accession Protocol promised that, if political and economic conditions were met, it would be granted market economy status (MWS) 15 years later (i.e. at the end of 2016). This classification would mean that other countries would no longer be able to impose punitive duties on products produced in China under dumping conditions. From an EU point of view, 5 criteria must be met in order to enjoy market economy status. However, as China continues to fail to meet them, it cannot, rightly, be treated like any standard WTO member. Given the concerns of businesses and trade unions in the EU about the negative consequences of such A MET for EU jobs, the environment and sustainable economic growth, this resolution is to be welcomed. Already today – and without MET – overcapacity in China, for example in the steel sector, is having serious social and economic repercussions in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Recognizing China's market economy status or changing methodology would potentially reduce anti-dumping duties from 44% to about 10%. Experts estimate that by granting China market economy status, the EU would deprive itself of 90% of its anti-dumping measures. According to the Trade Union-affiliated Institute for Economic Policy (EPI), which is based in Washington, European production could be reduced by 2% of gross domestic product (GDP) per year. Between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs could be at risk in Europe as early as 2020, including 183,300 to 366,800 in France. That is why a motion for a resolution was put forward by the ENL group, which I obviously voted for.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EFDD resolution on this issue, but could not support giving China market economy status. To put it bluntly, China is not a market economy.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. If China achieves market economy status it will be very difficult to combat Chinese distortions of competition. Europe is not united, it is an addition of 28 national egoisms and everyone is trying to get their act together, where the Chinese can very easily oppose each other, wine against diesel cars. It would be urgent for Europe to be coherent. We want to flatter the consumer with an ever cheaper life but we do not change anything in our tax and social laws and we risk a transfer of activity that causes mass unemployment. Europe needs to wake up. The deficit in imports and exports compared to China in 2014 was 100 billion euros. That is the number of jobs that have been relocated. It is for all these reasons that I did not vote in favour of this text.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. The People's Republic of China is one of the largest economies in the world and Europe has a great trade relationship with this country: China is now the European Union's second trading partner; in turn, the European Union is China's first trading partner. All trade between the two economies reaches €1 billion a day and foreign direct investment between them has grown significantly. The European Union sets out five criteria for determining whether or not we are facing a market economy. According to the latest assessment by the European Union, China only meets one of the criteria. In fact, 56 of the current 73 anti-dumping measures imposed by the European Union refer to imports of Chinese goods. China does not meet all these criteria and so its consideration as a market economy should be rejected at the moment. The change of its status should only take place when the European Union considers that China meets all the established criteria.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the status of a Chinese market economy. China supports its business, makes extensive use of State aid and subsidises exports at a price that is not in line with the laws of supply and demand. The country's surplus production contributes to cheap chinese exports of goods to the EU, which is damaging, for example, the EU steel industry. I support the calls for the European Commission to propose new rules to combat dumping. The Commission must take into account the concerns expressed by EU industry, trade unions and other stakeholders about the consequences for EU jobs, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth in all affected manufacturing sectors and eu industry as a whole, and ensure that jobs in the EU are protected in this case. It is also necessary to carry out a global reform of EU trade defence instruments in order to ensure a level playing field for EU industry and China, as well as other trading partners, in full compliance with WTO rules.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. China has been a member of the WTO since 2001; its membership protocol then stipulated that its status would have to be revised after a period of fifteen years, and we have come to an end.  However, the fact that it is not a market economy allows the EU to impose anti-dumping measures, which are crucial when we know that 80% of EU imports that have been investigated for dumping or subsidies by the Commission come from China.  Granting China market economy status would jeopardize between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs in Europe by 2020, of which 183,000 to 366,000 in France, particularly in the steel sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have co-signed and, of course, approved this joint resolution which stresses that China is not a market economy and therefore calls on the Commission to oppose any unilateral decision to grant China market economy status. The resolution also calls on the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed by the industrial sector, trade unions and other EU stakeholders about the impact on employment, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth in the Union. Similarly, Parliament believes that until China is eligible for market economy status, the EU should use a non-standard method for dumping investigations. Finally, MEPs stress the imminent need for a general reform of the EUROPEAN Union's trade defence instruments in order to ensure that the EU industry has a level playing field with China and other trading partners. This joint resolution is an important first step, but we must now ensure that political pressure on the Commission and the Council is maintained and intensified. This is about thousands of jobs in the Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The People's Republic of China and the European Union are among the largest traders on the planet and can count on a reciprocal trade of over one billion euros per day. The joint motion for a resolution on China's market economy status, which I voted for in Parliament today, addresses the thorny issue of granting this status to the Asian country in the period after 11 December 2016. Section 15 of the Protocol of Accession of the PRC to the WTO already provides for non-standard methodologies to ensure price comparability which may also be applied beyond that date. Parliament called on the Commission not to unilaterally grant SEM to China until china fulfils the five criteria adopted by the EU to define this status. China's overcapacity already has serious social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU, so the Commission needs to develop a common strategy within the WTO to prepare the appropriate anti-subsidy and anti-dumping measures compatible with the international regulatory framework.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention in considering possible recognition as a market economy to China a threat to millions of jobs in the European Union. We consider the resolution to be ambiguous because it does not clearly urge the European Commission not to grant this recognition to China. We tabled two amendments which called on the Commission to do the same in a very concrete way, but unfortunately they were rejected in plenary.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. With regard to the status of market economy to be granted or not to China, I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by our ENL group and refusing to grant this status and I abstained on other resolutions that do not take clear positions on the subject. For example, the joint resolution of the EPP, Socialist, ECR, ALDE and Green groups only pushes back the deadline by calling, among other things, for this subject to be debated only at an upcoming EU-China summit which would exclude the Member States from each ability to have their own voice on the subject. Furthermore, our resolution reminds us that China is the EU's second largest trading partner and that the EU is China's largest trading partner, with trade well in excess of EUR 1 billion per day; therefore, we recognise the importance of trade with this sovereign country, but stress that China does not meet the five criteria established by the Union to define countries recognised as "market economy". Finally, China's overcapacity in production already has major social, economic and environmental consequences in the Union, and we hope that the Commission will take into account the concerns expressed by the industrial sector.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 China is not a market economy: state interference persists in the economy and banking sector, state interventionism in the form of massive business subsidies, and cost overproduction in order to annihilate European and global competition. Granting China market economy status would make entire vital production sectors disappear from our territories and with them hundreds of thousands of jobs. I believe that in the joint resolution proposed, unlike the one we have tabled, it lacks a clear and explicit request not to grant China market economy status, which is why I did not see fit to support it with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the resolution. However, I would like to underline strongly the importance of China ratifying the ILO's basic conventions. The recognition of the right to trade union organisation should be one of the basic requirements of china on the part of the EU for further development in the negotiations. In this context, it is also of great importance that China works with climate change in the steel industry to reduce energy consumption and CO2 emissions. With these two clarifications, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament examines the status of trade relations and market economy between the European Union and China. Parliament stresses that the EU-China Strategic Partnership, in which free and fair trade and investment plays a major role, is very important, but points out that China is not a market economy state and that five EU criteria describing a market economy are not yet met. Parliament therefore considers that, as long as China does not meet all five market economy criteria established by the EU, the EU should apply a non-standard methodology for determining price comparability in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations of Chinese imports, in accordance with the provisions of the Protocol on China's accession to the World Trade Organisation, which will not expire in December 2016, and ensure their full validity. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed by EU industry, trade unions and various stakeholders about the consequences for EU jobs and sustainable economic growth in all affected manufacturing sectors and for EU industry as a whole, and to ensure the EU's global competitiveness. Parliament also calls on the Commission to increase the effectiveness of the anti-dumping measure in order to ensure a level playing field between EU industry and China, in full compliance with World Trade Organisation rules.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 China is not a classical market economy, which is why I supported the motion for a resolution on EU-China trade relations and market economy status, which highlights the shortcomings in china's eligibility for market economy status. Until China fulfils the five criteria set by the EU for the definition of market economies, a non-standard methodology for determining price comparability should be used for anti-dumping investigations of Chinese imports. The Commission must take due account of the concerns expressed by MEPs about the industrial sector in the EU and ensure the protection of European jobs, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth. The consequences of China's overproduction are already showing through the adverse impact on the EU steel industry, with already visible social consequences. However, I will not oppose granting market economy status to China when the conditions are met and when it does not pose such a high risk to the European economy.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and China are two of the largest trading entities in the world, as well as partners of extreme mutual importance, with a daily trade volume of more than one billion euros. It is therefore clear that EU-China relations on trade, as on any other, are of fundamental and strategic importance for both realities of which we must be aware in every decision we take. However, we must also be realistic and make it clear that China is not currently a market economy. In view of the imminent expiry of the clause in Section 15 of China's protocol on access to the WTO, with the resolution we are approving today, Parliament stresses the importance of taking timely and realistic decisions. State intervention in the Chinese economy is still very strong and contributes greatly to price formation, preventing a calculation of the dumping margin based on the conventional methodology that normally applies to market economies. It is not a question of erecting protectionist barriers, but of defending our industry against unfair competition while waiting for the conditions for truly fair and sustainable trade to take place.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution. The resolution deals with trade between the EU and China, and specifically with the fact that at the end of 2016 the terms which China signed up to the World Trade Organisation in 2001 will expire and need to be re-evaluated. I do not agree with the EU dictating to China how to run its economy – however, there are objective criteria agreed by WTO members as to what qualifies as a ‘market economy’ status for a state. This resolution stresses that China does not meet these five criteria. It reiterates the importance of trade between the EU and China while also acknowledging the concerns expressed by trade unions across Europe, particularly in relation to manufacturing and industries including steel, textiles, solar and chemical products. Unions are concerned that price dumping by China in the EU market has a negative impact on jobs, and this would worsen if China were to be unilaterally granted market economy status without meeting the objective criteria.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that granting market economy (ESA) status to China is not only extremely dangerous from an economic point of view, especially in view of the current state of the European continent's economy but has several legal and political problems, given that China, given the enormous interference of the state in the economy , is certainly not a market economy.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2001, the People's Republic of China has been a member of the WTO (World Trade Organisation) with the status of "economy in transition" and, therefore, not yet entitled to market economy status (ESO). From the point of view of trade defence, the Chinese system is generally inadequate for the recognition of the ESA. The central government, in fact, directs the economy with the aim of creating national champions. Companies, often under state control, have access to cheap raw materials and capital, thus altering trade flows and the competitive environment.  The main demands made in the resolution, which reiterates its opposition to the full granting of market economy status to China, are greater involvement of the other institutional actors, coordination with the main trading partners and the call for a different system for calculating dumping.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote is on the resolutions of the political groups on China's market economy (ESME) status. The issue of the ES MES revolves around the interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the world trade forum. It contains a section, Number 15, which is the subject of a full political and legal dispute. Thanks to this document, the WTO countries can treat imports from China as coming from a country that is not a market economy and, as a result, subject to much higher duties (about 30 % of the value of the product).  According to all observers, including Trade Commissioner Malmström, China has not become a market economy in the meantime. Despite this evidence, however, the importing countries of Northern Europe and the multinationals would very much like to see the Asian giant granted market economy status. This would mean that chinese products would be able to be charged much lower duties of around 6 %. However, a widespread network of small and medium-sized enterprises and workers' unions is working hard to avoid this dramatic hypothesis.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which opposes China's market economy status. I am strongly opposed to China's status as a market economy.  The country does not meet the five criteria of a market economy as defined by the World Trade Organization. There is therefore no reason for her to attain this status.  In addition, we must ensure that our companies compete fairly internationally. If China uses unfair processes to bring down prices, we must respond with appropriate trade defence instruments.  This resolution will make the European Parliament's voice heard in the Council of European Ministers, which will decide how to proceed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this motion for a resolution in order to avoid an unconditional recognition of China's status as a market economy. An unconditional opening of Europe to Chinese exports would give China the opportunity to offload its overproduction to the EU, invading the market with products at relatively low prices. Take, for example, that at present China's only overproduction of steel exceeds the total steel production of the entire European industry. I call on the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed in the EU by industry, trade unions and various stakeholders about the consequences for employment in the EU. Whatever decision the EU makes, it is necessary to think about a 'plan B' that includes equivalent trade defence measures that can counter unfair competition practices. The Commission must strengthen the effectiveness of its anti-dumping instrument in order to ensure a level playing field for european industry with China, in full compliance with WTO rules. I stress the importance of the EU's strategic partnership with China, in which trade and investment play an essential role, and I therefore call on the Commission to make proposals to protect Europe's interests by finding a third way that can find a solution that satisfies both sides.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution deals with trade between the EU and China, and specifically with the fact that at the end of 2016 the terms which China signed up to the World Trade Organisation in 2001 will expire and need to be re-evaluated. I disagree with the EU dictating to China how to run its economy – however, there are objective criteria agreed by WTO members as to what qualifies as a ‘market economy status’ for a state. This resolution stresses that China does not meet these five criteria. It reiterates the importance of trade between the EU and China while also acknowledging the concerns expressed by trade unions across Europe, particularly in relation to manufacturing and industries including steel, textiles, solar and chemical products. Unions are concerned that price dumping by China in the EU market has a negative impact on jobs, and this would worsen if China were to be unilaterally granted market economy status without meeting the objective criteria. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which was adopted on Thursday as I believe that China should not be granted market economy status since it does not as yet fulfil the relevant criteria. I nevertheless agree that China remains one of the most important EU partners and this decision does not make it less so.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 China has joined the World Trade Organization with a protocol that specifically regulates its status and treatment with other global trading partners. This protocol, which provided for the non-automatic recognition of China's market economy status, expired in January 2016, raising many concerns for single market member states. China is, in fact, the European Union's second largest economic partner, and the Member States have always sought to establish economic relations inspired by mutual respect and fair and fair cooperation. However, it notes that the Chinese economy is still characterised by strong government influence and a non-competitive situation among economic actors. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution in which Parliament urges the Commission to take due account of the concerns expressed in this regard and not to grant China market economy status.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on how to deal with imported products dumped from China on the European market. The message conveyed by this resolution is unequivocal: China cannot be granted market economy status to date. This status would require the EU to abandon its trade defence instruments against China, which is still far from meeting the required criteria. Indeed, Chinese aid for the export of certain products on the one hand, and unjustified restrictions on the export of raw materials on the other, strongly unbalance trade between the EU and China.  Moreover, the low protection of intellectual property rights in China promotes large-scale counterfeiting and in no way meets the expected standards of a market economy. The European Commission is due to vote on granting China market economy status by 11 December, when certain provisions of China's WTO accession protocol expire. I hope that it will follow the recommendations of the European Parliament.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully supported the proposed text of the resolution. Entire sectors and thousands of jobs are waiting to see in which direction our further reflections on the possible recognition of China's market economy status will lead. We are still lacking a plan for moving forward, so I expect the European Commission to present it to us shortly. I believe that the EU's interest must be to protect our domestic environment where it faces unfair competitive pressures or unfair trade practices that do not belong to international trade. We need to keep the possibility of applying safeguard trade measures in the EU at least at the level that is the case today. Furthermore, I consider it essential that we coordinate the eu procedure closely with our main trading partners, such as the US, Canada and Japan.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and reiterate the importance of an EU strategic partnership with China, in which trade and investment play an important role, and which should be based on reciprocity and mutual benefits.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on China's market economy status is a further step in the development and strengthening of Europe's economic ties with that state. As the existence of thorough forecasts and structures in relations between the two sides will form the basis for fruitful activities, I believe that such resolutions are legitimate and positive. I have therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring China's market economy status would make it easier for china to trade and thus allow its products to circulate in our Common European Market with greater freedom. I voted in favour of this report in order to express my disagreement with releasing this market economy status to China. I believe that it is too dangerous not only for Europe but above all for Italy, since China's products do not most of the time meet our quality and safety standards in production. I believe that China must first guarantee a better level of human rights and protection at work, as well as greater reciprocity with European products. My intention is to defend the Italian economy against the threat of unfair competition that is too strong, which is why I voted in favour, in order to deny them this status. Before allowing trade partnerships, it is essential that there are fair commercial bases in full compliance with our European standards that best protect the quality, traceability and safety of our products, which are so envied in the world.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ It is important that we take due account of the concerns expressed by EU industry, trade unions and other stakeholders as to the consequences for EU jobs, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth in all the manufacturing sectors affected and for EU industry as a whole, and ensure, in this context, that EU jobs are defended.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 When China joined the WTO, a specific dumping calculation methodology was envisaged, which was included in Section 15 of the Protocol of Membership, in which China undertook, inter alia, to allow all its prices to be determined by market relations, and the EU should ensure that China fully fulfils its WTO obligations. To this end, the Commission should coordinate with the EU's main trading partners how best to ensure that all provisions of Section 15 of China's WTO Protocol of Membership remain in force after 2016. At the same time, as long as China does not meet the 5 criteria imposed by the EU in order to be considered a market economy, the EU should use the exceptional methodology in the context of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations into Chinese imports. I therefore agree that the EU should carry out a general reform of the EU's trade defence instruments in order to ensure that its industry has a level playing field with China and other trading partners, in full compliance with WTO rules.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament took a strong position on trade policy, deciding not to submit to Chinese pressure and asking the Commission to conduct trade negotiations with the country of the Rising Sun without being conditioned by deadlines (December 2016) and unilateral positions. China's market economy status cannot be recognised because it has not yet carried out reforms to meet the five criteria required by the European Union. With the resolution voted on here today, we have defended our industrial sector, which could have suffered serious economic, social and environmental repercussions, as demonstrated by the recent negative impact that the steel sector has already had on unfair Chinese competition. In order to relaunch European trade policy, we need to protect our businesses through fair trade relations based on mutual respect and fair cooperation.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recognizing China's market economy status would have very serious consequences for Europe and its industry. One of the fundamental problems with China's recognition of market economy (ESME) status is that it opens up to 'downward' negotiations on European standards and principles. Negotiations on recognition in the WTO will be conducted by the European Commission and the final decision will have to be approved in Strasbourg by the European Parliament and the Council (the Member States). We therefore have the right to oppose the granting of ESA status to China if we all put the right pressure on the various political groups and governments of the Member States. Steel, mechanics, chemistry, ceramics, bolting, paper, footwear, textiles, furniture, are some of the sectors put at risk by the recognition of the ESA to China. In view of the very important problems that the recognition of market economy status would entail, I am voting against it. It is essential that the European Parliament bases trade relations on a fair basis, in full compliance with WTO rules, on mutual respect. I voted against the resolution before us.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
