text: in writing. – As I have highlighted with the vote in the amendments, I consider it necessary to have a firm position against the Commission's intention to proceed, after 2016, with further liberalisation of trade with China. The joint motion submitted to the vote, despite recognising that the current situation would not support such a procedure, merely repeats the Commission's argument. It thus endorses poor public consultation and leaves the door fully open to eliminating anti-dumping protection in exchange for privatizations and deregulations in the Chinese economy. We cannot defend economic interference in China, nor an intensification of global competition that would seriously harm social and environmental standards in industry and the jobs it generates in Europe. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the idea of recognizing China's market economy status. Aggressive economic policies, based on subsidies and dumping, are still being promoted in the country, which violate the rules of the free market and put our businesses and our productive fabric in great difficulty. The government finances entire production sectors, allowing the export of products at significantly lower costs than the real ones. A practice of unfair competition that is insidious and harmful to other economies, which are invading goods at prices outside any market logic. All this puts the European productive fabric in great difficulty, damaging its deepest roots, especially in states such as Italy, which has always based its capacity for growth on the development of manufacturing. First of all, we must ensure that China respects the essential rules of international trade and transparency in economic relations. Only in this way will it be possible to build solid cooperation relationships that are beneficial to our economy and that of China.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 On 11 December 2016, Chapter 15(a) (ii) of the Protocol on China's accession to the WTO will expire. The exact legal effect of this phenomenon remains unclear and is the subject of serious debate among industry experts. Both the Commission and the Parliament of Legal Services provide for changes in the functioning of European anti-dumping law, in particular as regards the methodology used to determine the so-called normal value, anadjumen in anti-dumping investigations.  Instead of specifying the legal changes that may result from the expiry of Section 15(a) (ii), I believe that it is worth supporting the 4 basic principles that should accompany a possible Commission decision on this matter.  1. the need to ensure full compliance with EU law of the EU's obligations under its WTO obligations, 2. the need to take into account not only the effects of the expiry of the abovementioned heading, but also to take into account those provisions that will remain after 11 December 2016, 3. ensuring that the EU remains a decisive player in solving problems and taking important decisions, 4. any legislative proposal should be based on a thorough assessment and recognition not only of the legal aspects of each decision , but in the medium to long term economic, social, industrial and strategic impacts. In view of the above-mentioned aspects, I voted yes.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution sets out the European Parliament's position on granting market economy status to the People's Republic of China, including a decision to be taken before December 2016. Having been a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) for 15 years, the People's Republic of China wants this status, which would allow it to significantly reduce anti-dumping measures against it.  With a large majority of my colleagues, I have spoken out against granting this status, as China does not currently meet the five criteria set by the WTO to comply with market economy status. I also believe that the Union must reform its trade defence instruments, in order to better protect European companies from external competition, and to ensure fair trade rules. At present, it is clear that granting China market economy status would lead to unfair competition from Chinese companies to Europeans. For these reasons, I opposed the granting of this status and voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which supports the idea that China is not a market economy because it does not meet the five European criteria for obtaining this status. Its exports to the European Union must therefore be treated in a "non-standard" manner for dumping and import subsidy investigations from China in order to determine price comparability. I also wish by this vote to protect the European economy and industry.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament, in its near-unanimity, considered that China, having clearly not become a market economy, could not claim to benefit from this status. Europe must be able to continue to impose anti-dumping duties as a deterrent and our producers must feel that they are truly protected from China's unfair trade behaviour. Europe must also strengthen its trade defence instruments, and develop a genuine European industrial strategy geared towards the areas of the future. Finally, on this very political issue, Europe will have to speak with one voice.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. The resolution on China's market economy status must be a clear message to national governments and the European Commission.  Indeed, like many other Members, I would like to stress that China does not meet the European criteria of a market economy at all and therefore cannot claim that status. I would like to point out the danger of 'dumping' that our economy and European workers face if we do not put in place effective trade defence mechanisms.  In addition, we must take into account the refusal of our major trading partners, the United States, Canada and Japan, to grant China market economy status. I therefore hope that the European Union will be coherent with its partners by not granting this status to China either.  Finally, I voted in favour of this resolution, because it is a strong signal to the Member States, which must now take a strong stand, so as not to sacrifice the european Union's economy.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Section 15(a) of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO sets out the rules applicable to China in the anti-dumping procedure and the dumping limits to be applied in the proceeding. This provision expires in December 2016 after a 15-year 'grace period'. Therefore, the EU, as a WTO Member State, must also decide what rules it will apply in the internal market in relation to chinese products to be imported, and more specifically whether China has met the five WTO criteria for the acceptance of a State a part as a market economy.  The European People's Party is united in the fact that China is not a market economy, as it has, among other things, an official influence on the pricing of its products for each export. Steel products and solar panels are particularly sensitive products for the EU. The joint ALDE-PPE-S&D-ECR-Verts/ALE decision confirms this position and I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I have signalled my opposition to granting China market economy status, which would prevent the European Commission from opposing anti-dumping measures against Chinese products.  China remains a largely subsidized economy that keeps sales prices artificially low, combined with a less-so-called social and environmental that the European Union cannot endorse. Moreover, such a decision would be catastrophic for certain industries. It is estimated that between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs are at risk in Europe. The situation is already critical in some sectors, particularly steel.  Rather than embarking headlong into ever-increasing liberalisation, the Commission must make proposals to strengthen and protect its own market. It must work to strengthen Europe's anti-dumping arsenal. This means strengthening trade defence instruments (IDCs) to increase applicable anti-dumping taxes, drastically shortening the time of investigations and simplifying complaints by opening up this possibility to trade union organisations.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. As things stand, I oppose any unilateral decision to grant China market economy status.  Although it is an important trading partner of the EU, China clearly does not meet the criteria of a market economy. I believe that until this is the case, its exports to the EU should be treated in a "non-standard" way in terms of dumping and subsidies. State subsidy, China's excess production capacity and the resulting reduced-price exports are already having very strong and very negative social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU. Currently, 56 of the EU's current 73 anti-dumping measures apply to imports from China. A change in the status of the Chinese economy would aggravate this situation.  I therefore call on the Commission to reach an agreement with the other major trading partners to find a balanced and WTO-compatible response. I also stress the urgent need for reform of the EU's trade defence instruments, in particular anti-dumping law.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. China is not a market economy as it does not meet the five criteria set by the EU for defining market economies. Granting China market economy status could have devastating consequences for the European market, for employment (3.5 million jobs would be lost) and a fall in GDP from 1 to 2%. Many manufacturing sectors would be affected, in particular steel, ceramics, textiles and technology. It is necessary to reformulate the Eu ropean Union's trade defence instruments in order to ensure a level playing field for EU industry with China and other trading partners, in accordance with WTO rules. One proposal would be to quantify the carbon content of products and to percentage it on VAT, a mechanism that would actually make European industries more competitive thanks to lower CO2 emissions from its production, compared to those of the Asian giant. I voted in favour.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. China should be denied market economy status or we will have to give up effectively combating the dumping of this economy. Nevertheless, I abstained on this text because it is very vague on a subject that is of great importance. For example, it calls for market economy status to be discussed at an EU-China summit, but it is a sovereign decision that is not intended to be negotiated with China.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 China as a sovereign state has chosen interventionism in the economy and trade, so the EU must resist any process that undermines the economic interests of its Member States. It should not recognise China as a market economy country and should not initiate the 'standard methodology' on imports of Chinese products into the Union.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 As long as China does not meet the five criteria imposed by the EU in order to be considered a market economy, an "exceptional methodology" should be used in relation to Chinese imports. It should be noted that 56 of the 73 anti-dumping measures currently in force in the EU relate to imports from China. Any decision on how to deal with Chinese imports must ensure that European law complies with WTO rules. I also agree that China's overcapacity is already having important social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU and, even in terms of employment in the EU, the social effects of granting China market economy status could be substantial.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Abstention: the text is too vague, it calls for China's market economy status to be discussed at an upcoming EU-China summit.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This is an issue that goes far beyond the trade issue, inseparable from the complex process of resuming forces at the global level, China's role in this process and the relations between the transatlantic bloc and China. The EU has linked five criteria to the definition of the concept of "market economy". China currently meets one of these criteria. We accept neither the preponderance of the concept in defining the rules (or absence thereof) governing international trade, nor the criteria which the EU has decided to associate with it. We advocate regulated trade in the interests of the peoples, not a deregulated trade, which tends to level down living and working conditions – an objective pursued by the WTO. We believe that each country should sovereignly define its trade policy according to its specific interests. The whole logic of this resolution's argument treats the impacts of trade with China as if the EU were a homogeneous bloc. Right. On the other hand, the EU institutions are given the power to decide on the level of trade relationship, which is an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States, which are held hostage to commitments that they do not negotiate and that go against the national interest, such as Portugal.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution against the recognition of market economy status for China. While we agree with the need for the EU to explore new trade opportunities, it is clear that there is no free market in China. The State intervenes heavily to determine the prices of goods, and to totally condition the market. Entire sectors of the European economy, from steel to textiles to footwear, are already suffering from huge quantities of cheap Chinese products, and currently granting this status would be the death blow to thousands of European companies and their workers.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The ever-increasing increase in cheap and lower-quality goods from South and South-East Asia, particularly in the steel sector, is causing significant economic losses not only to European producers, but mainly to alarming job cuts. First of all, it is the duty of the European Union and its political leaders to protect its citizens, including from the economic disadvantages of current globalisation. Any non-solution to the problem threatens employment in the regions and thus the social rights of European citizens. The main task of the European institutions at present is to actively hit and restrict the import of cheap goods so as not to further endanger workers, jobs and social protection and stability in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against all the reports on China's market economy status as China, as a sovereign state, has chosen to intervene in the economy and trade, so the EU must resist any process that undermines the economic interests of its Member States.  It should not recognise China as a market economy country and should not initiate the 'standard methodology' on imports of Chinese products into the Union.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as though I will support the Commission in ensuring continued compliance with WTO law, I oppose any proposal that will change EU anti-dumping law to the detriment of the EU’s ability to tackle anti-competitive market practices which in turn may injure EU industry, such as steel in the UK.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation abstained on Amendment No 7 of the EFDD, as the resolution already clearly states that the European Parliament is opposed to recognition of market economy status for China until the 5 criteria of the European Union are met. The S&D Group has taken the lead on this issue from the outset and has finally managed to anchor the debate on China on the agenda for the plenary session and to adopt a strong resolution. It was therefore very important for the Social Democrats to receive the widest possible support for this resolution – but this would have jeopardised support for Amendment No 7.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The issue of market economy status (MES) for China is a key topic of current interest in the European Parliament. We must therefore engage in a transparent and cooperative process that leads to a successful and mutually acceptable outcome. I strongly believe that any decision on MES should be based on a solid and comprehensive impact assessment in order to evaluate the consequences on jobs and sustainable growth in all EU sectors. There is an evident need for the EU to maintain an effective anti-dumping instrument mechanism that takes the real market situation in China into account. We need to be united in the fight for balanced and reciprocally beneficial EU-hina relations. Our demands and proposals will ensure that fair conditions are upheld in the European Union’s trade policy towards China, and that there will be no automatism which could put European jobs at risk.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 As China is the EU's second largest trading partner and the EU is China's first trading partner, the promotion of the strategic partnership is of the utmost importance. Trade and investment have a key role to play in this respect, based on mutual benefit. However, we must be true to the rules and, until China fulfils the five criteria set by the EU, it cannot be considered a market economy. Furthermore, it is necessary to ensure that the Union industry can act as an equal partner with China in full accordance with WTO rules and to ensure that any method used effectively protects the Union industry against dumped imports from the PRC. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. The EU and China do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments, as well as an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account the distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria established by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution, led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority, raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's resolution we have reiterated our strong and clear no to the granting of market economy status to China. China is not a market economy. It's undeniable. As a Delegation from Forza Italia, we have said this on several occasions in recent months and we will continue to repeat it, as we have done with today's important resolution, for which we have played a decisive role. It is now up to the Commission to take measures to defend our companies against unfair Chinese competition. We cannot afford to substantially and irreversibly weaken the instruments available to companies, especially SMEs, to protect themselves from unfair Chinese competition. A weakening of our trade defence instruments would risk being particularly penalising for Italy, both from the point of view of competitiveness and from the point of view of employment. The Commission shows that it is at the side of European SMEs, workers and entrepreneurs and defends the principle of genuine and fair competition.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament expresses a strong position against the risks of commercial and social dumping that Chinese competition could represent. I support the text negotiated by the political groups; A joint effort to accompany globalisation and international trade by including high standards of social protection and respect for rights is important.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative joint resolution on eu-China relations and market economy status, because I strongly supported the need, which the S&D Group has expressed, to open a public debate on this issue, which is important and straight for the future of the European Union, industry and European workers. China is not a market economy at present, because it meets only one of the five criteria laid down in the wto's international trade regulation. In addressing this problem, the rules of international trade go hand in hand with those of labour protection, European industry, particularly manufacturing industry, with the protection of consumer rights. It would, however, be as small-sighted as it is harmful if, in dealing with the same, we were to take account only of the needs of the latter to the detriment of the workers. Because then we would end up endorsing phenomena such as social and environmental dumping and unfair competition. Europe needs a genuine European industrial policy more than ever, and that is the crux of the problem. It needs it not to protect itself, but to recreate sustainable conditions of growth and development and to continue to play a leading role in world trade.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on China's market economy status. The text identifies the problem of intolerable price dumping - especially in the steel sector. China's behaviour has nothing in common with a market economy. We are talking about highly subsidised products, which are now seriously distorting the world market price and threatening jobs in Europe.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution. Indeed, the recognition of the Chinese economy as a market economy at the moment will entail a sharp decline in the competitiveness of European industry. China is not yet fully a market economy, as the state subsidises some of its private companies there, applying rules that are difficult to reconcile with free market rules and deliberately undercuts export prices. The resulting high level of China's production capacity results in low-cost exports of industrial products to European Union countries. China's exports of cheap steel from state-owned steel mills in the Land of the Rising Sun could seriously hit hundreds of thousands of European steel workers whose jobs could be at risk. Europe will need time to adapt its economy to strong Chinese competition. Believing that China will continue to be a great partner of the EU, I am in favour of submitting a draft of new but fair anti-dumping legislation as soon as possible. The Union should make it clear to its Chinese partner that recognising its economy as a market economy is nevertheless a process, not a one-off and one-time act.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The strategic partnership with China as the second largest trading partner is of enormous importance. The market creates new jobs and promotes economic growth.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. China is a very large and ancient nation, which has made remarkable economic progress since it allowed the development of individual enterprise, and abandoned the absurd planning of the Mao-Tse-Toung era. But can it be described as a market economy when it fulfils only one of the five criteria defined by the European Union? Its economy remains largely managed and subsidized. The artificial use of the exchange rate of its currency remains a commercial weapon. But Europe in Brussels is hesitant, despite the millions of jobs at stake and the survival of entire industrial sectors. One country is afraid for its own exports, another for investment promises, and another for the vitality of its ports. International trade can only develop in a certain degree of equality. China knows this better than anyone, since it was a victim, at the time of the unequal treaties, of Western economic imperialism, especially Anglo-Saxon, and of open door policy. Achieving this equity requires that the social protection, wage levels, working conditions and trade union freedoms of Chinese workers be closer to ours. Industrial property must also be guaranteed and protected from undue infringement. That is not yet the case; we hope that progress will be made in this direction.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation abstained on Amendment No 7 of the EFDD, as the resolution already clearly states that the European Parliament is opposed to recognition of market economy status for China until the 5 criteria of the European Union are met. The S&D Group has taken the lead on this issue from the outset and has finally managed to anchor the debate on China on the agenda for the plenary session and to adopt a strong resolution. It was therefore very important for the Social Democrats to receive the widest possible support for this resolution – but this would have jeopardised support for Amendment No 7.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention in considering possible recognition as a market economy to China a threat to millions of jobs in the European Union. We consider the resolution to be ambiguous because it does not clearly urge the European Commission not to grant this recognition to China. We tabled two amendments which called on the Commission to do the same in a very concrete way, but unfortunately they were rejected in plenary.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. State dirigisme, price fixing, voluntary overproduction, currency manipulation... all these elements show us that 15 years after its accession to the World Trade Organization, China is objectively not a market economy. Is it worth remembering that three quarters of Europe's anti-dumping measures concern China? That the EU has introduced 54 punitive taxes on products subsidised by the Chinese state and sold below their cost price? The choice that the Union must make is therefore not technical, but it is genuinely political and leads us to reflect on the future of our trade policy. To grant this status to China is to condemn many European industries already weakened by this unfair competition. To grant this status is to deprive us of fair anti-dumping measures that respond to illegal practices under international trade law. To grant this status is to finally give in to Chinese pressure and to make an admission of great political weakness. I therefore voted strongly in favour of this resolution, with the aim of sending a strong signal to the Member States that they should modernise our trade defence instruments and stop fearing any economic reprisals from China.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution calling on the Commission and the Council not to grant market economy status to China until the Chinese economy is one where supply, demand and prices of goods and services are determined by the market. China is not a market economy and should not be recognised as one when calculating anti-dumping sanctions. Granting them market economy status in the current circumstances would tighten the noose around the UK steel industry’s neck. We urgently need to modernise our trade defence measures and should not be afraid to use all the tools at our disposal to protect European industries against dumping and other harmful trade practices. The British Government must realise that the current crisis is linked to their inaction at EU level. The Commission and governments must listen and act, and do so now, while we still have a steel industry.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. China believes that under the WTO accession protocol, Europe must recognise it as a market economy by the end of 2016. But the position of the French Socialists is unambiguous. As our vote proved, this request is not current.  The Chinese state plays a significant role in its economy, notably through subsidies. It therefore has massive overcapacity that makes it capable of flooding its products with the world market. Granting China market economy status would be tantamount to removing the majority of anti-dumping measures that are in force today. Europe's trade defences would be greatly weakened, which would be dramatic for European industry. In total, between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs would be at risk in Europe and a potential decline in European GDP of 2 to 3% would be expected.  From a legislative point of view, China does not meet four of the five criteria for defining a market economy established by the EU.  To deny this status to China is also to defend European citizens, to defend workers, consumers who must be able to trust Europe.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. The best option would be to find a legal solution to satisfy the WTO legal requirements but at the same time amend the legislation, securing the ability to continue using prices other than domestic ones for the calculation of normal value. This would head off legal challenges while retaining the TDI flexibility. The Commission should come up with a balanced proposal that will take account of the EU’s legal obligations within the WTO, and at the same time find the way to mitigate negative consequences for our industry.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. There are still many uncertainties about how the EU will act when the exemption in China's WTO accession protocol expires later this year. It is up to the Commission to present in its impact assessment convincing options for protecting European industry, while avoiding a trade war with China. We Swedish Social Democrats believe that it is only when we have seen the Commission's analysis and proposals for measures that we can take a position on this issue. We therefore chose to abstain.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Section 15(a) of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO sets out the rules applicable to China in the anti-dumping procedure and the dumping limits to be applied in the proceeding. This provision expires in December 2016 after a 15-year 'grace period'. The EU, as a WTO Member State, must decide what rules it will apply in the internal market to chinese products to be imported, specifically whether China has met the five WTO criteria for adopting a State as a market economy. The European People's Party is united in the fact that China is not a market economy, as it has, among other things, an official influence on the pricing of its products for each export. Steel products and solar panels are particularly sensitive products for the EU. The joint ALDE-PPE-S&D-ECR-Verts/ALE decision confirms this position and I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ While China is a valued and extremely important trading partner for the European Union, it is not yet a market economy. The five criteria established by the EU to determine whether a state has market economy status have not been fulfilled. As China does not meet the EU’s five criteria required to qualify as a market economy, the EU should be able to use a non-standard methodology in anti-dumping investigations into Chinese imports for the purpose of determining price comparability. Furthermore there should be effective trade defence instruments that guarantee a level playing field with China for EU industry in compliance with WTO rules. For these reasons I have voted in favour of the motion.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no objection to its contents.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. If companies sell their products below the cost of production in order to push existing competition out of the market, then this is "dumping". In order to prevent this method of foreign competition, the EU may adopt anti-dumping measures. Such anti-dumping duties are calculated in the case of market-based countries of origin on the difference in prices between the home and export markets. If the exporting state is not a market economy, other methods can be used to estimate the cost of production. This is how higher anti-dumping duties are likely to be imposed. According to the common interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the WTO, the EU must recognise China's market economy status at the end of the year and thus have to apply lesser anti-dumping in order not to violate WTO directives. ALFA stands for the rule of law – the EU must also adhere to international agreements itself. I am therefore voting against this report.  However, there are sectors in China (particularly steel) where production costs are well below the cost of production, allowing for a cut throat competition in the EU. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Member States address the problem in a timely manner and obtain an alternative WTO-compliant method of appropriate anti-dumping measures. Anti-dumping must not be used as a protectionist tool – European companies should prove themselves in international and fair competition.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Section 15(a) of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO sets out the rules applicable to China in the anti-dumping procedure and the dumping limits to be applied in the proceeding. This provision expires in December 2016 after a 15-year 'grace period'. Therefore, the EU, as a WTO Member State, must also decide what rules it will apply in the internal market in relation to chinese products to be imported, and more specifically whether China has met the five WTO criteria for the acceptance of a State a part as a market economy.  The European People's Party is united in the fact that China is not a market economy, as it has, among other things, an official influence on the pricing of its products for each export. Steel products and solar panels are particularly sensitive products for the EU. The joint ALDE-PPE-S&D-ECR-Verts/ALE decision confirms this position and I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint proposal for a resolution on china's market economy status, as it represents a compromise between most political groups in the European Parliament. China is an important trade and strategic partner of the European Union and it is therefore necessary to ensure fair and free trade that complies with the principles of the World Trade Organisation and the principles of the European Union. It should be stressed that China is not yet a market economy and that it has not met the EU criteria for determining whether an economy is a market economy. It is also necessary to take into account the potential consequences of partnerships on jobs in the Union, on industry, the environment, and on other affected manufacturing sectors in order to fully guarantee and protect the INTERESTS of the EU.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. China considers that it is entitled to automatically receive market economy status and, above all, not to suffer strong anti-dumping duties. Our group has proposed a resolution calling for China not to be granted market economy status and to strengthen our trade defence mechanisms. With this in mind, I abstained on this text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 In December this year, the transitional measure for calculating China's dumping ends and the EU therefore needs strong instruments to protect its market from Chinese dumped products. That is also why I voted in favour of this resolution. Fair price comparability and a level playing field for our industry are needed. The result should be a balanced proposal that takes into account both the interests of heavy industry and importers and shippers in need of access to foreign products.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: in writing. In the resolution on the granting of the Statute of Market Economy to China, EHBildu's position has been abstention. Measures against economic, social and environmental dumping are necessary to protect labour rights and the environment, not only in trade relations with China, but also with any other country. Otherwise, the impact on the economy itself is severe, as we are seeing in the steel sector in Euskal Herria. However, trade relations, under the rules of the World Trade Organization, follow neo-liberal guidelines that, for the sake of free competition, impede any action by the public authorities in favour of the strategic productive sectors of countries and therefore impede the defence of employment and labour and social rights in our countries. The motion for a resolution does not make a strong defence of the productive sectors affected in Europe, and accepts the neo-liberal free competition scheme, even if, in this case, it relucts China to grant the Statute of Market Economy.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution which reminds us that China does not meet the European criteria in order to obtain market economy status, which is why the EU should not recognise this status to China. Thousands of jobs are at stake. The EU must take a firm position in the face of unfair competition from China in certain sectors such as steel.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Writing. The SPÖ-EU delegation abstained on Amendment No 7 of the EFDD, as the resolution already clearly states that the European Parliament is opposed to recognition of market economy status for China until the 5 criteria of the European Union are met. The S&D Group has taken the lead on this issue from the outset and has finally managed to anchor the debate on China on the agenda for the plenary session and to adopt a strong resolution. It was therefore very important for the Social Democrats to receive the broadest possible support for this resolution – but this would have jeopardised support for Amendment No 7.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Automatic recognition of the market economy status of the People's Republic of China would lead to enormous problems and massive job losses for European industry and tens of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises. Anti-dumping instruments would be much more difficult to use. A market distortion with a negative impact on employment, growth and innovation, especially in key European industries, would then be inevitable. I am therefore voting against the proposal tabled, because it is far too softly worded, does not take a clear stance and is only reluctant to support a refusal to grant China market economy status.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the resolution on granting Market Economy Status to China. It cannot be denied that China is a very important trading partner for the European Union and that a way for the EU to comply with the international agreement within the WTO must be found. However, in my view, it is very important to realise that China still does not meet 4 out of 5 points defining the market economy. At present, the EU applies most anti-dumping measures directly to China. The EU's responsible authorities should ensure that in the future there are legal instruments in which the EU can protect its producers against anti-dumping, while respecting international obligations. A striking example is the EU steel industry, which is very concerned about granting market economy status to China, because the situation in the sector is not easy. Producers are concerned about the economic growth of the sector if EU producers are not provided with legal protection. Already, EU producers have to meet high EU requirements in various areas, such as environmental requirements that limit the capacity of industry in the EU, but China does not have such high environmental requirements. As a a backd up, the EU steel industry is already in a slightly weaker position and is more difficult to compete. By giving China market economy status, we must not put EU producers at a disadvantage.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. China is clearly not fulfilling the needed five criteria established by the EU marking the status of a market economy. The state interference with the economy regarding prices, costs, outputs and inputs is not in line with a well-functioning market economy. Further, the EU Trade Defence Instruments legislation is still blocked in the Council. It is one thing to pursue economic relations with China, but we have to first and foremost think of our citizens, of European jobs and industry. TDI must be in place to protect the jobs and our industry in the EU. The dramatic developments in the steel industry are a good example of what can happen without proper trade defence instruments in place.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution calling on the Commission and the Council not to grant market economy status to China until the Chinese economy is one where supply, demand and prices of goods and services are determined by the market. China is not a market economy and should not be recognised as one when calculating anti-dumping sanctions. Granting them market economy status in the current circumstances would tighten the noose around the UK steel industry’s neck. We urgently need to modernise our trade defence measures and should not be afraid to use all the tools at our disposal to protect European industries against dumping and other harmful trade practices. The British Government must realise that the current crisis is linked to their inaction at EU level. The Commission and governments must listen and act, and do so now, while we still have a steel industry.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. If companies sell their products below the cost of production in order to push existing competition out of the market, then this is "dumping". In order to prevent this method of foreign competition, the EU may adopt anti-dumping measures. Such anti-dumping duties are calculated in the case of market-based countries of origin on the difference in prices between the home and export markets. If the exporting state is not a market economy, other methods can be used to estimate the cost of production. This is how higher anti-dumping duties are likely to be imposed. According to the common interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the WTO, the EU must recognise China's market economy status at the end of the year and thus have to apply lesser anti-dumping in order not to violate WTO directives. ALFA stands for the rule of law – the EU must also adhere to international agreements itself. I am therefore voting against this report.  However, there are sectors in China (particularly steel) where production costs are well below the cost of production, allowing for a cut throat competition in the EU. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Member States address the problem in a timely manner and obtain an alternative WTO-compliant method of appropriate anti-dumping measures. Anti-dumping must not be used as a protectionist tool – European companies should prove themselves in international and fair competition.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Section 15(ii)(a) of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO lays down the rules applicable to China in the anti-dumping proceeding and the dumping limits to be applied in the proceeding. This provision expires in December 2016 after a 15-year 'grace period'. Therefore, the EU, as a WTO Member State, must also decide what rules it will apply in the internal market in relation to chinese products to be imported, and more specifically whether China has met the five WTO criteria for the acceptance of a State a part as a market economy.  The European People's Party is united in the fact that China is not a market economy, as it has, among other things, an official influence on the pricing of its products for each export. Steel products and solar panels are particularly sensitive products for the EU. The joint ALDE-PPE-S&D-ECR-Verts/ALE decision confirms this position and I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The baking proposal for China's market economy status is a current issue. When China entered the WTO, it did not yet have market economy status. She was therefore given the opportunity to change her status in 15 years. In the end, however, China has not yet reached the point of meeting all five criteria set by the European Union for economic status. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal, which aims to point out to China that it still has to make an effort in the EU to protect its market and its companies.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 China is and remains an important strategic and commercial partner for Europe, but it is not a market economy. And it will not be until it has met the five criteria set by the EU that define market economies. We have thus expressed our opinion, almost unanimously, by adopting this resolution, which, although not legislative, will serve as a guideline for the Commission in the presentation of its proposal. Our aim is to safeguard European companies from unfair competition and possible dumping that would have repercussions not only on our economy but also on the environment and social. That is why we have asked the Commission to exclude the automatic recognition of China's market economy status and to maintain the current anti-dumping measures, in accordance with WTO rules. Finally, we called on the Council to reach an agreement quickly with Parliament on the modernisation of the European Union's trade defence instruments.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The EU and China are two of the biggest traders in the world. China is the EU’s second largest trading partner and the world’s second fastest growing economy. Having regard to that, it is of great importance for us to develop bilateral relations between the EU and China. However, EU-China trade relations should be based on mutual respect and fair cooperation, in full compliance with WTO rules and fundamental human rights. The Chinese economy should not be granted economy status because it does not fulfil the five EU criteria.  Unfortunately, so far the Chinese economy is still largely controlled by the state and the government does not provide effective legal framework to protect individual property rights (including intellectual property rights). In addition, the Chinese Government usually uses its power to supress people’s labour, civil and human rights. The EU has a responsibility to ensure the inclusion of labour and human rights (especially intellectual property rights) in its trade with China. On the other hand, the Chinese Government should leave the market alone, because market liberalisation in practice improves ties among nations, increases a country’s wealth and promotes human rights. In fact, market liberalisation is the only path to a normally functioning market economy and fulfilment of the five EU criteria.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on China's market economy status. China has been a member of the WTO since 2001. It is rightly not considered a market economy. This allows the EU to impose very strong but logical anti-dumping measures in an industry, especially when a Chinese industrial sector exports its surplus below cost. 80% of EU imports that were investigated by the European Commission over dumping or subsidies came from China. China's economy has huge production overcapacity, particularly in commodities such as steel, due to the sharp slowdown in some Chinese domestic markets over the past two years. China must be denied market economy status, otherwise we will no longer have effective anti-dumping instruments, as the ELN Group has made clear in its own resolution.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Market economy status is made up of five criteria ranging from the independence of markets from the state to the existence of a transparent and non-discriminatory corporate law. China, which has been a member of the WTO (World Trade Organization) since 2001, meets only one of the criteria. As the country has not been granted market economy status, the EU can strongly curb Chinese exports by applying anti-dumping measures. Indeed, China has such capacity for overproduction that it tries to sell surplus stocks to other domestic markets. However, it is actively working to obtain this recognition from the EU, which will enable it to invade our markets with its low-cost products. I agree with our group's proposal to deny China market economy status and strengthen our trade defence mechanisms. I logically voted for this resolution. On the other hand, I abstained for the text of the joint resolution, that of the GUE, Greens, S and D and EPP groups. I voted against those of the ALDE and ECR.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'Our delegation supports this joint resolution on China's market economy status. We expressly note that the country does not yet meet the five criteria for market economies established by the EU. Until this is met, China cannot be granted market economy status.  The country plans to be officially recognised as a market economy by the World Trade Organisation (WHO) in December. This would make it much more difficult to continue the current European approach to Chinese dumping policy. The calculation of dumping duties on the basis of internal Chinese prices will still not yield market prices. The lack of competition on a level playing field for our European producers could therefore potentially mean a severe loss for jobs and prosperity in the EU. China does not function today as a fully fledged, free market and cannot be granted market economy status. We ask the Commission to take this into account in the run-up to its proposal and after taking note of the economic impact analysis. We also call for accelerated modernisation of European trade defence instruments in order to keep European industry competitive with its trading partners.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. As I have highlighted with the vote in the amendments, I consider it necessary to have a firm position against the Commission's intention to proceed, after 2016, with further liberalisation of trade with China. The joint motion submitted to the vote, despite recognising that the current situation would not support such a procedure, merely repeats the Commission's argument. It thus endorses poor public consultation and leaves the door fully open to eliminating anti-dumping protection in exchange for privatizations and deregulations in the Chinese economy. We cannot defend economic interference in China, nor an intensification of global competition that would seriously harm social and environmental standards in industry and the jobs it generates in Europe. That's why I voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. If companies sell their products below the cost of production in order to push existing competition out of the market, then this is "dumping". In order to prevent this method of foreign competition, the EU may adopt anti-dumping measures. Such anti-dumping duties are calculated in the case of market-based countries of origin on the difference in prices between the home and export markets. If the exporting state is not a market economy, other methods can be used to estimate the cost of production. This is how higher anti-dumping duties are likely to be imposed. According to the common interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the WTO, the EU must recognise China's market economy status at the end of the year and thus have to apply lesser anti-dumping in order not to violate WTO directives. ALFA stands for the rule of law – the EU must also adhere to international agreements itself. I am therefore voting against this report.  However, there are sectors in China (particularly steel) where production costs are well below the cost of production, allowing for a cut throat competition in the EU. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Member States address the problem in a timely manner and obtain an alternative WTO-compliant method of appropriate anti-dumping measures. Anti-dumping must not be used as a protectionist tool – European companies should prove themselves in international and fair competition.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I see protectionism behind the proposals on the so-called market status for China. Within the framework of international agreements, the EU has sufficient instruments to prevent anti-dumping or compensatory duties on imports of subsidised products or steel from China, if such subsidisation is demonstrated. But we cannot blame China for helping companies with government loans and artificially weakening the exchange rate when we do the same in Europe. Restricting imports can trigger a trade war, China can also restrict imports from Europe, and we will all pay for it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Trade transactions between the Union and China exceed EUR 1 billion. since 2015, Chinese foreign investment in Europe has outgrown European investment in China, a major boost for various European industries. However, the Union still applies a large number of safeguard trade mechanisms such as anti-dumping measures, safeguards and subsidised imports. The most common backstop trade mechanism are anti-dumping measures aimed at protecting the European Union market and domestic producers from cheap imports from China. Of the 73 anti-dumping measures currently in force in the EU, 56 apply to goods imported from China. I supported the proposal for a resolution in view of the fact that China's economy is the second largest in the world and the second largest trading partner of the European Union.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Eu-China trade is currently more than EUR 1 billion a day. Although China has undertaken to allow all its prices to be determined by the market, the disproportionate level of State interference in the Chinese economy makes prices and costs not reflect and respond to market supply and demand resulting in overproduction of production. China therefore does not meet the requirements of a market economy, which in the context of mutual trade ultimately damages the Union's market and economy and threatens millions of jobs. This is currently most affected by steel producers and the mining industry in the Union. I therefore support the proposal that the Commission should make every effort to fulfil China's obligations and that the EU use a non-standard methodology in determining price comparability in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations of imports from China, in accordance with the Protocol on China's accession to the WTO.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. At present, under EU law, China is not a market economy because it does not meet four of the five definition criteria.  Yet China, which is already flooding the global steel market - which it sometimes sells at prices below its production costs - aspires to this status.  The granting of status to China would prevent the European Union from resorting to the imposition of anti-dumping duties, and would necessarily cause considerable economic and social damage in Europe.  I therefore vote in favour of this resolution, which explicitly asks the Commission not to grant China market economy status, because Beijing does not meet the criteria for such a status. In these times of economic crisis and global competitive pressure, it is our duty to work to strengthen the EU's anti-dumping arsenal in order to preserve our economy from the aggressive policies of third countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on China's market economy regime, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/5/2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is complete and well documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on the joint resolution. Since 2001, China has been a member of the World Trade Organization but is not considered a market economy. This allows the EU to impose very strong anti-dumping measures on it. An effective trade defence must be put in place quickly, as there is still a legal risk that China will attack the EU in the WTO in order to prohibit the introduction of important anti-dumping duties. Recognising China's market economy status or changing methodology would potentially reduce anti-dumping duties from 44% to around 10%, deprive the EU of 90% of its anti-dumping measures, or even reduce European production by 2% of gross domestic product (GDP) per year. Between 1.7 and 3.5 million jobs could be at risk in Europe as early as 2020, including 183,300 to 366,800 in France; that is why we are going to submit a resolution asking that China not be granted market economy status and that we strengthen our trade defence mechanisms.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a resolution that responds to the Commission's intention to grant Market Economy Status to China. While I fully respect China's economic development, the size and strength of its economy, I do not believe that it is a market economy as we know it in a neoliberal sense. The state still has high powers to intervene in the economy. I do not believe that China meets the WTO conditions for granting such status. Last but not least, I am concerned about the fate of several tens of thousands of jobs in Europe as well as the possible emergence of raw material dependence and dependence on products from China, let us remember, for example, the completely liquidated footwear or textile sector in the Czech Republic under pressure from cheap imported products. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for this Parliament's resolution in which we advocate that as long as China does not meet the five criteria set by the EU to define a market economy, its exports must be treated differentiated. We must protect European producers, our industry, while respecting our obligations within the World Trade Organization, so we call on the Commission to put forward a proposal that balances both aspects.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Parliament has been able to make a strong and unambiguous voice heard by voting by a very large majority (over 500 votes in) a resolution that opposes China's granting of market economy status. This coveted status by Beijing (which believes it should receive it automatically at the end of 2016) would prevent the European Union from resorting to much of the anti-dumping instruments it currently opposes to unfair Chinese competition, which is already causing considerable social damage. Millions of jobs - in steel, ceramics, chemistry, electronics or toys - are directly or indirectly at risk. Under the decisive leadership of the Socialists and Democrats, the European Parliament has passed a resolution whose content is well within the urgency of the emergency. First, in advocating the maintenance of a "non-standard methodology", we have clearly called on the European Commission to join forces with our major trading partners (USA, Japan, India, etc.) to continue to protect itself from Chinese dumping. Finally, to national governments, we reiterated our call to strengthen our anti-dumping arsenal. Without it, whole sections of our industry are doomed to extinction.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the provisions set out in the EP resolution, which emphasise that China is not a market economy state. As long as it does not meet all five EU criteria required to be met in a market economy country, the EU should impose certain measures in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations on Chinese imports in order to compare prices. In its resolution, the EP also draws attention to the concerns expressed by EU industry, trade unions and other stakeholders about the consequences of China's economic policies on EU jobs, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution. China’s exports will be treated in a non-standard way until it meets the five criteria for market economy status; we need a level playing field for EU industry and jobs.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. China believes it is in a position to receive market economy status immediately, and to be able to evade strong anti-dumping measures. This is despite the threat to the steel industry as its overproduction of steel, in particular. According to the Trade Commissioner, it has only one of the five characteristics defining a market economy. To not oppose this status was to deprive ourselves of effective instruments against Chinese dumping. The ENL has tabled a motion against resolution. As a result, I voted in favour of the ENL's motion for a resolution denying China that this status should be granted and for measures to strengthen our trade defence mechanisms.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. China is one of the EU's most important trading partners and for EU trade relations. I followed the meaning of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution, which denies china the granting of market economy status. The EU has imposed five technical criteria for defining the market economy and, at the moment, China meets only one of those criteria. Preliminary estimates show that around 188,000 jobs could be lost in EU sectors currently affected by Chinese dumping if mitigation measures are not taken.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ It is essential that EU industries are protected from unfair trading practices. China as yet does not fulfil all of the necessary criteria to be considered as having this status and I therefore supported this cross-party resolution.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In 2001, China joined the WTO as a non-market economy. As it did not meet the criteria for a market economy, the accession protocol provided for several temporary derogations from WTO rules. By the end of 2016, these exemptions will expire. Many of them have already expired. But China is still not a market economy at the moment. It also meets only one of the five criteria defined by the EU. China is a key strategic partner for the EU. However, for it to remain so and for good relations to continue, we must ensure that the EU has the capacity to effectively combat unfair dumping practices. The European Commission will soon publish an impact assessment in this area. I am concerned about the negative impact that the end of the waivers will have on our economy. I therefore call on the Council to urgently define its position on the reform of European tools to combat dumping in the context of international trade. As a Liberal, I want to emphasize the importance of respect for the rules in a globalized economy. If they are not respected, we need to have effective tools to respond appropriately.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – China is the European Union's second largest trading partner and the Union is China's largest trading partner. Mutual trade amounts to over EUR 1 billion per day. Any decision on how products imported from China are treated after December 2016 must guarantee compliance of Union law with World Trade Organisation rules. In the context of China's accession to the World Trade Organisation, a specific methodology for calculating dumping was agreed. China's overcapacity in terms of production already has serious social, economic and environmental consequences for the Union, as evidenced by their current negative impact on the steel industry, and the social impact of granting market economy status in terms of jobs in the Union could also be significant. I consider it worth recalling that 56 of the 73 anti-dumping measures currently in force in the EU apply to Chinese imports and China is not a market economy and therefore the five criteria identified by the Union for establishing this status have not yet been met. I agree with the motion for a resolution in question.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Until China fulfils the EU’s criteria for market economy status, its exports to the EU must be treated with caution. The Commission should assess whether China’s costs and prices are market-based, so as to ensure a level playing field for EU industry and protect EU jobs. The Commission needs to listen to the concerns of EU industry, trade unions and stakeholders, about the possible consequences for jobs, the environment and economic growth in the EU. Therefore, I have voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution and against the idea of automatically granting China the status of a market economy. The resolution duly recognises the strong economic relations between EU and China and the importance of respecting international commitments, notably the provisions of China’s accession Protocol to the WTO, and I support this approach. At the same time, the EU legislation foresees clear criteria, which are not applied only to China, which guide the determination of whether a country can be considered or not a market economy. And China does not currently fulfil those criteria. Together with an overwhelming majority of my colleagues, I therefore call upon the Commission to take due account the interests of the EU as a whole and notably the need to defend EU jobs, ensure high environmental standards and promote sustainable economic growth.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject indicated, the EFDD, ENF, ALDE, PPE, S&D, GUE/NGL, ECR and Verts/ALE political groups tabled a motion for a parliamentary resolution. Among them, ALDE, PPE, S&D, ECR and Verts/ALE reached a compromise and developed a joint proposal. I voted in favour of the compromise motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. China has been a member of the WTO since 2001. It is not considered a market economy. This allows the EU to impose very strong but logical anti-dumping measures in an industry, especially when a Chinese industrial sector exports its surplus below cost. However, the clause defining the status of the Chinese economy in the WTO accession protocol expires at the end of 2016, meaning that the Chinese economy could be recognised as a market economy, which would deprive the EU of almost all of its anti-dumping measures.  This mistake by world and European leaders would have catastrophic consequences for European economies in general, and French in particular.  China's economy remains largely subsidized by the state, social protection and wage levels are paltry compared to those of European countries. It is therefore clear that patriotic elected officials are very strongly opposed to the recognition of China's status as a market economy.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 China is a strategic trading partner for the European Union, being its second largest trading partner, generating a turnover of over EUR 1 billion per day.  The Chinese state joined the World Trade Organisation in 2005, pledging to allow all prices to be determined by market conditions, so the EU must ensure that China complies with this obligation. However, there has been a state influence on the economy, distorting the signals that reflect supply and demand. To this end, I am voting in favour of the joint resolution signed by the EPP Political Group, because I believe that China must comply with its obligations because it is a member of the WTO.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The U.S. government has indicated that it will not grant China market economy status. Recognising China's market economy status or changing methodology would potentially reduce anti-dumping duties from 44% to about 10%. Experts estimate that by granting China market economy status, the EU would thus deprive itself of 90% of its anti-dumping measures. That is why I abstained in the vote on the joint resolution.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the granting of market economy status to China. The text reaffirms in very clear terms that China, whose economy is largely state-run, is ongoing dumping which harms European products, and does not yet meet the criteria of a market economy, which, as things stand, disqualifies it for obtaining status. According to several studies, granting China market economy status would reduce EU GDP by 2% and threaten between 1.5 and 4 million European jobs. It would also limit Europe's power to sanction China's forms of dumping. That is why I strongly oppose it.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on China's market economy status. I could not support the report, because we must not forget that china's dumping policy has also put the steel industry in a critical position in Slovakia. The Eastern Slovakian IronWorks is being offered for sale, and if the buyer is ultimately a Chinese group of investors, we will be able to see up close the concrete strategic benefits chinese state aid brings to China. Because the steel industry is a strategic industry, not only from a military point of view, but also from a commercial point of view: in the field of mechanical engineering, including the slovak-related automotive industry.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution following the evaluation made by my political group.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – China is an important economic partner for Europe. The country is a large market, with opportunities to deepen relations and realize more European goods on the Chinese market. I strongly believe that the trends of economic growth in the country create a prerequisite for more quality agricultural products such as organic products, but also for foods with geographical indications for the Chinese market.  At the same time, however, referring to opinions on the functioning of the Chinese market, I supported this resolution because I believe that the People's Republic should make further efforts to obtain market economy status. Still, strong state intervention and influence on the Chinese economy, as well as companies' decisions on prices, costs, output and raw materials, do not meet market signals. This in turn creates conditions for unfair competition in bilateral trade, and it poses dangers to the livelihoods of European producers and industries.  In this regard, I also supported this resolution, and in particular the call that, until China fulfils all five EU criteria in order to meet the definition of a market economy, the EU should adhere to the relevant provisions of the Protocol on China's accession to the WORLD And prepare a proposal for further steps in line with this principle.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the joint resolution on China's market economy status, because I believe that the current level of influence of the Chinese State on its economy, together with its production capacity, offers the possibility of offering dumping prices on the EU market, with multiple effects for the companies and economies of the Member States. At the same time, the importance of economic exchanges between the EU and China is very high for the industries of both economies. In this context, and in the context of the forthcoming G7 and G20 negotiations, I believe that a detailed analysis of the types and implications of the measures necessary to protect savings and jobs in the EU must be made.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution which states that China does not currently qualify for market economy status and must take this EU into account in its trade policy until it fulfils these conditions. From a legal point of view, the situation is quite complicated and therefore the content of the impact study that the Commission is expected to come up with in July will be important. In it, the Commission should also answer the question of how we will be able to use certain customs-type trade practices in the future in order to protect our market in cases where Chinese competition is not entirely fair. Moreover, in my view, it must be remembered that this is not only about the so-called granting of market status to China – which is not exactly an accurate description of the situation – but also about what the EU's trade relations with China will look like in the future. I stress that we must proceed quickly and effectively, for time is running out.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at this vote, I would have voted in favour of this report, because I believe that we must protect our European industry from cheap imports. As long as China does not meet the five EU criteria for market economy recognition, the European Union should continue to impose anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties on low-cost dumped imports from the country.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important that the EU continues to comply with its international commitments in the WTO, but in doing so, a way of ensuring that EU industry is protected from unfair trade must also be found.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 The trade relationship between the European Union and China is very intense. China is, in fact, the EU's second largest trading partner, while and the EU is China's main trading partner. Not to regard Beijing as a 'market economy' does not mean adopting a protectionist attitude towards this important partner; it simply means meeting the five criteria set by the EU for defining market economies. For China, these criteria, given the current level of state influence on the economy, are far from being met; The decisions of firms on prices, costs, production and factors of production do not respond to market signals reflecting supply and demand. According to the clause inserted at the time of the Asian giant's accession to the WTO, which authorises a specific methodology for calculating dumping, 56 of the 73 anti-dumping measures currently in force in the EU apply to Chinese imports. However, the WTO Protocol is ambiguous on the question of recognising market economy status at the end of 15 years. Action is therefore needed to protect European competition and to protect our companies from possible economic, social and environmental dumping. With this resolution, we are therefore calling on the Commission to exclude automatic recognition in the future proposal.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
