text: Writing. – The resolution calling on the Commission and the Council of the EU not to recognise Market Economy Status in China within the WTO and to take trade defence measures on Chinese imports into the EU, expresses the sharpening of the confrontation between the EU's monopolies and those of China, as well as more generally the monopolistic groups of the BRICS countries. This prospect is of serious concern to large monopolistic groups in the EU, particularly those active in manufacturing industries, such as the steel industry, where Chinese capitalist groups strengthen their position vis-à-vis their European Union counterparts. Competition is further complicated by intra-city opposition in the EU, with other parts of the capital looking to boost trade with China, looking forward to its large capitalist market. Monopolies, the EU, urban governments and parties, employers' and sold-out reformist trade unions are trying to cost the working class the interests of capitalists in the dispute with its competitors. However, the war between monopolies, the increase in their competitiveness, presupposes a greater break in the wage, labour and social rights of the working class. It is in the interest of the working class to raise its own flags, fighting to overthrow the power of monopolies, to become the owner of the wealth it produces.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On the question brought to the attention of this Parliament, namely whether or not to regard China as a market economy, I would like to stress that, although it has been part of the World Trade Organisation since 2001, it still does not meet the criteria underlying a competitive economy. In my opinion, particular attention deserves the anti-dumping measures that are currently in place, which are currently one of the few instruments that make it possible to support the production of European products and to avoid a loss of employment. I therefore believe it is necessary for the Commission to ensure that China undertakes to respect the rules of free trade. I would therefore support the position of my political group.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ When China became a member of the World Trade Organization in 2001, its economy was expected to grow into a market-driven economy by 2016. Although this has not happened, China is intensively promoting the idea of acquiring free market status. On the other hand, the EU has pledged that China will acquire this status by the end of this year and is obliged to fulfil its commitments. Granting this status will limit the possibility of imposing tariffs when importing Chinese goods into the European market, thereby boosting commodity exchanges. The European Union and China are among the world's largest trading powers. China is the European Union's second largest trading partner, while the EU is China's largest trading partner, with the value of their daily trade well exceeding €1 billion. Since the Chinese market is the main profit generator for a number of industries and brands from the European Union and therefore Croatia, I supported the adoption of this resolution.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 When, fifteen years ago, China joined the WTO, precise rules were established to prevent the economies of the other member countries of the organization from being penalised by unfair competition practices, implemented by Chinese producers. The forecast was that, by the end of 2016, China would become a market economy. Unfortunately, to date, China is a long way from implementing all the reforms necessary to be able to call itself a market economy. The rules protecting industry in other countries must therefore continue to apply. China's widespread and persistent practices of social, environmental and commercial dumping would jeopardise the future of the entire European manufacturing industry. Millions of jobs and a fundamental share of Europe's GDP are at stake. The S&D Group is in favour of free trade, but this presupposes that all companies compete on an equal footing. This is not a protectionist attitude, nor is this a vote against China. China, however, is not yet a market economy. I am happy to note that, despite the initial mistrust, all the main political groups have ultimately decided to join our position.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ China is the EU's second largest trading partner, while the EU is China's largest trading partner. China and the EU trade around a billion euros per day. Given the current level of state influence on the Chinese economy, it can be concluded that companies' price decisions, costs, etc., do not correspond to market signals that monitor supply and demand.  China's overcapping policy already has strong social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU, as can be seen for example in the EU steel industry, especially in the UK, and I believe that giving China market economy status could have significant negative social consequences for JOBS in the EU. I note that China is not a market economy and does not meet the five criteria defined by the EU set by non-market economies. I therefore call on the Commission that as long as China fails to meet all five criteria for market economy status, the EU should use non-standard methods with regard to measures against dumping and measures against State aid with regard to Chinese imports when determining price comparability, in accordance with paragraph 15 of the Chinese Association Protocol. In my view, the Commission must strengthen the effectiveness of anti-dumping measures to ensure a level playing field for EU industry in relation to Chinese industry, in line with World Trade Organisation rules.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 From the point of view of trade relations the question arises between whether or not they continue to put up barriers to a WTO member country. In this context it should be noted that, from the point of view of the EU integration process, what we are witnessing is the imposition of its federalist character and great economic power. The whole logic of the argument deals with the impacts of trade with China, as if the European Union of a homogeneous bloc were, and gives the European institutions the power to decide on the level of trade relationship, which is an attack on the sovereignty of Member States that are held hostage to commitments that do not negotiate and that go against the national interest. The resolution even states that the Commission should coordinate "this issue with the EU's main trading partners, in particular in the context of the upcoming G7 and G20 Summits". Member States, like Portugal, should be able to define their economic strategies and establish trade relations with other countries. It is not acceptable what, for example, the EU common market strategy has imposed on the country in this area, making it impossible for it to take measures to define special protections for the economy and national production. For the above the vote of abstention.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Regarding the possible granting of market economy status to China after December 2016, Parliament calls on the Commission to investigate as soon as possible the legal and economic consequences of adopting this methodological principle, primarily on the economic operators of the European Union. The EU, as a major partner of China, is obliged to respect the provisions of the common agreements, but must not leave the economic market unprotected. I therefore support the resolution, expressing the hope that the legal aspects of the Treaties with China are set up flexibly enough to protect the economy of the European Union and its Member States and that the future will bring about continued strong economic cooperation and mutual investment with China.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I am aware of the fact that trade between the People's Republic of China and the European Union amounts to an incredible EUR 1 billion per day, I take the view that China cannot be automatically promised market economy status at the end of 2016. China's production, which unfortunately cannot yet be described as a market economy, is already a significant problem for several economic sectors of the European Union, which could deteriorate further with the new status. While the strategic partnership between the European bloc and China is very important, it is equally important to maintain the principles of free and fair trade and investment. I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as China should receive market economy status, but this should only happen once all five conditions have been met. These conditions are not met today, so it is appropriate for the European Union to continue to apply a non-standard methodology for determining price comparability in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations on imports from China. It is also appropriate for the Commission, which is responsible for the European Union's trade policy, to coordinate its next steps in dealing with this case with its other trading partners.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On 11 December 2016, the member countries of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) must decide whether to grant China the so-called market economy status (ESA). Such recognition would allow the Asian giant access to all markets regulated by the WTO. The debate requested this week, with the vote on motions for resolutions, was called for to discuss with the Commission the position to be taken by the EU at that time. China is not just any economy and it is well known that many production sectors do not meet minimum standards for the protection of workers and the environment. Moreover, China's overcapacity and subsequent exports at reduced prices are already having serious social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU, especially in the EU steel sector. We must protect European industry and guarantee the employment of our citizens. Without forgetting the importance of the partnership between the EU and China and that of the Chinese market, which has been the main driver of profitability for a number of EU industries and brands, I voted against the motion for a resolution because I believe that the EU should not recognise China as the ESA.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am in for globalization and fair competition provided that all states apply the same rules. It is in this spirit that I voted for this resolution. I even intervened in the Chamber to remind us that it is now impossible to grant China market economy status. What for? Simply because China does not meet the 5 precise European criteria for defining a market economy. On 11 December, the European Commission will decide whether to grant this status to China. However, we must already think about the revision and modernization of our trade defence instruments (IDC) or promote the introduction of an additional tax on products from Chinese dumping to finance a fund to support our companies that could possibly fall victim to retaliatory measures. China is a major trading partner of the European Union. It is therefore essential to strengthen our necessary solidarity on this issue with the United States and Japan, which, alongside Europe, are China's other two main partners. Our approach to it must be diplomatic, technical, but above all pragmatic.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Aggressive pricing practices lead to adverse effects on the economies of importing countries. In order to prevent material damage arising from such practices, legal safeguards are necessary to allow differentiated treatment of imports from countries whose economies do not meet the five criteria relevant to market economy (EME) status.  Since 2001, the provisions of Section 15 of China's Protocol of Membership to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) have been the legal basis for the application of an exceptional methodology to imports from this Part. Under the Protocol of Association, the suspension of the decision to grant the EME by the European Union effectively expires on 11 December 2016. In this sense, and since the current level of state interference in the Chinese economy precludes the fulfilment of its WTO obligations, Parliament opposes the unilateral granting of the MME to China, stressing that the scope of the provisions remains unchanged, even after the deadline for non-allocation of the EMM has expired. Having said the above, and in order to ensure that EU industry has a level playing field with China and other trade leavers, I voted in favour.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. With this resolution, Parliament expresses, in particular to the Council and the Commission, its refusal to grant China market economy status. While, according to the European Commission's criteria, China still cannot claim this status, such a decision would limit the Union's already limited capabilities (thank you!) to defend itself on a trade front.  The issue is vital for the European economy: strategic industrial sectors would be even more at risk, such as steel or chemicals, and in the long run, it is estimated that this grant to China would lead to a 25-50% increase in Chinese imports, a 1 to 2% reduction in European GDP and a loss of jobs of 1.7 to 3.5 million.  We are not talking about protectionism here, quite the contrary. We have always sought to develop a close and strengthened partnership with China. But this can only be done in the context of fair competition and in this respect, the transformation of China into a genuine market economy is essential; which, despite progress in opening up over the past 15 years, China has not yet completed.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. In today's resolution, the European Parliament considers that market economy status cannot be granted to China. The European Union will have to decide by 11 December. For environmentalists, China is not a market economy, so Europe has no reason to treat china as such, as long as it does not meet the required criteria. On the contrary, we must retain all the tools to enable fair and fair competition, preserving European industry and employment.  We need to go even further, strengthening our trade defence tools, which have been ineffective in recent years. Photovoltaic panels, steel, etc.: the absence of effective anti-dumping measures and the division of Member States (too concerned about their bilateral relations with China) have affected the general European interest for too long. To reverse this trend, Europe must develop genuine trade diplomacy.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It establishes the importance of partnership with China, in which fair and free trade plays an important role. It stresses that China is not a market economy and that the 5 criteria established by the European Union for defining market economies have not yet been met. This vote is a significant sign that Parliament will not accept any measures that weaken our ability to defend against abusive and unfair practices. The Commission needs to take into account the concerns expressed by industrialists, trade unions and other bodies about the consequences for jobs in the EU, the environment and sustainable growth in all affected sectors. It calls on the Council to reach an agreement with Parliament to modernise its trade defence instruments in the face of China's dumping.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 The Socialists oppose an automatic grant of market economy status to China. China and the EU do not compete on an equal footing as the Asian country does not respect WTO rules, is not a market economy and practices social, labour, environmental and price dumping. To address these unfair trade practices, the EU must have renewed, more effective and faster trade defence instruments and an anti-dumping methodology that takes into account distortion of Chinese prices and production costs until the 5 criteria set by the Union to be considered a market economy are met. This resolution led by the socialist group and adopted by a very large majority raises all these issues, so I have supported it with my vote. The EU cannot afford to lose a single job for granting China a trade status it does not deserve. If China wants to be treated as a market economy, it has to act as such.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted by a very large majority an ambitious resolution on China's market economy status. A resolution that the European Commission cannot ignore when making a choice about the possible recognition of China's market economy status and the anti-dumping method that will be applied to China's unfair exports. For the European Parliament, China is not a market economy. Moreover, it meets only one of the five technical criteria defined by the European Union to qualify for market economy status. It is for this reason that I fully support the position taken by the European Parliament to continue to apply a specific anti-dumping method to unfair exports from that country. The resolution also stresses the "imminent" need to reform the European Union's trade defence instruments. We need to defend our European industry in the face of unfair competition from other countries. It is high time that the Council took its responsibilities on this issue or our industry and its workers will continue to bear the consequences.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. China is a very important trading partner for the EU. Unfortunately, this country is not one that is particularly scrupulous in the implementation of the rules on fair competition, and the products it dumps often seriously undermine attempts to rebuild the industry in Europe. I therefore support the noty that it is still too early to talk about China's recognition of a functioning market economy.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. In 2001, China signed a WTO accession protocol that provided for a transitional period for its accession, allowing the European Union to apply a specific method of calculating dumping. By the end of 2016, this transitional period could come to an end and China believes that the European Union should automatically recognise it as a market economy.  This would mean that the EU would have to abandon the anti-dumping instruments it has today to protect itself from unfair Chinese competition. Recognition of China's market economy status could then lead to a serious crisis for European industry, with many job losses at stake.  However, China is not a market economy because it still does not meet the five criteria set by the Union. It is therefore essential that the Union retains its means of action against China and this is precisely the call that Parliament makes through this resolution. So I supported her.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 On the joint resolution that we have today here and of which I am one of the proponents, I would just like to point out a few ideas. From the outstage, the realization that China is not a market economy and will not be until the end of the year. Secondly, that the European Union will respect world trade organisation rules in its trade relations with China. Thirdly, we will have to initiate a thorough reform of our Trade Defence Mechanisms to ensure adequate levels of fair competition between our companies and our trading partners. And finally, that the mechanisms for determining production prices in comparative terms and for launching anti-dumping or anti-subsidy investigations should follow their own framework from 11 December next, the date on which the current regime expires. After this House's support for these positions, we now expect the Commission to submit credible and feasible proposals for our trade relations with China (after the public consultation process is complete). I remember that we no longer have much time to act proactively, and haste, as we know, is the enemy of good decisions.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the issue of granting China market economy status. China still does not currently meet the five criteria required by the EU to qualify for market economy status and that is why I refuse to consider china to be granted market economy status as automatic.  Such a grant would have catastrophic consequences for jobs and businesses in Europe.  We must continue to fight against all forms of unfair competition and the text underlines the imminent need for a reform of the European Union's trade defence instruments, a modernisation that we have been calling for for many years. In particular, 56 of the 73 anti-dumping measures currently in force in the EU apply to imports from China.  Despite the expiry of certain provisions of China's WTO accession protocol, we must continue to be able to effectively combat Chinese dumping and develop our jobs and businesses in Europe.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the sensitive debate on the recognition of China's market economy status, I voted in favour of this joint motion, which expresses the position of the PPE Group and the demands of the Italian delegation in particular. It brings together a very large majority of Parliament on a clear message to the Commission: recognition of the ES MES to China cannot be granted without taking into account the criteria laid down by the EU itself for establishing a market economy. Since China does not meet these criteria, it cannot be regarded as a market player in the same way as Europe. For this reason, the resolution calls for a legitimate defence of European industry, not against the market, but according to market rules. This means protecting both the free market, European companies and thousands of jobs. This resolution also has the merit of presenting a realistic proposal to tackle the problem, to be implemented within the margins allowed by China's protocol of accession to the WTO; It calls on the Commission to use a non-standard methodology for determining price comparability with regard to Chinese exports until China meets the EU criteria of a genuine market economy.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention in considering possible recognition as a market economy to China a threat to millions of jobs in the European Union. We consider the resolution to be ambiguous because it does not clearly urge the European Commission not to grant this recognition to China. We tabled two amendments which called on the Commission to do the same in a very concrete way, but unfortunately they were rejected in plenary.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. As I have highlighted with the vote in the amendments, I consider it necessary to have a firm position against the Commission's intention to proceed, after 2016, with further liberalisation of trade with China. The joint motion submitted to the vote, despite recognising that the current situation would not support such a procedure, merely repeats the Commission's argument. It thus endorses poor public consultation and leaves the door fully open to eliminating anti-dumping protection in exchange for privatizations and deregulations in the Chinese economy. We cannot defend economic interference in China, nor an intensification of global competition that would seriously harm social and environmental standards in industry and the jobs it generates in Europe. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 China is not a market economy. The European Parliament has made this very clear in the resolution adopted today by a large majority. Fifteen years after accession to the Protocol on Access to the World Trade Organisation, China has not yet implemented the reforms necessary to meet the five criteria laid down by the European Union. I therefore expressed my strong support for the call to oppose any unilateral granting of market economy status to that country. Such a decision would, in fact, undermine the effectiveness of the anti-dumping instrument - which currently allows European companies to protect themselves from unfair Chinese competition - and would therefore jeopardise the competitiveness of the EU's manufacturing sectors and entire production sector. China's overcapacity and the resulting exports at reduced prices are already having serious social, economic and environmental repercussions in the EU, especially in the steel sector. I therefore hope that the European Union will not only maintain, but also strengthen, trade defence instruments, in order to safeguard its businesses and workers.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. China has asserted itself as a solid player on the international scene and as one of the EU's main trading partners. As Article 15 of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) Protocol approaches in December 2016, the EU must adjust its trade defence mechanisms with regard to bilateral trade with China. It is necessary to assess the potential consequences that the granting of market economy status to China will have on the European economic and social sector. The implications will be felt in terms of employment in the industrial sector, investment and competitiveness. When China joined the WTO in 2001, it pledged to implement reforms to achieve a market economy. However, after 15 years, it meets only one of the five criteria it should meet to be considered a market economy.  I voted to approve the resolution because I believe that granting China market economy status will have serious economic consequences for the EU, in particular for the development of a sustainable economy, for the metallurgical and chemical industries and for jobs in the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I have been extremely concerned about the granting to China of market economy status since the Protocol of accession to the World Trade Organisation by China which, upon expiry at the end of this year, has the potential to grant China market economy status. I would argue that this is a misinterpretation of section 15 of the WTO Protocol, as China must first meet all five of the EU’s criteria to qualify as a market economy, which it has not done. Hence, I oppose and will oppose any unilateral concession of market economy status to China, not least until it has fulfilled its obligations to meet the five criteria laid out in the WTO Protocol of accession. We must have a coordinated strategy with our major trading partners and we need to use special rules in anti-dumping cases until China becomes a genuine market economy.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. In fact, I consider it important to make it clear that, unless China fulfils all five criteria by which the EU sets the conditions characterising a market economy, Then Chinese imports into the Union must be regulated in order to guarantee and protect eu industry and economy.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although China is the EU's second largest trading partner and the EU is China's largest trading partner, with mutual trade amounting to more than EUR 1 billion per day, I am of the opinion that China does not meet market economy criteria. China joined the World Trade Organisation (WTO) in 2001. The Accession Protocol provides that China's transition to a market economy will be automatically recognised after 11 December 2016. China currently fulfils only one EU criterion for recognising its economy as a market economy. The government subsidises various industries significantly, allowing it to export and sell its goods significantly cheaper. This week in Strasbourg and last year in Brussels, representatives of companies that produce steel in the EU came to express their concerns. If we were to recognise China as having a market economy, we would completely paralise European steel producers, thereby destroying 3.5 million jobs and reducing annual GDP turnover by around EUR 300 billion. As I come from Košice, where the iron giant is the largest employer and 10 000 people would lose their jobs, I voted for China to be given market economy status only after it has met all five criteria by which the EU defines a market economy. Until then, appropriate customs measures need to be applied to goods imported from China.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. If companies sell their products below the cost of production in order to push existing competition out of the market, then dumping is the case. In order to prevent this method of foreign competition, the EU may adopt anti-dumping measures. Such anti-dumping duties are calculated in the case of market-based countries of origin on the difference in prices between the home and export markets. If the exporting state is not a market economy, other methods can be used to estimate the cost of production. This is how higher anti-dumping duties are likely to be imposed. According to the common interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the WTO, the EU must recognise China's market economy status at the end of the year and thus have to apply lesser anti-dumping in order not to violate WTO directives. ALFA stands for the rule of law – the EU must also adhere to international agreements itself. I am therefore voting against this report.  However, there are sectors in China (particularly steel) where production costs are well below the cost of production, allowing for a cut throat competition in the EU. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Member States address the problem in a timely manner and obtain an alternative WTO-compliant method of appropriate anti-dumping measures. Anti-dumping must not be used as a protectionist tool – European companies should prove themselves in international and fair competition.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Strategic relations with China are very important to us, but given the current situation where ensuring the same rules at global level is questionable, we demand that European defensive market mechanisms remain effective, especially in the light of the unfair trading practices of this strategic partner. We are already see how alarming our steel industry is, because prices are being dumped on third country markets because of their overcapacity. It should be noted that these defensive commercial practices do not only predominate in the steel industry, but also other industrial sectors are at risk. Recognising China's "market economy" status would not be a rebuttable decision.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ China is the EU's second largest market partner, while the EU is China's largest partner with over €1 billion worth of trade. The EU's strategic partnership with China is thus of great importance, and investments, which should be based on the principle of reciprocity and common benefits, also play a key role. But it is also important to stress that China is not a market economy and the five criteria by which the market economy is defined, established by the EU, have not yet been met.  Until China meets these criteria necessary to obtain market economy status, the EU should use non-market methods in anti-dumping and anti-system investigation procedures for research into Chinese imports.  I believe it is necessary to create an effective trade defence instrument to ensure economically equal competition with China in full compliance with World Trade Organisation rules and to ensure that any method adopted effectively protects European industry and European jobs from dumped imports from China.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and China are the two largest trading partners in the world. China is the European Union's second largest trading partner, while the European Union is China's largest trading partner. Trade between the two entities amounts to more than €1 billion per day. Parliament underlines the strategic importance of the European Union-China partnership in which trade and investment play an extremely important role for each other. However, Parliament considers China not a market economy because it has failed to meet five criteria established by the European Union to define which country falls into the market economy category. All concerns expressed by European industrialists regarding the implications for jobs in the Union, as well as for sustainable economic development in all manufacturing sectors, but also for European industry as a whole, should be taken into account. They emphasise the need to ensure the competitiveness of the Union in a global context. I support Parliament's decision not to grant the People's Republic of China market economy status because it does not meet the criteria set by the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution on the market economy status of China. The European Parliament must play a key role and its role must not be undermined. The strategic partnership between the European Union and China must be equal and equitable and based on fair trade relations. It must also be aimed at improving standards in the area of human and labour rights.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution, which stresses that the five criteria established by the EU to define market economies have not yet been fulfilled by China and that, until China meets all these criteria, the EU should use a non-standard methodology in anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations into Chinese imports in determining price comparability. China’s overcapacity has impacted hard on our industries in recent months and has had a particularly detrimental impact on the steel industry in my constituency. It is therefore vital that the EU retains the full and continued ability to take timely, necessary and effective measures to tackle anti-competitive market practices.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 China as a sovereign state has chosen interventionism in the economy and trade, so the EU must resist any process that undermines the economic interests of its Member States.  It should not recognise China as a market economy country and should not initiate the 'standard methodology' on imports of Chinese products into the Union.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Section 15(ii)(a) of China's Protocol of Accession to the WTO lays down the rules applicable to China in the anti-dumping proceeding and the dumping limits to be applied in the proceeding. This provision expires in December 2016 after a 15-year 'grace period'. Therefore, the EU, as a WTO Member State, must also decide what rules it will apply in the internal market in relation to chinese products to be imported, and more specifically whether China has met the five WTO criteria for the acceptance of a State a part as a market economy.  The European People's Party is united in the fact that China is not a market economy, as it has, among other things, an official influence on the pricing of its products for each export. Steel products and solar panels are particularly sensitive products for the EU. The joint ALDE-PPE-S&D-ECR-Verts/ALE decision confirms this position and I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint proposal for a decision, primarily because it ensures, in its current form, that the People's Republic of China will continue to not benefit from automatic benefits for partner countries recognised as market economies on the European Union market, as opposed to certain proposals raised during the preparation process. I have considered the fact that China has so far failed to meet the requirements agreed in this regard when it joined the WTO and that the GOI is not seeking to substantially improve the conditions for Access to the Chinese Market for European goods and services, in particular as far as access to public procurement is concerned. In these circumstances, an unfounded granting of market economy market preferences could trigger a new price dumping of Chinese goods on the EU market.  This would, in particular, jeopardise a number of European jobs in the steel industry and several other manufacturing sectors, while I consider it my obvious duty as a European left-wing politician to defend them. In addition to all these aspects, the proposal for a decision rightly points out that the People's Republic of China has now become the most important player in world trade, the EU's main trading and economic partner, with which continued dialogue and cooperation will continue to be in the interest of the Union and its Member States.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint report because I think it is important that we carefully assess the economic and social impact of the solution on the European Union's internal market. It is absolutely essential to find a solution that is compatible with WTO rules.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission not to unilaterally grant China market economy status until china meets all five EU criteria. While we recognise the importance of trade relations between Europe and China and the EU's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation, we believe that such a concession would have destructive effects on industry and employment, affecting strategic sectors already aggravated by Chinese overproduction and making anti-dumping policies impossible. We therefore condemn the attitude of the Commission to date, which has not taken account of the concerns of industry, workers and citizens, nor has it given sufficient space to public debate, by launching a poorly thought-out and misleading public consultation. We hope that the Union will update its trade defence instruments, without exposing its strategic sectors to unfair foreign competition, and find, together with its trading partners, a balanced solution to restart trade relations between Europe and China from a level playing field and respect for the socio-economic rights of industry, workers and citizens in both economies. We will ensure that the resolution adopted, although less incisive than that tabled by our political group and rejected by this House, is fully respected by the Commission.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of granting market economy status to China has been hotly debated in recent months. Representatives of several European industries warned of the negative impact of granting this status to the European workforce. As the world's second-largest economy and globally manufactured supplier, China could gain an unjustified significant advantage in relation to the EU and the Member States. Undoubtedly, the GOC has made significant progress towards meeting the requirements for granting this status since joining the World Trade Organisation in 2001. The necessary changes in the functioning of China's economy have been highlighted by the five criteria established by the Commission since 2008 and concern compliance with the demand and supply rule in the setting of product prices, the use of a type of accounting in accordance with the rules of independent auditing, the regulation and transparency of public subsidies, compliance with internationally established foreign exchange rules and the adoption of clear legislation on property and bankruptcy. At the moment, the Chinese economy is in the process of transforming and implementing those criteria. I think it is early to make a cutting decision, which could negatively affect relationships with such an important partner.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. It is important to stress that the strategic partnership between the EU and China must be based on fair trade relations, in full compliance with WTO rules, mutual respect and fair and equitable cooperation, and aim to improve human and labour rights standards.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Under the current circumstances I am against granting market economy status to China and therefore fully supported this resolution. While I am very much in favour of fair competition and trade, it is clear that China does not yet meet all the criteria for qualifying as a market economy. I believe that such a decision should be based on sound legal analysis and a thorough impact assessment, rather than on premature and unsubstantiated conclusions. We see already that the overcapacity of the Chinese market has a strong and negative social, economic and environmental impact in our economy, especially on the steel sector. Our industry needs actions from our side and I am asking the Commission to revise our trade defence instruments to ensure a level playing field in full compliance with WTO rules.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Compliance with international commitments and the eu's necessary participation in world trade policies through the World Trade Organisation cannot result in unfair harm to our businesses. It is clear to everyone that China is not a market economy. It is therefore necessary for us, as legislators, to take action to protect European companies, which would otherwise be exposed to deeply unfair competition. It is our duty to prevent millions of jobs from being put at risk throughout Europe. This is not a battle against China, a major trading and political partner, but in favour of fair and sustainable global trade. The future of the European Union depends not only on its political leadership or security, but also on its economic strength and industrial weight. We must always stand up to them when we take decisions of this kind. For these reasons, I believe that Parliament must speak out strongly against the recognition of China's status as a market economy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒The European Union-China trade relationship is of utmost importance as China is one of the Union's most important trading partners.  However, when China joined the World Trade Organisation, it was found that it had not completed the transition to a market economy and therefore allowed other Members of the World Trade Organisation to apply non-market methods to imports from that country until its transition to a market economy was completed. In order to protect the European Union market, the Commission needs to adopt a clear and effective strategy to give market economy status to third countries in order to continue to combat all forms of anti-competitive behaviour and market distortions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the market economy status of China, as China does not yet fulfil the European Union's conditions for obtaining market economy status. The European Commission must listen to the EU's concerns of industry and trade unions about the potential environmental, jobs and economic growth impacts that China's market economy status would bring. At the same time, we must not forget the importance of partnership with China, as it is the EU's second largest partner, with daily trade in goods exceeding one billion euros.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention in considering possible recognition as a market economy to China a threat to millions of jobs in the European Union. We consider the resolution to be ambiguous because it does not clearly urge the European Commission not to grant this recognition to China. We tabled two amendments which called on the Commission to do the same in a very concrete way, but unfortunately they were rejected in plenary.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Granting market economy status to China would pose a threat to Europe's energy-intensive industries, such as the steel industry. It would not be able to compete with china's subsidized production, thanks to excessive environmental and other EU regulations. China does not meet the criteria for granting the Statute, which is why I supported the European Parliament's resolution.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. If companies sell their products below the cost of production in order to push existing competition out of the market, then this is "dumping". In order to prevent this method of foreign competition, the EU may adopt anti-dumping measures. Such anti-dumping duties are calculated in the case of market-based countries of origin on the difference in prices between the home and export markets. If the exporting state is not a market economy, other methods can be used to estimate the cost of production. This is how higher anti-dumping duties are likely to be imposed. According to the common interpretation of China's protocol of accession to the WTO, the EU must recognise China's market economy status at the end of the year and thus have to apply lesser anti-dumping in order not to violate WTO directives. ALFA stands for the rule of law – the EU must also adhere to international agreements itself. I am therefore voting against this report.  However, there are sectors in China (particularly steel) where production costs are well below the cost of production, allowing for a cut throat competition in the EU. It is therefore important that the Commission and the Member States address the problem in a timely manner and obtain an alternative WTO-compliant method of appropriate anti-dumping measures. Anti-dumping must not be used as a protectionist tool – European companies should prove themselves in international and fair competition.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against granting China market economy status because China is simply not a market economy. Already now without this status Chinese products have flooded European markets. Think about the steel industry or textile products. Under Section 15 of the Chinese WTO Accession Protocol, China can be treated as a non-market economy (NME) in anti-dumping proceedings if Chinese firms cannot prove that they operate under market economy conditions. The main implication of NME status in anti-dumping proceedings is the possibility to use other methodologies to determine the normal value of the good, instead of using domestic prices to compute the dumping margin. China will invade our European economies with cheap subsidised products that will kill our European SMEs and manufacturers. China does not have the same social and economic costs as in Europe. I want to protect European quality products made in Europe. European quality and health standards are the highest and Chinese products would undermine safety for health and the environment. We should stand behind European companies and jobs on this file.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. China has been a member of the WTO since 2001. It is not considered a market economy. This allows the European Union to impose very strong but logical anti-dumping measures in an industry, especially when a Chinese industrial sector exports its surplus below cost.  80% of EU imports that were investigated by the European Commission for dumping or subsidies came from China. China's economy has huge production overcapacity, particularly in commodities such as steel, due to the sharp slowdown in some Chinese domestic markets over the past two years. China must be denied market economy status, otherwise we will no longer have effective anti-dumping instruments. There is a legal risk that, even if it is denied market economy status, China may still attack the EU before the WTO and eventually prevent it from putting in substantial but logical anti-dumping duties. The ENF Group has proposed a resolution calling for China not to be granted market economy status and to strengthen our trade defence mechanisms.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2001, China joined the World Trade Organisation, and the Accession Protocol provides that by the end of 2016 at the latest it will be granted market economy status. Market economy status is not a symbol, but is about legal status within the World Trade Organisation. Where a country does not have this status, anti-dumping procedures are facilitated for countries that consider themselves to be victims of unfair competition. It is estimated that if market economy status is granted to China, between 1.7 and 3.5 million European jobs could disappear. A potential decrease of 2-3% of European GDP is also expected if this status is granted to China. Moreover, the five criteria set by the EU for granting market economy status are not currently met by China, so the EU should continue to impose anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties on imports from that country beyond December 2016, as long as these conditions are not met. I therefore voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on China's market economy status.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted abstention in considering possible recognition as a market economy to China a threat to millions of jobs in the European Union. We consider the resolution to be ambiguous because it does not clearly urge the European Commission not to grant this recognition to China. We tabled two amendments which called on the Commission to do the same in a very concrete way, but unfortunately they were rejected in plenary.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 China is our second largest trading partner, while the EU is the largest one for China with an average daily trade of over one billion euros. At the same time, of the 75 EU anti-dumping measures in force, 56 are for imports from China. In practice, the EU recognises the existence of a state dumping policy in Chinese exports, but it must further strengthen the protection of European industry from such unfair practices.  The Chinese State's intervention with subsidies and other support for the formation of non-market prices in exports is sufficient evidence of the absence of market economy status not only according to European criteria, but also to the WORLD's criteria. I call for all acceptable and legitimate solutions to be found to prevent further exposure of the European economy to the dangers of China's non-market trade practice, threatening the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in various industrial sectors.  Today, the available overcapacity in China, surpassing the production capacity of European steel, ceramics, glass, solar panels, etc., is a real threat to our economy with significant economic and social consequences, including mass closures of jobs and businesses. The EU cannot afford to do so.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I stress that the Chinese economy is not a market economy and that it does not meet the five criteria set by the EU to describe a country with such an economy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this resolution, Parliament states that as long as China does not meet the five criteria established by the EU to define a market economy, its exports must be treated differentiated. We are talking about an issue of great importance and magnitude and which would have economic, political and social consequences throughout Europe, so it is necessary for this house to send a clear message through this resolution in view of the next steps that the European Commission takes on this issue. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution on China's market economy status. We note that China still does not meet the proposed criteria for market economies. Until this is met, China cannot be granted market economy status.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We are sensitive to the profound impacts that such recognition will have at the level of our productive apparatus. And this position stems from past experiences with the opening up of the EU market to global competition in key sectors of the Portuguese economy such as textiles or footwear. It is not understood why the parties that are now so concerned about the Chinese market have not shown so much concern in the past about opening up the EU market to countries such as India or Pakistan, just to name a few. This question also serves to question the role of the European Union, which is now unilaterally in the right to decide what a national economy is or is not. It aims to teach lessons in democracy and now also on a liberal economy. In other words, as we have denounced, free trade agreements are not neutral and often become instruments of political interference.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. China cannot be granted ME status because the economic system is at odds with Western systems. Examples of this are the lack of autonomy of the banking system, as well as the extreme form of the planned economy and the incomparable influence of a political party.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from the vote on the motion for a resolution following statements by the Council and the Commission in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. Indeed, if the EU were to promote free trade with China – and not to promote and protect the interests of powerful industries with the best ties with political leaders – it would only have to abolish all trade tariffs and tariffs on Chinese goods. Denying China market economy status, however, means giving regulators more opportunities to protect old and uncompetitive EU industries from Chinese competition. This protection is, of course, not free of charge – because consumers who have to pay more than they need to pay for their consumption.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Led by Labour and Social Democratic colleagues, the European Parliament has clearly indicated that it will not allow the granting of market economy status to China as things stand. Despite its transformation in the last 15 years, China simply is not yet a market economy, and in the EU we must not expose our industries to unfair competition. Instead, we must modernise our trade defences. Being a part of the EU, the largest economy in the world, allows the UK to contend with China on an equal basis, and gives us the tools to protect our industries, together with our European colleagues. Outside the EU, UK industries would be much more open to be undercut on the world stage, and our government more likely to be negotiated into a corner by giant players like China. The EU has the power and potential to forge a fairer and more equitable world trade system, which puts planet and people before profit. Working together with progressives from across Europe, I will continue to advocate and work towards that goal. The UK must lead that development from within the EU.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – I agreed to the resolution on China's market economy status. I am well aware that in December 2001 the EU concluded an agreement with China on granting this status in 2016.  This is a complex multifaceted problem. We need to look at the legal implications and we are talking about major interests for European industry, but also for our trading relationship with China, one of our most important trading partners. It's mainly about how we deal with dumped goods from China on our market. We must also ensure that the proposal that the European Commission will make on this subject is also in line with the EU's obligations at international level.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – Through this resolution, the Commission is invited to reach an agreement with the EU's main trading partners, especially in the context of the upcoming G7, G20 and EU-China summits, but also to oppose any unilateral decision granted to China. Account must be taken of the interests of industry, trade unions and other interested parties of the Union as regards the impacts on employment, the environment, standards and sustainable economic growth in the Union in all the manufacturing sectors concerned. The resolution calls on the Council to quickly reach an agreement on the modernisation of EU trade defence instruments in order to ensure fair competition for Union industry vis-à-vis China and other trading partners in full compliance with WTO rules.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The EU must safeguard the interests of industry and its production within the European market and internationally. Our trade relations must be governed by mutual respect and meet the conditions and criteria set and taken into account in this text. I co-signed this resolution and, of course, voted in favour of it.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. As demonstrated, China's export prices are not determined by supply and demand; as a result of its overproduction, it sells its products at lower prices, in order to reduce it. For this reason, it is clear that it is not a market economy and that, therefore, considering it as such would only harm the Union. Moreover, another reason why we cannot consider China a market economy is as simple as it does not meet the five criteria of the European Union. So I do not support China's market economy status and I fully hope to continue the empowerment and improvement of trade defence instruments to defend our companies from unfair practices.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 By 11 December 2016, the European Commission will have to decide whether to grant China market economy status, a hypothesis that would automatically bring down all the defence instruments that Europe today uses to counter unfair competition from the Asian giant. While European companies have to comply with very strict protocols and constraints, Chinese companies are supported by state aid, very low energy costs and labour exploitation, including child labour. If China is recognised as a market economy, all anti-dumping duties will automatically fall, it will be the end for European small and medium-sized enterprises with an estimated loss of 3 million jobs throughout Europe, 400 thousand in Italy alone. This resolution has the great merit of acknowledging in black and white that China does not meet the five criteria required to be called a market economy. It also suggests that the Commission consider a non-standard methodology in pricing goods imported into Europe from China. Only in this way will it be possible to assess whether unfair Chinese competition continues to harm the European company.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The resolution calling on the Commission and the Council of the EU not to recognise Market Economy Status in China within the WTO and to take trade defence measures on Chinese imports into the EU, expresses the sharpening of the confrontation between the EU's monopolies and those of China, as well as more generally the monopolistic groups of the BRICS countries. This prospect is of serious concern to large monopolistic groups in the EU, particularly those active in manufacturing industries, such as the steel industry, where Chinese capitalist groups strengthen their position vis-à-vis their European Union counterparts. Competition is further complicated by intra-city opposition in the EU, with other parts of the capital looking to boost trade with China, looking forward to its large capitalist market. Monopolies, the EU, urban governments and parties, employers' and sold-out reformist trade unions are trying to cost the working class the interests of capitalists in the dispute with its competitors. However, the war between monopolies, the increase in their competitiveness, presupposes a greater break in the wage, labour and social rights of the working class. It is in the interest of the working class to raise its own flags, fighting to overthrow the power of monopolies, to become the owner of the wealth it produces.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal submitted. The EU-China partnership, in which free and fair trade plays an important role, is very important, yet there are objective arguments that China is not a market economy. In particular, China does not meet the five market economy criteria set by the EU. As long as China does not meet these 5 criteria, the EU should continue to use a non-standard methodology for assessing chinese import prices under the Protocol on China's accession to the WTO. I am in line for the issues related to the granting of MARKET ECONOMY status to be discussed at the forthcoming EU-China Summit.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the joint resolution of the political groups on the status of China's market economy. This is a subject that has been the subject of various debates, not only in the European Parliament, but also among experts outside the institutions. On the one hand, we all agree that China is one of the EU's most important trading partners, but on the other hand, over-imports from China are causing major problems for domestic industries, as we can currently see in the case of the steel industry. That is why, in the resolution, we called on the Commission to deal properly with these serious impacts, not only on industry, but also on the related impacts on jobs, growth and, last but not least, on the environment. At the same time, the resolution declares that, since China does not meet several market economy criteria, it cannot automatically have this status. By supporting the resolution, I thus voted against the recognition of its market economy status.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recognition of China's market economy status because I believe that China does not yet meet the criteria necessary to be considered a market economy. I would like to say that, given the current level of state influence on the Chinese economy, companies' decisions on prices, costs, production and production factors do not respond to market signals that reflect supply and demand. I would also remind you that, in its Protocol of Membership, China has undertaken, inter alia, to allow all its prices to be determined by market forces, and that the EU must ensure that China fully fulfils its WTO obligations.  I believe that, as long as China does not meet the market economy criteria, the European Union should use an exceptional methodology in the context of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy investigations relating to Chinese imports to determine price comparability.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The resolution, which I voted in favour of, recognises in black and white that China does not meet the five criteria required to be called a market economy. If Europe were to grant China market economy status, all customs duties, currently in force, would automatically fall, which serve to protect European companies from unfair competition from Made in China products. Together with my colleagues in the M5S we fought to stop this concession. We have worked to ensure that a specific amendment is included in the report which clearly states that the European Union must not grant China market status. At M5S we fight to defend the excellence of Made in Italy in the world from unfair competition. The recognition of China's market status, as currently understood by the Commission, would have a traumatic impact on the Italian production sector, the world of employment and the country's know-how. To say no to the Mes to China is to say yes to the future of the Italian company. With this resolution we wanted to say no to the ESA without ifs and buts.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ I supported the European Parliament resolution on the market economy status of China. China is the EU's second largest trading partner, with daily trade flows well in excess of €1 billion. China's excess production already has major social, economic and environmental consequences in the EU. I therefore believe that there is an urgent need for a general reform of the EU's trade defence instruments, which fully respects WTO rules and which would ensure that European industry is level playing field with china and other trading partners.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, I believe that value-based politics is a good thing and an important thing, but there are values that are simply incompatible with each other. Sustainability on one side and neoliberal economic policy on the other, and global free trade on the other. The European Union is opposed to itself when its entire economic policy is based on free trade, and these agreements are bound up. He is now passionately preparing for TTIP, a free trade agreement with America and the United States. The essence of free trade is to transport goods, including agricultural products, from one end of the world to the other with great pollution. And the whole point of sustainability is to preserve the environment and the created world for future generations. It doesn't fit!

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – The 2030 Agenda renews the Union's international commitment to eradicating poverty. Again we are redefining and modernising our development strategies by 2030, so over the next fifteen years. I ask the European Commission for a detailed timetable by 2030, with precise targets, objectives and so on.m.d. We still have targets, objectives, indicators at global level – I would like them to be at national level, at the level of each industry, at the level of each area that could lead to the eradication of poverty. We have all of this, but we still have poverty that hasn't fallen at all lately. I also believe that the new development strategy must be the subject of consultation with all third countries, with non-governmental organisations, with national parliaments, with civil society and, above all, with what those in very poor countries need and with the people who should benefit from these programmes of ours.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The concept of sustainable development, generally speaking, means that we both take into account the needs of the present generation and cannot jeopardise the needs of the next generation, for example by designating economic, social, environmentally sustainable development. By the way, in 2015, in Brazil, within the framework of the UNITED NATIONS, the countries of the world agreed on seventeen sustainable development goals and one hundred and sixty-nine sub-objectives. Of course, I will not talk about them now, but it is clear that the Sustainable Development Agenda by 2030, all the sustainable development objectives defined, are important, which we must record on our road map, as they say. And it is particularly important why I support this document today that it is the call for the Commission and the European External Action Service to cooperate actively with the Member States in developing their path to sustainable development.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the 2030 Agenda is a global framework which was introduced in 2015 to help eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development by 2030. The goals set out in this agenda are ones that this Parliament has long been committed to achieving. It is of great importance that this Union sets out a sustainable development strategy that encompasses all the goals, targets and global indicators set out in the 2030 Agenda, which all Member States have committed to implementing. I am pleased and proud to say that the negotiations for the 2030 Agenda were co-facilitated by the Irish Permanent Representative to the United Nations. So Ireland has long since committed to these sustainable development goals and the 2030 Agenda, and fully supports further implementation of these goals within the Union.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report primarily due to the fact that we do not believe should the EU should have the right to any foreign intervention. Any agenda associated with development should the prerogative of the Member State.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The objectives and targets of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development must be analysed on the basis of a set of global indicators. The resolution calls for the general coherence of the action of the Union and the Member States towards these objectives. Reference is made to the MFF (multiannual financing framework) and calls on the Commission to draw up a detailed roadmap. The resolution therefore contains an excellent approach to European sustainable development policies. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Last September, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted at the United Nations, which includes very positive elements for us in achieving global goals such as the eradication of hunger, gender equality, or the promotion of peace. However, the European Commission has not taken concrete action to meet this agenda. We supported this resolution because it urges the Commission to take specific measures to achieve these objectives, which requires a real economic commitment to cooperation policies, which sets out the obligation of 0.7% of the budget for this purpose. It also calls for a reorientation of existing policies, so that cross-cutting criteria such as sustainability for the environment, health promotion, or universal access to basic resources such as water are considered. We hope that this resolution will be taken into account and do not add to the long list of failures in this area, because the unwillingness of the governments of the global North has not met these objectives that initially set 2015 as a target.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In particular, the proposed resolution calls on the Commission to produce a communication ahead of the UN High-Level Policy Forum for Sustainable Development in September 2016, which will be held at the UN with all member countries.  These are essentially measures based on environmental bans, regulations, taxation and incentives.  As long as the constraints concern only the Europeans but neither the Chinese nor the Americans, there is no reason to vote in favour. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am, of course, hugely sympathetic towards the situation in developing nations, the EU strategies in this regard have often proved counterproductive. This should be a matter for the UK Government.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the follow-up to the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals and the current situation. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals are a revised international commitment to eradicate poverty, redefine and update development strategies for the next 15 years and ensure their implementation. I support the calls for the Commission to come forward with a proposal for a comprehensive strategy for sustainable development covering all internal and external policies. The EU Strategy for Sustainable Development and related implementation policies should be widely consulted by all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a decision addresses the preconditions for implementing Agenda 2030 on sustainable development. As is known, Agenda 2030 was adopted at the United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development in New York in September 2015. Resolution 70/1 of the United Nations General Assembly calls for an annual survey of progress in this area in order to achieve jointly agreed targets (essentially keeping global warming below 2°C but if possible below 1.5°C). In order to achieve these objectives, 17 directions have been set, including 169 targets, with 230 global indicators to measure progress.  The proposal for a decision calls on the Commission to propose a sustainable development strategy with the full involvement of Parliament. As the High Level Policy Forum on the subject will re-convene in July 2016, the EU should define its own position by then and Member States should develop their own indicators in line with global indicators. The proposal limits the waste of resources that has developed in developed countries and would stop the destruction of the environment, one of the consequences of which is the catastrophic extinction of animals, which is why I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal for a decision.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This resolution proposed by most political groups deals with Agenda 2030 and the sustainable development goals to be achieved. The text proposes measures based on prohibitions, regulations, taxation, ecological incentives, often with few constraints: nothing is said of countries that refuse to submit to such constraints, such as the United States or China.  Similarly, the fact that the amount of waste and miscellaneous discharges (soil erosion, carbon dioxide releases, etc.) increased by 28% in the United States between 1975 and 1996 is not mentioned, nor is the capital notion of natural resource limits.  Furthermore, the resolution calls for the European Sustainable Development Strategy to be the subject of extensive consultation including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society, which seems to be a no-brainer. The measures proposed in this resolution are insufficient and poorly targeted; so I voted against it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which calls on the Foreign Affairs Council in its Development Formation to adopt, before the United Nations High-Level Political Forum for Sustainable Development in July, a common and coherent position of the Union, taking into account the position of the European Parliament expressed in this resolution. It is crucial that the Union presents a common position when we know that agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals constitute a new international commitment to the eradication of poverty, the redefinition and modernisation of our development strategies for the next 15 years and the achievement of results.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2030 agenda and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals are an important starting point from which to start defining the path to achieving the political priorities of the world agenda for the coming years, in particular in terms of development, the fight against poverty, hunger and malnutrition. The implementation of the SDOs involves, first and foremost, the creation of appropriate statistical indicators, which make it possible to monitor accurately the implementation of the strategy both globally and at European and national level. The motion for a resolution, which I supported today, addresses this priority, and also calls on the Commission to produce a specific communication to define how the 2030 agenda can be implemented at European and Member State level. The EU, through the Foreign Affairs Council, must quickly draw up a common position on the SDOs to be presented at the political forum next July. Together with this, the Commission and the EEAS must work to ensure, within the review of the Europe 2020 strategy and in the future EU global foreign and security policy strategy, a sound strategic coherence with the objective of sustainable development.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution which measures concrete actions for the European Commission on the Sustainable Development Goals. Following the adoption of the so-called Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 within the United Nations last September, the European Commission has done little or nothing to adapt its policies to this new development agenda. We consider it essential that the Commission urgently establish a roadmap in this regard, as the resolution positively points out.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. If the fight against poverty is a legitimate objective, I had to vote against this resolution which uses the most laudable principles (fighting poverty, sustainable development) as a Trojan horse to once again await the sovereignty of States. The resolution calls for "the development of a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of domestic and external policies"; It should be remembered that many of these areas, particularly social policies, are still within the competence of European nations. If international coordination is needed to achieve poverty reduction targets, it must be done in a concerted manner by the legitimate representatives of each country, or, even more efficiently, through bilateral agreements with the countries most concerned, which would allow for a truly targeted, and therefore concrete, approach. Moreover, as has been pointed out by several amendments, the Union has a good game of trying to reduce poverty even though it itself creates situations of great precariousness, in particular because of free trade agreements which are, more often than not, to the detriment of the interests of the Member States and their peoples.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that the text contains passages that we can support, it remains yet another demagogic appeal to help third countries, without adding anything about a more rational and effective management of this aid. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted in September 2015 entered into force on 1 January. Countries will need to intensify efforts over the next 15 years to end poverty in all its forms, reduce inequality and fight climate change. Since they are not binding, it is up to governments to adopt them as their own and to establish national frameworks for their achievement.  As the resolution, which I have supported, urges the adoption of a joint strategy by the European Union for the implementation of the SDGs, as well as to agree and develop indicators to assist in the process of monitoring the achievement of the objectives, and to ensure sufficient resources, by calling on the EU and its Member States to commit without delay to reaching 0.7% of GDP in development aid.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because, in order to ensure a new global framework for sustainable development, greater coherence between different policies and EU actors is needed, which requires further coordination, dialogue and cooperation between the EU institutions and their mutual action at all levels, so that the three pillars of sustainable development (environment, economic and social) are integrated into the EU's internal and external policies. The 2030 agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals are a revised international commitment to eradicate poverty, redefine and update our development strategies for the next 15 years and ensure that we implement them.
