The European Parliament calls on the Commission to submit a proposal for a comprehensive strategy for sustainable development covering all internal and external policies and its comprehensive timetable for 2030, a mid-term review and a specific procedure to ensure Parliament's full involvement, including a specific implementation plan. Parliament also calls on the Commission to draw up a communication on the follow-up to and revision of the 2030 Agenda, including clear information on the structure of the implementation of the Agenda at EU and Member State level.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the next steps and the review of the 2030 Agenda. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development establishes a global framework for poverty eradication and sustainable development by 2030 and is based on the Millennium Development Goals adopted in 2000. It is the first global agreement that sets out a universal and comprehensive plan for action and includes an ambitious set of 17 overarching SDGs. The agenda clearly expresses sustainable development guidelines based on peace and justice. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the EU is one of the communities of The Member States of the United Nations that adhere quite consistently to the guidelines of the Agenda - not least, the EU is the world's largest donor of humanitarian aid. Unfortunately, this cannot be said for some other, more developed UN Member States.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted at the United Nations Summit in New York last September 2015, is the document that must provide our guidelines in this area and with regard to which the European Union must therefore conform all its policies and actions. It is in fact a universal reference framework, aimed at helping all countries to fight poverty and achieve sustainable development by 2030, with 17 ambitious targets specifically for sustainable development and 169 associated objectives, which need global mobilisation and the implementation of coherent and effective environmental policies , economic and social. I supported the text adopted today as it aims to strengthen EU action in this field and its contribution to achieving the objectives set. In line with this, I hope for greater commitment on the part of the Commission, with a view to the High-Level Political Forum scheduled for July 2016 and with a view to presenting concrete proposals on how to integrate all development policies more effectively into the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, while also providing for appropriate monitoring and review mechanisms, ensuring the full participation of the European Parliament.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Resolution. In particular, I voted in favour of an amendment which highlighted the destructive impact which trade agreements such as TTIP, TiSA and CETA could have on achieving the 17 Sustainable Development Goals. These goals were laid down by the United Nations on 25 September 2015 and the aim is to work towards these goals by 2030 and the EU has agreed to fully implement the Agenda These goals include aims to eradicate poverty, hunger, illiteracy and disease, provide clean water, take action on climate change and achieve gender equality. The resolution also calls for the Commission to come forward with proposals for an overarching strategy on how these goals can be incorporated at all policy levels and for a detailed timeline for review, which I and my Sinn Féin colleagues will be monitoring closely.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is important for the European Union to use all its influence and soft power to ensure that the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals are ambitious projects that really make life better and more sustainable for citizens around the world.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2030 Agenda is a United Nations "action plan" signed, with great emphasis by the international press, by the main countries of the world last September, in New York; It is based on 17 lines of sustainable development and 169 objectives. The plan focuses on the protection of human rights, the achievement of gender equality and the employment of all women. A real 'direction' for yet another theoretical and demagogic objective of 'balance between the three dimensions of sustainable development: economic, social and environmental', the plan does not address the issue of a radical, necessary change in the development aid policies of third countries, without therefore indicating new ways of conditioning aid and a more stringent verification between some of the right proposed objectives and their effective implementation. I abstained.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 And today over a billion people live in extreme poverty, facing major environmental challenges - two-thirds of nature's services, including fertile land, drinking water and clean air, are in decline. From the outset, development cooperation has been part of the European integration process. For a new Europe, ready to meet the needs and needs of European citizens for easier living, a Union policy is needed to keep pace with the rapidly changing global environment. Partnerships with developing countries and emerging economies encourage smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. We must all work for a better Europe. The new Sustainable Development Goals are at the heart of the 2030 Agenda Agreement. I support this draft EP resolution as ambitious and autonomous environmental objectives, with an important commitment to accessibility of sustainability in the areas targeted by the targets, will lead to economic growth, increase energy production and agriculture and restore social balance. The 2030 Agenda and the SDGs are the renewal of international commitment to poverty eradication.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution today, which calls on the Commission to present a communication on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda containing clear information on the structure of implementation of the Agenda at EU and Member State level. Signed less than a year ago by UN member governments, the 2030 Agenda obliges all countries in the world to apply in concrete terms the 17 Sustainable Development Goals it contains, guiding the world on the way forward over the next 15 years. In fact, a process is being set in place which will lead to a new model of development that goes beyond GDP, that is, avoiding relying solely on quantitative growth and which is based on respect for and protection of the planet's natural capital. The resolution calls on the Commission to present a proposal for a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant policy areas, with a detailed roadmap until 2030, as well as to develop effective monitoring, review and accountability mechanisms for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and to report regularly to Parliament.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which refers to the 17 Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations on 25 September 2015. These goals include aims to eradicate poverty, hunger, illiteracy and disease, provide clean water, take action on climate change and achieve gender equality. The aim is to work towards these goals by 2030 and the EU has agreed to fully implement the Agenda. Every year, a progress report will be presented on these goals at UN level at the High-Level Political Forum (HLPF). Reports are made based on data produced by national statistical systems. This Resolution calls for Ministers in the Foreign Affairs Council to adopt a coherent and common position ahead of the July HLPF on how the EU will work towards these goals through its work. The resolution also calls for the Commission to come forward with proposals for an overarching strategy on how these goals can be incorporated at all policy levels and for a detailed timeline for review. In particular, I voted in favour of an amendment that drew concern for the negative impact TTIP, CETA and TiSA could have on achieving the SDGs.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I am concerned that the Foreign Affairs Council has still not adopted any common EU position ahead of the High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development meeting in July. This should be published as soon as possible ahead of this extremely important meeting. Relevant Directorates-General and the European External Action Service should also be involved in the integration of the 2030 Agenda in the forthcoming review of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the motion for a resolution and stress that the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals represent a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty, redefining and modernising our development strategies for the next 15 years and achieving results.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the follow-up actions and progress of the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is a positive attempt to analyse the results and progress of the 2030 Agenda as set out in previous discussions. As we must monitor the progress of the efforts that are under way, I believe that this proposal is positive and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it demonstrates Parliament's position that it wants to plan an economic and political strategy effectively and concretely, in relation to the objectives set for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. In fact, the objectives proposed in this report constitute, in my opinion, a renewed commitment to combating poverty by redefining development strategies for the next 15 years. I believe that proper and targeted programming with a view to cooperation and development between the various Member States is essential for achieving the objectives and objectives that Europe itself is proposing, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ We need a proposal for an overarching Sustainable Development Strategy encompassing all relevant internal and external policy areas, with a detailed timeline up to 2030, a mid-term review and a specific procedure ensuring Parliament’s full involvement, including a concrete implementation plan coordinating the achievement of the 17 goals, 169 targets and 230 global indicators.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report primarily due to the fact that we do not believe should the EU should have the right to any foreign intervention. Any agenda associated with development should the prerogative of the Member State.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the adoption by the United Nations in September 2015 of a new strategy for the Development Agenda by 2030, through the adoption of 17 Sustainable Development Goals, the UN General Assembly called for the objectives and targets to be monitored and revised on the basis of a set of global indicators, and the progress report should support the follow-up and review work of the High Level Political Forum for Sustainable Development. I support this resolution by considering that the new universal framework for sustainable development requires greater coherence between the various EU policy areas and actors through increased EU coordination in order to ensure the integration of environmental, economic and social pillars into the EU's internal and external policies, and the Foreign Affairs Council should be given before the July meeting of the Development Forum , adopt a coherent and common EU position, taking into account the Position of the European Parliament.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this report primarily due to the fact that we do not believe should the EU should have the right to any foreign intervention. Any agenda associated with development should the prerogative of the Member State.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted at the United Nations last September, which includes very positive elements for us in achieving global goals such as hunger eradication, gender equality, or the promotion of peace. However, the European Commission has not taken concrete action to meet this agenda. We supported this resolution because it urges the Commission to take specific measures to achieve these objectives, which requires a real economic commitment to cooperation policies, which sets out the obligation of 0.7% of the budget for this purpose. It also calls for a reorientation of existing policies, so that cross-cutting criteria such as sustainability for the environment, health promotion, or universal access to basic resources such as water are considered. We hope that this resolution will be taken into account and do not add to the long list of failures in this area, because the unwillingness of the governments of the global North has not met these objectives that initially set 2015 as a target.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new global framework for sustainable development requires concerted action between different international and European actors to achieve the objectives set. It will be necessary to integrate the three pillars of sustainable development (environmental, economic and social) into the EU's internal and external policies. In particular, the review of the European Consensus on Development should embrace a new paradigm that includes the 2030 Agenda in the multiannual financial framework and implements adequate and targeted aid programming within the framework of development cooperation, while respecting the principles of aid effectiveness. By voting in favour of this resolution, I intend to support the search for a common position within the European institutions to ensure that results are achieved on the 17 Sustainable Development Goals. I therefore support the call for the Commission to present a communication on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda, so as to provide a coherent strategy and related implementation policies for sustainable development that include consultation with all stakeholders: the European Parliament, the High Level Political Forum, national parliaments, local authorities and civil society.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The UN General Assembly adopted the new 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its Sustainable Development Goals in September 2015. The objectives and objectives are aimed at economic growth, social development and environmental protection. Both the agenda and the objectives and tasks are universal in nature, as they affect and affect all people in developing and developed countries. Issues such as improving people's quality of life, social protection and the environment in which they live are at the centre of attention. The joint motion for a resolution focuses on the EU's common position at the High Level Policy Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF). I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, the UK being one of the largest funding donors for international development projects in the world. The UK at national level is currently reviewing how the Sustainable Development Goals will be implemented, with a focus on ensuring that value for money is given for the UK taxpayer and that aid given is provided effectively and in the right areas.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted at the UN summit held last September 2015 in New York, is the first global agreement defining a universal action programme with an impact on all countries and their national policies. As pointed out in the resolution I supported today, I believe it is crucial for the credibility and leadership of the EU to present a common position on this sensitive issue before the meeting of the High Level Political Forum in July. In this regard, I have some concerns that the Commission has not yet published a communication on the review of the 2030 Agenda, which is of fundamental importance in order to form the basis for a common EU approach. I would also like to stress the need for a more in-depth dialogue between the European institutions on the implementation of the Agenda, and to call on the Commission to develop effective monitoring, review and accountability mechanisms for its implementation. The 2030 Agenda and its objectives constitute an international commitment to eradicate poverty, redefine and modernise development strategies for the next 15 years.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution underlines agenda 2030's commitment to sustainable development, which aims to eradicate poverty, redefine and modernize development strategies. MEPs emphasise the importance of consultation with all stakeholders involved, including national parliaments and local authorities, in the process of drawing up the European Union's new sustainable development strategy.  Considering that it is essential to establish close collaboration between all stakeholders at the level of the European Union and the United Nations, in order to assess the achievement of the sustainable development objectives, to coordinate joint policies and programmes, I supported this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda was adopted by the United Nations on 25 September 2015. It includes 17 Sustainable Development Goals.  I supported this resolution on monitoring and progress on the implementation of these objectives because it encourages the implementation of a comprehensive strategy until 2030, including internal and external policies.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In 2000, UN member states gave themselves 15 years to achieve the "Millennium Development Goals," eliminate extreme poverty and hunger in the world, and ensure primary education for all. One year after their deadline, although we are still very far from the targets, we see that significant progress has been made by the international community. Global poverty has been reduced, access to safe drinking water has increased and the number of children in primary education has increased.  A new international framework for development policies must now be developed. For the European Union, the world's leading provider of development aid, it is important to lead an even more ambitious development strategy, and to focus on issues that have emerged or increased over the decade, such as rising inequality and the challenges of climate change.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is the responsibility of the UN Secretary-General to report each year on progress in the SDGs in support of monitoring and review by the UN High Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF). The aim of this motion for a resolution is to create a coherent and coherent EU position at the HLPF meeting in July.  This is also important because the Commission has still not issued a communication on the follow-up to the 2030 agenda, which could form the basis of the common position. It also urges the Commission to develop an effective monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor the implementation of the 2030 agenda. The motion also reiterates its call on the EU and its Member States to re-commit to participate in Official Development Assistance (ODA) with 0.7% of their gross national income (GNI).

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text on Agenda 2030 and the objectives to be achieved in terms of sustainable development only highlights the inability of conferences, summits and meetings on this subject to change the concrete situation. Prohibitions, regulations, taxation, ecological incentives have clearly not prevented man from consuming the stocks that had been built up by the planet for millions of years.  However, this resolution requires the countries concerned to be accountable within the framework of the 2030 agenda, particularly on the basis of indicators related to the Sustainable Development Goals.  In view of the inadequacy and shortcomings of this approach, I voted against this text.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report proposes that the EU act as a leader in the international scene of eradicating all dimensions of poverty. To achieve this requires a serious and concrete outflow of economic resources, equivalent to 0.7% of the gross national product of the Member States. The aim should be to focus the Union on the issue of eradicating the poverty and misery that plagues its Member States, in particular those in its southern part, and to respect the sovereign right of state governments to take decisions in favour of the inhabitants of their countries.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 It is the responsibility of the UN Secretary-General to report each year on progress in the SDGs in support of monitoring and review by the UN High Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF). The aim of this motion for a resolution is to create a coherent and coherent EU position at the HLPF meeting in July. This is also important because the Commission has still not issued a communication on the follow-up to the 2030 agenda, which could form the basis of the common position. It also urges the Commission to develop an effective monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor the implementation of the 2030 agenda.  The motion also reiterates its call on the EU and its Member States to re-commit to participate in Official Development Assistance (ODA) with 0.7% of their gross national income (GNI). I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals constitute a renewed international commitment to eradicate poverty, redefine and modernise development strategies for the next 15 years and ensure that results are achieved. Monitoring of the objectives achieved and clear and shared planning of future ones are necessary. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Foreign Affairs Council and the European Commission to take parliament's position into account when adopting the common position with a view to the July 2016 meeting of the High-Level Political Forum.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposed set of 230 indicators for sustainable development goals (SDGs) represents a good starting point and provides a solid framework for monitoring and assessing progress in achieving the 17 SDGs. I therefore agree that the Foreign Affairs Council should take a coherent and common position of the EU, taking into account Parliament's position as expressed in this resolution. The 2030 Agenda and the SDMs represent a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty, redefining and modernising our development strategies for the next 15 years and ensuring results.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I vote against it: these are generally measures based on prohibitions, regulations, taxation, ecological incentives, with unfortunately often few constraints.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The "2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development" consists of 17 objectives, divided into 169 goals. Unanimously approved in September 2015 at a UN summit, the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, conceived from the Millennium Development Goals, aim to be a common vision for humanity and a social contract established with the peoples of the world. The resolution not only welcomes the objectives and importance of their universality, but also highlights the fact that the EU (as a regional bloc) and its Member States (individually) have committed to implementing all objectives and targets. However, throughout the resolution there is no criticism of the fact that the EU's own formal and informal legislation (notably with regard to economic governance) is an obstacle to meeting these objectives, as institutionalisation and the imposition of neoliberal policies further aggravated poverty and hunger, deregulated labour laws and therefore removed dignity at work , accentuated inequalities between classes, degraded public health and education services and inhibited economic growth.  While we are following the urgent need to work for the SDDs to be achieved, we cannot remain indifferent to the hypocrisy of the EU and its omission in this resolution.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission should submit to the European Parliament a proposal for a sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of internal and external policy. The new European Union Sustainable Development Strategy and related implementation procedures should be the subject of extensive consultation with all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and, last but not least, civil society. The revision of the European Consensus on Development must fully reflect the new 2030 Agenda, which includes a shift and a full-fledged transformation of the European Union's development policy.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because it does not address the issue of a radical and necessary change in the development aid policies of third countries, without, for example, providing for verification between some of the right proposed objectives and their effective implementation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report proposes that the EU act as a leader in the international scene of eradicating all dimensions of poverty. To achieve this requires a serious and concrete outflow of economic resources, equivalent to 0.7% of the gross national product of the Member States. The aim should be to focus the Union on the issue of eradicating the poverty and misery that plagues its Member States, in particular those in its southern part, and to respect the sovereign right of state governments to take decisions in favour of the inhabitants of their countries. For these reasons I am voting against the follow-up actions and the progress of the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The 230 Sustainable Development Goal indicators represent a good starting point and robust framework intended for follow-up and review of progress towards achieving the 17 SDGs and we must insist on their achievement as much as possible. Therefore, it is fundamental to hear from the Commission updates on the follow-up and review of the Agenda 2030. I agree strongly with the idea that it is crucial for the EU’s credibility and leadership to develop a coherent and common EU position on the implementation of the Agenda 2030. The Inter-Agency and Expert Group on the SDG indicators represents a remarkable achievement and a good basis for negotiations since the proposed indicators draw attention to a far more diverse set of structural concerns. Finally, I believe the new EU Sustainable Development Strategy and associated implementation policies should be subject to a broad consultation with all stakeholders.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is indeed crucial that the political and financial commitments made under Agenda 2030 are implemented quickly and effectively.  The European Union has managed to speak with one voice and has been a leader in inclusive negotiations for Agenda 2030. In particular, the integration of issues of rule of law, democracy and good governance, particularly in Objective 16, bears the imprint of the European approach. Without a strong European strategy, guaranteeing the coordination and coherence of our policies, we will not be able to live up to what we have defended in the negotiations. Thus, monitoring and reviewing this agenda will be crucial to achieving the expected results.  The European Union and its Member States must now review the European consensus for development to fully reflect Agenda 2030.  Finally, as the resolution points out, the mid-term review of the annual financial framework will also be an important way to reflect the commitments made by the Union in Agenda 2030.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Eradicating poverty and, with it, achieving the SDGs remains our priority. The Union has a serious responsibility to the present, but also to the future generation. The perspective of the 2030 agenda is positive, according to which the SDGs are integrated and indivisible and balance the three dimensions of sustainable development: economic, social and environmental. I have approved the motion for a resolution.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 One year after the EU's adoption of the UN Sustainable Development Agenda, I believe that proceeding with initial monitoring of the actions and results of the plan is an act of due responsibility towards citizens and the whole of society.  Global geopolitics is going through times of great economic and social fragility; That is why I believe that the 17 ambitious objectives set deserve our full attention in relation to their progress, confirming the urgency and priorities of EU actions. Indeed, I believe that overcoming the crisis by aiming for a new model of development that involves not only quantitative but also qualitative growth of the planet – as the concept of the circular economy, for example – well sums up– means investing in a real cultural revolution involving participatory development, capable of enclosing economic growth, but also social progress and greater environmental protection in coordinated and common work.  This is an important challenge to deal with major threats such as hunger, poverty, social exclusion and at the same time aim to develop a new model of growth: employment, finance, energy and socially inclusive.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP non-legislative resolution on the proposal presented following statements by the Council and the Commission on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda. I am, in fact, in favour of the report of the Expert Group on Indicators relating to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDRs), which is responsible for drawing up a proposal for the framework of indicators for monitoring the objectives and targets for post-2015 development.  230 indicators have been proposed for the review of the 2030 Agenda, which are a good starting point for the Sustainable Development Goals and which provide a solid framework for the follow-up and review of progress. I believe that the 2030 Agenda and its development goals constitute an international commitment to erasing poverty by modernising development strategies for the next 15 years. Full use will have to be made of the next mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework to ensure that all agenda commitments agreed with the EU are met.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on "Continuation and current status of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals". Sustainability is an important objective of the EU and all Member States. To this day, however, there is a lack of instruments, partly the courage to really tackle these objectives and to develop our economy towards a sustainable system without any destructive pressure to grow.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution which measures concrete actions for the European Commission on the Sustainable Development Goals. Following the adoption of the so-called Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 within the United Nations last September, the European Commission has done little or nothing to adapt its policies to this new development agenda. We consider it essential that the Commission urgently establish a roadmap in this regard, as the resolution positively points out.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it represents a new step in the European Union's commitment to sustainable development. It provides a necessary clarification of responsibilities but also encourages the development of new synergies between the European institutions in favour of the environment. These measures are a guarantee of a more effective and coordinated programme to achieve the ambitious targets set for 2030.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. It is important that the Commission should include more policy areas (as for now only the environment, economic and social areas are included), so it would truly reach the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 It is the responsibility of the UN Secretary-General to report each year on progress in the SDGs in support of monitoring and review by the UN High Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF). The aim of this motion for a resolution is to achieve a coherent EU position at the HLPF meeting in July.  This is also important because the Commission has still not issued a communication on the follow-up to the 2030 agenda, which could form the basis of the common position. It also urges the Commission to develop an effective monitoring and accountability mechanism to monitor the implementation of the 2030 agenda. The motion also reiterates its call on the EU and its Member States to re-commit to participate in Official Development Assistance (ODA) with 0.7% of their gross national income (GNI).

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution. The Sustainable Development Goals are important tools in the global development strategy. The EU should produce a coherent and common position in relation to the implementation of the SDGs. We are committed to the eradication of poverty and therefore we should redefine and modernise our development strategies to ensure that these goals are achieved. The universality of these goals should be stressed and the EU along with its Member States should commit fully to their implementation, both in practice and in spirit.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I had no objections to its contents.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that Europe as a whole must be united with regard to the vision for modernisation and development strategies for the next 15 years. As such, it is crucial to involve all stakeholders in consultation – in particular civil society. Furthermore, it is important to underline one particular aspect in this resolution – a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty. This should be the EU’s top priority.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on the state of play and further action on Agenda 2030 and the SDGs, as needed to modernise the EU's development strategy for the next 15 years, and to focus further efforts towards eradicating poverty internationally.  I believe it is necessary to ensure the implementation of a comprehensive strategy involving all relevant foreign and domestic policies and in which the European Parliament will play an active role. It is also necessary to align the political and development objectives of agenda 2030 with budgetary possibilities and forecasts.  I support the proposal calling on the Commission to provide clear information on the implementation structure of this Agenda at European and national level, and I therefore support this resolution.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and fellow UKIP voted against this report primarily due to the fact that we do not believe should the EU should have the right to any foreign intervention. Any agenda associated with development should the prerogative of the Member State.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. In particular, the resolution calls for the European Sustainable Development Strategy to be the subject of extensive consultation, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society. This I support, hence my vote in favour of the text.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the European Union to take a united position at the forthnd-level UN Policy Forum for Sustainable Development, and to strengthen policy coherence for development.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting against this resolution. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals will be used to give the Commission renewed powers and mechanisms that it could then fully use to implement the Agenda without prior consultation and consent from Member States.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because it calls on the European Union to make full use of the multiannual financial framework on the one hand to ensure financial mechanisms and, on the other hand, for Member States to reiterate their commitment to 0.7% of GNI for official development aid and to submit a timetable for the gradual increase in development aid in order to achieve 0.7%.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution on the follow-up to the 2030 Agenda and its review, as I believe that achieving the Sustainable Development Goals offers the EU the opportunity to turn the commitments made into concrete actions. It is essential to develop a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant internal and external EU policy areas and which will encourage all Member States to commit to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and to adopt relevant national frameworks for their implementation and implementation. I believe that Europe's role should be strengthened not only as a major donor of humanitarian aid, but also as an active factor determining the development of the world. This will strengthen cooperation in shaping new security strategies, addressing global crises, challenges and threats, as well as implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals represent a renewed international commitment, aimed at eradicating poverty and redefining and modernising development strategies for the next 15 years. The adoption of this resolution is part of this context. Parliament called for the adoption of a joint inter-institutional position and for the Commission to adopt a concrete implementation plan to coordinate the achievement of global objectives, targets and indicators and, above all, to ensure their full implementation. In view of the next mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, we also call for the financing mechanisms and budget lines to reflect the commitments made under the 2030 Agenda agreed by the Union. To this end, we call on the Member States and the Union to renew their commitment to the 0.7% GNI target for official development aid and to ensure that this aid gradually increases.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development seeks to build on the Millennium Development Goals and complete those goals which have not been achieved. Therefore, the main goals and targets of the 2030 agenda over the next 15 years have been put in areas of crucial importance for humanity and the planet, such as: people, planet, prosperity, peace and partnership. It should be emphasised that the EU has played an important role in shaping the 2030 agenda, through public consultations, dialogue with its partners and in-depth research. The EU should continue to play a crucial role, this time in the implementation of the agenda. A good starting point for this will be if we manage – through coordination, dialogue and joint work at all levels within and between EU institutions – to ensure the integration of this universal agenda in EU internal and external policies. Thus, the EU will have an opportunity to make the world a better place by 2030.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the monitoring and progress of agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals. National Front MP Jean-Luc Schaffhauser intervened to denounce the charade of European policy in this area when we know that Greece, currently under attack by the EU, is experiencing a sharp increase in child mortality, that the health crisis continues (see the Red Cross and Doctors of the World). Talking about sustainable development under these conditions is therefore disturbing. The text refers to the countless summits, texts, ranging from the United Nations to the various gas plants of the European institutions. All the measures recommended, even if they can be beneficial, have obviously not solved the problems at the moment, especially since countries are not immune to them, such as the United States and China.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out against this text. It comes from the majority of the Parliament's political groups (EPP, S-D, ECR, ALDE, EFDD, GUE) and tends to bring European citizens closer to the sustainable development goals set out in Agenda 2030. In particular, it calls on the Commission to develop a communication on the HLPF (High Political Forum on Sustainable Development) to be held in September 2016. In addition, the text aims to organise a broad consultation involving all civil society actors. The proposals are therefore windy and do not concern themselves with urgent situations such as the health crisis in Greece, which is experiencing a sharp increase in infant mortality.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Last September, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted at the United Nations, which includes very positive elements for us in achieving global goals such as the eradication of hunger, gender equality, or the promotion of peace. However, the European Commission has not taken concrete action to meet this agenda. We supported this resolution because it urges the Commission to take specific measures to achieve these objectives, which requires a real economic commitment to cooperation policies, which sets out the obligation of 0.7% of the budget for this purpose. It also calls for a reorientation of existing policies, so that cross-cutting criteria such as sustainability for the environment, health promotion, or universal access to basic resources such as water are considered. We hope that this resolution will be taken into account and do not add to the long list of failures in this area, because the unwillingness of the governments of the global North has not met these objectives that initially set 2015 as a target.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. As we already know, the 2030 Agenda is an action plan developed for people, the planet and prosperity that aims to strengthen universal peace and definitively eradicate poverty. In this area, we must highlight the role played by the Union and its institutions, as well as by its Member States, main players in order to achieve these objectives. What this proposal aims to do is for developing countries to set regular targets, which will be examined by the Commission and forwarded to Parliament for action.  In addition, it recalled that a significant endowment of economic resources was necessary in order for the objectives set to be effectively achieved.  On the basis of the above, I consider this Resolution of great importance, since the eradication of poverty in the world is an urgent challenge, as well as a priority for the Union and for citizens.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the EU's call on member states to allote 9.7% of GDP for international aid. We will help poor countries better by freeing up international trade with them. State development aid is not working and is sauing the market in poor countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 needs to provide a holistic response to growing global challenges. It is a new global framework for combating poverty and achieving the 2030 SDGs and contains a package of 17 objectives necessary to achieve the purpose of the Agenda. These objectives cover and cover areas such as the fight against poverty, inequality, health, sustainable growth and development, climate change, etc. The objectives of the Agenda build on the development goals adopted in 2000 and represent cooperation within the international community to fulfil a global commitment to create a better future. The Agenda is the first global agreement to set out a comprehensive global road plan for action and to affect all countries. It is essential that all countries participate in the implementation of this programme in order to jointly meet the 17 ambitious targets set by the Agenda. Particular emphasis was placed on the successful implementation of these objectives, so I supported this proposal for a resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 10/5/2016 and because this motion for a resolution is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  This motion for a resolution comes from the majority of the political groups in the European Parliament.  It aims to set sustainable development targets (economic development compatible with respect for the environment) for the needs of the 2030 agenda. This document will define the European Union's multi-year development strategy. In the immediate future, the resolution calls on the Commission to produce a comprehensive document, out of the progress made by 22 States, including four Member States, on environmental protection. This communication will be used for the UN Forum on Sustainable Development, scheduled for September 2016. We do not object to the necessary protection of the environment. However, the very notion of sustainable development is based on the idea of "global governance" that we reject. In addition, we doubt the effectiveness of measures taken by supranational bodies in terms of sustainable development.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the SDGs were endorsed by the UN General Assembly in September 2015. This is a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty, redefining and modernising our development strategies for the next 15 years. The document contains 17 new SDGs and 169 sub-objectives ensure a balance between the three dimensions of sustainable development – environmental, social and economic – for example in the following areas: poverty, inequality, food security, health, sustainable consumption and production, growth, employment, infrastructure, sustainable management of natural resources or climate change, but also gender equality. A full range of resources, both domestic and international, as well as public and private, is needed to successfully fulfil this programme. All countries must contribute their fair share, taking into account their level of development, special conditions and capacity. National own and mutual responsibility will be key to the agenda. I voted yes.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Parliament's motion for a resolution following statements by the Council and the Commission on the monitoring and status of agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals. It is necessary for the European institutions to constantly monitor the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs to ensure that we make progress in the fight against poverty and correct the course of action where necessary, ensuring that there is adequate implementation of the three dimensions of sustainable development: economic, social and environmental development.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that substantial changes and a comprehensive reform of EU development policy are necessary in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The United Nations has been working since September on renewed Sustainable Development Goals, a roadmap for the next 15 years, through common precise development indicators. A meeting in July will discuss the progress of the work. While the Commission and the Council are discussing this, the European Parliament has still not been consulted, a symbol of the lack of cases given to democracy in Brussels. The resolution calls for the EU Positioning Commission's proposal on this work to be widely known and for parliaments to be properly consulted and associated. The text supports the objectives, in particular, of the eradication of poverty. It highlights the remarks of UN experts on the need for resources in national statistical offices. If not, how can reliable development indicators be established? Our concerns about TAFTA and other treaties for multinationals are irreconcilable with these objectives. They were therefore rejected. The text is very deficient, especially on the Paris agreement on climate change, and tends to defend the questionable idea of a necessary common eu position at the UN, ignoring the sovereignty of states. Nevertheless, I am voting to show my support for the work of the United Nations.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The resolution is based on the concept of sustainable development. This unreasonable notion attempts to unite ecology and economic interests, with the practical inertia inherent in it. As a result I voted against it.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The challenges we face call for us to develop a comprehensive sustainable development strategy within the European Union to translate the 17 Sustainable Development Goals into concrete terms. In my view, this strategy must be inclusive, taking into account the positions of all development actors, covering all relevant areas of domestic and external policies, involving the private sector as a development actor, and proposing integrated solutions to preserve the indivisible nature of the 2030 agenda. It is essential for the credibility of the Union and its leadership position to present a common position.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I followed the European Parliament's motion for a resolution to call on the European Commission to submit a proposal for a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of internal and external policy, with a detailed timetable by 2030, including a mid-term review and a specific procedure ensuring the involvement of the European Parliament.  I voted in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for more coherence between the EU’s policies and closer cooperation between the different partners when it comes to reaching the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Poverty eradication is a major objective of the Union's development policy. The Millennium Development Goals have raised awareness of the issue of eradicating global poverty as an urgent challenge and priority in taking global action, as the level of achievement of the Millennium Development Goals varies and, overall, the international community is far from achieving the goals that should have been met as early as 2015. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development lists 17 SDGs and 169 targets that demonstrate great ambition by trying to build on the Millennium Development Goals and complete what they have not achieved. Eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and a necessary condition for sustainable development. The Member States and the Union institutions must take concrete steps to achieve the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the state of play of the Agenda 2030 and Sustainable Development Goals because the development policy is a key in achieving a more inclusive and peaceful world by uniting global efforts to improve people’s lives worldwide and eradicate poverty.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The EFDD and jointly the PPE, S&D, ECR, ALDE and GUE/NGL political groups submitted a motion for a parliamentary resolution on the subject indicated. I supported the joint motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to produce a communication ahead of the Forum on Sustainable Development, scheduled for September 2016, to be held at the United Nations with all member countries. Basically, these are measures based on prohibitions, regulations, taxation, ecological incentives, with, alas, often few constraints. All these measures, even if they can be beneficial, have obviously not prevented the destruction of the planet and its resources, since we also know that countries are escaping these measures, such as the United States and China. While we can only share the alarming observation of the state of the planet and the plundering of resources by the industrial economy and the dogma of infinite growth, it is not desirable to support this resolution insofar as it succeeds in endorsing the hypocrisy of the world's leaders on these issues.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the High Level Political Forum (PanF) plays a key role in reviewing the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and that it should ensure a coordinated and effective assessment of needs, as well as the adoption of the roadmaps needed for the effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda. The 2030 Agenda and the SDMs represent an international agreement aimed at eradicating poverty, redefining and modernising our development strategies for the next 15 years and ensuring results. I believe that the EU should adopt a strategy for sustainable development and its implementation policies should be the subject of extensive consultation involving all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The resolution calls for the European Sustainable Development Strategy to be the subject of extensive consultation including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society, which seems to be a no-brainer. So far, few amendments have been tabled, so the most interesting comes from the GUE and concerns about the threat TTIP, CETA, TISA. But as is often the case, support for this political group seems irrelevant. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the status of Agenda 2030, which enshrines sustainable development and the fight against climate change in a common framework for both developed and developing countries. In particular, the resolution calls on the European Union to negotiate a united position for the upcoming UN High-Level Political Forum for Sustainable Development (FPHN). It also calls for greater coherence of policies in the service of development.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2000, the United Nations launched the Millennium Development Goals (MDG) programme, which sought solutions to the most serious global problems, such as reducing child mortality, halving the number of people suffering from severe poverty and famine, and reducing the spread of deadly diseases. The programme, known as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), will continue until 2030 and will, to my great delight, be extended to environmental objectives such as the sustainable use of the seas, oceans, forests and the whole ecosystem.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that reiterates the fact that the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs are renewed international commitments to eradicate poverty, redefine and modernise our development strategies for the next 15 years and to make sure these targets are achieved.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the sustainable development of the European Union must be one of the main objectives of the community. In this respect, the report voted today encourages the European institutions and the institutions of the Member States to have closer cooperation with a view to economic, social and environmental development. I also welcome the fact that the report encourages the European Commission to develop effective mechanisms for monitoring, evaluation and accountability for the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, which are unavailable for assessing progress.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the resolution also contains, in my opinion, a very important call on the EU and the Member States to confirm their intention to allocate 0.7% of GNI to official development assistance and to present a timetable for gradually increasing official development assistance in order to achieve this 0.7% objective. Unfortunately, funding for development programmes such as the UN World Food Programme and the EU Trust Funds for Syria and Africa remain well below expectations and well below the commitments made. Therefore, EU Member States must make a significant addition in this area if the fight against poverty and conflicts in the world and the related causes of the protracted migration crisis are to be successful.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at the votes, I would have voted in favour of this report. The report is intended to respect the democratic and political room for manoeuvre of the government.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Greater cooperation and coherence between the different policy areas and EU actors is essential to ensure that the three pillars of sustainable development are integrated into the EU's internal and external policies.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled. The 2030 agenda is more ambitious and provides concrete action not only for developing countries but also for developed countries. Its implementation must be given particular attention. It covers all three dimensions of sustainable development: environmental, social and economic. I believe that the Commission should develop a sustainable development strategy covering all internal and external policies and providing for a comprehensive 2030 agenda.  and its review schedule. In addition, the EU Strategy for Sustainable Development and related implementation policies should be widely consulted by all stakeholders. In order to contribute to poverty eradication and sustainable development by 2030, it is essential to provide for appropriate and targeted aid programming and development cooperation, with due respect for the principles of aid effectiveness.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this report primarily due to the fact that we do not believe should the EU should have the right to any foreign intervention. Any agenda associated with development should the prerogative of the Member State.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the indicated in UN General Assembly Resolution 70/1, in view of the need, also manifested at European level, to review and implement the framework indicators for monitoring the objectives of the post-2015 and 2030 agenda and considering, finally, that at the heart of the 2030 Agenda is the eradication of poverty and the definition of development strategies over the next 15 years and that the Sustainable Development Goals must be the basis of all future EU trade agreements, I believe that my fellow Members' proposal should be encouraged at European and international level. I would therefore like to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – This Agenda is a plan of action for people, planet and prosperity. It also seeks to strengthen universal peace in larger freedom. We recognise that eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and an indispensable requirement for sustainable development. All countries and all stakeholders, acting in collaborative partnership, will implement this plan. Therefore I vote for the Agenda 2030 and Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted at the UN in 2015 and continuing on the Millennium Development Goals adopted in 2000 sets out a global framework to eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development by 2030. The 2030 Programme covers an ambitious set of 17 SDGs and 169 related objectives, mobilising all countries and stakeholders to achieve these objectives and impacting national policies. The programme is a universal framework for all countries.  I share my concern that the Commission has not published a communication on monitoring and evaluating the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development ahead of the High-Level Policy Forum on Sustainable Development, which would certainly help to agree the EU's common positions, in particular with the commitment to eradicate poverty, which I personally consider one of the priorities. In this regard, it is good to carry out extensive consultations with all stakeholders, and it is necessary to develop effective monitoring, evaluation and accountability mechanisms for the implementation of this Programme and to launch a high-level dialogue on the implementation of the SDGs with a view to coordinating eu policies, programmes and actions, the UN and other donors.  I supported the Resolution on monitoring and evaluating the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and call on the Commission to accept the European Parliament's requests and to report regularly on the progress made.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution as I strongly support the need for a unanimous EU position on sustainable development issues. The new universal framework for sustainable development requires greater coherence between the different policy areas and the actors involved, which requires further coordination, dialogue and cooperation at all levels within the Union. The Commission and the EEAS need to present a comprehensive strategy on the implementation of the 2030 Agenda involving all relevant areas of action both inside and outside the Union, and this new approach must ensure the full participation of Parliament, in particular with regard to development policy and the coherence of development policies, in accordance with the principles of transparency and mutual responsibility. It is necessary to integrate this strategy into all EU institutions in order to ensure effective cooperation and overcome the 'watertight compartment' approach. The Eu ropean Union must also pursue close cooperation with UN bodies in order to coordinate the policies, programmes and activities of the EU, the UN and other actors involved, and enhance accessibility to disaggregated data in order to monitor progress and assess results.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Strategy represent a renewed moral obligation of the European Union to do whatever it takes to achieve economic development, but to economic development that takes care of both its environmental and social implications, and which strives to combat poverty. I insist that the new Sustainable Development Strategy and its appropriate implementation be the subject of a wide range of consultations with national parliaments, local authorities and civil society representatives, etc., in order to hear all the different opinions of the relevant actors before developing the Strategy itself. I invite the Commission to present concrete proposals on more efficient policy integration for sustainable development in the implementation of Agenda 2030. I call on the Commission to develop effective means of supervision, audits and accountability mechanisms for the implementation of Agenda 2030 and to report on the implementation of the same to the European Parliament.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The "2030 Agenda on Sustainable Development", adopted in 2015 at the UN, consists of 17 objectives conceived from the Millennium Development Goals. They aim to be a common vision for humanity and a social contract between world leaders and peoples. The resolution not only welcomes the objectives and importance of their universality, but also highlights the fact that the EU (as a regional bloc) and its Member States (individually) have committed to implementing all objectives and targets. However, throughout the resolution there is no criticism of the fact that the EU's own formal and informal legislation (in particular with regard to economic governance) is an obstacle to meeting these objectives, as institutionalisation and imposition of economic and neoliberal policies further aggravated poverty and hunger, deregulated labour laws and therefore , realed dignity from work, accentuated inequalities between classes, degraded public health and education services and inhibited economic growth.  While we are following the urgent need to work for the SDDs to be achieved, we cannot remain indifferent to the hypocrisy of the EU and its omission in this resolution. For this reason, we abstained.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. The Union has adopted a highly ambitious plan containing guidelines for poverty eradication, as well as 17 sustainable development targets and 169 intentions to address most of the world's complex problems. The objectives of Agenda 2030 are objectives that the European Union has always set for its Member States, but also represent EU policies as trans-national advocates of peace and stability. I support the European Parliament's resolution, which shows the breadth and ambition of objectives in the areas of development of economic, social, political infrastructures of globalised societies. I hope that action will be accelerated in the areas of promoting a stronger partnership between Member States and that the Union will be a positive example that will act as a mirror to the performance and achievement of the Agenda objectives.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the importance of European and global development policy, I supported the resolution on monitoring and the state of play of the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs. The Council of the European Union for Foreign Affairs needs to develop a common position in this regard, which would be the starting point for the next high-level political forum. Needless to say, even though there has been an overall decline in poverty compared to previous decades, there are still about 900 million people in the world who have to survive with less than $1.9 a day. Therefore, the basic conditions for a decent life and the satisfaction of the most basic human needs can often not even be talked about. I therefore called on the European Commission, with my vote, to put forward a proposal for an overarching internal and external policy strategy, the development of which should be consulted by all relevant parties. This includes civil society, whose role is irreplaceable in providing development aid. Furthermore, I supported the renewal of the member states' already historic commitment to contribute 0.7% of gross national income to official development assistance. At present, only 5 Member States have not forgotten this commitment. As in other areas, I believe that if the Member States were more conscientious and fulfilled their commitments, Europe would not be facing a crisis of this magnitude at present.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the European Union to have a common and coherent position at the UN High-Level Political Forum in July.  Indeed, it is crucial that the EU participates in the context of this high-level political forum in the review of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals that were adopted in September 2015 by the United Nations (Agenda 2030).   It should also be stressed that the European Parliament calls in this resolution on the European Commission and the EEAS to put forward concrete proposals on how to more effectively integrate policy coherence in the service of development into the implementation of Agenda 2030. It is a political priority for me to ensure the coherence of the actions taken by the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The role of the European Parliament is to monitor the actions of the European institutions and to participate in the development of their guidelines. As part of the achievement of the United Nations Agenda 2030 objectives, I voted in favour of a resolution calling on the European Commission to propose a comprehensive sustainable development strategy with a detailed timetable until 2030 and also asking it to present a paper on the monitoring and review of this Agenda 2030, to understand the structure of its implementation at the level of the European Union and its Member States.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the monitoring and progress of agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals. This resolution reflects the European Parliament's position for the United Nations High-Level Political Forum for Sustainable Development (FPHN) to be held in July 2016. The forum aims to assess needs and adopt the roadmaps needed to implement Agenda 2030.  In this context, the Commission should propose a comprehensive sustainable development strategy as well as present a communication on the monitoring and review of Agenda 2030. It will also be necessary to ensure that the mid-term review of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) reflects the commitments made by the Union in Agenda 2030.  Presenting a common and coherent position on sustainable development is important for the credibility of the European Union. It should also effectively integrate policy coherence, including through regular dialogue with all stakeholders to ensure effective cooperation between the institutions. Finally, it would be necessary to increase the democratic control of the European Parliament in the implementation of Agenda 2030.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission should present a proposal for a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of internal and external policy, with a detailed timetable by 2030, a mid-term review and a specific procedure ensuring parliament's full involvement, including a concrete implementation plan. The same should be done with the making available clear information on the framework for implementing the 2030 Agenda at Union and Member State level. I would also like to draw attention to the European Union and its Member States' commitment to allocate 0.7 % of GNI to Official Development Assistance.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development adopted in September 2015 entered into force on 1 January. Countries will need to intensify efforts over the next 15 years to end poverty in all its forms, reduce inequality and fight climate change. Since they are not binding, it is up to governments to adopt them as their own and to establish national frameworks for their achievement. As the resolution, which I have supported, urges the adoption of a joint strategy by the European Union for the implementation of the SDGs, as well as to agree and develop indicators to assist in the process of monitoring the achievement of the objectives, and to ensure sufficient resources, by calling on the EU and its Member States to commit without delay to reaching 0.7% of GDP in development aid.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I have of course supported the text of this resolution. I also supported an amendment that is particularly concerned about the negative impact that future trade agreements such as TTIP, the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Trade in Services Agreement (ACS) will have on sustainable development objectives. The amendment called on the European Commission to ensure that all trade policies are aligned with human rights and sustainable development goals. However, it was not retained by the majority.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this very important document. The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid. At the same time, reading the document is sad, seeing how even with the huge EU support, the development goals are not achievable. The fate of the Millennium Development Goals to Eradicate Poverty in the World is worth it! I support the document, but at the same time I ask the Commission and all my colleagues – do we really need to change the approach to providing development aid and to calculate, above all, the real results and the effectiveness of the funds spent by the EU, and the EU's role in the application of corrective measures as well?

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The document "2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development" was approved in New York last September. The European Parliament considers that it will be up to the Political Forum for Sustainable Development to ensure a coordinated and efficient assessment of the needs and the adoption of the measures necessary for the effective implementation of this Agenda. This and the Sustainable Development Goals represent an international commitment by the EU and its Member States to eradicate poverty by redefining and modernising development strategies for the next 15 years.  This resolution - which I voted in favour of - calls for the Commission to present a proposal for monitoring and implementing the sustainable development strategy covering the relevant internal and external policies as well as the timetable ahead of 2030. Given the importance and universality of the objectives with which the EU has committed itself, the EU's new sustainable development strategy and its associated implementation policies should be subject to extensive public consultation, in particular with all stakeholders, using a more inclusive procedure.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Union to have a united position at the forthnd-level UN Policy Forum on Sustainable Development and to strengthen policy coherence for development. Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals are a new international commitment to poverty eradication and new strategies for policies for development. The aim is to emphasise the need to make policies in the development service coherent between them, both at European and international level with the United Nations, for example, and all other donors. I supported this text because it also reminds us of the need for the Union to ensure that the review of the Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) is an opportunity to take into account its commitments in Agenda 2030.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, the result of a broad compromise, the European Parliament calls on the Foreign Affairs Council to express an EU common position in the context of the adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development within the United Nations. It also called for this agenda to be translated into a common strategy at Member State level, capable of giving Europe a leading role in its implementation. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and those who supported the tabling of this resolution, I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution which measures concrete actions for the European Commission on the Sustainable Development Goals. Following the adoption of the so-called Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 within the United Nations last September, the European Commission has done little or nothing to adapt its policies to this new development agenda. We consider it essential that the Commission urgently establish a roadmap in this regard, as the resolution positively points out.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Last September, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development was adopted at the United Nations, which includes very positive elements for us in achieving global goals such as the eradication of hunger, gender equality, or the promotion of peace. However, the European Commission has not taken concrete action to meet this agenda. We supported this resolution because it urges the Commission to take specific measures to achieve these objectives, which requires a real economic commitment to cooperation policies, which sets out the obligation of 0.7% of the budget for this purpose. It also calls for a reorientation of existing policies, so that cross-cutting criteria such as sustainability for the environment, health promotion, or universal access to basic resources such as water are considered. We hope that this resolution will be taken into account and do not add to the long list of failures in this area, because the unwillingness of the governments of the global North has not met these objectives that initially set 2015 as a target.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the next High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development to be held in July, the resolution adopted today is the European Parliament's contribution to the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda, aimed at erasing poverty and redefining and modernising development strategies for the next 15 years.  I hope that in this context, the European Union will adopt a solid common position in order to effectively integrate all dimensions of sustainable development and to strengthen the coherence of development policies also within the UN working structures. Indeed, the current scenario requires not only greater coordination, dialogue and cooperation between all EU actors, but also a shared international vision of global humanitarian priorities. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I am absolutely sympathetic to the 2030 Agenda and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It seems very important to me that there should be a Communication from the Commission on the monitoring and revision of the 2030 Agenda containing clear information on the framework for implementing the Agenda at Union and Member State level. I also argue that the proposals and budgetary implementations of the European institutions should reflect respect for the SDDS and that Member States' budgets affect significant sums in place to achieve the SDDS. Since all these perspectives are reflected in this motion for a resolution, I voted positively. In general terms, I agree with Amendment No 1.
