However, I consider it excessive to be sure that the international trade agreements in preparation will have negative impacts on the SDDs and it seems to me that we should not disperse this important document by other legal initiatives that are underway. That's why I abstained.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that dialogue is needed to find the right solutions. Therefore, in order for the EU to achieve the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, it is necessary to set specific objectives on the basis of close consultation of all stakeholders. For this reason, I supported this resolution, which stresses the need to ensure that the EU Strategy for Sustainable Development is precisely the subject of wide consultation with all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society, through an inclusive process.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this Report, and this reasoning for voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Last year was the European Year of Sustainable Development, as a number of major development aid events took place during its course. The last Paris Agreement of December 2015 was a watershed moment for the international community, as it succeeded in reaching a consensus between developed and emerging countries. However, how the objectives and commitments set will be met will be crucial. To this end, a meeting of the UN Economic and Social Council will also take place in July this year to discuss the implementation of the post-2015 development agenda, with the intention of finally reaching results from commitments. It will be essential for the European Union's negotiating position to adopt a coherent and common position. In view of this, the Commission should have come up with an evaluation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. So, before the forthcoming meeting of the UN High Group, it looks like the EU will be struggling to pull the same end. However, we must bear in mind that the main commitment to sustainable development is to try to eradicate poverty, redete and modernise the development strategy for the next 15 years. The misdeeds that we are constantly talking about in relation to development aid should serve as a memento and motivation for more consistent promotion of the interests of those directly affected by poverty.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The idea of sustainable development in Europe should be both legitimate and credible. It requires progress in three areas, a common solution to economic, social and environmental issues in a consistent manner and avoiding splits between policy types in order to achieve the objectives set.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ A new universal framework for sustainable development requires more connectivity between different policy areas and EUROPEAN Union actors and further coordination, dialogue and joint work at all levels within and between the EU institutions to ensure the integration of all three pillars of sustainable development (environmental, economic and social) in EU external and internal policies. Likewise, Agenda 2030 and the SDGs represent a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty and redefining and modernising development strategies for the next 15 years. The implementation of the SDGs itself includes a significant role for the Political Forum on Sustainable Development at high level, which must become the main body for ensuring the monitoring and evaluation of the implementation of the SDGs in order to ensure a coordinated and effective assessment of the needs and adoption of the plans and decisions necessary for the implementation of the SDGs. An overview of the state of play and further activities of Agenda 2030 and the SDGs are of utmost importance and I therefore support this proposal for a resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ A new universal framework for sustainable development requires more connectivity between different policy areas and EUROPEAN Union actors and further coordination, dialogue and joint work at all levels within and between the EU institutions to ensure the integration of all three pillars of sustainable development (environmental, economic and social) in EU external and internal policies. Likewise, Agenda 2030 and the SDGs represent a renewed international commitment to eradicating poverty and redefining and modernising development strategies for the next 15 years. Agenda 2030 redefines cooperation within the international community on the global commitment to create a different future for people and the planet through sustainable development. Also, the agenda aims to respect human rights, as well as achieve gender equality and empower women and girls in society. I support the proposal for a resolution because I believe that Agenda 2030 is one of the key elements for eradicating poverty, but also for future world integration. I also support this proposal because the SDGs are of utmost importance.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution at the conclusion of the debate on the Statements by the Council and the Commission on the next steps and the review of the 2030 Agenda. With the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs, the international community commits to poverty eradication and redefins and updates our development strategies for the next 15 years. I support the call for the Foreign Affairs Council to adopt a common position of the European Union, in line with Parliament's position, of course, on the next steps and the current state of play of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. This is essential for credibility and for maintaining the EU's leadership.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution is only promises based on institutional solutions and tried and tested recipes, such as further engagement and initiatives by EEAS. It does not contain any criticism of EU policies on interventions in third countries and links development with security. We have observed an attitude of abstention because we remain committed to sustainable development.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report proposes that the EU act as a leader in the international scene of eradicating all dimensions of poverty. To achieve this requires a serious and concrete outflow of economic resources, equivalent to 0.7% of the gross national product of the Member States. The aim should be to focus the Union on the issue of eradicating the poverty and misery that plagues its Member States, in particular those in its southern part, and to respect the sovereign right of state governments to take decisions in favour of the inhabitants of their countries.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because I consider the assessment and analysis contained there in it to be useful for the European Union, despite our serious problems in other areas at present, to meet the common goal of continuing to be a leader and guide in financing international development and addressing other related global challenges. In my view, the 17 target groups (SDG) formulated under Agenda 2030 are still the most comprehensive global strategy offering realistic emerging alternatives. I consider it particularly important that Agenda 2030 prioritises the most vulnerable groups, women and children, in the fight against global poverty and vulnerability for economic, political or climatic reasons.  On the basis of this report, I also see an opportunity to make better use of the crisis management and resolution synergies between the refugee crisis as a direct European problem and the sustainable development of the world in the current situation in the EU. I agree with the principle of Agenda 2030 that assistance should be focused where it is most needed, but I believe that in the coming years the EU's efforts will need to give greater prominence to the regions and countries that are the main source of the mass migration and refugee wave (mainly in Africa, sub-Saharan Africa and the Middle East). This should in no way undermine our commitments, but it could make EU involvement in global efforts more targeted and effective.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union, together with the Member States, is the largest donor of development aid and it is the EU that has led to the process leading to the adoption of the 2030 Agenda. This is a great success, which is largely the result of a coherent and coordinated action by all stakeholders. The adoption of the 2030 Agenda is at the same time a promise by world leaders to eradicate extreme poverty, achieve sustainable development and ensure dignity and justice for all. Before the High Level Forum for Sustainable Development, the EU Foreign Affairs Council should develop a common and coherent EU position on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Parliament's report rightly expresses concern about the European Commission's failure to publish a communication on the way forward and to review the 2030 Agenda before the Forum meeting. It is now necessary to turn words into deeds and to implement the 2030 Agenda. As a world leader in development, the Union has the greatest responsibility to promote the implementation of the 17 SDGs, both internally and externally. Therefore, for the CREDIBILITY of the EU within the international community, it is necessary to present a common position of the EU and its Member States as soon as possible.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The Millennium Development Goals aimed to completely eradicate poverty by 2015, and although the goals have not been reached, the MDGs managed to raise international awareness about ending global poverty and its urgency. The Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals demonstrate great ambition and seek to achieve the goals that the MDGs did not. I fully support this resolution as I believe that the action plan in the next 14 years is crucial for the wellbeing of humanity and the planet and a periodic follow-up is necessary.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I validated this resolution with a positive vote. In this text, we call on the Commission to put forward a proposal for the development of a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of domestic and external policies, which provides for a detailed timetable until 2030, a mid-term review and a specific procedure guaranteeing Parliament's full participation, as well as a concrete implementation plan to coordinate the achievement of the 17 objectives. 169 targets and 230 global indicators. It is also important to stress the importance of the universality of the objectives, and the fact that the European Union and its Member States are committed to fully implementing all objectives, in practice and in spirit.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the follow-up and state of play of the Agenda 2030 and Sustainable Development Goals, as I believe that it is crucial that the EU adopts a coherent and common position to ensure its leadership on this ambitious agenda. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals embody a courageous international commitment to eradicate poverty and develop new development strategies for the next 15 years, and we should work hard to formulate an EU Sustainable Development Strategy to play our part in delivering on its objectives. Democratic scrutiny over the process will be key to the strategy’s success, which is why I would like to see the European Parliament being more involved in the formulation, implementation and monitoring of the process.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Millennium Goals offer us the opportunity to imagine and present more ambitious policies in development cooperation. The review of the European Consensus must fully reflect the new 2030 Agenda, which includes a paradigm shift and a real transformation of the European Union's development policy. Targeted aid planning, avoiding waste, is crucial to achieving the objectives of cooperation with third countries. It will be important to use the next mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework to ensure that the financing commitments made reflect all the commitments made under the 2030 Agenda and agreed by the European Union and its Member States. I also believe it is essential that the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development cooperation by all 28 Member States is finally reached. Too few now do so, and our credibility is at stake.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Agenda 2030 is a universal programme covering all countries, rich and poor, with a view to full integration and the economic, social and environmental dimensions of sustainability. The programme adopted in September 2015 defines cooperation within the international community in achieving the SDGs. This is the first global agreement to set out a universal, comprehensive programme that will affect all countries and achieve its objectives to achieve a balanced development of the environmental, economic and social dimensions. As this programme renews the international commitment to eradicate poverty, redefine and modernise the development strategy for the next 15 years and ensure delivering results, I supported this resolution.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the next steps and the state of play of the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs, as the proposed package of 230 indicators for the SDGs is a good starting point and a solid framework for further steps and an overview of progress towards the 17 SDGs. The focus is on the international commitment to eradicate poverty, to redefin and modernise our development strategies for the next 15 years and to deliver results.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution which measures concrete actions for the European Commission on the Sustainable Development Goals. Following the adoption of the so-called Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 within the United Nations last September, the European Commission has done little or nothing to adapt its policies to this new development agenda. We consider it essential that the Commission urgently establish a roadmap in this regard, as the resolution positively points out.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The resolution, considering that optional labelling schemes generate only confusion (considering L), calls for mandatory indication of origin in a very broad way. There is certainly a small caveat: in the light of this resolution, the draft national provision for origin indication, which France has recently notified to the Commission and the Member States, according to the procedure established by Regulation 1169/2011, could well be considered a "best practice" to be shared, or even extended to the whole internal market through a specific enforcement act adopted by the Commission. I voted for this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Systemic strategic planning, implementation and reporting are needed in order to ensure a coherent and integrated implementation of the UN development system. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution which measures concrete actions for the European Commission on the Sustainable Development Goals. Following the adoption of the so-called Sustainable Development Agenda 2030 within the United Nations last September, the European Commission has done little or nothing to adapt its policies to this new development agenda. We consider it essential that the Commission urgently establish a roadmap in this regard, as the resolution positively points out.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this resolution as important amendment tabled by the Greens failed and because there was no majority for a high-level EU declaration on demonstrating the EU’s commitment to the 2030 Agenda in all external and internal policy areas.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I recall that without a serious and concrete flow of economic resources, it is not possible to achieve effectively the ambitious targets set out in the 2030 agenda.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. – Through this resolution, the European Parliament expresses its position on the monitoring and status of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals, stressing the EU's willingness to exercise global leadership to eradicate poverty, approving the objectives and targets set out in the 2030 Agenda Declaration, urging Member States and the Union institutions to take concrete action to achieve the 2030 Agenda Goals for Sustainable Development and calling on both the Commission and the other relevant Union institutions to report regularly to the European Parliament on the state of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals. In short, we are talking about a report which expresses the European Parliament's commitment to the Sustainable Development Goals, so I think it is necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution because the Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development aims to build on the Millennium Development Goals that we have not achieved in the past. The European Union must play a leading role in improving the world at a global level.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when the UN and governments around the world continue to call for the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to the four winds, it should be clarified that they do not represent the interests of the majority of the planet's population – those who are now exploited and oppressed under the current political and economic order. The SDS say they can eradicate poverty in all its forms by 2030. But they rely mainly on global economic growth to fulfil this enormous task. If this growth is similar to that of recent decades, it will take 100 years for poverty to disappear, not the 15 years that the SDGs promise. And even if this were possible in a shorter timetable, it would be necessary to increase twelve times the size of the global economy, which, in addition to making our planet uninhabitable, will obliterate any advances against poverty. Instead of concealing this obvious madness with false hope, we must start by addressing two decisive problems: income inequality and the economic system that generates this inequality.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the European Parliament resolution on the follow-up and review of the 2030 Agenda. In terms of content, I cannot follow the resolution for a number of reasons. I am not convinced by the approach to sustainability, let us be a further convinced, let us be the idea that the EU should follow the Lisbon Strategy or the 2020 Agenda with a Europe 2020 strategy – the new approach for the post-2020 period. I did not vote against it simply because I am not fundamentally opposed to global or European cooperation, of course, with different content and nature.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this resolution’s call to integrate the economic, social and environmental pillars of sustainable development. Whenever these perspectives are separated and there are policy inconsistencies and incoherence, it is the most vulnerable who suffer. International efforts to develop better indicators and data collection tools are key to progress and to improve decision-making. It is only when we have gender-sensitive data that we can truly see the scale of gender inequalities, and take action to close gaps. It is disappointing that among the 169 different SDG targets, only five address youth and young people. Sustainability is all about the future, and handing over a better world to the next generation, to the youth. Decision-makers and elected representatives, including myself, must work together with youth organisations and civil society in order to ensure that young people are firmly at the centre of international sustainable development strategy and the implementation of the SDGs.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2030 agenda because I believe that it is only through the use of regular review mechanisms that we are able to achieve the SDGs. I hope that the Commission will shortly present a strategy in this area, covering all the relevant internal and external aspects. It should include a transparent framework for monitoring and evaluating progress towards these objectives. The 2030 Action Programme agreed last autumn is an ambitious project aimed at eradicating poverty completely by mainstreaming sustainable development in economic, social and environmental terms. During the negotiations, the EU has repeatedly stressed the integrated nature of these three aspects and has committed itself to implementing them both within the Community and in external relations.  The traditional model of development cooperation is becoming increasingly important and should be limited to countries affected by conflicts and crises. On the other hand, the need for more flexible and innovative instruments based on measurable and verifiable development achievements is increasing. The new objectives are based on a partnership model between developed and developing countries, taking into account their different capabilities and needs. That is why cooperation at all levels is so important – from governments to the private sector to regional and civic initiatives.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – I believe that the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs are an important tool in eradicating poverty and redefining our strategies so that they are truly effective. For this reason, through a resolution, the Commission is invited to present a comprehensive sustainability strategy covering all relevant areas of internal and external policies with a detailed timetable for 2030 and their interim evaluation. It is essential that the European Union make full use of the future review of the medium-term multiannual financial framework to ensure that financial mechanisms reflect all commitments made by the Union under the 2030 Agenda. This resolution allows us to ask the European Union and its Member States to renew their commitment to provide 0.7% of GNI for ODA and to present a detailed breakdown to ensure a gradual increase in OFFICIAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE to achieve this objective. For me, it is very important to ensure policy coherence for development within the framework of the 2030 Agenda, and I therefore recommend that this new approach be included in the main interests of all the EU institutions in order to ensure genuinely effective cooperation.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution which I have co-signed. This text reflects the global framework for Sustainable Development and the strategy that the EU as a whole must pursue to achieve the 2030 Agenda objectives.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the 2030 Agenda. The latter unites all the states of the world in their commitment to building a model of common and sustainable development. The 2030 Agenda proposes a series of concrete policies to overcome the fight against hunger and poverty and to enable more and more sections of the population to access basic services and to obtain recognition of their right to education. The environment is also being considered, as greenhouse gas emissions are to be significantly reduced and global measures to protect natural resources are expected. The European Union must be on this world leader. I therefore welcome all the initiatives along these lines and hope that the debate on this issue will continue to be lively and proactive.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the follow-up and state of play of the 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals because We consider EU-UN institutional cooperation at multilateral level essential to achieve the common objectives of poverty eradication and the redefinition and modernisation of our development strategies for the next 15 years. I would like to call on the Commission to present a proposal for a comprehensive sustainable development strategy covering all relevant areas of internal and external policy, with a detailed timetable by 2030, a mid-term review and a specific procedure ensuring the full involvement of the European Parliament. I underline the need to extend the spirit of cooperation to all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society, through an inclusive and transparent process to achieve sustainable results.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the 2030 Agenda, which establishes a global framework for the eradication of poverty and the achievement of sustainable development by 2030, based on the Millennium Development Goals adopted in 2000. It is the first global agreement that sets out a universal and comprehensive roadmap for action and is based on a global partnership that involves action by governments and stakeholders at all levels. The European Union has been leading the way in this process from the outset, as it is by far the world's largest donor of development aid. I believe that the new EU strategy for sustainable development and the related implementing measures should be consulted extensively by all stakeholders, including national parliaments, local authorities and civil society, on the basis of an inclusive process.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, let me quote a sentence from the report, point H: 'whereas the food supply chain, which includes many food business and other stakeholders, is often long and complex', and 'as consumers know less and less about how the food they eat is prepared, ...'. Good morning, dear European Union. yes, that's right. Then I suggest we save what can be saved. The landowspers are kindly authorised to return the land to the local farmers and to the local population. Oligarchs, local oligarchs as well as foreigners. Let us restore this local food production, local food production, farming, food processing. Let's get this country back on its feet, and then there won't be any problems like this. Again, let's save what's left to save.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, even after yesterday's debate, I finally decided not to support this report. I am convinced that the mandatory indication of where the product comes from does not say anything about the quality of the product. That is, if supporters of mandatory regulation, compulsory labelling, say that this will improve our food as well, improve information about what we eat in principle, that is not true in my opinion. I think that those consumers who still want to have information about where the product comes from can choose the goods, the food from the manufacturer who voluntarily states this on the labels of their product. So I am not in support of further regulation, I am in a good place for this to be maintained in voluntary form, let those manufacturers who wish to address their consumers in this way state this on the products. But regulation, in my opinion, is unnecessary.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Madam President, I support mandatory country of origin labelling on processed meats and milk because, after numerous food scandals, consumers are demanding that they have the choice and that they know what is in their produce. In recent polling, 90% of those surveyed said that they wanted mandatory country of origin labelling for processed meat, and 84% wanted mandatory country of origin labelling for milk. Some have suggested that if this was put in place it would support local producers and local farmers and ensure that people knew what they were eating. Therefore I call on the Commission to support us in our calls for mandatory labelling, in particular on processed meats and milk produce.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, today I voted in favour of the country of origin labelling resolution, along with my fellow Conservative MEPs, and I am very pleased to see it passed.  The Yorkshire Post in my constituency has been campaigning to address the current situation whereby dairy products made with foreign milk can be labelled as British. Consumers want to support our dairy farmers but they can only do that if food is clearly labelled and after today’s vote the Commission must sit up and react. This vote is good news for consumers, for our dairy sector and a real boost for the ‘Clearly British’ campaign.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, in answer to concerns about food quality, food safety and animal welfare, origin labelling can provide consumers with a means of making informed choices about the food they wish to purchase and consume. It also seems that consumers’ interest in the labelling of the food they consume is considerably strong. That is why mandatory marking of foodstuffs should be used as widely as possible. Nevertheless, in the case of more advanced levels of processing, requiring complex traceability measures, mandatory origin labelling can lead to significant increases in production costs. Considering the limited willingness of consumers to pay higher prices for their products, and the fact that around 90% of companies in the food sector are SMEs, I believe that a voluntary approach would be the optimal way forward in such cases. Voluntary origin labelling is already widespread and, as the Commission has pointed out in its report, if used, it would not raise additional operational challenges for producers, while the costs passed on to the consumer would be kept to the minimum.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr I believe that, as in the case of today's yet another issue of traceability of fishery products in the public sector, this document is absolutely important, because I will repeat it over and over again that the consumer has the right to know what we have on the tray. One can, by the way, understand that there is no information when people buy berries, apples or mushrooms at aunts on the market, but here it is clear that the consumer is absolutely, at least in my country, Latvia, absolutely convinced that he buys clean products and has certain origins. But in the case of supermarkets, it is clear that this is not really possible given the delivery route. Consequently, I join the position that, whether meat or beef, pigmeat, poultry, the place of origin must be indicated, and I necessarily believe that there can be no compromise in the case of food. Especially when it concerns specialized baby food.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, the people have to know what they are eating.  Madam President! "The people have to know what they are eating." That sounds logical and sounds good, but nevertheless we should answer three questions in this report.  The first: Is it already possible to know exactly where the food comes from? This is possible, and if you really want to know exactly, you should go to the direct marketer around the corner – there he can look at the pig beforehand, from which his sausage is made later. If you also look at the economic situation, the situation is often difficult for direct marketers. It seems that consumers are not taking advantage of the information available.  Secondly, can it prevent food scandals? Let me tell you openly: no. Anyone who exchanges horsemeat for beef with criminal energy, or vice versa, will continue to do so in the future – it is quite simply a matter of being punished, and it must be revoked from the licence to continue producing food. Thirdly, are the costs justifiable? I say this to them quite frankly, and there is a risk that the costs will ultimately be passed on to farmers. That is why three times no, and that is why I was unable to vote in favour of the report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Madam President, I am very pleased that we have adopted this proposal today, this resolution for the mandatory indication of the country of origin on food, and I am also glad that we have managed to defeat the food industry lobby, which has been very strong these days. Several feasibility reports on mandatory product labelling were published by the European Commission in 2015 and showed us that it would cost industries more if they had to put labels on their country of origin, and that would lead to price increases and price increases should be borne by consumers. I do not understand why industries cannot bear this price increase, because it is their obligation to write down which country has produced a particular product that they put on the market and not consumers to bear this cost. Further, as far as Romania – and my colleagues have referred to their countries – it is very important for us and for Romanians to know where these products come from. For example, there is a "buy products made in Romania!" campaign. People want to do that but often milk from yogurt or cheese comes from other countries. We want to know where it's coming from.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, first of all let me say that for many years I pushed hard to ensure country of origin labelling for poultry meat, and last April I was very pleased to see that poultry meat, pig meat, sheep meat etcetera had mandatory country of origin labelling. However, we still have some loopholes in relation to processed meat, and this resolution today is an attempt to start, or continue, the conversation around how to ensure that consumers have sufficient information to make informed judgments, without ensuring we have disproportionate costs. With regard to milk and dairy produce there are some difficulties, and I was disappointed that we did not recognise this by supporting Amendment 5 which highlighted the negative effect mandatory labelling could have on dairies in border regions. We need to look at this issue, but it is very important to remember that country of origin labelling often supports locally produced milk rather than the cheapest milk sourced from anywhere in the world. Finally, I was happy to see that Parliament agreed that any country of origin labelling would not be weakened by any trade agreements, including TTIP.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, staon mé ón vóta deiridh sa tuarascáil seo. Because I think it is important that the Commission discusses the findings of the feasibility reports. A mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for milk – milk used as an ingredient in dairy products – and types of meat other than beef, swine, sheep, goat and poultry meat. If mandatory labelling is to be introduced in these instances, the extra cost that would be put on producers must be taken into account by this Parliament. If mandatory labelling is going to raise the cost of production beyond a feasible level, it may not be the best course of action. Agriculture and food production are both hugely important sectors in Ireland and so I am very concerned about the assessments made on mandatory feasibility. I would like to hear from the Commission before any further action is taken. Agus sin an fáth gur staon mise agus mo comhghleacaithe i Fine Gael sa tuarascáil seo.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers from confusing buyers. We have abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring adequate information and transparency of food production processes is an indispensable tool for protecting the health and free choice of European citizens. It is therefore only right to extend the number of foods subject to compulsory indication of origin. Specifically, the motion for a resolution refers to: milk; meat other than beef and veal, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat; un processed food; products based on a single ingredient; and, finally, all the ingredients that represent more than 50% of a food. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal, because I believe that the right to health and information for citizens must be recognised and protected.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. In this resolution, it is proposed to indicate the country of origin or place of origin of some foods. I voted in favour because I think it is important that the place of origin of all food products be specified, and so do most consumers in the European Union. Implementing a mandatory indication of origin would be a major step in providing adequate transparency in the food chain and for potential consumers, which would facilitate an increase in conscious and responsible consumption, an essential step in the face of transformative consumption

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution following an oral question on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs.  This text calls for a very broad indication of origin in the face of the observation that optional labelling schemes only generate confusion. I strongly support these measures, which help to inform European consumers more precisely. Transparency as to where a food comes from or where a food comes from is a right for all citizens.   We also recall that "origin" cannot be reduced to a simple question of costs for businesses, but must instead be a lever in favour of the primary sector in particular. It is an instrument that can encourage an agricultural sector already well affected by the European crisis, which our farmers are suffering from in France as elsewhere.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. This resolution aims to increase transparency on the origin of processed and certain varieties of unprocessed meat and dairy products. The aim is to rebuild consumer confidence in the food industry following the scandals of recent years. In principle, I am in favour of greater transparency in food. Consumers have the right to know where these products are made and what they contain. As far as meat products are concerned, I am in favour of full traceability. As Belgium has already successfully implemented these, the move to EU-wide mandatory indications of origin would be quite feasible. In the case of dairy products, however, the situation is different. The full traceability of dairy products is a disproportionate economic obstacle for dairies established in border regions. In border regions, dairies often source their milk from different countries, which makes it practically very cumbersome or almost impossible to separate dairy products from different Member States. In the end, I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The resolution, considering that optional labelling generates only confusion, calls for the indication of origin of certain compulsory food products to be extended. I voted in favour of this resolution, which improves tracing.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers confusing buyers. We abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone. We want the UK Parliament, not the unelected EU Commission to legislate on this matter.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foodstuffs. A consumer survey by the European Commission in 2013 showed that 9 out of 10 respondents are important to know the origin of food. I support the calls for the European Commission to put forward rules that oblige them to make the origin of these products compulsory. More detailed information would make the food supply chain more transparent by allowing the traceability of meat or milk suppliers, which would restore consumer confidence. At present, only the origin of fresh beef and imported poultrymeat must be noted in the EU, but I support this requirement for other meat products.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the motion for a resolution is to introduce a mandatory designation of origin for meat products or food products containing meat components, as well as for milk and milk products and, in part, eggs. On the basis of the lessons learned from the previous horsemeat scandal, it should be mandatory to indicate on each meat product the origin of the meat used as the raw material. This is because consumers expect and consider it important to indicate origin on products for reasons of national emotion, tradition and food safety. The marking will allow the purchasing confidence index to increase in the markets of each Member State in the direction of meat products and to detect foods of uncertain origin.  They shall provide adequate information and better information as to whether the products concerned contain raw materials from regional, domestic, Member State or third countries. Foods made from genetically modified or cloning raw materials become distinct from traditional foods on the basis of this information. An essential point of the motion is for the EU to require compliance with the new food safety and designation of origin requirements in all its ongoing negotiations with third countries (TTIP, EU-Cuba trade agreement, etc.), thereby protecting the EU's internal markets and the interests of consumers. In view of this, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to follow up on its obligations to implement the standards, in accordance with Article 26, paragraph 5, of Regulation 1169/2011 of 25 October 2011. Considering that optional labelling schemes are only confusing, the resolution calls for a very broad indication of origin.  I voted in favour of this measure, which goes towards a generalisation of the traceability obligation and thus ensures the protection of consumers as well as SMEs engaged in a quality-oriented approach to their products.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which recalls that Parliament is in favour of the mandatory indication of the country of origin or the place of origin of meat in processed foods and that such an indication should be made mandatory also for types of meat other than beef, swine, sheep, goat and poultry meat, for milk, milk used as an ingredient in dairy products. , and for unprocessed foodstuffs, products with a single ingredient and ingredients that make up more than 50% of a food item. This is not only a request from the vast majority of Europeans, but also measures that will organise product traceability and thus promote accountability and transparency.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution which asks the Commission for more information so that the consumer knows the country of origin or place of origin of the food he consumes. The aim is to restore consumer confidence in food products and improve transparency and traceability. In this way we are listening to the citizens, who in a Eurobarometer survey in 2013 were in favour (88% in favour) of indicating the origin of the food they consume. Further progress towards greater supervision is needed to combat fraud and never suffer scandals like horse meat again.  We also ask the Commission to analyse and study the feasibility and economic proportionality of this measure, although according to a study by Bord Bia in Ireland the producers who participated in its quality assurance plan, which includes origin labelling, did not experience an increase in cost.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 According to a Eurobarometer survey, 84% of European citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk and 88% who consider it fundamental for all types of meat. The motion for a resolution on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods, which I voted for in Parliament, addresses this problem by proposing solutions. The text adopted calls in particular on the Commission to make labelling compulsory for meat products, all types of milk and milk products, with the possibility of extending these measures to other single-ingredient foods or foods with prevailing ingredients. Through new rules, with reduced operating costs, it would be possible to increase product traceability and transparency at all stages of the food chain, protecting consumers more than cases of fraud and increasing their confidence,

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution to be mandatory to be included in the labelling of processed foodstuffs, the country of origin of meat and milk with the aim of combating food industry fraud and improving consumer information. The proposal also calls for promoting in the EU the labelling of foodstuffs which are made taking into account animal welfare. Labelling is a necessary tool for the consumer to have maximum information when buying their food. It is essential for strengthening trade in local products.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I welcome this resolution which calls on the Member States of the European Union to make it mandatory to indicate the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs, such as dairy products and meats. In the past, my country has always fought for the respect and protection, in international trade, of the original mention of its own products - I am thinking in particular of our wines, our champagne and our cheeses - and it only makes sense to extend this protection to other products and this for all the countries of the Union. Such protection not only defends the interests of the industries of the Member States but also contributes to the necessary protection of consumers and, in the case of food, animal welfare.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I supported this resolution calling for the country of origin for certain foodstuffs to be made mandatory, given the inefficiency of optional labelling. This measure seems to me to be essential from the perspective of protecting the food security of the citizens of the Member States. All the more so since Regulation 1169/2011 gives Member States the right, according to local practices and circumstances, to have unpackaged food regulations. Respect for the traditions, the sovereignty of European nations, but also the assurance of protection of this standard of food security, even in the event that TTIP is implemented.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that origin labelling is a fundamental contribution for the entire agri-food chain, to protect Italian and European quality production, to protect consumers and production in our territories. At this time of crisis in the agricultural sector, I believe that compulsory labelling of the country of origin or place of origin can represent added value, to be used in our favour, against increasing counterfeiting in the food sector. For these reasons, I supported the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. It is necessary to restore consumer confidence following food scandals in recent years, such as horse meat in 2013, so I consider it highly important that the indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods is mandatory. Consumers have the right to know where the food we eat comes from, without being mistakenly induced, gaining greater control and limiting the risk of product fraud. Country of origin labelling is a broadly supported measure, both by consumers, farmers and consumer organisations, and the cost of it is low, so it must be mandatory for slightly processed dairy and meat products. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with mandatory designations of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs. The food supply chain is often long and complex, involving a large number of food business operators and other countries, and consumers are becoming less aware of how their food is produced, and individual food business operators do not always have a general view of the whole product chain. The EU already has rules on origin labelling and are effectively applied to a number of other foods, including unprocessed meat, eggs, fruit and vegetables, fish, honey, in particular virgin olive oil, virgin olive oil, wine and spirits. The European Parliament calls on the Commission, when preparing legislative proposals in this area, to implement a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, milk products and meat products and to assess the possibility of mandatory country of origin or place of origin designation for other foods or products of one ingredient with a single dominant ingredient. Calls also on the Commission to come forward with legislative proposals making the designation of origin compulsory for processed meat-containing foods in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers in the wake of the horsemeat scandal and other food fraud.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs. According to a 2013 Eurobarometer survey, 84% of consumers believe that the country of origin should be indicated on milk, whether liquid milk or dairy products. The Commission's report of 17 December 2013 showed that 90% of consumers want to know the origin of processed meat in food. The motion for a resolution welcomes the findings of the Eurobarometer and calls for mandatory labelling of the origin of meat other than beef, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat or poultrymeat, milk, milk used as an ingredient in dairy products, unprocessed foods, single ingredient products and ingredients representing more than 50% of the food. I would like to recall that the European Parliament has already called for mandatory labelling with the country of origin labelling of meat in processed foods from the end of 2015. I hope that this time the Commission will take our warnings and consumer warnings with all seriousness.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ A declaration that does not say that e.g. lasagna produced in Croatia contains beef from Poland is not fair to consumers and paves the way for various scams.  Labelling of the country of origin of meat should be facilitated by member state authorities to combat food fraud and punish perpetrators. That is why I support this resolution and call on the Commission to take the steps requested by Parliament.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on mandatory origin labelling. The report renewed the European Parliament’s call on the Commission to stop ignoring citizen demand and come forward with legislative proposals to extend the current origin labelling regime to more products including: milk and milk products used as an ingredient as well as meat used as an ingredient in processed foods. After a series of food fraud scandals consumer confidence has dropped. Increasing transparency in the food chain by extending origin labelling to more products on the market would be a significant step in regaining some of this lost trust. Moreover, surveys have shown that the vast majority of consumers want to know where the food they buy and eat comes from. The success of Bord Bia’s Quality Assurance scheme in Ireland has shown that such labelling schemes can be achieved. Any existing and future labelling legislation must also take account of the unique situation in Ireland caused by partition and renewed efforts must be taken by all key stakeholders to avoid any further situations where produce born and reared in one part of Ireland and finished in another is being labelled as ‘mixed-origin’.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important for the Commission to present a legislative proposal for the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods in order to restore consumer confidence after the various frauds in the food sector such as, for example, the horsemeat scandal.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 84 % of consumers consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk, sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products. As far as processed meat is concerned, the Commission's report of 17 December 2013 shows that 90 % of consumers want to know the origin of meat in processed foods. Despite this, the Commission concludes that maintaining labelling on a voluntary basis could be the most desirable solution for the above-mentioned products. According to the study accompanying the report on milk and meat types other than those of the bovine species, the costs of compulsory origin labelling for milk and milk used as an ingredient in milk products increase as the production process becomes more complex.  However, the Commission does not distinguish slightly processed products from highly processed ones. We therefore call on the Commission to define 'slightly processed' foods, particularly with regard to dairy and meat products, since the costs of origin labelling should be significantly reduced if their scope is limited to milk intended for direct consumption, to slightly processed dairy products, for example cheese and cream, as well as to certain slightly processed meat products. , such as sausages and bacon.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution calls on the Commission to finally follow up its obligations to implement the provisions of Article 26 of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on compulsory indication of origin (food information to consumers – is horizontal legislation on food labelling). In particular, considering that optional labelling schemes would only lead to confusion and opacity (recitals L and § 20), compulsory indication of origin is required on almost everything (§ 24-31). Care must be taken to ensure that this very good text is not distorted by the PPE amendments and the deletion of the parts on which the 'no origin' groups have asked for a separate vote. In this regard, I would draw attention to Amendment No 8: they finally confess the real reason for their opposition. We point out, as we have explained in recent days to the President of Federalimentare, that "origin" cannot be declassricated as a mere matter of costs for companies, but on the contrary it is a lever of the "value" of the primary sector and, then, of the processing sector. It is an instrument that can help to counter the confirmed crisis in the agricultural sector caused by the EU's free trade policies, as France has understood, for example.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the regulation on informing consumers about food provides for the need to inform the consumer, the feasibility of this measure faces a number of obstacles by compulsory indicating the country of origin or place of provenance of the meat. Indication of the origin of the meat can constitute a non-tariff barrier, which will affect many European processors, leading to the generation of strong non-competitive influences. The increased cost will also lead to a decrease in consumption with all its negative influences on the economy. For the Romanian situation, the context is different, since at national level Romanian producers use voluntary labelling of the origin of meat, having in the Romanian consumer a follower of Romanian products, but at European level Romanian preparations that entered the European Union late in the European Union could be eliminated by existing and already strong brands on the European market. Considering that tightening the labelling rules would not have beneficial effects on market participants: consumers, producers, processors, I am voting against this motion for resolutions.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mandatory country of origin indication on dairy products, meats and processed meats. I believe it is essential that consumers are fully informed of what they have on their plates. Transparency throughout the food chain is an absolute necessity. Strict labelling of dairy products, meats and processed meats must be mandatory in order to improve food traceability. We must learn from the horsemeat scandal. Through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to draw up a proposal to make country-of-origin labelling of certain foodstuffs mandatory.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission to apply the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for products intended for direct consumption. The EU regulation on the provision of information to consumers approved in 2011 made origin or origin labelling subject to an impact assessment for certain foods. The study shows that the costs of ensuring transparency in the food chain of these products may be too high, but this assessment appears to be incomplete and does not take sufficient account of the fact that traceability costs are not the same for all products. For these reasons, I agree with the call for the Commission to implement the obligation to label origin for products whose traceability costs are derisory, and to deepen its study in order to consider extending the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin to other single-ingredient or predominantly ingredient food products, drawing up legislative proposals in these areas.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because the overwhelming majority of citizens consider having knowledge of where their food comes from to be very important to them. In Ireland the border remains an obstacle to transparency when it comes to origin labelling. I also supported an amendment calling for more information on the impact of trade deals on food labelling. My Sinn Féin colleague Lynn Boylan had input into the resolution during negotiations. In the last resolution on this issue to be voted on by the European Parliament, in February last year, Parliament called on the Commission to come forward with country of origin labelling (COOL) for meat used as an ingredient in processed foods. This resolution focuses more on products such as milk, products which use milk as an ingredient and ‘lightly processed foods’, whilst still maintaining the call for COOL for other products. The Commission has cited ‘costs and administrative burdens’ to business operators for not bringing in COOL for such products and this resolution scrutinises these excuses.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this motion for a resolution because I agree that the measures outlined in it involved a concept of ‘lightly-processed’ which is impossible to define and its introduction could create many problems for the entire industry. I believe that it would also have a very negative impact on farmers and the small and medium enterprises which are the backbone of our economy.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures introducing clear and transparent labelling of products sold directly to consumers, especially when it comes to food production. Having said that, before introducing such measures, we have to assess fully their potential impacts on all the parts of a supply chain. It is perfectly reasonable to come up with compulsory labelling of fresh or frozen meat products, however the resolution added also products containing milk or meat and that could be, in my view, rather complicated for our producers. I am not convinced about the added value for the consumers. I would prefer to leave them liberty to decide whether labelling of origins of those ingredients should be or not present. That is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, which reiterates Parliament's position in favour of the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat in processed foodstuffs. This indication should also be made compulsory for meat species other than beef and pigmeat and meat of sheep, goats and poultry, milk and milk used as a component of milk products, as well as for uneded foods, foodstuffs consisting of a single ingredient and ingredients corresponding to more than 50% of the food.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs is a positive and necessary effort to protect consumers in Europe. As we all know that there are increased risks due to the increased possibilities of importing products from areas where insufficient controls are carried out, I believe that such efforts are in the interests of European citizens and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the obligation to indicate the origin of certain foods, in particular milk and specific types of meat. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I am very sensitive to this issue and in this vote I strongly emphasised the importance of compulsory origin labelling. I am of the opinion that the introduction of this system is in the interests of European consumers and I believe that it is the european Parliament's duty to protect them in the best possible way. Furthermore, as an Italian MEP, I believe that it is my duty to act in the interests of my country in particular, which is why I voted in favour, in order to protect made in Italy in the best possible way. I am of the opinion that since our products are desired and envied all over the world it is necessary to proudly guarantee their origin, symbol of a country unbeatable in food quality.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has voted several resolutions on country of origin labelling. In its resolution of 11 February 2015 on meat in processed foods, Parliament urged the Commission to come up with legislative proposals to make labelling the origin of meat in processed foods mandatory, in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers. However, the Commission has yet to make any such proposals, citing the costs of mandatory country of origin labelling to industry and predicting that consumers would not be willing to meet the additional costs.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers from confusing buyers. We have abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the biggest concerns of European citizens has been the question of the origin and provenance of certain foods such as meat, milk and dairy products, whether for public health reasons or by right to information for a consumer-clarified choice. I support this resolution, which strengthens labelling and the provision of information to consumers on foodstuffs, and particular attention should be paid to the origin of meat in processed foods in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and restore consumer confidence.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers from confusing buyers. We have abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's is a victory for our excellent food products and for our Made In Italy. With the resolution on compulsory labelling of the country of origin, the European Parliament is in favour of ensuring the transparency and traceability of certain foods, to the benefit of European consumers, and of our businesses. In fact, the majority of Members have asked the Commission to draw up legislative proposals making it compulsory to indicate origin for single-ingredient food products or with a predominant ingredient. I hope that the Commission will soon make concrete our request to put consumers in a position to decide knowingly what to put on their tables.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the mandatory call for indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for types of meat other than beef, pig, sheep, goat and poultry meat, milk, milk used as an ingredient in dairy products, unprocessed foods, single ingredient products and ingredients that represent more than 50% of a food. It makes sense that the indication of the country of origin or the place of provenance shall be mandatory where failure to indicate this might mislead the consumer. I agree with the call upon the Commission to submit legislative proposals making the indication of the origin of meat in processed foods mandatory in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers in the wake of scandals and other cases of food fraud.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – This resolution proposes to indicate the country of origin or place of origin of some foods. I voted in favour because I think it is important that the place of origin of all food products be specified, and so do most consumers in the European Union. Implementing a mandatory indication of origin would be a major step in providing adequate transparency in the food chain for potential consumers, which would facilitate an increase in conscious and responsible consumption, an essential step for transformative consumption.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it deals with issues that are at the heart of the interests of European citizens. Ensuring the origin of milk, alone or used as an ingredient in dairy products, is an indispensable measure to protect both the quality of dairy products and employment in this crucial sector for many Member States. I therefore support Parliament's initiative to call for the establishment of a working group to evaluate the Commission's report on milk and other meat, in order to introduce compulsory origin labelling at a sustainable cost to businesses and consumers. I also believe that the ongoing TTIP negotiations on free trade with the United States must not jeopardise any of the European provisions on the indication of the country of origin on the label for dairy products, as well as meat and all meat products. Finally, I believe that the European Union has a responsibility to protect European consumers by promoting the greatest possible degree of transparency and preventing cases of food fraud. This resolution goes in the direction of new legislative proposals on origin labelling by the Commission and tougher penalties for fraudsters.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – Parliament's resolution urges the Commission to propose EU rules that make it mandatory to indicate the origin of certain foods, such as milk, dairy products and meat products, in order to make the food chain more transparent and to better inform European consumers. The practical feasibility of the idea and its impact on the internal market and its competitiveness may raise questions. It is well known that the participation of European SMALL and medium-sized enterprises in the production chain is significant. The cost implications and other negative consequences of the introduction of a mandatory system are unforeseeable.  The report notes that the Commission should take into account and analyse the economic impact of mandatory designation of origin on SMEs in the agricultural and food sectors. In addition, the impact on consumers is important, and consideration should be given to the design of any legislative proposal whether the mandatory designation of origin or the level of consumer prices should be given priority. Making the designation of origin and origin compulsory may result in an unintended price increase in such basic foodstuffs. As a first step, practices in the field of designation of origin and origin should be developed, which are already in use and have been established on a non-binding basis.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Commission was required to submit several feasibility studies to Parliament and the Council on extending the obligation to label the origin of certain categories of food: these reports were published in June 2015 (COM(2015)0204 and COM(2015)0205). They do not contain any legal proposal as it would, in the Commission's view, have to increase the cost to industry and consumers are not willing to incur additional expenditure.  I personally support the principle of mandatory labelling of the country of origin of food where this is practical and is based on the needs of consumers. The Commission's analysis is useful, but the conclusion does not address important aspects, i.e. the profits from better consumer information. I am convinced that, in the case of feasibility studies for milk and dairy products, the cost assessment for the industry is exaggerated, as all these products are in one category. If the scope were limited to slightly processed products only, the costs associated with this would be much lower. Many manufacturers and sellers in the EU already provide such information on their own initiative, reflecting the actual needs of consumers and low costs.  Mandatory country of origin labelling of slightly processed products would be an important step towards restoring consumer confidence following the horse meat scandal and allowing them to make more informed choices. Despite the above considerations, I consider this proposal to be favourable, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which extends mandatory country of origin labelling, without requiring any additional legislation. Although country of origin labelling helps provide consumers with more information, in many cases this is done by producers voluntarily and it is my view that any such rules on labelling should be done in the least administratively burdensome way possible.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The aim of this resolution is to respond to the various reports published by the European Commission on the issue of labelling in relation to Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 and the various resolutions adopted by the European Parliament, the last of which was adopted on 11 February 2015. This resolution, unlike the 2015 resolution, covers not only meat used in processed foods, but also consumer milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and other types of meat. It also evokes eggs and egg products. The resolution calls for mandatory indication of the country of origin or where these foodstuffs come from. It therefore calls on the European Commission to draw up legislative proposals in these areas.  Although not opposed in principle to mandatory labelling, I believe that it poses real challenges in terms of means, control, cost and implementation. Moreover, in terms of international trade, such a measure could handicap our export products, although it could promote consumer information, traceability and citizen consumption in the face of imported products. Considering all these elements, I abstained.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In line with the expectations of both consumers and French farmers, and taking into account the economic feasibility of such a measure, I voted in favour of this resolution which should allow for better traceability of dairy products, meats and processed meats.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: Written. 'I abstained in this vote, as there are two interests opposed to each other, both of which the SP considers to be of value. On the one hand, I believe that consumers have the right to know where dairy and meat comes from. On the other hand, mandatory commitment threatens to lead to unreasonable burden-sharing for small businesses. The SP would therefore have preferred that voluntary labelling would have been given an opportunity first, or that, in the event of compulsory labelling, small businesses would be excluded.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The demand for food labelling from European consumers is clear and unambiatakable. According to a 2013 Commission report, more than 90% of Europeans believe that mandatory labelling should be applied to processed products. 88% feel it is necessary for meat, and 84% for milk.   The implementation of such a measure would be a major step forward, both in terms of the transparency of the food chain and consumer information. Food fraud scandals, such as the horsemeat scandal in 2013, could be prevented.  This new resolution, which follows a series of texts adopted by Parliament on mandatory labelling, should prompt the European Commission to make a swift legislative proposal to this effect.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I fear that the mere use of the voluntary indication of the origin of the products will create two categories of consumers: those who will have the choice of the product they want and those who will not. We must therefore reconcile consumers with their diet after the various food crises we have experienced. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or the place of origin for certain foodstuffs. Farmers and processors already have an obligation to trace. Thus, I want to find the right balance between the interests of consumers and the competitiveness of our companies. It seems to me that a mandatory common European base would lead to less distortion than a voluntary rule.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. The N-VA delegation voted against the resolution on mandatory origin labelling of milk and meat as an ingredient. We call for further work on the voluntary origin labelling system, which is already being applied cost-effectively today. That is also the position of the European Commission. Mandatory origin labelling is detrimental for a variety of reasons. Origin labelling indicates the origin, but does not increase quality nor traceability and does not prevent fraud. Moreover, it is a taste of protectionism, which is contrary to the principles of the Single European Market and is particularly at a disadvantage to smaller export-oriented regions such as Flanders and border regions. The operational and practical feasibility is an objection, as are additional administrative costs and burdens that ultimately lead to a higher price for the consumer, who may find origin labelling relatively important but does not want to pay extra for it.  The N-VA deplores the lack of realism of the adopted text and believes that a solution to the breached consumer trust is not due to additional rules, but through more controls, strict enforcement of existing agreements and tougher penalties.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text calls on the Commission to comply with its obligations to implement standards. To the extent that optional labelling schemes only cause confusion, the resolution requires a very broad indication of origin. I voted for this text which defends traceability, particularly on processed foods and stresses the consumer's interest in it. It also highlights the Commission's overstatement of the cost of traceability.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support this report and therefore decided to vote in favour. In fact, we totally need more differentiation. All milk products cannot be placed at the same level in terms of economic costs and labelling.  The EC fails to distinguish product features in general when talking about the information from different analyses. I agree with the rapporteur that the costs will be significantly lower. Moreover, labelling is already a reality for many other products, and therefore, as it is not a novelty, businesses do not have to find it very difficult to adapt when it comes to certain foods.  As trade increases and products are huge, it must be possible to ensure that consumers can deservedly trust the product they are buying.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. Parliament once again calls on the Commission to put forward legislative proposals making it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods, in order to ensure greater transparency along the food chain and to better inform European consumers, while taking into account its impact assessments and avoiding excessive costs and administrative burdens. The aim of this resolution is to give fresh impetus to EU action in this area and to remind the Commission to take into account the views of European citizens who expressed themselves in the 2013 Eurobarometer survey, in which 84% of citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk and 88% of citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of meat other than meat of the bovine species. , pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat. The introduction of compulsory labelling of the origin of all foodstuffs is in the interests of European consumers.
