In addition, the Commission must ensure that ongoing trade negotiations, such as those relating to TTIP, do not weaken any of the existing EU provisions on country of origin indication on the label and that they do not affect the right to propose further provisions on other foodstuffs in the future.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report as we agree with the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, dairy products and meat products. We also agree on intensifying controls, improving the implementation of existing legislation and imposing tougher penalties to avoid all kinds of food scandals and frauds. The health of European citizens takes precedence and must be protected.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 84% of European citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk and 88% consider it necessary to indicate the origin of the meat.  The indication of the country of origin or place of provenance should be mandatory for all types of milk intended for consumption, dairy products and meat products, as this is a way of restoring consumer confidence following the horsemeat scandal and other cases of food fraud. The extension of this requirement to other foodstuffs consisting of a single ingredient or with a predominant ingredient should be considered.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote for: the resolution calls for the mandatory indication of origin in a very broad way.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. In addition to the foods covered by the resolution voted on today by the European Parliament, there is no doubt that the issue of compulsory indication of origin for food is of fundamental importance for the protection, above all of health, of consumers. We therefore reiterate our support for political and legislative initiatives that make indication of origin mandatory for food, supporting the "made in". On the other hand, labelling, as well as health protection, can be used as a marketing tool to give added value to labelled products. We are also in favour of a step-by-step approach, based on a regulation of voluntary labelling and with the ultimate objective of compulsory labelling, which can be achieved taking into account the results of voluntary labelling.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 26(5), Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of information to consumers on foodstuffs, the Commission should submit, by December 2014, reports and possible legislative proposals on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain types of meat and milk, unprocessed foods, products with a single ingredient and ingredients representing more than 50% of a food. On 20 May 2015, the Commission published two impact assessment reports, with a delay of 6 months. The conclusions were the same in both reports: no action should be taken, and the labelling of all these categories of food should remain on a voluntary basis. This resolution defends the opposite position. The Commission's analysis neglects the positive aspects of country-of-origin labelling, such as the benefits of increased information and consumer involvement, support for local production and economy, smaller transport distances, shorter supply chains and fresher products. Not being a panacea, the indication of the country of origin is positive from various points of view. Any requirements that the measure may entail for some SMEs should be duly taken care of in the legislative process. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Pressure to raise awareness of the composition and country of origin of food products is an important topic. It should lead to increased transparency and increased confidence in products offered on store shelves throughout the European Union. At the same time, it is something that consumers themselves have been demonstrably demanding. Surveys confirm that more than 80 percent of people consider it important to be able to know the country of origin of the milk consumed. For processed meat, this figure exceeds up to 90 percent. We deal with this issue repeatedly, but so far without the necessary response, either from the European Commission or from individual Member States. This is only about the need to provide the consumer with sufficient information to make more informed choices and not to be misled unnecessarily.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I agree that many products must be origined.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report as I agree with the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, dairy products and meat products. I also agree to intensify controls, improve the implementation of existing legislation and impose tougher penalties to avoid all kinds of food scandals and frauds. The health of European citizens takes precedence and must be protected.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Country of origin labelling (COOL) was already mandatory for beef and fish under EU law, and was extended to fresh pig, sheep, goat and poultry meat under the Food Information Regulation. During negotiations on the Food Information Regulation, Parliament supported S&D amendments calling for COOL to be extended to cover all meat, meat in processed foods and milk & dairy products. I believe COOL is needed because consumers want to know where their food comes from, especially as it has environmental and animal welfare consequences; it would force producers to get a greater grip on their supply chain and limit the risk of fraud; it would help restore consumer trust in the food industry. COOL is very popular with consumers: 90% support COOL for meat in processed foods and 84% support COOL for milk. It is also supported by many farmers and consumer organisations.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support any resolution that seeks to facilitate the mandatory indication of the country or place of origin of foodstuffs. In the case of milk and meat products, indication of origin may be considered particularly important in order to preserve quality and ensure transparency and traceability. In the case of milk and milk products, 84% of consumers and 90% of consumers feel the need to indicate origin. The labelling of similar products aims to restore consumers' confidence in food products, to maintain the viability of European businesses and to help local economies.  Parliament's position states that the mandatory labeling should also cover other similar products, i.e. meat products other than beef, pigs, sheep, goats and poultry, as well as unprocessed foods, products consisting of a single ingredient and ingredients which make up more than 50% of a food.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we defend consumers and value our products: in fact, we ask the committee to extend the mandatory indication of the place of origin to milk and milk products but also to certain meats. The same applies to a number of other products, including those consisting of a single ingredient. We are convinced that this compulsory indication is also an indispensable measure to combat food fraud and to protect employment in a sector such as the dairy sector, which is experiencing a serious crisis. Today, half of the products that enter the shopping cartel do not include their place of origin on the label, and this is a gap that needs to be filled by measures such as those we have asked to take today.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution 'Mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods'. The proposals made here for better traceability of food are difficult to implement in real terms and represent an unjustifiable additional expenditure, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. In view of the milk and pigmeat crisis, it makes little sense at present to impose additional costs on farmers. In addition, research shows that consumers are unwilling to bear the resulting costs through higher product prices.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Consumers have a right to know where their food comes from. My Labour colleagues and I are calling for clear, honest labelling to enable consumers to make informed choices without being misled – and hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Everyone wants to know what they are eating and where they are eating. I'm the first. It's not even politics anymore, it's common sense. That is why I have always supported, in this chamber, the mandatory indication of the country of origin. Today, the resolution we are voting on calls for this indication to be mandatory for all meats and milk, including when these products are used as ingredients in foodstuffs. I would have been happy to add the methods of slaughter, but I fully support this proposal as it is. Opponents of this measure cite additional costs for the agri-food sector, which studies are far from confirming, let alone reality, where discretionary systems exist. My country is also preparing to set up an experiment in this area. Of course, labelling is not a guarantee against fraud and cannot be used as a substitute for necessary controls. But it is a question of enlightening the consumer while leaving him, as much alas as his financial means allow him, the freedom to choose. Perhaps this is what frightens us: that this free choice systematically and massively leads to a national and local preference, which would de facto call into question the dreams that some of a totally globalised agricultural market have.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution to be mandatory to be included in the labelling of processed foodstuffs, the country of origin of meat and milk with the aim of combating food industry fraud and improving consumer information. The proposal also calls for promoting in the EU the labelling of foodstuffs which are made taking into account animal welfare. Labelling is a necessary tool for the consumer to have maximum information when buying their food. It is essential for strengthening trade in local products.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I support mandatory country of origin labelling on processed meats and milk because, after numerous food scandals, consumers are demanding that they have the choice and that they know what is in their produce. In recent polling, 90% of those surveyed said that they wanted mandatory country of origin labelling for processed meat, and 84% wanted mandatory country of origin labelling for milk. Some have suggested that if this was put in place it would support local producers and local farmers and ensure that people knew what they were eating.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because mandatory origin labelling would entail a higher regulatory burden for most assessed products.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I had no objections to its findings.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted for the motion for a resolution submitted after the oral response question B8-0363/2016 in accordance with Article 128(5) of the EIA. Rules of procedure on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods (2016/2583 (RSP)), since I agree with the statements in the Resolution and consider it extremely important to minimise the possibility of consumer fraud.  In this regard, I agree with the introduction of a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for meat in processed food products; with the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for meat other than beef, pig, sheep, goat or poultry meat, for milk, milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed food, single-ingredient products and ingredients accounting for more than 50 % of a food product. In my view, mandatory country or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, dairy products and meat products should be applied.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers from confusing buyers. We have abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission to follow up on its obligations to meet its standards enforcement obligations. I am obviously in favour of the mandatory indication of origin for certain foodstuffs, which is why I naturally voted for the text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the requirements for transparent labelling of products with regard to countries of origin. However, I believe that such measures must not disproportionately affect food business operators through administrative burdens. The aim of such measures is mainly to provide the consumer with information on products, so labels should primarily remain legible and understandable, not confusing. I would therefore prefer to label the country of origin of milk for drinking or meat and milk as an ingredient in the product on a voluntary basis. That is why I did not support the motion for a resolution calling for mandatory labelling.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. As in a previous vote in February 2015, I chose to abstain on the mandatory country of origin indication for processed meat products as well as dairy products. If I am in favour of greater transparency, I wonder about the feasibility of this measure and in particular about the additional costs that this obligation could represent for SME/SMEs.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This resolution calls for mandatory origin labelling for milk, dairy products and meat. From the consumer's point of view, traceability of the production cycle and origin marking are very important, because they serve to protect consumers and strengthen the rights of consumers. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this resolution

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted against the resolution providing for a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs. Although, in theory, this would be a welcome plan, I believe that the resolution also includes hidden risks, or underwater stones. There is concern that by adopting a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs, we are faced with the risk that the production process of these products will become much more expensive, thus making the products in question much more expensive. Studies show that indeed a large proportion of consumers would support the introduction of such labels, but would still be opposed if this would make these products considerably more expensive. I believe that such a step would require an in-depth study of the consequences for producers and prices, which would therefore have an impact on the final price for consumers.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Labour MEPs believe consumers have a right to know where their food comes from. We are calling for clear, honest labelling to enable consumers to make informed choices without being misled.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. – I fully support this motion, as it contains a detailed analysis of the key points of the Commission’s reports of May 2015 regarding the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods, and adopts a critical approach towards its conclusions. The Commission’s reluctance to proceed to a decision on mandatory country of origin labelling is based on some elements that need to be reviewed. It seems that this stance overstates the costs and the administrative burdens of origin labelling to business and does not take into account the high proportion of citizens (80%) who consider it necessary to indicate the origin of some products, especially milk whether sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products. Given the tremendous number of scandals regarding food safety, there is a clear need to focus on the consumer’s information and protection.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. With the adoption of this resolution, Parliament has been the spokesman for the demands made by a very large majority of European citizens regarding the labelling of meat and milk. In particular, we have asked for the compulsory indication of the origin of milk, sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products. We have also called on the Commission and the Member States to consider extending the mandatory indication of the country of origin to other single-ingredient or predominantly ingredient food products. With regard to the labelling of meat, we have asked the Commission to extend the indication of compulsory origin to meat other than those currently regulated (beef, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat), also in order to allow European consumers to make a conscious choice. Finally, we also call for compulsory labelling of meat in processed products. Although labelling is of great interest to European citizens, it is not in itself a guarantee against food fraud; That is why we are calling for an efficient control system to ensure consumer confidence.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Following the vote in ENVI last March, a final vote was taken today in plenary on the indication of the origin and compulsory origin of certain foods including milk, meat, processed products (such as ragout, lasagne, tortellini) or with a predominant ingredient (such as pasta). Taking note of the approach expressed, the European Commission will now have to submit ad hoc legislative proposals. This is a fundamental step that responds to the need for transparency for consumers. 'transparency' and 'accountability', therefore, the watchwords that characterise the demands aimed at guaranteeing consumers, the last link in the supply chain, especially after the scandals that have affected European territory and which we would like to see never happen again. A great signal also for european quality product manufacturers and for the protection of Made in Italy and its economic potential. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution and I am very pleased with today's vote because we have given a strong signal to give European consumers complete and clear information about the origin of many food products.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or the place of origin of certain foodstuffs. The resolution, considering that optional labelling schemes are only confusing, calls for a very broad indication of origin. I am pleased to note that this relevant text has not been distorted by EPP amendments. I would like to remind you that "origin" cannot be reduced to a simple question of costs for businesses, but must instead be a lever in favour of the primary sector, in particular. It is an instrument that can encourage an agricultural sector already well affected by the European crisis, which our farmers suffer in France as elsewhere.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text encourages the Commission to exercise stricter management, monitoring and enforcement of mandatory standards. In addition, it supports mandatory labelling schemes to indicate the origin of products. This text is common sense. I have personally defended this subject on numerous occasions in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. So I supported him by voting for it.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. In this resolution, it is proposed to indicate the country of origin or place of origin of some foods. I voted in favour because I think it is important that the place of origin of all food products be specified, and so do most consumers in the European Union. Implementing a mandatory indication of origin would be a major step in providing adequate transparency in the food chain for potential consumers, which would facilitate an increase in conscious and responsible consumption, an essential step for transformative consumption.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the tightening of mandatory food information, such as the obligation to indicate always the country of origin of milk and milk-containing products. If consumers want that information, it's an opportunity for companies to volunteer. The scope of mandatory data is already so large that it is rather confusing and counterproductive for consumers.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The rules defined for the labelling of the country of origin of products have been in force for some time and have been used effectively on a wide range of food products such as wine, fish, honey, eggs, vegetables, various types of olive oil and the like. Regardless of the wide range, some key products are still not covered. According to Eurobarometer data from 2013, 84% of respondents indicated that there is a need to emphasise the country of origin for milk regardless of whether it is sold as a separate product or as a dairy supplement. According to the same year of the survey, 90% of consumers expressed the importance of emphasizing the country of origin of the meat used in processed food products. Parliament supports the introduction of mandatory country of origin or place of origin for meat in processed food products. The proposal for a resolution underlines the importance of a level playing field in the internal market, and the aim of mandatory labelling of origin in food products is to regain consumer confidence in food products. I supported the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods. In my view, labelling the origin of food products such as milk and processed meat products contributes to increasing bonding and gaining customers' trust in the products at their disposal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 11/5/2016 and because this motion for a resolution is complete and substantiated.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods, in order to ensure that consumers are properly informed and to facilitate the promotion of Romanian products on the markets. There is demand for Romanian products, the high quality of which is recognised, so mandatory labelling of the country of origin will ensure a more efficient promotion of these products on the external market. Last but not least, Romania represents a highly competitive market for organic products, labelling in this respect would create a significant openness for Romanian organic products and a considerable advantage for European consumers.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this text. This resolution calls on the Commission to monitor its obligations to implement the standards and sets an extensive scope for the obligation to indicate the country of origin or where the food comes from, which we agree with. It should be noted that the draft national origin indication provision, notified by France to the Commission and the Member States, could well be considered a "best practice" to be shared or even extended to the whole internal market by a specific act of enforcement adopted by the Commission.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a report on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods. I believe that consumer information is of great importance. The consumer must be sufficiently informed of where the product is produced in order to make a truly informed choice. A person's health comes first. Knowledge of the place of origin of the product can tell the consumer what the quality of the product is, namely milk and meat, i.e. products that the consumer buys almost daily. According to a 2013 EUROBAROMETER survey, 84 percent of consumers consider it necessary to list the origin of milk, including in dairy products. I supported the proposal.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority yet another resolution calling on the European Commission to speed up the revision of the Consumer Information Regulation to make it mandatory to mention the origin of meat and milk used as ingredients in prepared dishes. Three years after the food and health scandal of "horse lasagna", the European Commission is still unable to respond positively to 70% of European consumers, who are calling for this information to be mandatory. To oppose this, the European Commission cites extra costs of 20% to 50% compared to the current price. These figures are more than exaggerated. The mandatory traceability system for fresh meat works and can easily be extended to meat in prepared meals. All studies show that such traceability and transparency would not be expensive. The Commission must put an end to its spurious pretexts and delaying manoeuvres: it is time for it to act.  I welcome the experimentation obtained by the French government; we must call on the European Commission to generalise this scheme to all Member States. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the mandatory indication of the country of origin of meat and milk in processed products. I believe that the origin labelling of these products allows consumers to be better informed and their confidence in foodstuffs restored.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this motion for resolution. While supporting information for consumers and given the fact that mandatory country of origin labelling is already in place for beef and other meats, I am concerned about the potential implications for the internal market, in particular the practical implications for milk and dairy products and the possible consequences for Ireland – a major exporter of agricultural products.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament reaffirms its request for mandatory indication of the country of origin or where meat comes from processed foods. It also requires it for types of meat other than beef, pork, sheep, goat and poultry meat and for milk. According to various surveys, around 85% of EU citizens believe it is "necessary to indicate the origin of meat and milk". The resolution also regrets that the Commission is holding back this process by arguing that there are additional labelling costs, which would fall at the expense of the consumer. Food security is priceless and the various scandals related to traceability problems (Spanghero and horse lasagna, for example) show us the urgency to act. I vote For

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. For the proper traceability of foodstuffs, the resolution calls on the Commission to give full value to the rule of obligation to implement standards. Indeed, optional labelling schemes create confusion. Thus, the aim was to extend mandatory labelling widely. As a result, I voted for

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods, because I share the position that the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of the meat in processed foods should also become mandatory for other types of meat, in addition to beef, pork , sheep, goats and poultry, for drinking milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed foodstuffs, products consisting of a single ingredient and ingredients representing more than 50% of a food.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support this resolution as it would leave farmers and small scale agricultural producers with yet more unnecessary administrative burdens.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – With this report, Parliament would encourage the Commission to draw up legislative proposals on the mention on food labels of the place of origin for meat other than beef, pig, sheep, goat and poultry meat and for milk and milk products. The Commission has long since finished the preparatory work. The need now is to use legislative proposals to clarify the policy to be implemented.  Both the consumer and the producer of the foods listed can benefit from this. It is important that the consumer knows what he is buying and that the producer sees the quality of his product supported by a clear label. A nutrition label that stands for transparency and quality, works market-enhancing. At the time, Belgium demonstrated that with transparency and a clear label, you retain the confidence of the market and of the consumer. However, it is advisable to take into account the following elements when labelling. Firstly, the principles of administrative simplification must be respected. Secondly, in complex and internally highly controlled processing processes such as the processing and production of drinking milk - a process of many suppliers - it should be sufficient to specify the EU as a place of origin on packaging.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – I believe that labelling should also be compulsory for meats other than beef, pig, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat, milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed foods, mono-component products and ingredients that account for more than 50% of the food. Similarly, mandatory country or place of origin labelling of all types of drinking milk, dairy products and meat products, and consideration should be given to extending the mandatory indication of the country or place of origin to other single-ingredient or foodstuffs with one main ingredient, by submitting legislative proposals in these areas. The introduction of the origin of meat in processed foods should become mandatory in order to guarantee greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform European consumers in the wake of the horsemeat scandals and other cases of food fraud. Of course, mandatory labelling requirements should take into account the principle of proportionality and the administrative burden for food business operators and law enforcement authorities. I believe that the proposal will help restore consumer confidence in food products. The proposal has my support.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Written. 'I abstained in this vote, as there are two interests opposed to each other, both of which the SP considers to be of value. On the one hand, I believe that consumers have the right to know where dairy and meat comes from. On the other hand, mandatory commitment threatens to lead to unreasonable burden-sharing for small businesses. The SP would therefore have preferred that voluntary labelling would have been given an opportunity first, or that, in the event of compulsory labelling, small businesses would be excluded.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety proposes to Parliament a resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs. The named foods are milk used as an ingredient in milk, milk products, processed meat products and meat products other than beef, pork, sheep, goats and poultrymeat. It recommends that the Commission implement a mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all milk, milk products and meat products and to consider extending the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin to other products consisting of a single ingredient or to products having a single main ingredient.  It also calls on the Commission to take the necessary steps to reduce abuses of the rules on voluntary indication of the origin of foodstuffs. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This resolution considers that the optional labelling schemes of the place of origin of the foodstuffs affected by such a requirement are confusing and calls for the extension of the mandatory indication of origin. Vote in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the 2013 Eurobarometer survey, 84% of EU citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk, whether it is sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products. According to the same survey, 88% of EU citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of meat in addition to beef, pork, sheep, goats and poultry. I am voting in favour of the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat in processed foods and should also become mandatory for meat other than beef, pork, sheep, goats and poultry, for drinking milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed foodstuffs , products consisting of a single ingredient and ingredients representing more than 50% of a food. My favourable position is also due to the demands expressed by azorean milk producers and meat producers in Mainland Portugal, thus monitoring their concerns and requirements.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. In light of this resolution, the draft national origin indication provision, which France recently notified the Commission and Member States according to the procedure established by Regulation 1169/2011, could well be considered a "best practice" to be shared or even extended to the entire internal market through a specific enforcement act adopted by the Commission. Moreover, during the plenary vote, since the EPP's amendments were rejected, this positive text was not upset in its balance, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution. Indeed, if the deepening of the labelling of food products, especially processed products, responds to a legitimate demand of some consumers, it is in practice very difficult to implement and risks leading to an increase in administrative burdens for producers, which would pass on the cost to consumers.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the growing complexity and greater integration of production and supply chains, the risks of food fraud and the difficulties for consumers in making informed choices when buying dairy products, and meat products, we welcome the resolution. Furthermore, the European Parliament, through its report of December 2013, had already urged the European Commission to proceed with a legislative proposal making it compulsory to indicate the country of origin of the meat present in processed products. We therefore deeply regret the lack of feedback on this matter. As evidenced by a Eurobarometer survey in 2013, European citizens, increasingly attentive to the impact of their consumption on animal welfare and environmental conditions, have expressed themselves in favour of regulatory innovation that makes their choices more informed and production chains more transparent and aware. The agreement would also contribute to the fight against food fraud which, in addition to posing a threat to consumers, damages, erodes their market shares and causes image damage, local producers. Furthermore, given the time of serious consumer mistrust of large food companies and the agencies responsible for their control, the measure would increase their credit.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion. Citizens of the European Union need to know where milk and dairy products and processed foods come from, but the adoption of this motion would place too much bureaucratic burden on companies. This would increase the costs of dairy products and processed meat products, and thus the prices of products.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that considers it necessary to indicate the origin of milk, whether sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products. The same applies for the origin of meat other than beef, pig, sheep, goat and poultry meat.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods because I believe consumers have the right to make informed decisions and know what they are consuming. The horsemeat scandal of a few years ago involved several countries and questioned the image of all their producers. Europe is culturally heterogeneous and traditions for some cannot and should not be imposed ubiquitously. The scandal in question proved that. Therefore, without opposing the principle of free movement of goods in the Union, I believe that by introducing mandatory information it reduces the risk of instant collapse of a strong building image – a topic extremely sensitive for newer EU Member States, including my country – Bulgaria. I also see potential for business through the introduction of a designation. It will allow for more visibility and enhance the regional identity of producers, which will help to value their livelihoods. In my opinion, this is particularly important for peripheral and unurbanised regions, which are often a source of meat and milk production. This designation also benefits the development of regional economies, which is why I supported the text of this resolution.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution calling for the Commission to propose legislation making the indication of country of origin or place of provenance available for drinking milk, and dairy and meat products, including meat in processed food, as it is in the interest of consumers to be able to make informed decisions about food consumption by enhancing transparency. Indeed, different surveys clearly indicate that a majority of EU citizens are in favour of labelling meat and dairy products, showing that this resolution is very timely and needed.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 Indication of the country of origin may be useful information for consumers who indicate in surveys that they would welcome this information for a wider range of foods than beef, pork, poultry and mutton, where this figure is already reported. On the second scale dish, it is necessary to raise the increased costs for manufacturers and the question of feasibility at all, in particular for multi-ingredient foods, for which the origin marking of each individual ingredient could be placed on a relatively long list. I therefore take an approach that does not subject all foodstuffs to a uniform origin labelling regime, but distinguishes between single-component foodstuffs, where origin labelling could be mandatory, and multi-component foodstuffs, where it could remain voluntary.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at the vote, I would have voted in favour of this report. I believe that consumers should be able to see the origin of their product. The Commission is invited to press ahead with the compulsory designation of origin for milk, dairy products and meat.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. It is reasonable to make such labelling on a voluntary basis, but it is extremely costly to make it compulsory and it is also extremely difficult to identify and verify the correct origin of all components.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The resolution on the indication of the country of origin of milk and meat in the processed products concerned deliberately limits its scope to a small portion of these products, based on their small degree of processing (cheese, yogurt, bacon, etc.), because – as it expressly states – it does not want to burden food monopolies financially. For the umpteenth time, the European Parliament is proving that in the balance of profits it willingly sacrifices the health and even the lives of workers. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted in favour of even this limited obligation to indicate the country of origin, pointing out that international agreements drawn up by the EU, such as CETA with Canada and the forthcoming TTP under negotiation, abolish traditional Greek designations of origin, such as feta cheese or Kalamata olives, to the detriment of small producers and for the benefit of food multinationals. That is why, of course, the resolution observes a 'fish silence', as well as the EU CAP which is taking out poor farmers and small farmers by concentrating land and production on rural capitalist enterprises, on government measures, such as that of SYRIZA-ANEL in Greece, to lengthen the shelf life of fresh milk and to make yogurt from milk powder that hits small producers to serve the interests of large companies in the sector.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP supports country of origin labelling to help producers selling their goods and for consumers to know with certainty where their food is coming from. We believe in the importance of defending the interests of farmers and consumers, whilst preventing large retailers from confusing buyers. We have abstained on the final vote because, as much as we agree with the desirability of mandatory country of origin labelling, this should be a matter for Member States to determine alone.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of Parliament's position on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods, such as milk, and taking note of the great public's attention to this, I agree with the position taken by this proposal. I would also stress the need for information campaigns to promote these products. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Food-labelling has become a major issue ever since concrete attention has been paid to how certain foods are produced and manufactured. It is important to create a consumer market for foods which is as transparent as possible, to enable a decent supply and demand on the European market. In my opinion every consumer has the right to know where their food came from, hence I vote for the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Resolution on mandatory country of origin or place of origin for certain foods. This resolution is a step in the right direction, although I regret that the labels on the products do not contain information on the full lifecycle of the product from farming to shelf with key elements that may affect the quality of products such as the place of cultivation and the date of slaughter and the date of the first freezing in meat. Such labelling would prevent fraud with the placing on the shelves of meat several years old. Also, marking the origin of products on our shelves could not sell lower quality milk that does not pass quality controls such as milk produced in Croatia, or milk that arrives in powder. There is a similar situation with eggs that are produced in Croatia often have to meet higher standards than the competition. I welcome the points of resolution that speak of excessive fear of rising prices due to the indication of the country of origin. Past experience shows just the opposite. Consumers want to be informed about the food they buy. A number of labelling schemes work successfully while the impact on the price is small or insignificant. Through the practice of listing the country of origin, citizens' trust is increased, and in addition the "wind in the back" of small and medium-sized farms is given through the recognition of the product itself and the country from which the product comes.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament supports the introduction of mandatory country of origin or place of origin for meat in processed food products. Such indication should also be mandatory for meat other than beef, pig, sheep, goat or poultry meat, for milk, milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed food, single-ingredient products and ingredients accounting for more than 50 % of a food product.  I am particularly pleased that Parliament has called on the Commission to consider extending mandatory country or place of origin to other food products. We are aware of the problem of olive oil counterfeiting, which research has shown to be the most distorted product on the European market, which will be put to an end in this way.  While I support the European Parliament's decision, I believe that there should be some exceptions to milk and dairy products due to the extremely difficult situation in which the dairy sector finds itself. Studies have shown that consumers are more important to taste and duration than their origin when purchasing products, and that only 50% of consumers are willing to pay a 1-2% higher price of the product in order to have origin data. In addition, large dairy companies source raw materials from multiple manufacturers and it is difficult to determine the unique origin of such a product.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 An indication of the country of origin for labelling for all processed meat and milk products should be mandatory in order to make the food supply chain more transparent and to help maintain consumer confidence in food. According to Eurobarometer data, 84% of European citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk; 88% consider this labelling necessary for meat (excluding beef, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goats and poultry, which are already covered) and more than 90% consider labelling to be important for processed foods. The compulsory indication of the country of origin is a powerful incentive to encourage food companies to make the most of high-value-added production in terms of quality and working methods geared to respect for animals and the environment. In particular, I would like to stress that this motion for a resolution is in line with Italian interests. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The principle of mandatory labelling of the country of origin of food, if practical and based on the needs of consumers, is worthy of support. The Commission's analysis is useful, but the conclusion does not address important aspects, i.e. the profits from better informed consumers. Feasibility studies for milk and dairy products exaggerate the cost assessment for industry by assessing all these products in one category. If the scope were limited to slightly processed products only, the costs associated with this would be much lower. Many manufacturers and sellers in the EU already provide such information on their own initiative, reflecting the existing need among consumers and low costs. Mandatory labelling already exists for many products, i.e. meat, eggs, fruit, vegetables, fish and many others. The Commission should submit a proposal for a mandatory designation limited to milk and lightly processed dairy products such as cheese and cream, as well as slightly processed meats, where there is evidence of consumer interest in such information. However, any proposal must minimise costs for producers and consumers. An additional assessment by the Commission of how to implement such a proposal in a cost-effective and proportionate manner would be welcome. Mandatory country of origin labelling of these slightly processed products would represent an important step forward in restoring consumer confidence and would enable them to make more informed choices. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in favour of country of origin labelling, particularly for meat, in particular to prevent further scandals, such as those related to horsemeat or other cases of food fraud, from happening again. This text is balanced, in the sense that it responds to strong consumer demand and takes into account the problems related to the risk of increased costs and administrative burden for companies having to apply the legislation.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. In February 2015, MEPs in the European Parliament had already demanded that the Commission enact rules to make it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods. It is May 2016 and Jean-Claude Juncker and his team have still not moved. Worse, Health Commissioner Andriukaitis reiterated that the Commission would do nothing with regard to mandatory labelling. I am disappointed by the rejection of the environmentalists' amendment calling for animal-derived foods to be labelled as containing GMO residues. Transparency is important to consumers, but the Conservative majority rejected this amendment. Just as it rejected our amendment requiring that the origin of meat be labelled as soon as it exceeds 10% of the composition of a prepared food. This would have concerned quiches, lasagna or ravioli. This vote is a step in the right direction despite attempts by the Conservatives to sabotage the amendments to remove the reference to "compulsory" labelling, but have failed to do so.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution calling on the European Commission to put forward legislative proposals to make it mandatory to indicate the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs.  It is time to provide a clear and effective response to French and European consumers who, according to several studies, want to know the origin of the food they eat. The voluntary system is not sufficient, more than one product in two in France does not indicate the place of origin. The European Commission must act to ensure transparency and traceability throughout the food supply chain. That is why I have reaffirmed my support for mandatory labelling indicating the country of origin or where meat comes from processed foods. We also call for this mandatory labelling to be extended to other foodstuffs and propose to prioritize labelling for consumer milk and lightly processed dairy products (such as cheese and cream) as well as for lightly processed meat products (such as bacon and sausages). This resolution is a strong message that reflects consumers' interest in being better informed, so that they can make informed choices about their diet.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament voted in favour of making the indication of the country of origin or place of provenance mandatory for all types of milk intended for consumption, dairy products and meat products. We also ask the Commission to consider extending this requirement to other foods consisting of a single ingredient or with a predominant ingredient, by drawing up legislative proposals on these matters. The aim is to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and provide more complete information to European consumers. According to a Eurobarometer survey, the vast majority of consumers want to know the origin of these products.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. It is necessary to restore consumer confidence following food scandals in recent years, such as horse meat in 2013, so I consider it highly important that the indication of the country of origin or place of origin of certain foods is mandatory. Consumers have the right to know where the food we eat comes from, without being mistakenly induced, gaining greater control and limiting the risk of product fraud. Country of origin labelling is a broadly supported measure, both by consumers, farmers and consumer organisations, and the cost of it is low, so it must be mandatory for slightly processed dairy and meat products. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of this resolution, which stresses in particular that the mandatory indication of the origin of milk sold as a consumer product or used as an ingredient in dairy products is a useful measure to protect the quality of dairy products, combat food fraud and preserve employment in a sector already battered and facing a serious crisis. In line with the horsemeat lasagna case, the voted text also reminds us that mandatory labelling of meat in processed dishes is also a consumer demand.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the origin of foodstuffs must be labelled. And not only for technical reasons, but also for the need to ensure the consumer's certainty that he acquires the product he wishes to purchase. The talk of transition periods is nothing more than a disconnect, and it seems that it is particularly supported by those who like to hide ingredients of unexplained origin under one label.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which calls on the European Commission to speed up the revision of the Consumer Information Regulation in order to make it mandatory to mention the origin of meat and milk used as ingredients in prepared dishes. While the vast majority of European consumers want this type of information on the products they buy, the Commission continues to oppose these transparency measures. It cites the costs of such provisions, even though experiments and voluntary mechanisms have shown that effective consumer information can be done at a lower cost.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution which affirms the need to provide more precise and detailed information to consumers on the origin of certain foodstuffs such as: all types of milk intended for consumption, dairy products and meat products. In fact, according to the Eurobarometer and a Commission report on this matter, a very significant number of European consumers consider it important to indicate the origin of the product used in an unprocessed way or as an ingredient in processed food products: 84% for milk; 88% for meat and more than 90% for processed food products containing meat. It seems clear to me that only with the implementation of such measures will greater rigour be promoted, as well as higher qualitative and hygio-sanitary levels in this sector, further stimulating the restoration of consumer confidence in food products and promoting greater transparency, traceability and readability of the information provided to them through labelling. In this Resolution I advocated mandatory labelling for the origin of the products referred to in opposition to the recommendation of the political group to which I belong, which advocated voluntary labelling. I did so, together with the Portuguese Members of the EPP for the reasons previously put forward.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. \u2012 I am not a fan of the EU's lavish regulation, but on labelling I am in favour of mandatory reporting of diverse and adequate product information to consumers. I am therefore in favour of the Commission creating a proposal to extend origin marking to certain products. The consumer has the right to know, for example, the country of origin of the food.  The current Food Information Regulation allows the country of origin to be declared in the form of the EU or non-EU. Such labelling does not provide the consumer with sufficient information. According to press reports, the origin markings of a chain of stores selling food have been misleading. Estonian bread, for example, has been sold as a Finn. The Suomi-Finland flag symbol has also been used in a number of manner next to the price data for foreign fresh meat. Labelling is irrelevant if the consumer cannot rely on them. That is why I voted in favour of the compulsory indication of the country or place of origin of certain foodstuffs.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the introduction of mandatory country-of-origin labelling for meat, processed meat, milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products. This resolution comes at a time when a Commission report highlights that 84% of EU citizens believe it is necessary to indicate the origin of milk and 88% consider such labelling necessary for meat. Mandatory labelling would help maintain consumer confidence in food products, especially French products, which meet high quality criteria, to make the food chain more transparent and to increase the added value it generates for farmers and the whole sector. I supported this resolution because it allows for further reflection on the issue of meat and milk labelling. Nevertheless, it remains essential to take into account the increased costs and administrative burdens in order to find the right balance between the interests of our consumers and the competitiveness of our businesses.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution concerns the mandatory indication of the origin and origin of the products and ingredients prevalent in food. As a result of this parliamentary passage, the Commission will be called upon to submit ad hoc legislative proposals so that the consumer can recognize the origin and origin of certain foods. I voted in favour of this resolution, the aim of which is to safeguard the consumer and the food heritage jointly.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution to be mandatory to be included in the labelling of processed foodstuffs, the country of origin of meat and milk with the aim of combating food industry fraud and improving consumer information. The proposal also calls for promoting in the EU the labelling of foodstuffs which are made taking into account animal welfare.  Labelling is a necessary tool for the consumer to have maximum information when buying their food. It is essential for strengthening trade in local products.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on mandatory country of origin labelling for certain categories of foodstuffs, to which we repeatedly call on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal for the mandatory indication of the origin of meat in processed products, but also, for example, the indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for all types of milk intended for drinking or milk products. Not only does this information require more than 80% of consumers, but by providing transparent and consumer-understandable information, we can contribute to combating food fraud and achieving a level playing field in the internal market. It is important to recall that consumers do not need a label made in the EU, but they want to know the specific country of origin.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. In this resolution, it is proposed to indicate the country of origin or place of origin of some foods. I voted in favour because I think it is important that the place of origin of all food products be specified, and so do most consumers in the European Union. Implementing a mandatory indication of origin would be a major step in providing adequate transparency in the food chain for potential consumers, which would facilitate an increase in conscious and responsible consumption, an essential step for transformative consumption.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the obligation to indicate the country of origin for all types of milk, dairy products and meat products. I believe, in fact, that compulsory origin labelling would give consumers the opportunity to be better informed and thus to make more informed purchases. Greater transparency throughout the food supply chain would also bring significant economic benefits to producers of raw materials. I am thinking, for example, of rabbit meat. In Italy, rabbit farming is the fourth largest livestock sector in terms of economic importance, after cattle, pigs and chickens. At present, the entire cunicola supply chain is experiencing a profitability crisis also due to European regulatory uncertainty and the high price volatility linked to the often unfair competition of the product imported from other countries. I hope that the European Commission will fill this regulatory vacuum and present a legislative proposal to extend the compulsory indication of the country of origin to this type of meat as well and thus to make the place of birth, rearing and slaughter of the animal so clearly on the label. Only in this way can we enhance the real Made in Italy and promote the quality and safety of our products.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The mention of meat and milk origin on the label allows for a differentiation which, by recognition of quality and the expression of consumer preference, contributes to the recovery of products, territory and their agricultural employment. This is of increased interest when the agricultural sector, in particular the milk sector, is experiencing a persistent price crisis.  In the Azores, the region from which I come, dairy production is one of the main activities on which the regional economy depends and is also a striking element of the regional landscape and culture. The sector has modernized and invested in improving quality to offer a product with superior characteristics to consumers. The mention of the origin "Azores" is a way of associating the product with the quality of its production, which should deserve the recognition and preference of consumers. The rules underlying origin labelling should be strict with regard to the correspondence between mention and content, precisely to ensure consumer confidence. I therefore advocate the indication of origin on the labelling of meat and milk because it is an element that allows the consumer a choice which is reflected in the protection of local and quality agricultural production.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I support honest food labelling and I support this motion for a resolution which calls for exactly this. Consumers should have the right and ability to know where their food has come from.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it very important to focus on greater support for our domestic food, including by labelling the origin of milk and meat in products. It is very sad that the share of Slovak food on the shelves of our shops is constantly decreasing. This has gone so far as to reach an all-time low of 39% this year. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The food chain is oftentimes long and complex and involves many food business operators and others. In its resolution of 11 February 2015, the EP called on the Commission to complement its legislative proposals to make the designation of origin of meat in processed foods compulsory in order to ensure greater transparency throughout the food chain and better information for European consumers, even if labelling does not in itself provide safeguards against fraud, and therefore an effective control system is also needed. I fully share the motion for a resolution in which we are in favour of mandatory origin labelling for meat in processed foods. Labelling should also be compulsory for meats other than beef, pig, sheep, goatmeat and poultrymeat, milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed foods and for ingredients which account for more than 50 % of the food. The Commission should present legislative proposals as soon as possible to make the introduction of the origin of meat in processed foods compulsory in order to guarantee greater transparency throughout the food chain and to better inform consumers following cases of food fraud.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution requiring mandatory country of origin labelling for certain foods. According to the rules in force today, origin must be compulsory in the case of certain types of meat, fish, fresh fruit and vegetables and some others. In my opinion, this adjustment is sufficient. The consumer has sufficient information and undertakings wishing to indicate origin in the case of other foodstuffs may do so voluntarily. Some actually do, using it as a competitive advantage. But making it an obligation for them in such complex cases as processed meat products would disproportionately put a disproportionate on them. And for most consumers, a complex and long list of the origin of all types of meat (both country of rearing and slaughter) on the packaging of the meat product would have no meaning. To be sure, there are cases of foodstuffs where the introduction of the obligation to indicate origin would be reasonable for consumers and, on the other hand, feasible without undue financial burden on producers, for example, the list of types of compulsorily labelled meat could be extended to include game or farm animals. However, the draft resolution links a few acceptable proposals to a large number of unacceptable proposals, which is why I could not support it as a whole.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament has adopted several resolutions in the past on the labelling of food countries of origin. For example, in its resolution on meat in processed food adopted on 11 February 2015, Parliament called on the European Commission to come up with a draft legislation that would introduce mandatory labelling of the country of origin of meat in processed food. Although this would ensure greater transparency in the food chain and also improve the information of European consumers, the European Commission has not yet made such a proposal. The resolution calls on the Commission to make it mandatory to mark the country of origin or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, milk and meat products, which is a very important requirement. It also includes a call for the Commission to submit legislative proposals to make labelling of the origin of meat in processed foods mandatory. In this context, it should be added that origin labelling is not enough in itself, and a strong approach must also be taken to strengthen monitoring and enforcement of legislation and to introduce stricter penalties for offenders, as the resolution also emphasises. As I agree that the European Commission should make legislative proposals to indicate the origin of food, which would also restore consumer confidence in food, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Indication of the country of origin of food is one of the factors that can influence consumer behaviour on the market. The measure at issue would lead to improved consumer information and increased transparency on selected products purchased, but exact origin labelling of food products produced within the European Union would, in my view, go against the rules of the internal market, which is why I am in favour of labelling food as 'Made in EU'/'Made in the European Union' in such cases.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Rules for listing the country of origin or place of origin already exist and work effectively for a range of food products, such as unprocessed meat, eggs, fruit and vegetables, fish, honey, extra virgin olive oil, wine and carbonated beverages. The fact is that the supply chain is often complex and involves a number of actors, and food operators do not always have a clear overview of the entire production chain. So it's no surprise that consumers don't know much about how their food was actually produced which is worrying because information about the origin of the food could positively affect their willingness to pay. Consequently, I support these motions for a resolution and consider that, inter alia, mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all types of milk, dairy and meat products should be carried out, as well as consideration of extending the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin to other foods containing one main ingredient.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Rules for listing the country of origin or place of origin already exist and work effectively for a range of food products, such as unprocessed meat, eggs, fruit and vegetables, fish, honey, extra virgin olive oil, wine and carbonated beverages. The fact is that the supply chain is often complex and involves a number of actors, and food operators do not always have a clear overview of the overall production chain. So it is not surprising that consumers are unaware of how their food was actually produced which is worrying, as information about the origin of food could have a positive impact on their value of willingness to pay. I support this motion for a resolution as I consider that mandatory country of origin or place of origin should be carried out for all types of milk, dairy and meat products, as well as consider extending the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin to other foods containing one main ingredient.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted against the motion for a resolution to the oral question on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs. The motion for a resolution is populist, so I could not support it. It also submits, inter alia, that mandatory labelling of the origin of milk sold as such or used as an ingredient in dairy products is a useful measure to protect the quality of dairy products and to combat food fraud, which is absolutely not the case. The horsemeat affair made this clear, as the meat had labels, but it was a fraud labelling.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for all types of drinking milk, dairy products and meat products is moving in the right direction. We also agree on intensifying controls, improving the implementation of existing legislation and imposing tougher penalties to avoid all kinds of food scandals and frauds. The health of European citizens takes precedence and must be protected.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion on the labelling of origin or origin of foodstuffs. Rules on indication of origin already exist and work effectively for many other foods, such as unprocessed meat products, eggs, fruits and vegetables, fish, honey, extra virgin olive oil, virgin olive oil and wine and spirits. However, most of these are voluntary and do not solve all problems, for example in the area of fraud. I agree that account should be taken, inter alia, of consumers' need for information, of the practical feasibility of mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin and of the cost-benefit analysis of the introduction of such measures. The indication of the country of origin or place of origin of meat and processed meat products has already provoked serious debates at commission level. The designation of origin or designation of origin may be extended to other products, but this can only be solved through a serious planning and legislative process and clarification of definitions.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union currently has clear rules on the origin of unprocessed meat (beef, pork, sheep, goat or poultry), eggs, fruit and vegetables, fish, honey, virgin and extra-virgin olive oil, wine and spirits. At the same time, dairy products and cheeses, as well as processed meat and other meats, are not regulated to the same extent. This resolution aims to include these types of food in the regulated category of compulsory country of origin indication. The voluntary regulations currently in place at Member State level are considered insufficient. At the same time, however, one detail that has been neglected is the increase in the prices of those products as a result of the application of the new rules. This is not in the interest of European consumers. For these reasons, I believe that the current resolution should take into account several aspects before establishing a binding regulation at European level.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I find it absurd that the needs of the consumer are denied. Indeed, the Commission refuses again and again to mention the origin of processed meats and milk, while almost 90% of citizens are in favour of the original mention on food. It must be believed that the leaders of the European Commission are among the remaining 10%...  There would be huge costs, the Commission said.  This is a lie, which is only intended to protect multinational agri-food companies! Companies already doing this labelling have seen their costs increase by only 0.67%. Parliament is therefore voting this afternoon for a new formal notice so that legislation on this matter can be introduced and that the consumer is heard. It's a question of transparency

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods. Considering that labelling products is already a common practice and that the EU already has the highest standards of food quality and security worldwide, I consider that mandatory labelling will result in increased protectionist behaviours. In addition, it will lead to significant additional administrative costs, particularly for SMEs, and an increase in the price of products which will outweigh the benefits of such a measure.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ According to Eurobarometer surveys from 2013, 84% of consumers think it is necessary to specify the country of origin of milk, whether it is sold as a separate product, or as an ingredient in dairy products, and the Commission's report of 17 December 2013 stated that as many as 90% of consumers want to know the origin of the meat used in processed products. However, in its report on milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products, the Commission concludes that voluntary labelling would be the most appropriate solution in the case of these products and has not yet presented any legislative proposals concerning processed meat. As there is a great deal of consumer interest in informing the country of origin, I believe that the Commission should initiate an obligation to mark the origin of food as soon as possible with minimal additional costs for producers and consumers.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution of 12 May 2016 on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foodstuffs (2016/2583(RSP)). Mandatory labelling would give customers more confidence in food products while making food supplies more transparent. Country of origin labels could make the EU market more competitive for Slovenian providers, as our products are considered to be of better quality.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution to be mandatory to be included in the labelling of processed foodstuffs, the country of origin of meat and milk with the aim of combating food industry fraud and improving consumer information. The proposal also calls for promoting in the EU the labelling of foodstuffs which are made taking into account animal welfare. Labelling is a necessary tool for the consumer to have maximum information when buying their food. It is essential for strengthening trade in local products.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Any further regulation will need to find a reasonable level between consumer information and unnecessary financial and administrative burdens for food producers. However, I do not consider the resulting text to be balanced, which is why I abstained.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution on the compulsory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance for certain foods because it constitutes a non-tariff barrier, which processors will be affected by, and the consequence being transmitted indirectly to national producers. Furthermore, a legislative proposal from the European Commission on this subject will create strong non-competitive influences and pave the way to restricting and tightening national labelling rules, without beneficial effects on market participants such as: consumers, manufacturers, processors. I think this proposal is unrealistic, based on populist demands. Farmers and SMEs will feel a financial pressure they would not have needed, as the Commission's report makes it clear that consumers are not willing to pay for the labelling of these products.  European producers use voluntary labelling, with national or even regional indication of the origin of the product, already having adist consumers of local products, and these movements supporting the idea of compulsory indication are clearly protectionist and not necessarily in the interests of the consumer.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In its resolution of 11 February 2015, Parliament urged the Commission to follow up on an earlier report with legislative proposals making it mandatory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods in order to make the food chain more transparent and to better inform European consumers. I voted in favour of this motion in accordance with S&D's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the motion for a Resolution to be mandatory to be included in the labelling of processed foodstuffs, the country of origin of meat and milk with the aim of combating food industry fraud and improving consumer information. The proposal also calls for promoting in the EU the labelling of foodstuffs which are made taking into account animal welfare. Labelling is a necessary tool for the consumer to have maximum information when buying their food. It is essential for strengthening trade in local products.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it restates Parliament’s position in favour of mandatory indication of the origin in processed food and asks for legislative proposals in that area.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
