text: Writing. – Article 26(7) of the Food Information Regulation provides that those reports must take into account, inter alia, the consumer's need to be informed, the feasibility of the mandatory indication of the country of origin or designation of origin and the cost-benefit analysis of the determination of such measures.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. This is an example of European regulatory ness that ignores all the objectives. I've resisted this. It leads to extra red tape, extra checks, higher costs and therefore higher consumer prices, a higher price that the consumer does not always want to pay. This proposal is a solution to a non-existent problem. Some manufacturers already voluntarily put on the label where the ingredients come from in order to be able to distinguish their products from other products. As a result, consumers can already buy processed foods, which indicate the origin of the ingredients. This does not require additional EU legislation.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with country-of-origin labelling of certain foodstuffs, such as milk or meat in processed foods. The stated aim is to ensure the transparency of the food chain and to restore consumer confidence, shaken after several scandals including that of horsemeat fraud in 2013. Indeed, despite the scandals, the European Commission still defends labelling on a purely voluntary basis. As this approach has shown its limitations, it is a question of obtaining mandatory labelling for so-called 'minor' types of meat (other than beef, swine, sheep, goat and poultry, for which compulsory labelling already applies), milk, unprocessed foodstuffs, products containing a single ingredient and ingredients that make up more than 50% of a food item. The EPP has tried by all means to weaken this resolution by using the usual argument of cost for SMEs - when they will, in my view, be the first beneficiaries and that transparency is in any case a point on which we should not compromise, under the pretext of weakening the market. I voted for this resolution and welcome its adoption by a large majority.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The committee, before basing its studies on the impact that country of origin labelling will have on producing companies and the fact that consumers are not willing to be the ones who would pay those increased costs, should first take into account that, in order to have a consumption of products from the Member States in order to have preference for consumers of those states, the first should be supported and encouraged the national production of each of those countries.  The implementation of policies in this context guaranteeing fair quotas and production rights and not asymmetric productions as the liberalisation of markets promoted by the EU does so. Policies that defend national productions. Then it would be necessary for the Commission to take into account the need to ensure competitive, competitive prices with foreign production for similar products of the same quality, i.e. ensuring identical work to producers, ensuring access to the goods and services necessary for production, at similar prices and qualities. In addition, proximity and access to national productions is increasingly conditioned by policies that promote and support large distribution companies to the detriment of local and traditional trade.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The authors of the resolution first point out the benefits of mandatory origin labelling of products such as meat and milk. On the one hand, consumers have the opportunity to see the origin of the product and, on the other hand, it is better to prevent fraud. The Commission is invited to press ahead with compulsory origin labelling for milk, dairy products and meat. The Commission is invited to make legislative proposals in this regard. It also calls on the Commission to promote labelling for the greatest possible animal welfare during rearing, transport and slaughter. In addition, eggs and egg-containing products should also be included in the list of products which must be labelled as a mandatory factor as to their origin. With its amendments, the EPP is once again showing its true face: the protection of consumers and the right of consumers to know where a product comes from is, in the OPINION of the EPP, a negligible luxury that could hinder the internal market.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the European Parliament resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of origin for certain foods. I was able to support many of the amendments and amendments to the resolution. I believe that the origin of a product is an essential distinguishing feature. Milk from England is a different commodity than milk from Germany. That is why I believe that mandatory origin labelling is necessary, useful and correct for reasons of consumer transparency. However, it is not for the EU to regulate this. The competence to do so lies at Member State level. A common market would require no more than the rule that there are no barriers to trade and import of goods of all kinds, provided that they bear only a correct designation of origin which enables the consumer to take an informed decision.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs believe consumers have a right to know where their food comes from. We are calling for clear, honest labelling to enable consumers to make informed choices without being misled. The EU consistently places high health and safety standards on food production. Exiting the EU could put British citizens at risk through deregulation and lower standards.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. I voted against compulsory labelling. The red tape and controls for this origin labelling leads to higher costs and therefore a higher price, a higher price that the consumer does not always want to pay. In addition, some manufacturers already voluntarily indicate on their label where the ingredients come from, in order to distinguish their products from other products. In other words, if the consumer really wants to know where the ingredients come from and also wants to pay for these extra costs, they can do just that. I am particularly concerned that the costs for SMEs would be very high. Moreover, compulsory labelling would not also stop food fraud.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I co-authored and voted for this report, because Labour MEPs believe consumers have a right to know where their food comes from. We are calling for clear, honest labelling to enable consumers to make informed choices without being misled.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – The resolution on the compulsory indication of the country or place of origin of certain foods that are not binding urges the Commission to enforce this labelling for all types of ready-to-eat milk, dairy and meat products.  This is based on the results of the 2013 Eurobarometer survey, which found that 84% of EU citizens consider it necessary to indicate the origin of milk. I note that even after the adoption of legislation that is among the most transparent in the world at European level, better informing consumers as a result of the horsemeat scandal and other cases of food fraud remains a problem. I supported the report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Geographical indication is a major conquest in the European internal market. It enhances the quality of food and protects consumers. Of course I voted in favour of this resolution, for the benefit of the consumer, the producer and the quality of our agricultural products.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I think the consumer has the right to know the provenance of the products he consumes, so I do think that labelling indicating this data is something interesting. However, I also believe that this should be optional for producers. First, because labelling would increase the cost of products, which could be detrimental to producers. Secondly, because I am confident that the real importance lies in the condition of the product and not so much in its origin. That is, that aspects such as quality, safety and the product that has been produced according to the standards are the ones that really have to be guaranteed. That is why I believe that those consumers who are really interested in knowing the origin of their products can do so by buying those who have decided to add that data. In addition, this optionality would prevent the market from over-bureaucracy.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme of this resolution is the indication of compulsory origin for foods not covered by current legislation, namely milk, milk used as an ingredient in milk products, meat types other than beef, pigmeat, sheepmeat, goatmeat and poultrymeat, un processed foods, single-ingredient products and ingredients representing more than 50% of a food stuff. This resolution therefore calls on the Commission to extend origin labelling to foods where consumers' interests are balanced with costs, for example milk or low-processing food. I am in favour of legislative proposals making origin marking compulsory for food, supporting 'made in'. I believe that labelling can be used as a marketing tool that provides added value to the product. We sponsor a step-by-step approach that starts with the regulation of voluntary labelling and sees mandatory labelling as the ultimate goal to be achieved.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The resolution on the indication of the country of origin of milk and meat in the processed products concerned deliberately limits its scope to a small portion of these products, based on their small degree of processing (cheese, yogurt, bacon, etc.), because – as it expressly states – it does not want to burden food monopolies financially. For the umpteenth time, the European Parliament is proving that in the balance of profits it willingly sacrifices the health and even the lives of workers. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted in favour of even this limited country of origin obligation, pointing out that international agreements drawn up by the EU, such as CETA with Canada and the forthcoming TTP under negotiation, abolish traditional Greek designations of origin, such as feta cheese or Kalamata olives, to the detriment of small producers and for the benefit of food multinationals. That is why, of course, the resolution observes a 'fish silence', as well as the EU CAP which is taking out poor farmers and small farmers, collecting land and production in rural capitalist enterprises, for government measures, such as that of SYRIZA-ANEL in Greece, for lengthening the duration of fresh milk and for the manufacture of yogurt from milk powder that hits small producers to serve the interests of large companies in the sector.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution based on the ENVI committee's question on mandatory country or place of origin labelling for certain foods. I think that, at a time when it is very difficult to trace where the food we consume or its ingredients comes from, any proposal that deals with better and more thorough consumer information is welcome. Research shows that consumers are interested in the origin of their diet and want to have enough reliable information to make an informed decision. And in the case of meat and milk, where its multiple processing into the form of different products can completely erase its origin, I believe that, in addition to voluntary schemes, mandatory origin marking schemes must be introduced at European level, especially as the voluntary schemes already in place show neither high additional requirements for producers nor high additional costs for consumers. I believe that such procedures will not only help to improve consumer awareness and enable them to make prudent choices, but will also restore their confidence in the food industry.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution we are about to vote on is a further step in the right direction to meet the information and safety needs of European consumers. In particular, I would like to focus on the fact that an important amendment has been included in the text which, together with other colleagues, I have promoted, in which we call on the European Commission to go beyond the current system by extending compulsory labelling to a whole series of products for which it is not required today, for example meat in processed foods and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products. A legislative initiative by the European Commission to move in this direction would, in fact, be essential in order to ensure greater transparency along the food chain, to better inform European consumers – given the importance for them of the wording of origin for an informed and informed choice of purchase – and to avoid fragmentation of the internal market, which could ultimately have negative effects on consumers themselves. This is all the more necessary today in the light of the recent decision by the European Executive to authorise a compulsory labelling system on an experimental basis in France.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the mandatory indication of the country of origin or place of provenance in certain foodstuffs because I consider it absolutely essential that consumers can know and rely on the labelling of the products they consume. At a time when there are many examples of media coverage of processed foods with ingredients other than those indicated on the packaging, it is imperative, on the one hand, to restore consumer confidence in labels and, on the other hand, to restore the credibility of the food industry. To this end, I would like to point out the call on the Commission to submit legislative proposals to make it compulsory to indicate the origin of meat in processed foods, as well as for meat other than beef, pork, sheep, goats and poultry, for consumer milk and milk used as an ingredient in dairy products and for unprocessed foodstuffs , products consisting of a single ingredient and ingredients representing more than 50% of a food.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. – If today we buy ready-made tortellini or lasagna, or sausages, burgers or dairy products such as yogurt and cheese on the label, we have no information on the origin of the raw materials that make them up. I have been fighting for a long time with my colleagues in the M5S to give consumers all the elements they need to make informed choices, so that we can choose the foods that they think best suits their diet and that of their children. This resolution, which I voted in favour of, calls for the origin marking label for processed and dairy products to become compulsory and not just voluntary. Production costs for companies with labelling would increase insignificantly. Making origin marking mandatory for food is a tool to defend "made in" and quality food. Labelling is an added value for the product that is recognised by consumers. The citizens want to know where what they eat comes from and how they produce, and with this resolution we wanted to send out a message that the European Commission cannot ignore.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 Resolution calling on the Commission to make the labelling of the country of origin or place of origin mandatory for all types of drinking milk, milk and meat products and to put forward legislative proposals to make it mandatory to make labelling of the origin of meat in processed foods mandatory.  I believe that the Resolution does not take into account some important aspects. The introduction of mandatory origin labelling may lead to the renationalisation of the European internal market. It also ignores the fact that the higher price for additional origin labelling represents an additional financial burden for farmers and poorer households.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, one of the biggest social problems in the European Union, and also in Hungary, in my own country, is the so-called demographic crisis, namely the fact that not enough children are born. It would be difficult to line up the reasons, but I would like to highlight two of them. One is that it is very difficult and increasingly difficult to reconcile the world of work and private life. The other is that, unfortunately, marriage is rare, a relationship in which love and justice are bound together in such a way that the education of children is a common task, both joys and worries are shared. I supported this report because it points in the direction of both, so it considers that the child's upbringing and care is a shared responsibility of the father and the mother and helps to reconcile the world of private life and work.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I did not support this material for one simple reason. I have nothing against parents having sufficient leave, my reason for not supporting them is because I believe that this area does not fall within the competence of the European Union. I believe that if we want to apply the principle of subsidiarity in the adoption of European legislation, then we should simply and well regulate such issues at European level. We should leave it to individual Member States to adjust parental leave themselves within their social systems. At the last meeting of this Parliament, we debated that the principle of subsidiarity should not be a mere formality, but should be applied consistently. And here, a month later, we have an example of a thing that, in my opinion, really, according to the principle of subsidiarity, should not be revised centrally in Europe.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Madam President, I welcomed the report today that was debated and voted upon on parental leave. Mums and dads across the European Union want to spend quality time with their children, in particular in those early days when a child comes into a family home, and I support calls for the paternity leave to be a minimum of two weeks across the 28 Member States. In the UK that has already happened; it was my party that wanted it extended to four weeks.  But 40% of fathers in the UK do not take extra leave and in the EU as a whole only 10% of fathers take one extra day of parental leave, whilst 97% of mums take the most leave that they possibly can take. Therefore this debate today is a question of equality and a question of fairness as well.  So we have the opportunity of making sure that parental leave is put on the political agenda and of extending paternity leave across the 28 Member States to a minimum of two weeks.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Chairman! The progressive development of parental leave systems, permanent adaptation – this is very important, because at this point in time there is a leave for new mothers only in several Countries of the European Union, while for dads it is very rare. For example, as we know, Norway can give dads up to fourteen weeks, Slovenia, Iceland to twelve, Lithuania to four, Portugal to three. In fact, everywhere else, in other countries, including my country, Latvia, dads vacation does not exceed one or two weeks.  This is wrong in my view, because dads would also like to spend time with their newborn sons, daughters and care for them. I am not calling for discrimination against women now, god forbid, of course, no, but I call for men not to discriminate, because the unification of this system will be good fruit, because it is the future of our European Union, it is our children. It is a matter of our existence at all, and it is a true social democracy.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, only 2.7% of fathers take parental leave across the EU, despite the fact that we have the option of fathers taking up to four months. One of the major issues here is that parental leave in most Member States is unpaid or very poorly paid. According to the OECD, in France you can take up to 28 weeks of paid parental or paternity leave. In the UK it is two weeks, in the Netherlands and Greece, it is just two days. In Ireland, as of yet, we have no paid parental or paternity leave. We need both.  This is a crucial issue if we want parents, but in particular fathers, to use parental leave. A policy instrument called ‘daddy quotas’ where a part of the parental leave is reserved for the father has been successful in very many Nordic countries. We have another possibility called ‘bonus months’ where if the parents agree to share the parental leave, they are given bonus paid weeks.  Finally, let me say that, once again, this morning, I called on the Commission to put in place a carers leave directive and I am very anxiously awaiting the new start for parents and carers that Commissioner Jourová promised this morning.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the report suggests a number of legislative changes to parental leave including extending the minimum amount of parental leave to 6 months and the inclusion of a minimum of 2 weeks’ paternity leave. The aim of this report is to assess the application of legislation on parental leave by different Member States and to draw the necessary political conclusions.  I support the calls of this report, alongside my EPP colleagues, as it recognises the importance of providing parents with adequate parental leave. Ireland currently follows EU directives on parental leave. We would welcome the calls in this report, including the minimum term of 2 weeks' paternity leave, as Ireland's employment laws do not as of now recognise paternity leave. However, the introduction of paternity leave in legislation would be of benefit to working parents in Ireland, and I am pleased to say that, in his first interview, the new Minister, Leo Varadkar, has said he intends legislating to make this happen. As Ms Stihler and Ms Harkin indicated, whether fathers take it up or not is a different matter.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour paternity rights and leave, but we cannot support calls for more EU legislation and interference on this subject. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide the terms of parental leave, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels whose policies and laws are not accountable to the voters.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a report calling for the evaluation of the framework agreement on parental leave between the EU and the social partners. Creating the conditions for being able to be at home with their children in the first few years of life is an important issue for the Christian Democrats, but it does not belong at European level. Unfortunately, the report proposes problematic top-down solutions on how to achieve equal take-up of parental leave. It includes calls for EU rules on quotas for paternity leave, an increased minimum level of parental leave in the Union and a restriction on the right to transfer leave days between parents. A review of all directives relating to family-related leave is also proposed, on the basis of the withdrawn maternity leave directive. The EU needs to concentrate on its core tasks – for Parliament to continue to demand that the EU be given greater family policy powers is fundamentally provocative. I therefore voted against the report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Parental leave is the right of both parents to abstain from work for a certain period, thus enabling family needs to be balanced with work commitments. Ensuring a certain flexibility in employment contracts is particularly important, not only from the point of view of a form of support for women workers, but above all with a view to achieving the employment targets of 75% of the Horizon 2020 programme. To this end, the aim has been to develop social policies and measures to facilitate reintegration into the world of work, as well as the full implementation of the directive in all Member States. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Although not absolutely, I agree with the basics of this report. Firstly, the reporting of the gender gap in the use of parental leave, for which it is necessary to reduce the current flexibility, as it promotes the reproduction at the domestic level of the patriarchal division of care tasks. Secondly, support for an ambitious maternity directive (after the Commission withdrew, ignoring Parliament's vote, its previous proposal) and harmonisation ensuring minimum paternity leave. Finally, the requirement for effective implementation by Member States of European legislation and the full participation of the social partners throughout the process. That's why I voted for it.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the application of the Council's 2010/18/EU Directive of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised parental leave framework. The aim here is to assess the implementation of parental leave legislation in the various Member States. Despite some measures that deserve our support, such as reducing administrative barriers to easier access to parental leave, the possibility of broadening the scope of parental leave, or the special attention that needs to be paid to children with disabilities, this report has many fundamental problems. Indeed, there is a real desire to standardised leave at European level and thus a further attack on the sovereignty of the Member States as well as the principle of subsidiarity. It should also be noted that this text proposes real interference in family affairs in order to remedy the low participation of fathers in parental leave and to increase the employment rate of women in a significant way, when this should be the choice of each family.  On the contrary, we believe that the economic difficulties faced by European citizens are not linked and should not be put in competition with intra-family life.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted for the text of my colleague Marie Arena. Today, in the European Union, workers can take parental leave when a child is born or adopted. However, the conditions for access to this right as well as financial compensation vary considerably between Member States. It is clear that men and women are not equal when it comes to parental leave. It is essential that Member States address this imbalance so that there is a real work-life balance for both sexes.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE organisations, UEAPME, SEEP and ETUC and the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC, because it is necessary to modernise and maintain the different types of authorisations in the EU to ensure gender equality, increase women's participation in the labour market and ensure a balance between personal and professional life.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Parental leave is of the utmost importance for the development of children and should therefore be further promoted. That is the key message of this own-initiative report. It is important that a future Commission proposal is comprehensive and therefore includes maternity, paternity and parental leave. The report confirms that the current legal framework, which entered into force 20 years ago, is outdated and needs comprehensive reform. From facilitating the re-entry into the labour market of women who have taken maternity leave to promoting paternity leave, this report makes concrete proposals on how to improve the legal framework and strengthen gender equality. This could ultimately lead to a stronger competitiveness of the EU. This initiative is also to be welcomed.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. On the pretext of the best interests of the child, the enhancement of the role of parent, social policies aimed at families, it is in fact the political will to achieve an employment rate of 75% of women that is expressed here.  However, contrary to what this report claims, it is the economic difficulties that lead to unemployment and precariousness. I voted against this biased report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this report makes many valid points, maternity/paternity leave should be a UK Government power, not for the EU to determine. I abstained.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, as advocated by the committee on its merits. Nevertheless, I am surprised that there is a case in which Europe has a real competence in this area. This initiative may lead to misunderstandings and frustrations.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on parental leave. Parents on these holidays are still quite rare, as they are usually taken by their mothers. In order to promote equal opportunities for women and men to reconcile private and professional life in the EU, common rules on childcare have been established. However, differences between countries, especially in the area of holiday payment, remain significant. I support the recommendations set out above on how to strike a balance in the area of parental leave. I agree that the proper payment of parental leave would help to fairly distribute work and family life between men and women.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to assess the implementation of parental leave legislation in the various Member States, in order to ensure "gender equality" and justice in the distribution of family tasks between men and women.  In concrete terms, the report proposes to simplify the transposition of European legislation, which constitutes a further infringement on the sovereignty of The Member States as well as the principle of subsidiarity. It is also an intrusion into the family life or even intimate of couples, putting in competition economic difficulties and intra-family life. So I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have obviously approved this resolution brought by my colleague Maria Arena. It stresses that the provisions necessary for the transposition of the 2013/62/EU directive on the application of the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and etents vary in different forms between Member States. In general, MEPs encourage Member States that have not yet done so to make available to the Commission, within a reasonable time, the tables of correspondence between the provisions of the directive and the transposition measures. They consider it essential that Member States have the necessary means of inspection to monitor compliance with legislation on the protection of the rights of parents. A study on this matter is the Commission requested. Regretting the disparities in the measures to transpose the directive between Member States, MEPs recommend that all possible measures be implemented to enable the correct and uniform application of the directive.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it is a balanced document which in turn defends a progressive and equal view of parental leave by establishing as its main priority the best interests of the child. The resolution also seeks greater coherence in transposing Directive 2010/18/EU into Member States.  It also points to other interesting aspects such as gender imbalance in the use of parental leave. At this point I consider it essential to promote parental co-responsibility. Although the text is not as ambitious, it does reflect another positive element such as a preference for a system in which parents can choose to qualify for permission.  The resolution in turn calls for facilitating the return to work of parents after the enjoyment of leave, calls for measures that address the needs of parents with children with disabilities, and points out the importance of individual and paid parental leave for same-sex couples Getting reconciliation between family life and working life is another challenge we must address. That is why I welcome the proposal, included in the text, to draw up an ambitious directive to that effect.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy includes among its objectives the achievement of an employment rate for women of 75%. One issue is strongly linked to the reconciliation of work and private life, which, in turn, sees the issue of leave legislation as a central element in its implementation. National legislation on leave currently provides for three types of family leave: maternity, paternity and parental leave; while at European level there are two directives, one on maternity leave and one, updated in 2010, on parental leave. The Arena report, which I supported with my vote, strongly calls for a strengthening of the relevant legislation, pushing for a strong guarantee of access to leave without any discrimination due to the sector of employment and the contractual characteristics of the work. Parental leave should be ensured fairly for both parents and the push to allow fathers to take advantage of this opportunity should be strengthened. In this direction, new European legislation on paternity leave should be adopted to ensure a minimum level of leave of two weeks.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The approved report is a progressive document, is an improvement over existing directives and aims to extend parental leave, promote a directive for paternity leave and also calls on States and the Commission to implement policies that promote more men's paternity leave. For us these measures are not sufficient because to achieve equality and co-responsibility between men and women in care, and that this does not adversely affect and discriminate in the labour market for women, we need to broaden the perspective and go to the root of the problem. We can only achieve equality if parental leave by birth or adoption is recognized as an individual right and therefore equal, non-transferable and paid at 100%. Despite the shortcomings and that from our perspective it is not a report of highs, it is an improvement in the face of the current situation and that is why we vote on it in favour.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. It goes without saying that family law, the education of children and social and family security benefits must continue to be the responsibility of the Member States. However, I am not against the EU's initiative to encourage Member States to take measures to encourage parental leave.  I believe that it is essential to guarantee women the right to balance employment with motherhood. All too often, it must be remembered, economic and professional pressures mean that women give up their maternity leave. Balancing work and private life is not easy, as we all know. I would like to remind you, however, that the family is currently under attack from all sides with the recognition of the GPA, adoptions by same-sex couples or attacks on traditional marriage. The family is the natural and fundamental element of society. We have to protect her. In this sense, encouraging parental leave for educational purposes is a first step. To be able to institute a real parental wage would certainly be a second one.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report to assess the implementation of parental leave legislation. First of all, it should be remembered that it must co-exist with maternity leave, as well as paternity leave. A diversity that can be found in social security benefits at the level of the Member States. However, while the rapporteur himself acknowledges these differences in social models, he calls for harmonisation, including through a real violation of the family and personal life of policyholders, since he calls for the individualisation of parental leave and the non-transferability of a significant part of it. I find this position shocking, not least because it calls into question the freedom of each couple to make decisions for themselves, and, even worse, the freedom of women to decide whether to work or stay at home to raise their children. Indeed, the real objective of this report is to achieve the rates set by the Europe 2020 strategy, which require 75% of women in the labour market. The woman is therefore reduced to a simple variable of economic adjustment, to the detriment of her true freedom.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Arena report on the application of Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave is a partisan text, which, although it is based on acceptable considerations on parental leave, then pushes for the legitimisation of homosexual adoptions throughout the European Union, despite the fact that several Member States do not yet have legislation in this area or is already prohibited by law. This is one of the repeated attempts to impose standard thinking on European citizens, including in the ethics of family relations. For these reasons, I did not support the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work-life balance and personality, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission to review the Parental Leave Directive and calls for a report on the implementation of this Directive. Parliament also calls on the Commission to present European legislation on paternity leave in order to achieve the best possible reconciliation between work and private life for families. The purpose of this report is to assess the implementation of legislation on parental leave in the various Member States and to draw the necessary political conclusions. The European Commission was surprised not to wish to carry out the report on the implementation of this directive itself. Fortunately, this task was carried out instead by a group of 33 national experts, the Eurofound Executive Agency and various European researchers. This is indeed surprising given that the Commission published an 'action plan' in the summer of 2015 on combining work-life balance, an issue that is inevitably linked to this legislation. As regards parental leave, the social partners were able to reach an agreement, which was subsequently converted by the European Union into law, but in the case of maternity leave, policymakers of the Council and the Commission were more inclined to leave the 1992 legal order, despite numerous attempts by the European Parliament to update the process of adopting its review.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave concluded between the Confederation of Large European Enterprises (Businesseurope), the European Trade and Small Business Association (UEAPME), the European Association of Enterprises and Employees of Public Service Providers (CEEP) and the European Confederation of Trade Unions (ETUC). Indeed, the Europe 2020 strategy sets a target of a 75% employment rate of both sexes. this target has already been achieved for men, while there is a high likelihood that women, where the employment rate is currently 63.5%, are unlikely to meet the target by 2020. The agreement adopted therefore calls for the adoption of large-scale measures to increase the integration of women into the labour market, in particular through policy packages to distribute family and household activities, child-rearing and care for other depende for other depende for women. I would also like to mention that slovenia, with the regulation of maternity and parental leave, is at the European Summit because of the length of leave and the balanced distribution of the sexes.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Even today, in Europe, there are no uniform, appropriate and flexible conditions for working fathers and mothers who need to reconcile their private life with their professional life. European legislation needs to be reviewed and modernised, which no longer corresponds to the current economic and social environment and the EU's employment targets for 2020. In order to respond to demographic, economic and gender equality challenges, it is therefore necessary to devise family policies aimed at promoting a smooth and gradual return to work that strengthen the flexibility, accessibility, duration, compensation and transferability of parental leave. For these reasons, I wholeheartedly support my colleague's report, which is sure that greater guarantees can support employment and give greater dignity to the role of parents.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Croatia has one of the best regulated maternity leave in Europe. It is sad that other Member States are not following such an example. I believe it is necessary to regulate maternity leave at EU level, in order to create greater certainty for parents.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I strongly support this report and voted in favour of it because it recognises the need to improve parental leave rights across Ireland and the EU, and aims to put gender equality at the heart of this strategy.  The southern Irish state is an example of worst practice in the EU. The 26 weeks of paid maternity leave is paid at a low flat rate. We’re still waiting for any paid paternity leave to be implemented and we only have unpaid parental leave. Discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace, low pay and precarious work, the punishment of lone parents who want to work, and skyrocketing childcare costs, all worsen the situation. Sinn Féin wants to cap and then reduce childcare fees; to restore the rights and payments to lone parents; and ensure paid maternity, paternity, parental and carer’s leave.  This report stresses the importance of these four types of leave. It also calls for non-transferability of parental leave – a proposal that supports gender equality in caring responsibilities, based on evidence that in states where leave can be transferred it is often transferred to the mother and there is a low take-up of paternity leave.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the family rights recognised by public policies, including parental leave, are identical in terms of individual rights and that both parents can be used equally, so as to encourage them to achieve a better work-life balance, in the best interests of their children, and that it would be important to , in addition, to achieve the target of an employment rate of 75% for women and men set by the Europe 2020 strategy and to promote gender equality.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Parental leave is an essential tool that should enable both parents to properly look after their children, ensuring a fair work-life balance. It is, however, a measure which, in its present form, presents important problems: while this instrument is often underpaid and too short when compared with real family needs, it is a mechanism that few men use, the latter being the cause of serious gender discrimination which adversely affects the employment rate of European women. The directive framing this measure is characterised by considerable disparities in transposition measures, which identify more or less favourable schemes, depending on the type of labour sector, which are extremely uneven. For all these reasons, I call on the Commission to present new measures to promote the use of parental leave by fathers and to ensure that the directive is implemented uniformly in every sector of work. I also believe that, with a view to reducing gender discrimination, we must promote innovative instruments, such as teleworking, which will facilitate a smooth and gradual return to employment and a better reconciliation of life and work.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The gender imbalance in taking parental leave persists even a decade after the transposition of the related Directive by the Member States. This makes it almost impossible to achieve the 75% employment target for women set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. Career equality for men and women is influenced by parental leave, and policies are needed to support women to enter and maintain the labour market and also to support their reintegration as mothers into the labour market. This agreement takes into account the main demographic, economic and gender equality challenges in the Union, highlighting the importance of gender equality and equity in the division of family tasks between women and men. It is also stressed the importance of adopting family policies to facilitate a gradual return to work, as returning to work after parental leave can be a difficult and stressful situation. I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement because I believe that women's participation in the labour market makes a significant economic contribution to the Union economy and also to demographic development.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the report promotes some legitimate reflections on the importance of conciliation and on strengthening protections for parents of disabled children, openly declaring the failure of European action in this area, the text is not acceptable. The rapporteur not only calls on the Commission to re-sign the European legislation governing this matter, thereby promoting yet another impulse to 'communitisation', but through continuous and explicit requests for parental leave adapted to the 'needs of same-sex parents' de facto aims at legitimising homosexual adoptions, taking it for granted even for those European countries that have not yet regulated this case or even constitutionally prohibit it (Romania , for example).  Traditionally, leave tends to be seen and analysed from a perspective that considers women to be the main caregivers, paying less attention to the situation of fathers. However, it is important to reflect on the leave related to caring responsibilities also from the point of view of fathers, especially in view of the much-desired increase in the employment rate required by the Europe 2020 strategy.  Our delegation, which has always fought against any manoeuvre to impose more Europe on its citizens, must all the more oppose any attempt by the EU to meddle in those areas. I am voting against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Parental leave is very important in order to allow parents to accompany their children during their youth. It promotes family relationships and the child's education. It also encourages equality between men and women in their role in their family structure. The Council's 2010/18/EU Directive on the application of the revised framework agreement on parental leave states that all workers are entitled to four months of parental leave. It is important that all Member States comply with the requirements of this directive. Member States should also exchange best practices so that the directive fully encourages both parents to take parental leave, not just women, which is the current trend. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report setting out the state of implementation of the framework agreement on parental leave and calling on the Commission to make new proposals to ensure that the directive is implemented correctly and uniformly in all EU Member States.  As a matter of fact, there is no failure on the part of The Member States to implement parental leave, but rather a certain disparity in the way in which it is carried out, in particular as regards the maximum duration, the remuneration schemes during leave and the scope. What has also emerged is the low use of parental leave by fathers, which is mainly explained by low pay as well as, in most Member States, transferability. I support the call for the Commission to strengthen European legislation on how parental leave is to be used to ensure uniform implementation of the directive across the EU and I fully support the call for Member States to ensure that family rights can be enjoyed equally by both parents, so as to encourage them to achieve a better work-life balance. , in the best interests of the children.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report and voted in favour of it because it recognises the need to improve parental leave rights across Ireland and the EU, and aims to put gender equality at the heart of this strategy.  The southern Irish state is an example of worst practice in the EU. The 26 weeks of paid maternity leave is paid at a low flat rate. We’re still waiting for any paid paternity leave to be implemented and we only have unpaid parental leave. Discrimination against pregnant women in the workplace, low pay and precarious work, the punishment of lone parents who want to work, and skyrocketing childcare costs, all worsen the situation. Sinn Féin wants to cap and then reduce childcare fees; to restore the rights and payments to lone parents; and ensure paid maternity, paternity, parental and carer’s leave.  This report stresses the importance of these four types of leave. It also calls for non-transferability of parental leave – a proposal that supports gender equality in caring responsibilities, based on evidence that in states where leave can be transferred it is often transferred to the mother and there is a low take-up of paternity leave.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the current situation regarding parental leave needs to be adapted to current circumstances. The report makes a number of good proposals and encourages awareness campaigns and exchange of best practices. I also welcome the fact that the report was drawn up with the aid of a considerable number of social partners.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the framework agreement on parental leave, carried by Maria Arena. It is more necessary than ever to affirm the need to apply common European rules on parental leave.  In general, I welcome the extension of the minimum duration of unpaid parental leave from four to at least six months and the introduction of European rules on paternity leave of at least two weeks. The differences in parental leave are still too great between EU countries. This report is moving in the right direction on the conditions of access to this right, in particular by requiring Member States to guarantee equal access to parental leave and incentives to encourage fathers to take it. Moreover, at a time when financial compensation for parental leave varies considerably, this report calls on Member States to revise their systems with the aim of achieving an adequate level of income replacement as decent as an incentive.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the report as presented because it proposes some measures contradictory to our national legislation in this area. I believe there should be more emphasis put on national decision-making processes when it comes to modalities and provisions on parental leave.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we believe that an integrated approach to the issue of gender equality and reconciliation of work with family life in future EU legislation will give coherence and transparency to the effort and contribute to promoting reconciliation of work with family life from a gender perspective.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, SEEP and ETUC, as well as the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC. It is true that European legislation on parental leave needs to be updated as issues of citizens' rights and equality arise. As this report highlights the need to improve the existing framework for the benefit of citizens, I think it is a positive step and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour of this report was essentially to define a political direction that is intended to unravel an overly complex tax in regulatory terms, namely parental leave. On the basis of the documentation presented to me, it has been interesting to note that, in this area, the current legislation has now been outdated, and that it has not been updated in such a way as to correspond more closely to the economic and social context of the current European Union. In my opinion, action must be taken as soon as possible in such a way as to harmonise the different ways in which parental leave is implemented between the various Member States, always with due regard for gender equality and equity. As this report is along these lines, I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this report is to assess the implementation of the legislation on parental leave by the different Member States and to draw the necessary political conclusions. However, owing to the fact that in the Member States this type of leave overlaps with others, the latter must also be studied; the political conclusions relating to parental leave are inextricably linked to those that must be drawn on maternity and paternity leave.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour paternity rights and leave, but we cannot support calls for more EU legislation and interference on this subject. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide the terms of parental leave, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels whose policies and laws are not accountable to the voters.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of work-life balance is indisputable. Much progress has been made in this area, notably by guaranteeing a set of rights for European mothers. However, there is an increasing need to ensure some level of protection for paternal parents, both as protection of family life and in the broader context of promoting gender equality. Portugal is at this level an exemplary Member State ensuring protection for both. However, many Member States remain where this is not the case. It is clear that there are still shortcomings that need to be corrected, in particular in the transposition of the applicable Directive. There are also many differences between the various Member States, but the increasing mobility of European citizens makes clear in itself the benefit of bringing the various legal regimes closer. Recognising that social benefits are a competence of the Member States, I believe that issues such as the remuneration of paternity leave or the defence of more simplified schemes, removing unnecessary barriers to these social rights, should be consensual points at European level.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I welcome the report's approach. Unfortunately, childcare and family work are not taken into account as an economic contribution throughout the EU. With the framework agreement, we will at least have uniform European minimum standards, which will allow us to ensure and support the return of mothers to the labour market with the aim of stable and adequate employment on equal terms.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour paternity rights and leave, but we cannot support calls for more EU legislation and interference on this subject. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide the terms of parental leave, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels whose policies and laws are not accountable to the voters.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Statistics show that only 10% of fathers take at least one day of leave; whereas, in contrast, 97% of women use the parental leave that is available for both parents. This shows how much specific measures to foster a new kind of organisation of work, through more flexible models, are sorely needed to bring the much needed cultural changes in our society. I favour the call on social partners to do their part to promote the solution whereby a significant part of the leave remains non-transferable to underline that both parents have to be treated in the same way in terms of rights to income and the duration of the parental leave. Gender discrepancy approximation at the workplace also demands fair redistribution of paid and unpaid work as well as of work, family and care responsibilities, and we legislators need to acknowledge that. The report is a step in the right direction in an attempt to reach the 75% employment rate target set in the Europe 2020 strategy being achieved for women (it currently stands at 63.5%) by 2020; however, there is a need for proactive policies designed to help women enter and stay in the job market.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – Although not absolutely, I agree with the basic points of this report. Firstly, the reporting of the gender gap in the use of parental leave, for which it is necessary to reduce the current flexibility, as it promotes the reproduction at the domestic level of the patriarchal division of care tasks. Secondly, support for an ambitious maternity directive (after the Commission withdrew, ignoring Parliament's vote, its previous proposal) and harmonisation ensuring minimum paternity leave. Finally, the requirement for effective implementation by Member States of European legislation and the full participation of the social partners throughout the process. That's why I voted for it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy's goal of an employment rate of 75% and reducing gender discrimination in the workplace are two priorities for the European political agenda as well as for the lives of EU citizens. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that promoting equal participation between the sexes in the labour market and the right to take parental leave is not only a right to be guaranteed to citizens, but also a duty on the part of the EU institutions, given a fall in the birth rate in many Member States and disadvantaged conditions for women who want to exercise, at the same time, their right to work and maternity. I support, therefore, the application of Directive 2010/18/EU on parental leave by The Member States, in full compliance with the existing legislation on collective bargaining between the social partners, with the hope that the differences between the national provisions for the transposition of the directive and between the same definitions of the various types of leave can gradually settle in order to guarantee parents equal rights relating to the family throughout the EU, first and most of all the right to reconcile work and family life.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past few decades, the European Union has adopted two legislations on family leave: maternity leave and parental leave. These acts no longer correspond to the economic and social context of the Union. The target of a 75% employment rate set out in the Europe 2020 strategy has already been met for men, but is unlikely to be achieved for women (currently 63.5%) by 2020 without measures to support women's participation in the labour market. I voted for equity in the division of family tasks between women and men.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The implementation report prepared by the S&D Group aims to assess the implementation by Member States of EU legislation on parental leave. The author tried to present the current state of play in all Member States. It is clear that the S&D Group has used this report to set out its ambitious policy priorities for legislation on maternity leave and paternity leave at EU level.  A number of amendments have been tabled to make the text more fact-based. These amendments addressed issues such as subsidiarity, competences, better regulation and the EU's role as an intermediary in exchanges between Member States. There have been references to excessive implementation, a note that social benefits fall within the competence of the Member States, and a call on the Commission to take into account non-legislative initiatives and the importance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.  Unfortunately, the final text contains two obvious limits for the ECR Group and for me, including a call for an EU directive on minimum paternity leave and an ambitious EU proposal on maternity leave. With this in mind, I voted against.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the provision that social and employment legislation is firmly a national competency. The UK itself has recently introduced a generous paternity leave arrangement and such matters should be dealt with at the national level.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the directive on the implementation of the framework agreement on parental leave. It aims to strike a balance between parental and professional life in the European Union. To do this, the rapporteur proposes the extension of paternity leave to two weeks in all Member States, and the flexible use of parental leave, granting this right to both parents under the same conditions. Given that French legislation already allows for 11 days of parental leave, I supported this report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. There is now a great deal of asymmetry in the implementation of parental leave. Fees vary from state to state depending on the sector of employment - public or private - and the type of contract. And many EU Member States still do not offer the possibility of paternity leave. Ensuring a minimum base of European rules and harmonising these rules at European level would allow for greater equity and a better balance between the professional and private lives of men and women in the Union.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Arena report on the revised framework agreement on parental leave because it is important to find a better work-life balance for all parents and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market after the birth of the child. It is indeed necessary that common rules on minimum parental leave be adopted at EU level. I therefore supported this report to make parental leave accessible to all workers, regardless of the types of employment contracts. Further, it seems to me that encouraging fathers to take parental leave is a way of strengthening the principle established in European legislation and defended by the EPP Group of Gender Equality in Employment, and of avoiding discrimination against women in the labour market.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 As far as the report is concerned, it is an interesting fact that there are fewer than 100 000 men across the EU who would take the leave they could. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity-parental leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months, the father can choose to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. It is also necessary to think about a new model of work organisation, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, and is more suitable than the current less successful models. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities.  I also think it is important to point out that, in addition to the minimum expectations of parental leave, I do not see the potential for edification at EU level, as the labour market opportunities, family models, traditions of work culture, etc. in some Member States are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. On the basis of experience, I believe that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating, persuading employers, promoting more modern new working time models, promoting good practices that are more adapted to today's lifestyle requirements and the needs of families, while at the same time showing employers that they would not be bad for the use of parents with children, but that they are acting in a family-friendly way that benefits them in a way that is particularly good for them. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report in line with the People's Party.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is clear that in Europe, despite the initiatives that have been taken in favour of parental leave, a great disparity persists in terms of conditions of access to parental leave and financial compensation. I believe that, in order to rebalance the situation, the issue of leave pay is essential, especially for parents with low incomes. I believe that everyone, regardless of gender, should be guaranteed the right to parental leave, regardless of the sector of employment or the type of employment contract under which fathers and mothers are employed. I also encourage the Commission to carry out a study on the state of application of the directive in the Member States and to propose measures to encourage fathers to make greater use of parental leave and to encourage them to better balance their private and professional lives, in the best interests of their children.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I appreciate the attention paid by both the European Parliament and the rapporteur to the topic of parental leave and the uneasring of work and personal life. I consider initiatives to promote the well-being of working life with family responsibilities and to promote return to work to be very important. However, I prefer non-legislative initiatives, positive motivation and the removal of obstacles. The European Union should maintain the principle of subsidiarity on this issue. I see no reason to treat european legislation on topics such as the use of parental leave by men or their contribution to the performance of household chores. I am also not entirely convinced that the extension of the minimum length of parental leave follows current trends and is in line with the objective of simplifying the return to work. For these reasons, I could not support this proposal and abstained.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report related to the framework agreement on parental leave. This report aims to assess the implementation of EU legislation on parental leave by Member States. While the rapporteur seeks to outline the state of affairs in all Member States, it is clear that the S&D Group is using this implementation report as an opportunity to outline its ambitious policy priorities with regard to maternity leave and paternity legislation at EU level.  My position, as well as my colleagues, is that motherhood must be determined not by EU legislation but by national legislation.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I have to vote against this report even though it has many positive points, as the EMPL Committee, using the Trojan horse method, is trying to pass same-sex couples as a family model. I am in favour of the traditional family in which responsibilities will be shared equally.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 As far as the report is concerned, it is an interesting fact that there are fewer than 100 000 men across the EU who would take the leave they could. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity-parental leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months, the father can choose to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. It is also necessary to think about a new model of work organisation, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, and is more suitable than the current less successful models. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities. I also think it is important to point out that, in addition to the minimum expectations of parental leave, I do not see the potential for edification at EU level, as the labour market opportunities, family models, traditions of work culture, etc. in some Member States are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. On the basis of experience, I believe that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating, persuading employers, promoting more modern new working time models, promoting good practices that are more adapted to today's lifestyle requirements and the needs of families, while at the same time showing employers that they would not be bad for the use of parents with children, but that they are acting in a family-friendly way that benefits them in a way that is particularly good for them. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report in line with the People's Party.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. The right to parental leave should be guaranteed to all without discrimination, regardless of gender, regardless of the sector of employment, be it public or private, and the type of employment contract of fathers and mothers. The aim of this resolution is to renew the call on the Member States to remedy the imbalances that still remain in the application of Directive 96/34/EC, in particular with regard to the maximum duration, the legal configuration, pay systems and gender imbalances in the use of parental leave. As Europe ages, social policies are increasingly needed to accompany families on their parenting paths, to look to a genuine reconciliation of private and professional life, for example by promoting teleworking and smart-working, and childcare services, with particular attention to poorer families at risk of social exclusion. I voted in favour.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. As Directive 2011/36/EU states, trafficking in human beings is a serious crime, often committed within the framework of organised crime, which constitutes a serious violation of human rights and is explicitly prohibited by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This report seeks to respond to this phenomenon from a multidisciplinary perspective, not only repressive-penal but also by taking a set of procedural and preventive measures The report represents an opportunity to assess the measures taken in the implementation of this Directive, focuses on the gender dimensions of trafficking in human beings and identifies possible deficiencies and other measures necessary to improve their effectiveness. In this regard, the Directive was to be incorporated into the national legislation of the Member States before 6 April 2013 and 27 Member States have done so, although the Commission has not yet reported on the measures taken by the Member States to comply with the Directive. In conclusion it is a positive report that deals with an issue on which the EU must be very committed

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Fathers and mothers do not enjoy the same form of parental leave, which harms families and the situation of women in particular, who often end up giving up their career prospects for their children. There is a directive in the EU to counter this trend, but the results of its implementation have been mixed. In the EU, workers are entitled to parental leave when a child is born or adopted. However, in Europe, access to and this leave, and its remuneration, is determined in accordance with national legislation, which varies significantly between Member States. I agree that the remuneration of parental leave is essential to ensure that men use it because it allows for a better balance of the various spheres of life between men and women, ending discrimination at work for women.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. European legislation on family leave is now obsolete and requires legislative action to adapt it to the changed economic and social environment. We therefore call on the European Commission to submit an appropriate proposal to Parliament as soon as possible, which will be able to respond to the demographic, economic and gender equality challenges of the Union.  The resolution voted on today by Parliament contains positions that we can support.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: we believe that the economic difficulties, which lead to unemployment and precariousness, faced by European citizens are not linked and should not be put in competition with intra-family life.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report lists a number of concerns and draws a number of policy conclusions, including but not limited to the following: - Parental leave legislation should be revised to improve points on duration, payment, transfer and field of application; - The right of women to combine employment with rights and the right to motherhood without being penalised for it should be guaranteed. It refers to the pressure of employers on women in job interviews; - The fundamental role of labour rights, safety at work, the defence of collective agreements and the promotion of family-friendly working environments; - Increasing the age of the child for whom parental leave may be used; - Ensure financial compensation for parental leave in order to reach a level that would act as an incentive. This is not a perfect report, far from it. It's insufficient. In particular as regards the absence of a reference to 100% pay, the lack of emphasis on increasing wages and labour rights as a means of promoting the right to motherhood and happy childhood in a context of gender equality, among other aspects. However, it is considered to be a positive document. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The rules on parental leave at European level are governed by a directive that was formally amended in 2010. However, the foundations of this legislation date back up to two decades, until 1996. This is not a modern legislative standard that reflects the current economic or social conditions in the European Union and its Member States. The promotion of maternity, but also the subsequent deepening of childcare, which allows for properly set parental leave, require improvements in standards, including a higher financial assessment during this type of family leave.
