It is precisely the lack of financial support related to parental leave that is one of the reasons why there has been a long-term low interest on the part of fathers in its use. Change in this area would lead to a better and more equal application of women in the labour market. This would also demonstrably bring positives in terms of the level of economic development in individual countries. It would also contribute to achieving the 75% employment rate target in the European Union set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. In the case of men, this méta has already been fulfilled, but unfortunately women are still a long way from it. At the same time, the definition of paternity leave must also be addressed in terms of promoting demographic growth. Unfortunately, the current European legislation does not know it.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which, despite some favourable points, focuses too much on parental leave for 'same-sex parents' and calls for a greater communitarisation of certain policies in this regard.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am obliged to vote against this report even though it has many positive points, as the EMPL Committee, using the Trojan horse method, is trying to pass same-sex couples as a family model. I am in favour of the traditional family in which responsibilities are shared equally.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this initiative report as I believe that the provision of social and employment legislation is a Member State competence unless there is a clear and justified reason for EU level action. Though I agree with the exchange of best practice, I do not see the added value in the legislative proposals that were recommended in this report. As of April 2015 the UK has implemented new reforms for a shared parental leave scheme and allows working couples to share untaken maternity leave and pay. Having this legislation decided on a national level allowed for an approach that is tailored to the UK labour market.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that modernisation of different leaves and their coherence in the EU are necessary to ensure gender equality, increase participation of women in the labour market and ensure work-life balance. Fathers should be encouraged to take parental leave, which should be adequately paid with individual and partly non-transferable rights. I support the call for an ambitious proposal on maternity leave and a directive on at least two-week paternity leave. It is fundamental to open up the discussion on necessary work-life balance initiatives and on the disparity of implementation of individual leaves. We must come as soon as possible with coherent legislative as well as non-legislative proposals. Moreover, we must continue to push for the revision of maternity leave, and repeat the call for a Paternity Leave Directive. This should be a positive and solid ground for the broader work on labour market conditions for work-life balance following publication of the road-map.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Arena's report on parental leave. The European Union is facing a serious demographic challenge as the birth rate in most Member States is falling. In order to overcome the demographic challenge, a fair family policy for men and women needs to be promoted. These measures should improve the position of women in the labour market and the compatibility of family and private life, reduce the differences between men and women in terms of remuneration, pensions and lifelong earnings.  I welcome the fact that the Eu is addressing the problem of family-work compatibility, as international research shows that this aspect has a fundamental impact on the desire to have children. The decline in childbearing is a European problem, so our priority is to change this trend. My country, Hungary support system, provides special assistance to families with children. It therefore applies a complex system of family support instruments, which is more favourable to mothers than the current EU draft. It is important to talk as much as possible at European level about how we can improve the situation of women in the labour market and facilitate the reconciling of work and family life, but I welcome the fact that the report is in favour of regulating the minimum period of parental leave at Member State level.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it calls for improvements in terms of work-life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive, promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Mrs Arena on her important analysis work on the transposition of the Parental Leave Directive. It is essential to ensure that on such an important social issue the disparities between the measures transposing the directive as regards the scope, as is the case, for example, in the various sectors of employment, are eliminated. I agree that the right to parental leave must therefore be guaranteed to all without discrimination, regardless of gender, regardless of the area of employment and the type of employment contract of fathers and mothers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. As an MEP for the Family Party, I am clearly committed to greater maternity protection and a better work-life balance. In both cases, parental leave plays a crucial role. Nevertheless, I abstained from the final vote on the report on the 'framework agreement on parental leave'. On the one hand, the report fails to identify the very different systems of parental leave across Europe and to achieve a definition – but this is the basis for a meaningful debate on European minimum standards. On the other hand, in many cases, the report goes far beyond the mark and calls for detailed rules at EU level, which are clearly within national competence. It would also be a matter of concern to me to talk about the instrument of parental salary in the course of parental leave – as the best practice model for Europe.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The agreement sets out the EU's demographic and economic challenges in the field of employment and labour policy.  Legislation on parental leave, maternity leave and family leave should be revised and strengthened in terms of duration, remuneration, portability and scope.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because the directive, of which the report calls for the implementation, needs to be transposed. It is a much needed update to parental leave legislation which better reflects the position of women in today’s labour market. It also serves as a great example of how our membership of the EU provides much needed support for parents that would not be provided by the Conservative government. The antiquated view that bringing up children should be the sole responsibility of mothers is holding back progress for gender equality. In addition, full implementation of this directive would give hundreds of thousands of fathers the ability to spend quality time with their new children after birth. The Labour Party believes that everyone, regardless of the employment sector they work in, the type of contract they have, or the gender that they or their partner are, should be guaranteed the right to parental leave without discrimination.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This new agreement on parental leave is intended in principle to broaden the scope of parental leave in all Member States. I support this extension of parental leave. Nevertheless, this report stigmatizes the low use by fathers of parental leave, as it places itself in a gender equality perspective in the distribution of family tasks between men and women. This text is therefore too intrusive, insofar as parents must be able to freely make the arbitrations they wish in the distribution of parental leave. Finally, the desire for standardisation under this text runs counter to the competence of Member States with regard to social security benefit schemes. This jurisdiction must remain exclusive, in order to respect the sovereign rights of states and guarantee the freedom of individual choices. So I voted against this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. Mrs Arena's report could have been limited to few things: the need to further improve the reconciliation between private and professional life, but through non-legislative initiatives and the exchange of good practices; the assertion that social protection is the sole responsibility of states; the observation that most national legislation on parental leave goes beyond the minimum European requirements, which are therefore not determinative; attention to cases of children with disabilities. He could have avoided idle ideological considerations and contradictions: to give parents autonomy and full responsibility in their organisation (hopefully), but to want to limit this autonomy by binding requirements and non-transferability of rights, or to seek further harmonisation and strengthen the role of the Commission. But I mostly voted against this report because, basically, it exists only to promote a high rate of employment for women: 75% in 2020. First workers, incidentally moms for the reproduction of labor forces. I believe in the crucial role of women and the family in society, including in their specific and irreplaceable functions, and I support a policy that would give them complete freedom of choice.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report taking into account the practical situation of the application of the old framework and the application of Directive 2010/18/EU. It is necessary for Member States to act towards gender balance in the issue of parental leave. Eurostat shows us that only a derisory 2.7% are men who have taken parental leave, which shows a major imbalance in gender equality. With this revision of the Framework Agreement, Member States are invited to find appropriate policies for women's reinstatement after maternity leave, with the public sector being an important employer that can balance the overall situation. I agreed to the amendment on maternity leave allowance of 100% of the reference salary so as not to be demotivating for parents with higher training to want their children.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a much needed update to parental leave legislation. The full implementation of this directive would give hundreds of thousands of fathers the ability to spend quality time with their new children after birth. The Labour Party believes that everyone, regardless of the employment sector they work in, the type of contract they have, or the gender that they or their partner are, should be guaranteed the right to parental leave without discrimination.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The approved report is a progressive document, is an improvement over existing directives and aims to extend parental leave, promote a directive for paternity leave and also calls on States and the Commission to implement policies that promote more men's paternity leave. For us these measures are not sufficient because to achieve equality and co-responsibility between men and women in care, and that this does not adversely affect and discriminate in the labour market for women, we need to broaden the perspective and go to the root of the problem. We can only achieve equality if parental leave by birth or adoption is recognized as an individual right and therefore equal, non-transferable and paid at 100%. Despite the shortcomings and that from our perspective it is not a report of highs, it is an improvement in the face of the current situation and that is why we vote on it in favour.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Despite the rhetoric of European leaders in favour of 'fighting all forms of discrimination, including those relating to gender', it is clear that, in reality, we are far from the gender equality desired by the Socialists. That is why I voted in favour of my colleague Marie Arena's report: while only 2.7% of fathers take parental leave today in Europe, it is essential to combat this imbalance which contributes to an economic and social dependence on women and prevents their emancipation. A revision of the Parental Leave Directive is therefore essential and must include: strengthening incentives such as decent financial compensation for the duration of leave, retaining a significant share of parental leave as non-transferable, improving access to affordable childcare, or increasing the length of parental leave and the period during which it can be used. Finally, there is an urgent need to review the maternity leave directive and adopt a directive establishing a minimum of two weeks of parental leave, at the risk that Europe will disappoint its citizens again.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The promotion of individualisation of the right to leave and of positive action aiming at the promotion of the role of fathers is essential in helping to achieve gender balanced reconciliation of work and family life.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Fewer than 100 000 men across the EU take maternity leave. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. A new type of work organisation model should also be considered, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, which is more suitable than the less successful models of the present. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities. It is also important that, in addition to the minimum requirements for parental leave, edification at EU level is not possible, as the labour market opportunities, family models, traditions of work culture, etc. in each Member State are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. Experience has shown that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating and persuading employers, on the dissemination of more modern new working time models and good practices, which are better adapted to the requirements of today's way of life and to the needs of families.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report due to having no objections with its contents.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. For me, the concerns of mothers and fathers in the professional world are very important. However, Mrs Arena's report contains many points which are not the responsibility of the EU institutions. That is why I have decided to follow the group line and reject the Arena report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. 'Same-sex parents should have the same rights as everyone else across the EU. For us Moderates, it goes without saying that the forms of parental leave are something the Member States themselves decide on. It does not get any better because we coordinate parental leave in europe. That is why we have voted against the resolution on parental leave. We do not want, in substance, legislation on parental leave that is a compromise with the rest of Europe. If we decide on this in the EU, we run the risk of having a situation where Swedish parents' parental leave will be decided at European level and not in each country and in their own family. It is not politics that should govern the everyday lives of families and decide which parent should be at home. The needs are different in different families and that decision makes people the best way. It goes without saying that this should apply to all parent constellations.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As far as the report is concerned, it is an interesting fact that there are fewer than 100 000 men across the EU who would take the leave they could. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity-parental leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months, the father can choose to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. It is also necessary to think about a new model of work organisation, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, and is more suitable than the current less successful models. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities. I also think it is important to point out that, in addition to the minimum expectations of parental leave, I do not see the potential for edification at EU level, as the labour market opportunities, family models, traditions of work culture, etc. in some Member States are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. On the basis of experience, I believe that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating, persuading employers, promoting more modern new working time models, promoting good practices that are more adapted to today's lifestyle requirements and the needs of families, while at the same time showing employers that they would not be bad for the use of parents with children, but that they are acting in a family-friendly way that benefits them in a way that is particularly good for them. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report in line with the People's Party.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report. It is clear that Europe needs to work on policies regarding parental leave in order to enforce gender equality and increase the participation of women in the labour market. At the same time, fathers should also have the opportunity to take parental leave with the appropriate paid leave.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and her fellow colleagues abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour paternity rights and leave, but we cannot support calls for more EU legislation and interference on this subject. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide the terms of parental leave, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels whose policies and laws are not accountable to the voters

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 October 2013. On 23 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised Parental Leave Framework Agreement concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and ETUC and on the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC on the basis that the current legislation in the area concerned does not comply with the current economic and social climate of the Union. I support gender equality and the division of parenting because it is an important factor for improving work-life balance. Therefore, I believe that individualization of the right to leave and promotion of the role of fathers can contribute to improving the current situation, and I support this Report in addition.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I completely agree that maternity or parental leave is a fundamental right and benefit for parents and children, and the matching of motherhood and working life is a subject worthy of our attention, I believe that there is no need to legisle these issues at European Union level. I think that, given the different historical experience, the different approaches to family and the different traditions in the countries of Europe, it is important to think about the principle of subsidiarity and the decision to leave it to the individual Member States on this issue. In order to harmonise the conditions of parental leave and to facilitate the reconciliation of working life with motherhood, the Union may call for non-legislative measures through other initiatives. However, such incentives should, in my opinion, be based on the principle of voluntary ness. For these reasons, I was unable to support the proposal and therefore abstained.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to make common EU rules on minimum parental leave better applied across the EU.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report seeks to create a European mandate for family policy behind better family planning to help children's development. This attempt goes beyond the EU's contractual competences. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is a much needed update to parental leave legislation. The full implementation of this Directive would give hundreds of thousands of fathers the ability to spend quality time with their new children after birth. The Labour Party believes that everyone, regardless of the employment sector they work in, the type of contract they have, or the gender that they or their partner are, should be guaranteed the right to parental leave without discrimination.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. For me, the concerns of mothers and fathers in the professional world are very important. However, Mrs Arena's report contains many points which are not the responsibility of the EU institutions. That is why I have decided to follow the group line and reject the Arena report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 As far as the report is concerned, it is an interesting fact that there are fewer than 100 000 men across the EU who would take the leave they could. Unfortunately, the reasons for this are not mentioned in the report. The Hungarian maternity-parental leave system is extremely generous, both parents can use it from the age of six months, the father can choose to stay at home with the child. However, this alone is not enough. It is also necessary to think about a new model of work organisation, which contributes more to the coordination of family and work, and is more suitable than the current, less successful models. This is particularly necessary for carers of children/family members with disabilities.  I also consider it important to point out that, in addition to the minimum expectations of parental leave, I do not see the potential for edification at EU level, as the labour market opportunities, family models, work culture traditions, etc. in some Member States are changing slowly and cannot be overridden in a short period of time. On the basis of experience, I believe that much greater emphasis should be placed on educating, persuading employers, promoting more modern new working time models, promoting good practices that are more adapted to today's lifestyle requirements and the needs of families, while at the same time showing employers that they would not be bad for the use of parents with children, but that they are acting in a family-friendly way that benefits them in particular. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report in line with the People's Party.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which aims to assess the implementation of legislation on parental leave and to draw the appropriate legal and political conclusions. Given the economic and social scene currently being erased in Europe, it is necessary to update this legislation in order to respond both to these challenges and to the effort to balance work and private life. Equal access to the labour market goes through a better division of responsibilities between men and women and contributes to economic recovery

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written. \u2012 This report was very easy to support. Maternity and paternity leave and parental leave have long been the subject of discussion in the European Union. In order to ensure a better balance between work and family life, we need a balanced family policy. Even the employment target under the Europe 2020 strategy will never be realised unless parents are better cared for! Four months' maternity leave is simply too short. It is proven that it is better for the child's development that the child can stay longer with his or her parents. It is also possible to consider whether equality is achieved in voluntary paternity leave. Even in Member States where paternity leave has been possible for a long time, there may not be any positive results. Only around 2.7% of those who take parental leave are men, and this figure is not much higher in my own country, where the potential parental leave for fathers has been around for a long time. So should we rethink this model? Every child and parent is happier when the relationship is in order. Moreover, having a child must not be a disadvantage in a woman's life, and it is not fair that women should be punished for having children in employment. In many cases, pressure can even be exerted not to remain on parental leave. Not to mention ying about future plans in job interviews. It should possibly also be possible to share the burden of parenthood among older employers. I think it is time to bring Europe in a truly more equal direction!

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, Parliament has assessed the implementation of the legislation on parental leave by the various Member States. Unfortunately, we have noted that there are still disparities between transposition measures as regards the scope, which leads to more or less worker-friendly schemes. What we are calling for is uniform implementation of the directive, both in the public and private sectors, and for the right to parental leave to be guaranteed to both parents, without discrimination.  In this regard, we call on the Commission to present a proposal for a revision of the directive which is truly ambitious and which will make it possible to improve the reconciliation of family and professional life. We also call for a European directive on paternity leave covering at least two weeks.  There are situations where it is necessary to extend the period of parental leave, especially in the case of parents with children with disabilities or long-term illnesses. Our request goes in this direction, together with the proposal to raise the age of the child for whom leave is possible. Finally, we call for family policies to facilitate a smooth and gradual return to work.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the committee's proposal on the framework agreement on parental leave. These rules, which no longer respect the modern economy, now require a review and promotion of a single purpose, as they have been drafted with different objectives in different contexts. The aim of the report is, in fact, to assess the application by Member States of the legislation on parental leave, taking into account maternity and paternity leave. The report also takes into account gender equality, the division of family tasks between men and women, and greater participation by women in the labour market. Only by promoting this equality, within effective policies in support of the family, will we be able to honour and respect the fundamental principles of the Union.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the framework agreement on parental leave, but there are a number of positive points. I am in favour of the possibility of broadening the scope of parental leave (duration, age), special attention for children with disabilities and adequate remuneration. The rapporteur says that social security benefits are exclusively the responsibility of the Member States, which is a good thing. Moreover, he is clear-headed in noting a wide disparity in the EU on the issue of leave. However, his observations, however correct, are misguided by a desire for uniformity. This is a further attack on the sovereignty of the Member States as well as on the principle of subsidiarity. There must also be a desire to interfere in the family life of the French and other Europeans.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The text focuses on the supervision of parental leave. Under the pretext of equality and justice between genders, he pursues a policy of unhealthy standardization of parental leave, erasing the fundamental differences that distinguish men from women. However, this policy of egalitarianism runs counter to the family model that I defend. In addition, the EU allows itself to interfere in the couple's lives of European citizens, depriving them of all freedom. If only proposals to support a birth policy and measures to support households with a child with a disability were retained, the text would be more valuable. For now, I can only oppose it by voting against it.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Although not absolutely, I agree with the basics of this report. Firstly, the reporting of the gender gap in the use of parental leave, for which it is necessary to reduce the current flexibility, as it promotes the reproduction at the domestic level of the patriarchal division of care tasks. Secondly, support for an ambitious maternity directive (after the Commission withdrew, ignoring Parliament's vote, its previous proposal) and harmonisation ensuring minimum paternity leave. Finally, the requirement for effective implementation by Member States of European legislation and the full participation of the social partners throughout the process. That's why I voted for it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 The report relates to the application of the Directive on the implementation of the revised Parental Leave Framework Agreement. It is important that family policy legislation improves women's position on the labour market, coherence between private and professional life, thus positively affecting demographic processes. An integral approach to gender balance, removing stereotypical gender roles and sensitising the public about these rights can help address imbalances that exist between Member States in terms of parental leave. I supported this report, as the implementation of the Agreement can make a significant contribution to the EU economy, strengthening the role of women in the labour market and helping to achieve the Europe 2020 target of greater female employment.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The issue of an adequate solution to parental leave in the context of the interest in the wider involvement of women in the labour process is becoming increasingly important. Basic European legislation on maternity and parenting leave was adopted more than 20 years ago.  Today, they no longer meet current requirements, in particular economic and social development, demographic development and gender equality requirements. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to carry out an analysis of the fulfilment and impact of the current standards, which should form the basis for drawing up new proposals on maternity, parental and paternity leave in order to strengthen the role of parenthood.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of Council Directive 2010/18/EU, of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, SEEP and ETUC and repealing Directive 96/34/EC on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/5/2016 and because this report is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The aim of the report is to assess the implementation of parental leave legislation in the various Member States.  We oppose the desire for uniformity that emerges from this text, which aims to ensure gender equality and a fair balance in the distribution of family tasks between men and women, emphasizing the economic contribution that women's greater participation in the labour market would represent. We oppose this affront to the sovereignty of the Member States and to the disrespect of the principle of subsidiarity. We oppose the interference in the family life, even intimate, of European couples by the individualisation of parental leave and the non-transferability of a significant part of it. While we support the possibility of broadening the scope of parental leave, special attention for children with disabilities and adequate remuneration, we dispute that these measures hide a political will to achieve the objectives set out in Strategy 2020, i.e. a employment rate for women worth 75%. We object to economic difficulties upsetting the balance of intra-family life.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a report that deals with the enshrinion of the right to parental leave at EU level at least at least in the minimum length. It aims to introduce a system that would also encourage fathers to stay on parental leave with their children for some time without harming them at work and when returning to work. I personally support this proposal, but only in the form of minimum harmonisation. I believe that in the Czech Republic we have standards set at a very high level. I support a system that ensures at least minimum rights for parents and is most beneficial to children. At the same time, I am in support of a system that allows flexibility in which of the parents will stay on holiday, and I am also in a strong for the possibility of choosing from different alternatives to be enshrined. I supported the report in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 From time to time, statistics show that parental leave has positive effects on our economy and our families. The report explains that the gender gap still persists in the working world and costs Europe €370 billion a year, not to mention the effect in our homes where children of delicate age do not interact enough with their parents. We want to see more women and men working, not choosing whether to make each other work. We must protect the right of all parents to rest in order to spend more time with their children without risking their jobs. We must put an end to discrimination in every aspect of the workplace, such as interviewers asking women if they have or want children but not asking men the same questions, without mentioning the gender pay gap. The provision of social welfare benefits is a matter for the Member States, then the Commission and Parliament must support them by standardising regulations and stabilising situations. I therefore voted in favour of this report and I expect to continue to strengthen the values of European families and working women.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. For me, the concerns of mothers and fathers in the professional world are very important. However, Mrs Arena's report contains many points which are not the responsibility of the EU institutions. That is why I have decided to follow the group line and reject the Arena report.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. •u2012 Parental leave when a child is born or adopted is a positive step to ensure equality between women and men and also to contribute to one of the purposes we have set ourselves, which is to contribute to the growth of birth in the EU, which in recent years has dropped alarmingly. My support for the report on the implementation of the Directive regulating this area, so that in the EU there is a clearer and more coherent framework, reaching all countries, in order to promote these permits.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Regardless of the best length and amount of maternity or paternity leave, the report is an unacceptable interference in the social policy of the Member States. Nor do I agree with the call for compensation for 'same-sex parents so that they can achieve a balance between family and working life'. Let's respect that a child has a father and a mother, but to talk about "same-sex parents" is playing God. Parents can only be a man and a woman.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The Parental Leave Directive (96/34/EU) was originally adopted in 1996 and adapted in 2010 (2010/18/EU) following a new agreement between Member States. There is, however, a need to modernise it since in principle it does not correspond to the present social and economic reality, but there are also divergent practices from the Member States, which is uneven in its implementation.  Although there has been no initiative on the part of the Commission to evaluate the Directive on parental leave, the Eurofound Executive Agency, together with researchers and experts from the Member States, have prepared an evaluation report. The study concluded that there is a wrong combination in the use of parental leave in relation to the other two types of leave that exist, namely maternity leave and paternity leave. The limited use of parental leave by fathers was also found, since there is a reduced remuneration during it. For these reasons, I would like to vote in favour of this report since I agree that the directive should be revised in terms of its duration, remuneration and scope. At the same time, I agree that there should be a directive on paternity leave, which has not been done so far.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP resolution on parental leave, as well as calls for not only mothers but also parents to take parental leave. Indeed, it is important to ensure that both parents have equal opportunities both in terms of benefits and the duration of parental leave. The resolution also calls for an extension of the period during which parental leave can be taken and the age of children whose care is available for this holiday. I also support the provision that parents with children with disabilities should take longer leave.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that looks at parental leave in the EU. Parental leave must be granted equally to all workers regardless of their employment type.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – This report calls on the Commission to put forward proposals to promote the balance between professional and family life. The current legislation on the engagement for family reasons is in need of change because it is no longer in line with the current social and economic context in which families organise their tasks. Parental leave has the advantage that women are no longer obliged to choose between children or careers. This leave will enable women to participate proactively in the labour market.  The idea that women take care of children and men take care of the economy is outdated. Men are no longer the sole breadwinner of the family and women get the prospect of better paid jobs. Yet only 1 percent of men effectively use paternity leave. If it is the aim of this report to divide family responsibilities more equally between men and women, then additional positive actions are needed to promote gender equality here too. In certain exceptional circumstances, it is also desirable, where children become seriously ill or are disabled, to extend or extend parental leave in order to allow a balance between the family situation and working life.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The current 1996 Parental Leave Directive provides at a minimum that all workers are entitled to four months of unpaid parental leave, including one month non-transferable (to the other parent). This report proposes to go further, particularly considering the persistent wage gap between women and men. Because in fact, men are better paid (up 16.2% on average), but it is often women who take this leave. The issue of leave pay is therefore paramount. The report defends, without elaborating, an "adequate and decent income that is incentive". More broadly, he advocates a better balance between work and private life. Above all, it proposes to increase the minimum period of leave to six months, to cover atypical contracts, such as the "zero-hours" contract popular with Mrs Merkel and Mr Cameron. It also proposes to establish and extend the age limit for the child to receive parental or care leave when the child is disabled. He asked for an easy takeover of the same position. Finally, he recalls that the Commission has not listened to Parliament's requests to improve maternity and paternity leave. I am voting for this request for upward social harmonization.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report intends, in the name of the disembodied principle of gender equality, to make paternal leave compulsory. The Europe 2020 targets must see the rate of women in work reach 75% in order to be achieved. This liberticidal and senseless framework agreement goes in this direction. Hypocrisy is total when the best interests of the child are proclaimed as a principle, while the child is moved to the third level. The central objective is very economic, and this is not the least of the paradoxes served: it poses a major occupational and economic difficulty if working men must systematically return home (six months) for each birth. In the end, this report appears to be anti-natalist. As a result I voted against this text

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – European Union legislation recognises two types of family holidays: maternity and parental leave. Each Member State of the Union has the issue of family leave regulated in its national legal systems differently, but the legislation of most of them distinguishes between maternity, paternity and parental leave. I would like to note that the legislation on family allowances should be updated to reflect the changing social and economic conditions of the Union. As the different types of family holidays overlap considerably in the Member States, political conclusions must therefore necessarily concern not only parental but also maternity and paternity leave. During the examination of the application of that legislation, shortcomings were not found as regards the exercise of parental leave by the Member States. However, differences in application methods have been identified, in particular when combining this holiday with two other types of family holidays. I believe that issues relating to its duration, remuneration, portability and scope of parental and maternity leave must be strengthened. I am also in favour of the introduction of legislation on paternity leave in the Union. In view of the above, the report has my support.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the agreement—framework on parental leave. I believe that the European Union faces a major demographic challenge, with declining birth rates in most Member States. The political debate should be held around joint action with the aim of strengthening the role of parents, promoting work-life balance. There should be a concern to achieve greater coordination, coherence and accessibility of licence schemes in the different Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent decades, two pieces of legislation have been adopted in the European Union on family leave. The Maternity Leave Directive was adopted in 1992 and the original Parental Leave Directive was adopted in 1996 and adjusted in 2010 after a new agreement was reached with the European social partners on the issue. The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs aims to assess the implementation of the parental leave legislation by the Member States and to draw the necessary political conclusions.  According to these conclusions: • The legislation on parental leave should be reviewed, confirming it in terms of duration, remuneration, transferability and scope; • The legislation on maternity leave should also be reviewed in line with recent European Parliament resolutions; • European legislation on paternity leave should also be adopted; • These laws should be developed in harmony, in particular on the basis of agreements between the European social partners. I supported the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The report's mission is to ensure gender equality and justice in the distribution of family tasks between men and women. In addition, the report stresses the economic contribution that women's greater participation in the labour market would bring. While some proposals are laudable, others are an interference in the free choice of families to organise their lives and Member States to legislate. Unfavorable vote.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Framework Agreement on parental leave as it provides a balanced approach towards a better work-life balance with a reduced administrative burden, thanks to the fair assessment provided by the social partners.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this Directive which aims to overcome the challenges of work-life balance by enabling the household to reconcile their personal and professional lives. It should also be stressed that mothers who have unfortunately had premature babies should have greater flexibility and longer parental leave in order to accompany their children on the spot and whenever necessary. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of the political debate also on a number of non-legislative initiatives, with a view to joint action with member states and civil society, in order to highlight the role of parents and promote work-life balance.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The strong references to the best interests of the child, to the enhancement of the role of parent, to social policies aimed at families, actually hide a dark political plan: on the contrary to this report, I consider that the economic difficulties, which lead to unemployment and precariousness, faced by European citizens, are not linked and should not be put into competition with domestic life.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to propose new guidelines on maternal and paternal leave, but also to revise the legislation on parental leave, particularly with regard to its duration, remuneration and portability. To the extent that there are now many disparities in the terms of parental leave, the adoption of a law that overhauls existing legislation is welcome.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Arena report and in favour of three points which I believe were essential and for which I had to remain faithful to French laws in this area. In France, fathers can benefit from paternity leave of 11 consecutive days (18 days for multiple births), within 4 months of the birth of the child, in addition to the 3 days of leave for birth. The Marriage for All Act of May 18, 2013 authorizes same-sex marriage. It has opened up new rights for marriage, adoption and inheritance. It allows the joint adoption of a child by both spouses or the adoption of the spouse's child. Parental authority is thus shared by both spouses, which gives them access to all the rights conferred on the parents, including parental leave. Finally, since January 2015, in order to reduce the professional penalties for mothers, in the case of a first child, the duration of parental leave is a maximum of 6 months for a single parent and 1 year in the case where both parents take leave.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We very much welcome the report on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. It is important to monitor and evaluate the different implementations of legislation in the different Member States. This report is also of further importance in that it puts forward proposals that improve and modernise existing legislation, including extending minimum leave from 4 to 6 months, raising the age of the child for whom leave can be offered, including measures such as individual rights and the non-transferability of part of the leave to improve dads' participation in parental leave. Finally, equally important is the direct request to the Commission to put forward as soon as possible a new and ambitious proposal on maternity leave and a proposal for a directive introducing at least 2 weeks of compulsory paternity leave.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the framework agreement on parental leave. The European Union needs directives and legislation that take into account the current social situation and challenges. The aim is to support family formation, and a framework agreement that can provide parents with a sense of security would be an excellent tool to achieve this.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Over the past few decades, the European Union has introduced two pieces of legislation on family leave: maternity leave (introduced as a directive in 1992) and parental leave (introduced as a directive in 1996). Although these pieces of legislation were considered modern 20 years ago, they are no longer in line with the economic and social climate of the Union of today. I have voted for this report that will assess the implementation of the legislation on parental leave by the different Member States and to draw the necessary political conclusions.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament's report on the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The whole Union is facing a serious demographic problem, with birth rates falling in most Member States. Fair family policies for men and women could improve women's prospects in the labour market, improve work-life balance and reduce gender disparities in pay, pensions and incomes throughout life, and have a positive influence on the demographic process. A mixed model consisting of maternity, paternity and joint leave, i.e. parental leave, allows both parents to make proper joint decisions on how they manage their leave rights in the best interests of children and taking into account the characteristics of their jobs. We encourage Member States to adapt their criteria for the design and eligibility of quality and inclusive education and care services for pre-school children in the face of increasingly diverse forms of work, thereby helping parents to meet their professional commitments or find employment, while maintaining a strong focus on the best interests of the child.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises the right of all employed EU citizens to four months unpaid parental leave. Moreover, the report sheds light on the implementation across EU Member States of the legislation on parental leave and in doing so finds that fathers are still not using parental leave to an extent that could positively affect and promote gender balance in the work sector and overall gender equality. I therefore support the report’s call for reviewing parental leave legislation in order to set up the right conditions for equal childcare responsibility in the EU.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the application of the Parental Leave Directive, which also indicates on some points possible directions for amendments to this legislation. I agree with the recommendation to consider extending the minimum length of parental leave from 4 to 6 months by ensuring better coordination and availability of leave systems in the Member States (maternity, paternity and parental) and calling for an EU directive on a minimum of two weeks of paternity leave. Improvements to existing legislation should be sought that emphasise the importance of childcare while facilitating the reconciliation of family and working life between the two parents.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at the vote, I would have opposed this report. The report also includes parental leave for same-sex couples, and I believe that this report only supports the gender mainstream, rather than thinking about more important approaches.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Studies show that fathers use very little parental leave. The main reason for this is the low benefits and its portability in many countries. However, it would also be important to create favourable conditions for the use of paternity leave and to improve provisions in the legislation on parental leave.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 Parental leave, introduced at European level a few years ago, is a fundamental right that lays down minimum requirements to facilitate the reconciliation of professional and family life. A right that promotes the participation of women in the world of work, encourages a fairer sharing of leave by both parents and increases opportunities for the most fragile families. I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Council directive reformulating the framework for parental leave and establishing a framework of more precise and harmonised rules at European level. An update of the previous directive, which was necessary, in a completely changed context, both socially and economically, on such a sensitive issue as parental leave. Finally, with the adoption of today's text, the European Union is making a serious commitment to promoting policies that really combat inequalities, including gender inequalities, and strengthen people's rights and towards the definition of measures that are fundamental to finding the right balance between professional and private life: one of the keys to our modern society.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. Parental leave not only contributes to gender equality and women's access to employment, but also allows both parents to meet their obligations towards their children. However, in recent years only 2.7% of fathers have used parental leave. In addition, the use of parental leave varies from country to country. I voted in favour of Mrs Maria Arena's report which promotes the modernisation and improvement of the framework agreement on parental leave. We call on the Commission to extend the minimum duration of parental leave from at least four to six months in order to improve the balance of family and working life. Parental leave should be an opportunity, not an obstacle.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The agreement between European capitalists and trade unions of the European employers' and sold-out trade unions (BUSINESS EUROPE – ETUC – SES), assessed in the report, is contrary to the needs of the working families, serves the strategy of reducing the price of labour force. The report's assessment that "the work of parents and the upbringing of children is a measurable contribution to the economy" reveals the EU's real interest in shielding the interests of monopolies. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece has been positive in its proposals to extend and guarantee parental leave to both parents. But it stresses that EU and government policy uses the construction of "reconciliation of work and family life" as a vehicle for cheap and rights-free women's work that multiplies capitalist profits. Eu and civil governments restrict entitlements, shrink benefits - such as maternity benefits - to cost less to state and employers. Highlighting the issue in the context of the demographic problem is linked to the capital's demand for cheap, technically adapted labour for its needs. Only production that works to meet modern popular needs rather than profit can combine equal female work with the protection of motherhood, the popular family, an achievement of socialism that we have known.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour paternity rights and leave, but we cannot support calls for more EU legislation and interference on this subject. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide the terms of parental leave, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels whose policies and laws are not accountable to the voters.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the legal framework for parental leave is complex and fragmented, the European Union refers to two key pieces of legislation: the 1992 Maternity Leave Directive and the initial Parental Leave Directive of 1996 and partly reformed in 2010. These instruments no longer respond to the socio-economic context of today's Europe and therefore need to be reviewed. I believe that this report, which concerns the assessment of the implementation of the legislation on parental leave by the Member States, is relevant for this purpose. I would like to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Children are, without doubt, the future of Europe. Hence I believe that every child born in the EU must have the chance to grow up with a caring parent and within a stimulating environment that teaches them the importance of the European values we hold. I vote for the new Framework Agreement on parental leave to enable parents to take care of their children without being hindered by their professional lives.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I find it devastating that only 2.7% of fathers in the EU benefit from parental leave, and I agree that we must encourage fathers to use this right more and thus become more involved in raising their children and make an equal share of family obligations, as children in their growing up, especially in their first years of life, need both parents equally - both mother and father, and it is necessary for both parents to ensure minimum conditions for the alignment of work and family life. Therefore, I support that parental leave be individual and at least in part non-transferable. But, unfortunately, in one of its works, this report goes beyond the framework set out in Council Directive 2010/18/EU and the framework agreement on parental leave reached by the social partners by impermissibly expanding and granting equal rights to mother and father to same-sex couples which are not mentioned by that Directive and framework agreement, which undermines both the principle of subsidiarity and encroaches on the family laws of the Member States which are not under the authority of the European Union. I also think it is of utmost importance to return the Maternity Leave Directive to ensure that all mothers in the EU have a minimum duration of maternity leave with adequate monetary compensation.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that parental leave is a crucial issue for our societies, it refers to work-life balance and to important issues related to gender equality and the economic contribution represented by the increased participation of women in the labour market. National legislation on parental leave is very complex and needs to be reviewed in order to meet the challenges of today's economic and social context. The Union has implemented legislation as a result of the agreement reached by the social partners, but in order for this legislation to be effective, it must be fully transposed by the Member States without the addition of additional administrative burdens that undermine its implementation. The Union must also call on the Member States to implement family-related social policies which provide for the application of all the benefits provided for in the directive, and which correct the gender imbalance in the use of parental leave. Particular attention should also be paid to pay schemes during the period of leave; This is also essential for low-income parents and single parents, so that they benefit from such leave on an equal footing with all other parents.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament, taking into account the Resolution of 9 June 2015 on the EU Strategy for Equality between Women and Men after 2015, stressed that the provisions necessary for the transposition of Directive 2013/62/EU differ by Member State, and considers that transposition should be fully in line with the legislation in force in the area of collective bargaining between the social partners. He emphasized that families with children and parents who decide to take a career break, in order to raise them, are not only faced with loss of income, but also with higher costs and very low valuation of their parental role. I welcome the Decision of the European Parliament, as the work done by parents within the framework of family and child-rearing is a measurable contribution to the economy and is also of great importance in the context of demographic change in Europe. As a whole, the European Union faces a major demographic challenge as birth rates in most Member States have declined. Family policies that are fair to men and women should improve women's position in the labour market and thus the coherence of private and professional life. Consequently, I stress the necessity of reducing gender gaps in salary, pension and earnings throughout my life, which will have a positive impact on demographic processes.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The document sins by a poor analysis of the effective causes of the decline in birth rates or the deepening of inequalities. Omit the inseparable relationship between the growing degradation of workers' living and working conditions, the destruction of public services and equipment and the neoliberal and austerity policies that the EU imposes. The report lists, however, some policy proposals that we are following: - the need to review legislation to improve points such as duration, payment, transfer and scope; - the recovery of the Maternity Leave Directive; - the defence that women should be given the right to combine work with rights and the right to motherhood without being penalised for it; - the importance of extending the scope of the right to parental leave; - the extension of the minimum duration of parental leave from four to at least six months. It should go further, in particular in the allocation of parental leave allowances, paid at 100 % of the reference remuneration, alongside the need to increase wages and labour rights as a way of promoting maternity rights. Overall it is a positive document that justifies the vote in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Union faces a major demographic challenge as birth rates in most Member States fall. On the other hand, the work done by parents within the family and the upbringing of children is also of great importance in the context of demographic change in Europe. The gender employment gap is causing major losses to European economies. By reduced excessive regulation in the Member States, regardless of gender, the right to parental leave should be guaranteed without discrimination, irrespective of the sector in which working fathers and mothers work or the type of contract they have. I supported the Arena's report, as it is the European Union that can focus Member States' attention on the need to act immediately and exchange best practices and provide assistance to those Members in need, in particular in the area of social rights affecting demographic stability and the future of Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 There are major differences within Member States with regard to the rules on parental leave. For example, public sector employees often have more protection than those in private companies, while in some Member States workers on fixed-term contracts are not entitled to parental leave. For this reason, common rules on parental leave should be promoted across the EU. The Directive introduces the framework agreement revised by the European social partners on 18 June 2009. It shall also apply to all workers irrespective of the type of employment contract and shall be granted for at least a period of four months. In my opinion, this is a step in the right direction and will help millions of young European families. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The implementation report prepared by the S&D Group aims to assess the implementation by Member States of EU legislation on parental leave. While the rapporteur has tried to present the current state of play in all Member States, it is clear that the S&D Group has used this report to set out its ambitious policy priorities with regard to legislation on maternity leave and paternity leave at EU level.  The ECR shadow rapporteur tabled a number of amendments in order to wash out some of the rapporteurs' proposals and to base the text more on facts. These amendments addressed issues such as subsidiarity, competences, better regulation and the EU's role in brokering exchanges between Member States. The ECR shadow rapporteur acted constructively to influence the content of the final compromise and, with the support of the PPE and ALDE Groups, adopted a number of ECR amendments, including references to excessive implementation, the fact that social benefits fall within the competence of the Member States and asking the Committee to take into account non-legislative initiatives and the importance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.  Unfortunately, the final text contains two obvious impassable limits, including a call for an EU directive on minimum paternity leave and an ambitious EU proposal on maternity leave. I was hereby unsued to support the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for this text on the application of the European directive of 8 March 2010 on parental leave. Parental leave is a right and it is important that common rules on minimum leave are applied in a harmonised way throughout the European Union.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on parental leave. There are currently disparities in the transposition of the EU parental leave directive in the Member States; In some Member States, for example, a worker will be less likely to be granted leave if employed on a fixed-term contract. There is also an imbalance between men and women: fathers use only marginally their rights to parental leave.  It is therefore necessary to implement measures to strengthen the taking of parental leave and to effectively promote a better balance between work and private life. In particular, fathers should be encouraged to make greater use of parental leave, which would help reduce discrimination against women in the labour market. Gender equality would also achieve the target of a 75% employment rate set in the Europe 2020 strategy.  Finally, I believe that the Commission should improve and strengthen the provisions on parental leave for parents of children with disabilities or serious or long-term disability-related illnesses.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. I would like to recall that the Framework Agreement on initial parental leave between social partner organisations, which later became the Council Directive, dates back to 1996 and was completely revised in 2010. The aim of this report was to assess its implementation, often quite diverse among Member States (duration, legal form, etc.). It also links motherhood and parenthood, as it often overlaps and presents a number of proposals for the improvement and modernisation of legislation. Some of the proposals are based on: gender equality when sharing family responsibilities and increasing the parent's participation rate in parental leave; increasing women's participation in the labour market (target of 75% in Europe 2020, currently 63.5%); promoting work-life balance; increasing the age of the child for which parental leave can be taken; improving coordination, coherence and accessibility with national leave systems, ensuring non-discrimination, including entry and return to the labour market here.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the application of the 2010/18/EU directive, which transposes the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded by the social partners.  First of all, on the evaluation of this directive on parental leave, I note that the differences between Member States are significant. Whether it is the maximum length of parental leave, the legal structure or the remuneration systems applicable during the leave period. I also regret the small proportion of fathers who use parental leave, since in 2010 they accounted for only 2.7% of all people who took such leave. That is, of course, not enough.  This report proposes several ways to fill the gaps in the current parental leave directive, such as the individualisation of public policy rights, the revision of financial compensation systems, etc. In addition to this assessment of the Parental Leave Directive, this report also addresses maternity leave and calls on the Commission to present an ambitious new proposal that will promote a better work-life balance, a claim I have been advocating from the beginning. So I can only rejoice.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 The right to parental leave is a crucial assistance that the state can provide for family development. I am convinced that the setting of sufficiently generous minimum standards at European Union level, such as a sufficient duration of at least half-year, the minimum duration of paid maternity leave with the possibility of extending it to good practices such as in Lithuania, where young mothers or fathers can take maternity leave of up to two or even three years; as well as the possibility of paternity leave, the right to other state aid would make a significant contribution to building a more sustainable and life-long Europe.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aimed to assess the implementation of parental/maternal leave legislation by the different Member States. Unfortunately, there are large differences in the application of parental leave by the different Member States. In order to address the enormous demographic challenges we face, the challenges of economic growth and the need to promote gender equality in the Union, this report warns of the need to correct these differences. This legislation shall be considered to be revised so that the points relating to the duration, remuneration, coherence, transferability and scope of allowances are strengthened. In general agreement with the principles proposed, I would remind you that this is a matter in which the principle of subsidiarity applies, and it is the responsibility of the Member States to define national policies relating to the family. Therefore, although I voted on the final report favourably, I would stress that many of the proposals in the initial proposal have been amended, and I have computed my vote with the Ppe voting list, with the exception of the granting of special leave to support premature babies - (proposal of) a measure I supported - and the extension of the period of parental leave (in which I abstained).

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the common rules on minimum parental leave to be better enforced. Indeed, in 2013, the EU adopted a directive on the application of the framework agreement on parental leave. The text calls on Member States to guarantee that working parents have the right to take parental leave, especially fathers. Today, only 10% of fathers take at least one day of parental leave. The aim here is to ask the European Commission to carry out a detailed analysis of the state of application of the directive in the Member States, but also to call for each parent, regardless of gender, to be guaranteed the right to parental leave.  It is essential to remember that the right to parental leave should not be conditioned by the nature of the employment contract either.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Arena report on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and CES and repealing Directive 96/34/EC. The European Union is facing a number of demographic challenges today. Therefore, the legislation on parental leave needs to be revised to reinforce aspects of duration, remuneration, transferability and scope (since childhood does not end at the age of eight). Maternity leave legislation should also be reviewed and European legislation on paternity leave should be adopted as a imperative.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of reviewing the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave. The shortcomings in implementation have been clearly identified: on the one hand, there is still no uniform implementation of the agreement in all countries. For example, the maximum duration varies and may even depend on the employment sector. There are also still large discrepancies in gender equality during parental leave in many Member States. In the report, we also call for more help for re-entry after parental leave, as well as for the Commission to monitor the Member States more carefully in general.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Although not absolutely, I agree with the basics of this report. Firstly, the reporting of the gender gap in the use of parental leave, for which it is necessary to reduce the current flexibility, as it promotes the reproduction at the domestic level of the patriarchal division of care tasks. Secondly, support for an ambitious maternity directive (after the Commission withdrew, ignoring Parliament's vote, its previous proposal) and harmonisation ensuring minimum paternity leave.
