Finally, the requirement for effective implementation by Member States of European legislation and the full participation of the social partners throughout the process. That's why I voted for it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because the directive, of which the report calls for the implementation, needs to be transposed. It is a much needed update to parental leave legislation which better reflects the position of women in today’s labour market. It also serves as a great example of how our membership of the EU provides much needed support for parents that the Tories would not otherwise grant. The antiquated view that bringing up children should be the sole responsibility of mothers is holding back progress for gender equality. Not only were the old rules taking women out of the labour market but they were not allowing men the chance to be fathers. The full implementation of this directive would give hundreds of thousands of fathers the ability to spend quality time with their new children after birth. I believe that everyone, regardless of the employment sector they work in, the type of contract they have, or the gender that they or their partner are, should be guaranteed the right to parental leave without discrimination.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ I am committed to families being encouraged in their parenting, enabling them to spend time away from work, especially when children are young. I agree that we need to promote and support more and better family-work balance. We also ought to recognise the overall value of informal work provided by parents at home and its benefits for a whole society. But the best way for these measures and regulations to be formed is by national governments and not by the EU. This report interferes strongly in the running of the institution that forms the foundation of our society, namely the family. It promotes so called ‘same-sex parenting couples’ - something that is a biological impossibility; insists that despite failed attempts to get men to do more housework by legislation being passed, the EU will continue to push forward with new proposals. That is unacceptable! How parents divide up the responsibilities in their family should be left just to themselves. Neither the states/governments nor any of the EU institutions have the right to meddle in a private sphere of citizens and dictate how people shall live their family life! I therefore voted against this proposal.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU as of 8 October 2013. On 23 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised Parental Leave Framework Agreement concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and ETUC and on the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC, as I believe that any working parent should be entitled to take four months of unpaid leave, regardless of the profession he or she is engaged in and the Member State in which he works. There are big differences in parental leave issues in EU Member States, but most people have one thing in common – public sector employees are more protected than those employed in the private sector. These differences should be reduced so that everyone has the opportunity to take parental leave under the same conditions. Based on the available data, it can be concluded that unpaid or low-paid family leave results in low usage rates and parental leave, if fully or partially non-transferable and adequately paid, is used more evenly by both parents, which contributes to reducing discrimination against women in the labour market.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Based on Eurostat findings and Eurofound research, we continue to note significant differences between men and women in maternity, paternity and parental leave, which shows clear gender discrimination in terms of childcare and women's participation in the labour market. I am particularly concerned that all the measures that have so far encouraged men to take equal responsibility for the family have not led to satisfactory results in many Member States. Although the original framework agreement/directive played an important role in helping working parents in Europe, I would like to thank the promoters for the report that has been presented, because I believe that this framework agreement will improve women's prospects in the labour market, improve work-life balance and reduce the gender gap in terms of wages, pensions and lifetime incomes. I also believe that the measures taken in the new framework agreement on parental leave will ensure a more balanced distribution of family responsibilities between men and women and encourage fathers to make more use of parental leave.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Union has adopted two legislative texts concerning family leave in recent decades, namely maternity and parental leave, which are relatively old and adopted on a different legal basis. The report sends a clear message to the European Commission and EU Member States to step up their efforts to further improve the conditions of parental leave. Workers and workers on parental leave must be entitled to adequate financial compensation and should be supported in returning to the labour market. Although special support is for paternity leave, it would make more sense if the rights to parental leave were non-transferable. I believe that the EU should develop a comprehensive package of measures on parental leave in the coming months, as regulated parental leave would contribute to balancing the work and lives of workers. The report pays particular attention to the link between parental leave and women's participation in the labour market, as well as paternity leave or lack of use. Such a report calls for an EU directive that would introduce mandatory two-week paternity leave. Although the report on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/ does not call for a revision of the Maternity Leave Directive, I believe that it represents a step in the right direction, which is why I supported it.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Today the European Parliament voted on the Arena report, which examines the implementation of the Parental Leave Directive by the various Member States. The report demonstrates the shortcomings and formulates recommendations, sending a clear message to the Commission and the Member States to speed up implementation and improve the EU framework around parental leave.  For example, the report calls for an EU directive on a minimum two weeks of paternity leave, measures to encourage fathers to take more parental leave, the non-discrimination against parents who return to work after leave, adequate financial compensation for parental leave and all in a broader context that should promote a better work-life balance for both parents. It is only a pity that the transfer of parental leave rights was no longer curtailed. As long as this remains possible, most of the concern falls inexorably on women. Nor is there any proposal to make a reworked proposal for maternity leave.  Nevertheless, I voted in favour of this report because it makes strong recommendations that are desperately needed to develop a more progressive society with a focus on a healthier work-life balance for all.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. For me, the concerns of mothers and fathers in the professional world are very important. However, Mrs Arena's report contains many points which are not the responsibility of the EU institutions. That is why I have decided to follow the group line and reject the Arena report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The reconciliation of family and professional life while maintaining the economic safety of the family is an important factor in the participation of parents in the upbringing of children. The Framework Agreement seeks and modernises the approach in ensuring an increase in the participation of fathers in parental leave, and takes into account the diversity of the development of the workforce and society, including the increasing diversity of family structures.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. 'The N-VA delegation believes that it is very important that we work towards (more) employment opportunities for women and gender equality and that we also look at the importance of the child. Although the report wishes to serve these objectives, it does not take the right approach. Indeed, a far-reaching European interference in the organisation of family life ignores the individuality of both The Member State and the family. More specifically, n-VA cannot, for example, support an ambitious European directive on maternity leave. However, Member States should consider ways of facilitating the combination of professional, family and private life. N-VA abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Parental leave has a positive and long-term impact on the development of the child, and the work that parents do within the family and child rearing is an essential contribution to the economy and is of great importance in terms of demographic change in Europe. Furthermore, the fact is that unpaid or low-paid family leave results in low rates of leave use and that fathers make little use of their right to parental leave. Parental leave that is wholly or partially non-transferable and adequately paid is equally used by both parents, which contributes to reducing discrimination against women in the labour market. Such leave therefore has a positive impact on achieving the 75% employment target set out in the Europe 2020 strategy for women. In order to achieve this objective, more proactive policies are needed to help women access and maintain the labour market, especially when they return to the labour market as mothers in order to achieve stable and decent employment.  I support this report because I believe that the provision of social security is the responsibility of the Member States, but also that the coherence, coherence and accessibility of the leave system in the Member States (maternity, paternity and parental leave) should be increased, as this increases the rate of leave use and its effectiveness in general.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the application of the Council Directive of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded between BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and the ETUC and repealing Directive 96/34/EC. The transposition of the provisions adopted in various forms in the Member States must be carried out in full respect of current legislation in the field of collective bargaining between the social partners.  As the Commission has withdrawn its proposal to amend the Maternity Leave Directive, I support the call to re-establish, while respecting the principle of subisdianess, an ambitious proposal that will effectively allow for a better work-life balance.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report as it contains very positive elements regarding the extension of parental leave.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses its opinion on the directive implementing the framework agreement on parental leave, in particular by applying this instrument a minimum duration (four months) to be applied to all workers, independent of the types of contract. In the complex consideration of the many amendments tabled, I, together with my group, voted in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The approved report is a progressive document, is an improvement over existing directives and aims to extend parental leave, promote a directive for paternity leave and also calls on States and the Commission to implement policies that promote more men's paternity leave. For us these measures are not sufficient because to achieve equality and co-responsibility between men and women in care, and that this does not adversely affect and discriminate in the labour market for women, we need to broaden the perspective and go to the root of the problem. We can only achieve equality if parental leave by birth or adoption is recognized as an individual right and therefore equal, non-transferable and paid at 100%. Despite the shortcomings and that from our perspective it is not a report of highs, it is an improvement in the face of the current situation and that is why we vote on it in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report, using the Trojan horse method, attempts to pass as a family model the same-sex couples, to which we are vertically opposed.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the revised framework agreement on parental leave. First of all, I welcome the initiative of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. I agree with the idea expressed in the report that an integrated approach to gender equality in all future EU initiatives would lead to coherence and transparency and promote gender balance in the field of work-life balance. I approve of the report's call on the Member States and the Commission to ensure that family rights are equally accessible to both parents, thereby encouraging better coordination of family and professional life with the best interests of their children. I particularly welcome the idea of the Commission and the Member States ingenticing society's attention to rights and remedies relating to work-life balance. Furthermore, I support the point in the report in which it emphasises that better coordination, coherence and accessibility of the system of leave within Member States (maternity, paternity or parental leave) would increase the take-up rate. In this respect, a European directive on paternity leave of at least two weeks is indeed essential, but for my part I am in the support of full equality of rights.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the report on the implementation of the revised Framework Agreement on Parental Leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and the ETUC and the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 on the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC. Many researchers believe that fathers who take parental leave form a better relationship with their children and are more likely to play an active role in their children's lives even later. I myself once played the role of stay-at-home father, which is why I think it is important that parental leave is guaranteed equally for all parents. However, social security matters fall within the competence of the Member States, which is why I abstained from the vote on the report as a whole.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Although much progress has been made in Europe, women still have lower employment rates than men (63.5%) and a factor that contributes to this figure is women’s primary involvement in parenting and house care responsibilities. Although, at the European level all employees have the right to four months unpaid parental leave, most Member States comply with the minimum requirements for parental leave and fathers make use of very little of these rights. Furthermore, women that take parental leave are faced with discrimination upon their return to the labour market and are given less favourable working conditions/contracts.  These discrepancies are hard to understand, since the job performed by parents represents a measurable contribution to the economy and parental leaves have long-term benefits for children’s development. I support this Framework Agreement as I believe that family policies that are fair to both men and women will not only improve women’s prospects in the job market and reduce gender pay gaps, but also bring significant benefits to the economy of the European Union.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour of my colleague Marie Arena's report. It must be noted that more than ten years after the directive was transposed into the Member States, the imbalance between men and women persists in the use of parental leave. There is also great variability between Member States regarding the maximum length of parental leave, its legal structure and the remuneration systems applicable during the leave period. I believe that the issue of pay during leave is essential for low-income parents and lone parents to enjoy the same benefits as all other parents. However, the various arrangements taken to encourage fathers to use parental leave can be commended.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to abstain from voting on the report on the Framework Agreement on parental leave, which calls on the Member States to better implement the common rules on minimum parental. This is because I believe that decisions in this area should be left to Member States individually. While I fully agree that parental leave is a fundamental right and essential for mothers, fathers, children and society as a whole, the EU has no competence on the matter and conditions of parental leave should therefore be decided upon accordingly, at a national level.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 Parental leave must be an opportunity not an obstacle. Parents should be able to take parental leave to care for their child, and this is all the more important even in non-ordinary situations, when, for example, the child is suffering from serious illness and needs the care and assistance of their loved ones. The need to be present in the child's life cannot and must not affect professional life. In the EU, it is all the more necessary to legislate on maternity leave in order to modernise and improve parental leave through the creation of a work-life balance, this conciliation is essential for the society in which we live and can certainly encourage a change in the trend towards the population growth of our continent.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the Parental Leave Framework Agreement because the issue should be the responsibility of the Member States, not the European Union. The European Parliament should encourage Member States to exchange experiences and practices of parental leave with each other, but must not induce in areas which, according to subsidiarity and proportionality principles, should be decided by each Member State for itself. Also, I believe that every parent, both mother and father, must decide for themselves whether they want to take parental leave and for what time period. That is why I consider the setting of minimum paternity leave inappropriate and unnecessary. It remains up to the Member States to provide parents with adequate remuneration during their leave and to ensure a simpler return to the labour market.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ European Parliament resolution of 12 May 2016 on the application of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded between BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and ETUC and repealing Directive 96/34/EC. There are big differences within the EU in terms of parental leave, especially the conditions for which it belongs.  Greater scrutiny by the European Commission in the implementation of regulations with a focus on gender non-discrimination on the right to parental leave is needed. Member States must ensure that the right to parental leave is accessible to all, while encouraging fathers to also exercise this right.  A proposal was also made to extend unpaid parental leave from 4 months to six months.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The approved report is a progressive document, is an improvement over existing directives and aims to extend parental leave, promote a directive for paternity leave and also calls on States and the Commission to implement policies that promote more men's paternity leave. For us these measures are not sufficient because to achieve equality and co-responsibility between men and women in care, and that this does not adversely affect and discriminate in the labour market for women, we need to broaden the perspective and go to the root of the problem. We can only achieve equality if parental leave by birth or adoption is recognized as an individual right and therefore equal, non-transferable and paid at 100%. Despite the shortcomings and that from our perspective it is not a report of highs, it is an improvement in the face of the current situation and that is why we vote on it in favour.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the resolution. I believe that this area should be left to the competence of individual Member States that have different cultural traditions and social conditions for parental leave.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to assess the implementation of parental leave legislation in the various Member States. However, parental leave is intertwined with two other types of leave (maternity and paternity). The three leave holidays are therefore to be addressed together, in a more comprehensive scheme of reconciling private and professional life. The report's mission is to ensure gender equality and justice in the distribution of family tasks between men and women. In addition, the report stresses the economic contribution that women's greater participation in the labour market would bring. The feigned references to the best interests of the child, to the enhancement of the role of parent, to social policies aimed at families, actually hide a political will to achieve the objectives set by the 2020 strategy, i.e. an employment rate of 75% of women.  We believe, on the contrary of this report, that the economic difficulties, which lead to unemployment and precariousness, which European citizens face, are not linked and should not be put in competition with intra-family life. I am voting against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The whole Union is facing a serious demographic problem, with birth rates falling, so fair family policies for men and women should improve women's prospects in the labour market, improve work-life balance. Furthermore, gender disparities in remuneration, pensions and income must be reduced, thus having a positive influence on the demographic process. The target of a 75% employment rate set out in the Europe 2020 strategy has already been met for men, but is unlikely to be achieved for women (currently 63.5%) by 2020.  In addition to ensuring gender equality and women's access to the labour market, parental leave should enable parents to fulfil their responsibilities to their children. I believe that it is important to review the implementation of the legislation on parental leave and to draw conclusions of the necessary policies.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent decades, two pieces of legislation have been adopted in the European Union on family leave, which concerned maternity and parental leave. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on Directive 2010/18/EU implementing the revised framework agreement on parental leave. The approved report is a progressive document, is an improvement over existing directives and aims to extend parental leave, promote a directive for paternity leave and also calls on States and the Commission to implement policies that promote more men's paternity leave. For us these measures are not sufficient because to achieve equality and co-responsibility between men and women in care, and that this does not adversely affect and discriminate in the labour market for women, we need to broaden the perspective and go to the root of the problem. We can only achieve equality if parental leave by birth or adoption is recognized as an individual right and therefore equal, non-transferable and paid at 100%. Despite the shortcomings and that from our perspective it is not a report of highs, it is an improvement in the face of the current situation and that is why we vote on it in favour.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it sends a clear message to the Commission and Member States to step up their efforts to implement and further improve the EU framework regarding parental leave, in particular to ensure adequate financial compensation for parents taking up such leave and to support them in returning to and staying on the labour market.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I believe that the directive should be revised, including the adoption of measures to introduce adequate and incentive-based financial compensation for the loss of income of parents taking parental leave, in order to ensure the social and economic well-being of families and to encourage parents to take parental leave; I stress the importance of introducing a holistic approach, including maternity, paternity and parental leave, in any review of this directive.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The document notes the large differences in regulatory frameworks on parental leave in the European Union and calls for measures to be taken to achieve a minimum of two weeks of parental leave in all Member States. We are therefore talking about a document which aims to promote some European harmonisation in this area, stressing the need to be able to access parental leave without any discrimination eer work or gender. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it requires improvements in terms of work and personal life balance, promoting gender equality and women's participation in the labour market, protecting their labour rights and the development of their careers. The Report calls for improvements in the transposition of the EEMM of the Parental Leave Directive by promoting upward convergence of its applications. Conciliation measures are proposed, promoting a more equitable sharing of family responsibilities between men and women. It promotes the individualization of the right to parental leave by promoting the role of parents (increasing the non-transferable part between parents) and protecting the rights of same-sex couples. Finally, it is proposed to improve the rights of parents by asking for an increase in the duration of parental leave up to 6 months. The Commission and the social partners are requested to increase the age of the child at which parental leave can be applied for and to extend the duration of leave in the case of children with disabilities or long-term illnesses.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because it emphasises the right to parental leave for European citizens. Moreover, this report notes that fathers still do not use parental leave to the same extent as mothers. In the interests of gender balance in the workplace, I therefore support the call to review the relevant legislation and to create the right conditions to achieve a better balance in this area.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: Written. \u2012 The own-initiative report on the implementation of the Parental Leave Directive is important and encourages men to use parental leave more. In Finland, the situation is better than the EU average, although improvement is still needed. However, it is up to the Member States and the EU to take account of matters that fall within their decision-making power and to respect this difference. Different countries have different social security practices and societies differ in other ways. It is therefore important for each country to be able to decide for itself the most appropriate practices. For these reasons, I abstained on several points and, in the final vote, opposed the adoption of the report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report focuses on the application of the Parental Leave Directive, which is one of the elements of the EU's policies for gender equality. It contributes to a better balance between work and work life and a better sharing of family tasks and promotes a return to employment for those who decide to stop working to care for their young children. But while all Member States have adopted parental leave, there are significant disparities between states and a limited number of fathers benefiting from it: only 10% of them and taking them into account from the first day.  This leave remains poorly paid and not covered 100%. Given the gender pay gap, it is still more economically advantageous if the mother stops working. This directive needs to be revised to take these elements into account, particularly in relation to its remuneration.  As usual when it comes to women's rights, the National Front voted against it. I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The report lists some concerns and draws a number of political conclusions, many of them positive. It falls short of what we are advocating, particularly with regard to the absence of a reference to paying to be 100% of the salary, to the increase in wages and labour rights as a way of promoting the rights to motherhood and a happy childhood, in a context of gender equality, the extension of compulsory time for mothers and fathers and total transferability in the remaining period. However, in view of the foregoing, it is considered to be a positive document and deserves the vote in favour.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the framework agreement on parental leave. The report proposes gender equality in sharing family responsibilities, as 97% of women take the parental leave available to both parents. In addition, it is proposed to extend the minimum period of parental leave from 4 to 6 months and to increase the minimum age of the child for whom parental leave may be taken. Finally, the report proposes improving coordination, coherence and accessibility to parental leave in the various Member States. I firmly believe that the modernisation of parental leave in Europe is necessary to ensure gender equality and increase the participation of women in the world of work.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's report on the implementation of Council Directive 2010/18/EU of 8 March 2010 on the implementation of the revised framework agreement on parental leave concluded by BUSINESSEUROPE, UEAPME, CEEP and ETUC and the repeal of Directive 96/34/EC. Parliament agrees that it wants to re-educate people. Fathers should take more parental leave and be persuaded to do so with financial incentives. The EU wants to prevent parents from choosing freely, it wants to enforce that. Parliament wants to force a certain kind of behaviour. That is not the task of the state. People should be able to freely decide how to distribute their domestic tasks. Parental leave must therefore be fully transferable. The future of society depends on the families and the parents who have children and raise them. Parents need time for their children. Finally, it is not Brussels' job to regulate parental leave, but that of the Member States.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union has previously applied the Parental Leave Directive, but it has not been respected to the same extent in all EU Member States. This is so important that it generates a sense of discrimination against women in terms of their professional activity. This will contribute to increasing gender diversification in companies, which is sometimes a significant problem in the corporate environment. I believe that fathers should also be able to receive tacierzyński leave to a greater extent than they have been before.  The focus should be on successively changing the popular opinion on the economic role of men and on the social role of women. Action should also be taken to maintain a work-life balance for all workers. Moreover, this will certainly have a positive impact on improving the economic situation of the labour market itself. I hope that this kind of solution will also stop discrimination against women on wages. The system must take into account all the factors that cause the economic system to be shaken, and the question of access to parental leave is certainly one of them.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Across the EU, only 10% of men take parental leave, compared to 97% of women. That staggering disparity illustrates the scale of gender inequality that persists in our society. Not only does that disparity in parental leave cost the EU economy EUR 370 billion a year, it also perpetuates gender stereotypes, as well as the social, economic and political exclusion of women. The less women participate in the economy, the less visible they are, and that invisibility then leads to exclusion, objectification, and violence against women and girls. The EU has worked so far throughout its history to advance gender equality, and it must now take yet another step in breaking that cycle of injustice. The Commission must now propose new ambitious legislative and non-legislative initiatives to transform this abysmal situation for the better.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – Today's children are the future of Europe. However, the success of future generations depends largely on the education they will receive. It goes without saying that parents play a crucial role in this. I have therefore agreed to this resolution. It exposes pertinent problems, such as the current situation in which parental and maternity leave are so far treated as two stand-alone mechanisms, and the fact that the latter is in need of an urgent update. Specifically, I believe, for example, that the age of the child for which parental leave can be exercised should be higher. In addition, parents should have more flexibility in exercising their rights. I am thinking of using, for example, teleworking, working from home and working smartly. This need for flexibility applies particularly to women who could therefore continue to participate in the labour market more easily.  We need to provide sufficient incentives to involve men in the parenting process, but it is also important to leave the freedom of choice with parents together. However, when taking action, we must always bear in mind that we want to avoid unnecessary administrative burdens at all times.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs today voted in favour of this report because it would be a much-needed update to parental leave legislation, and better reflect the position of women in today’s labour market. The full implementation of this directive would give hundreds of thousands of fathers the ability to spend quality time with their new children after birth, while giving women more opportunity to go back to work if they need or want to.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – The non-legislative resolution on parental leave highlights, among other things, the wide differences in the rules on parental leave, in particular who has the right to choose it.  For example, public sector employees have more protection than those in private companies. Through the resolution, Parliament calls on the Commission to commission a study on the state of implementation of the directive in the Member States, and stresses that everyone must be guaranteed the right to parental leave without discrimination, regardless of the employment sector or the type of employment contract under which fathers and mothers are employed. I have reservations about some of the specific requirements in the report, because the EU should only determine the framework and detailed solutions should remain within the competence of the Member States. Account must be taken of the national legislation to date and also of the culture of uneasy nations. The EP also expects detailed rules on the granting of parental leave to parents of children with disabilities or serious illnesses. Certainly, in such cases, the Union should set minimum standards so that these families are not discriminated against and their fundamental right to respect for human dignity is not violated. I supported the report and welcomed the fact that the rapporteur, who is from the Socialist political group, appreciated the work done by mothers and fathers in childcare and care. I stress its value throughout its mandate, and it is the left-liberal political groups that have not recognise this work as a contribution to THE HDP.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the resolution on parental leave tabled by my colleague from the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats Maria Arena. The introduction of parental leave is an essential democratic achievement in support of parents and children. As such, it must not only be vigorously defended but also implemented. The S&D Group's vision in this respect is very ambitious: to ensure equal protection for both mothers and fathers, to increase the duration of leave to 6 months, to extend protections for other types of family care as well, and to ensure that parents do not discriminate in the workplace. The resolution we have voted on, the result of numerous compromises, incorporates most of these proposals and certainly paves the way for further implementation of the right to care for one's family. The S&D Group has once again managed to prove itself as the promoter of the battle for gender equality.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The agreement between European capitalists and trade unions of the European employers' and sold-out trade unions (BUSINESS EUROPE – ETUC – SES), assessed in the report, is contrary to the needs of the working families, serves the strategy of reducing the price of labour force. The report's assessment that "the work of parents and the upbringing of children is a measurable contribution to the economy" reveals the EU's real interest in shielding the interests of monopolies. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece has been positive in its proposals to extend and guarantee parental leave to both parents. But it stresses that EU and government policy uses the construction of "reconciliation of work and family life" as a vehicle for cheap and rights-free women's work that multiplies capitalist profits. Eu and civil governments restrict entitlements, shrink benefits - such as maternity benefits - to cost less to state and employers. Highlighting the issue in the context of the demographic problem is linked to the capital's demand for cheap, technically adapted labour for its needs. Only production that works to meet modern popular needs rather than profit can combine equal female work with the protection of motherhood, the popular family, an achievement of socialism that we have known.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report submitted. I am convinced that social security falls within the competence of the Member States. Policy discussions should also focus on non-legislative initiatives aimed at joint action with Member States and civil society to highlight the role of parents and promote work-life reconciliation. I believe that, in order to achieve a work-life balance balanced from a gender perspective, it is necessary to promote the individualisation of the right to leave and compensatory measures aimed at promoting the role of fathers. Member States should focus on removing barriers to returning to work after long parental leave in order to prevent citizens from being excluded from the labour market.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Arena report aimed to assess the implementation of European legislation on parental leave in individual Member States. I welcomed the fact that the report dealt to a large extent with the issue of the matching of work and family life, as this issue is controversial in many Member States. Also in Slovakia, the case of a Member of the National Council who was refused entry to the Chamber with a child resonates in the media at present. I have always held that, as far as possible, taking a child to work in certain situations should be possible, as the child feels best and most naturally in the presence of a parent. Among the other positives of the report, I particularly note that it dealt with paternity leave and the question of how to motivate fathers to take paternity leave. However, despite the positives, the report also contained negative aspects, including, in particular, calls for a revision of the Maternity Leave Directive or the introduction of uniform maternity leave for the whole of the European Union. Because of these facts, I have decided to abstain from the final vote.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the revised framework agreement on parental leave, which stresses that work-life balance is a fundamental right of the individual and must be taken into account when drafting labour legislation. Eurostat data in 2010 show that 3,518,600 people benefited from parental leave, of which only 94 800 (2.7 %) Men. According to eurofound's research, the gender gap in employment is causing serious losses for the European economy, which amounted to around EUR 370 billion in 2013.  The European Commission, together with the Member States, should take specific measures to organise new work organisation with more flexible models. These measures would help reduce discrimination against women and enable them to integrate into the labour market and stay there and to return to it without economic and social pressure.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, the essence of the phenomenon of trafficking in human beings is that they practically give and buy people as slaves and for the purpose of slave labour and, where appropriate, sexual slavery. Can it be a more important goal than preventing it and effectively exploring and trading it. Of course, the goal is very important, but it is very sad when you get to the point where you are already looking for such an important report, where the trick is, where the trap is. Well, I quickly found point 20, which states that 'it emphasises the importance of creating the possibility of legal and safe migration in order to prevent trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings'. Please, the phenomenon of violence against women last time, as such, was exploited for the purpose of saying that we should make legal mass migration in order to prevent and tackle violence against women. Now human trafficking is being exploited for this purpose. When are you going to stop lying and misrepresenting?

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – The fight against trafficking in human beings must be a priority for our society. It is, of course, incompatible with human dignity. I therefore welcome any proposal that seeks practical solutions to stop this modern-day slavery.  Unfortunately, I could not support Mrs Bearder's report. I consider the constant subsotion of the special status of LGBTI groups to be an abuse of a sensitive subject, such as trafficking in human beings, to push its agenda. Also, calls for the 'systematic recognition of the right of access to abortion' are a chronic overstep of the European Parliament's competences. While protecting life from conception to natural death is one of the fundamental pillars of European civilisation. When will representatives of LGBTI and pro-abortion groups understand that EU legislation should not be ideologically coloured just to assert its interests? And when will the legislators of this institution understand that they cannot arbitrarily violate the sovereignty of the Member States? – That is my question.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Trafficking in human beings in general is one of the most at lasting offences on our planet, and trafficking in human beings can only be compared to illicit arms movements or drug trafficking, but in this case the problem is, in principle, that no country or authority has complete data on trafficking in human beings, because an absolute majority of similar cases are simply concealed and in no way declared. Consequently, the identification of victims, assistance should be a matter of fundamental priority.  I will repeat this is a huge priority in my country, Latvia, because when we regained independence and when, as we said popularly, 'we drove west', several thousand people were victims of precisely these trafficking chains. I am, of course, in favour of this report, it is extremely important, it is in line with the real situation, especially in my country, Latvia.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – I voted for this report. We have a Europol study which tells us that in 2016, 70% of victims of trafficking in human beings and the majority of victims of sexual abuse are women from the European Union, mainly in Central and Eastern Europe, and the profit of trafficking is estimated at $150 billion.  And so far we have had strategies and action plans at national level, at European Union level, against trafficking in women. They did not work, because the traffic is still very high and the amounts of money won by traffickers increase.  I am pleased that this report provides for the appointment of special officers with special training who will work in countries with a high flow of migrants. I hope this will make a difference and reduce women's trafficking.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, human trafficking is the most despicable modern day act of criminality and we must do everything we can to try to prevent it. So this report is an opportunity to assess the measures taken, the implementation of the directive, focusing on the gender dimensions of victims of human trafficking and trying to identify further steps that may be taken to enhance the effectiveness of the Directive. Focusing on protection of human rights, trafficking from a gender perspective is a priority for the EPP and it is important that we not only work to prevent human trafficking, but protect victims of trafficking and work towards having better cooperation between Member States when tackling these human rights issues.  Ireland is committed to tackling and preventing human trafficking and this report tackles that issue in a largely positive way which we are happy to support and hopefully we can help to move towards reducing and eventually eliminating this despicable practice.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, unfortunately, the practice of trafficking in human beings is also flourishing in the European Union. We are not talking here and now, first and foremost, about human trafficking, which is often mentioned in the context of the migration crisis, but about the traditional forms that can be found in all Member States. Of course, there are states primarily regarded as source countries and target countries, but the fight against this form of illegal activity, the identification and protection of victims, must be strengthened in each Member State. Entire criminal gangs are built on trafficking in human beings, forcing European citizens to beg, provide sexual services or commit crimes. It is a significant figure, although unfortunately it is not surprising that 80% of the victims are women, and that many minors are in the net of traffickers. More effective action against trafficking in human beings is primarily the responsibility of individual national authorities, but by enhancing cooperation between police forces in EU Member States, these bodies can receive considerable help and encouragement.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour of clamping down on traffickers and criminal gangs who exploit the poor victims. However the EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking with the free movement of people across Europe. If we allow Turkey to join the EU or agree visa liberalisations this will only make trafficking much worse. UKIP cannot therefore support this report as it calls for more EU legislation and interference in criminal and immigration law. The only way we can deal a blow to the traffickers and save lives is to end the free movement of people and restore sensible and ethical border controls. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide criminal law, border controls and cooperation agreements with other countries, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on an own-initiative report dealing with the issue of trafficking and trafficking in human beings. Cross-border cooperation on this issue is urgent and important. I therefore voted in favour of the report. Since the report also deals with the issue of prostitution legislation, I would like to stress in this context that Swedish legislation is, in many respects, an example from which more countries should learn. On the other hand, this type of criminal justice issue should remain a national competence.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011\36\EU aimed to harmonise the rules on trafficking in human beings, paying particular attention to the protection and assistance of victims. To date, however, not only has Germany not yet transposed the directive, but the Commission has also not carried out those checks and reports on the actual implementation of the directive, which it had been involved in. The report analyses, very well, the gender dimension, the definition of traffic, the availability of data and statistics, proposing a series of initiatives aimed not only at improving the definition of 'trafficking', but above all at preventing and assisting victims. I voted in favour of this report, because condemning and eradicating this evil practice must be a top priority for all States.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The resolution adopted aims to assess the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, in particular from a gender perspective. It is well known that approximately 80% of the victims of these networks are women, so specific measures should be studied in this regard. In this regard, the resolution is positive as it shows that the humanitarian crisis with refugees has highlighted the inability of measures to prevent trafficking in human beings and therefore calls for improvements in registration and means, requests that persons engaged in necessity prostitution be included among victims of trafficking, that specific training of staff in contact with victims, the financing of agencies and reception centres working with victims, or the inclusion of forced marriages as a possible form of sexual exploitation should be improved. Finally, I consider it very positive to adopt an amendment requesting Member States that victims of trafficking be entitled to a residence permit. For all this, my vote has been favourable.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted against this text on the implementation of the 2011/36/EU Directive of 5 April 2011 on the prevention and fight against human trafficking and protection of victims from a gender perspective. The aim of this report is to combat trafficking in human beings and in particular against the various forms of exploitation of women: pimping, begging, clandestine domestic work, forced marriage, organ trade and illegal adoptions. Women and girls account for 80% of registered trafficking victims. While this objective is, of course, laudable, the final text is diverted from it. Indeed, the text proposes to regularise the victims of trafficking in the Member States where they reside: it is a question of creating safe channels of legal migration. Moreover, at the level of prostitution, the text calls for penalizing clients when it would seem more useful to effectively repress pimps who are not deterred by the too light sentences imposed on them. Finally, it should be noted that the penalties imposed on criminals are by no means a deterrent and are therefore not likely to impede the activity of these criminal networks.  For all these reasons, I objected to this report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because Member States do not adequately protect victims of human trafficking, particularly women and girls, and need to take more measures to prevent, help and support victims. We also call on Member States to ensure that police, judicial and medical staff and social workers receive adequate training so that they can identify vulnerable victims as soon as possible and provide them with the support they need. This includes access to housing, medical care, translation and legal advice, including compensation and recovery time of at least 30 days.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU of 5 April 2011 on the prevention and combating of trafficking in human beings and on the protection of its victims on the basis of the gender dimension, because it is imperative to identify and support victims and to impose stricter penalties on traffickers and those who exploit victims.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The laudable purpose of this report is diverted from its purpose. The regularization of all women who denounce a prostitution or begging network would be tantamount to opening up an important legal source of immigration. This will be even more true for humanitarian visas. Moreover, the penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks. With regard to clandestine work, "greater attention" is just requested to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies, but without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. I therefore voted against this report, which does not address the substance of a real problem.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ While I sympathise with the principle of this non-binding report, and am absolutely in favour of protecting the victims and clamping down on the traffickers, we cannot support more legislation and action by the EU. It is the EU which is facilitating this horrendous crime. It is the free movement of people, the Schengen Area and the open door immigration/asylum policy which is allowing trafficking to flourish once again. Free movement allows the perfect environment for trafficking to flourish, with no checks at the borders between countries and no criminal background checks.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, the result of a long work by my colleague Catherine Bearder, because human trafficking is a violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union as well as an attack on the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime that threatens the State, including the rule of law.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is a multi-million dollar form of modern slavery that carries out modern slavery every year. I support the recommendations, which stress that the deliberate exploitation of the victim of trafficking must be considered a crime. Prevention is essential in the fight against trafficking in human beings, and Member States must ensure that everything is done to prevent people from becoming victims in particular. Initiatives to address gender inequalities and empower women and girls could reduce their vulnerability to human trafficking. Education and empowerment programmes would help to achieve this. Under this Directive, Member States are required to ensure that the persons, departments or services responsible for investigating or prosecuting trafficking in human beings are properly trained. Training programmes should be further extended to include other relevant professionals, including police officers, judges, lawyers, medical and social workers directly exposed to victims and not only them.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report plans to step up the fight against human trafficking and in particular against the various forms of exploitation of women, which represent 80% of registered trafficking victims.  However, if the objective is laudable, the text proposes to regularise Roma and clandestine victims of trafficking in the Member States where they reside and stresses "the importance of creating safe channels of legal migration for women and children", thus exacerbating the terrible migration crisis facing our Old Continent.  Moreover, the penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks. It thus calls for penalizing the clients of prostitutes, while the penalties against pimps have no deterrent form in their current form.  I therefore voted against this report, the only concrete result of which is to create new channels of immigration, without solving the substance of the problem.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this report, which highlights the fact that 80% of the victims are women and that children account for about 16% of registered victims of human trafficking. Statistics also show that 70% of victims of human trafficking and 70% of suspected traffickers are EU nationals. The report stresses that asylum seekers, refugees and migrants are particularly vulnerable to trafficking and that special attention should be paid to women, children and other vulnerable groups. MEPs also call on the Commission and Member States to study the link between the increase in refugee arrivals and human trafficking. With regard to the gender perspective in the prevention of human trafficking, MEPs stress the need for an approach based on four key strategies: prevention, criminal prosecution, victim protection and multi-level partnership.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The report we adopted today fully addresses the aspects that need to be improved in view of the effective implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU. 80% of human trafficking victims are women, most of them deceived by false promises of employment and then raped, drugged, locked up, beaten, threatened and forced into prostitution. Cooperation between Europol, Eurojust and national and third-country authorities is essential, with a systematic exchange of information between Member States; Also, for the Commission to assess the Union Strategy for the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings, which ends in 2016. In addition, we still do not know the whereabouts of at least 10,000 unaccompanied minors who entered the European Union in 2015. It is not far-fetched to fear that many of them may have become victims of trafficking. All these aspects are rightly addressed in the report and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The migrant crisis facing Europe has highlighted an important issue, that of trafficking in human beings. Under this term lies a wide range of illegal activities ranging from sexual exploitation to forced labour, through organ exhalers, begging and forced marriage. These are human rights violations, crimes that affect the physical and psychological integrity of victims and involve women in 80% of cases. The Bearder report, which I have supported today, deals with the problem in a global way, starting with prevention, then through the identification and finally the assistance of victims. The text calls on the Member States to ensure that victims are also provided with legal assistance in civil proceedings and in immigration and asylum procedures, while training police, judicial and medical personnel to intervene in early identification and support for victims. An important step would be to guarantee victims residence permits and free access to the labour market within the Member States.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. Since the European Commission has not been able to meet certain deadlines set out in Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective, the Bearder report calls for its effective implementation. It details measures to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims in the light of the following aspects: gender dimension, definition of trafficking in human beings, data collection for effective statistical treatment, prevention, identification and assistance to victims. It has a special impact on gender treatment, because we must not forget that 80% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and minors. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is made up of fine principles, but misguides them for dogmatic purposes. Thus, if I am concerned like everyone else by trafficking in human beings in general, and in particular by the exploitation of women - who are often the first victims of precariousness - I regret that the text takes this pretext to encourage ever more immigration and ever more communitarianism. It is thus proposed by the rapporteur that any immigrant woman who is a victim of exploitation should be regularised, while at the same time nothing is really proposed to tackle pimping networks or pimps themselves. The rapporteur prefers to remain in the ideology, for which the only solution to these situations of great distress is through the massive and abusive funding of NGOs working on behalf of migrants. Apparently, in order to benefit from the compassion and protection of the European institutions it is better to be part of a minority that would have the status of "victims" with Brussels since the report stresses as much on migrants as on so-called LGBTI people, as if individuals could only be defined by this reduction in their membership in any community.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax sector, which I supported with my vote, is acceptable and does not present any particular critical issues.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights, a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organized crime that undermines the rule of law. The EU adopted in 2011 Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, which established a legal framework aimed at strengthening criminal actions against traffickers, improving the protection of victims of trafficking and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims.  In view of the Commission's failure to comply with its obligation to submit two assessment reports in April 2015, Parliament has prepared this report which stresses the urgent need to better identify victims, include a gender perspective in the prevention of trafficking in persons and in the identification, assistance and protection of victims of trafficking. It also recommends the application of harsher penalties for traffickers and those exploiting victims and greater cooperation across the EU. And it calls on the Commission for a new Strategy for the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the directive on preventing, combating and protecting victims of trafficking in human beings, taking into account the gender dimension. Trafficking in human beings, as stated in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, constitutes a violation of fundamental rights, it is also a violation of the victim's personal integrity and a serious organised crime that undermines the state and undermines the rule of law. This Directive aims to better protect victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims. It is generally recognised that this Directive is a comprehensive piece of legislation with a commendable approach to human rights and a clear emphasis on the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings. Although victims are people of different genders, age groups and different backgrounds, statistics clearly show that the majority (80%) of victims are women and girls. Gender is a determinant of vulnerability for both men and women. Women's vulnerability is linked to barriers to access to education, the gender pay gap, unequal access to decent work, gender-based violence, unemployment and underemployment, increasing poverty and migration among women, gender-related development strategies, strict migration laws and policies, as well as armed conflicts. These differences mean that women are less likely to perceive their experiences as exploitation, as they regard it as their role as guardians and service providers.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from a gender perspective, as it provides for better protection for victims of trafficking in human beings and reduces the chances of potential victims. Too little attention is paid to trade with certain vulnerable groups such as young people, the homeless, children and the disabled. This is even more current in the current refugee crisis and the alarming figures about missing children in Europe.  It is therefore necessary to improve the collection of data in order to identify more victims from these groups and to identify best practice in addressing their specific needs. In order to improve efforts to combat trafficking in human beings, the EU institutions must carefully assess the implementation of EU legislation in the Member States and, if necessary, take further legislative or other measures.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings. Most registered victims of human trafficking are women trafficked for sexual exploitation purposes. The Directive establishes a better legal framework to enable the prosecution of traffickers and the protection of their victims. Member States must take measures to reduce demand for trafficking in human beings, and one way is to charge those who buy services from traffickers.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that trafficking in human beings is a scourge that afflicts our time and must be eradicated as quickly as possible with cooperation between the Member States of the Union and between them and third countries of transit. It is a question of civilisation and the Union must be at the forefront of this fight against barbarism.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a dramatic phenomenon which is the cause of intolerable violations of fundamental human rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Directive 2011/36/EU allows, through measures such as the obligation on Member States to set up mechanisms for identifying and assisting victims, or through a regulatory framework that allows for faster and more efficient prosecution of traffickers, to combat an extremely complex and brutal phenomenon that affects thousands of people, mostly women, every year. However, in order for the instruments available to be even more effective, we need to increase the timeliness of the recognition of victims, and we must also ensure that they have effective access to the justice and services that EU legislation grants them. We also need to pay more attention to the flow of money in order to properly identify and prosecute organised crime networks that profit from trafficking in human beings.  Finally, if we are to achieve more ambitious results, it is necessary for the Member States to introduce tougher criminal sanctions and to increase police and judicial cooperation through Europol and Eurojust, sharing sensitive information and extending the existing training programmes for staff.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights, but also a violation of the personal integrity of the victim, being a serious form of organised crime. The main victims, 80%, are women, gender being a vulnerability factor. For women, the factors that increase this vulnerability are barriers to access to education, the gender pay gap, unequal access to job opportunities, underemployment, development strategies that do not focus on gender gaps. These types of barriers, especially those related to education, may influence women's perception, and there is a chance that they will not consider these experiences in terms of exploitation, but rather in terms of service providers. In order to have a clear and real situation, it is necessary for the Union to improve its methods of data collection, given that there are still a significant number of victims who are not identified, given that trafficking in human beings mainly affects 'hidden populations'. I was in favour of this report because I believe that prevention in the fight against trafficking in human beings is essential, and initiatives to reduce gender inequalities also need to be implemented.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some aspects that we can support, the report is too unbalanced on the pro-immigration front. I voted with one abstention.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a violation of numerous international laws and human rights. Today, according to UN reports, several agencies recall that trafficking in men and women should be recognised and the similarities and differences between women's and men's experiences of vulnerabilities and violations should be analysed. However, it is very difficult for the authorities to estimate the actual proportions of this type of traffic due, in particular, to low standard of living. Preventing and combating trafficking in human beings is a priority of the European Union and the Member States. It is necessary to inform victims of trafficking in human beings clearly about their rights. Union legislation sets minimum standards, but depending on problems at national level, Member States may adopt strict provisions other than those standards. I support this draft EP resolution because I believe that at the moment, when we are increasingly confronted with the phenomenon of migration, the gender dimension must be closely monitored in the implementation of EU legislation to combat trafficking in human beings.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings must end both inside and outside the borders of the European Union. To remedy this phenomenon, we have put in place a European legislative framework, the 2011/36/EU Directive, on the prevention and fight against human trafficking. This report examines the implementation by Member States of this directive. The report calls on Member States to implement the directive, whose measures are not yet fully implemented by member countries. The text also emphasizes better cooperation with Europol and Eurojust, the need to strengthen Frontex and the importance of a common investigative mandate. These different elements will help combat human trafficking in the EU. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that a further joint international effort is needed to prevent such inhuman and degrading situations.  Although the strategies adopted so far in the field of crime control, trafficking and victim assistance have been manifold, the response obtained is by no means reassuring.  Children and girls, accounting for 16 % and 13 % respectively of the total number of confirmed victims of trafficking in human beings, are certainly among the most vulnerable groups. Unfortunately, the statistics are not able to give an accurate representation of the real situation as there are a significant number of unifiable victims. Trafficking in human beings mainly affects the so-called 'hidden populations'. Peculiarities of these is the low level of complaint and the low rate of recognition.   Migrant trafficking and trafficking in human beings, although they represent different phenomena, often tend to overlap.  An adequate and well-calibrated response could then come from a thorough analysis of the latest trends, including the influence that the current migration crisis could have on the phenomenon in question.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important report, which is focused on the implementation of Directive 2011/36 on human trafficking. The directive included reporting obligations on assessing the measures taken to comply with the directive by Member States, which the Commission has failed to do. The report takes on the gendered dimension of trafficking as well as highlighting the heightened risk refugees and asylum seekers face of being trafficked. The report includes calls for the right to abortion services for women who are victims of sexual exploitation when the pregnancy has been caused by this exploitation, which I voted in favour of as Sinn Féin supports access to abortion in cases of sexual crime.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it contains unacceptable references to abortion. I believe that unborn children should never be punished for the actions of adults.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the own-initiative report which aims to express the European Parliament's position on greater protection for victims of trafficking in human beings. The relationship between the various aspects focuses on the particular vulnerability of women, the definition of the concept of trafficking and the availability of data and statistics. It is certainly to be welcomed that particular emphasis is placed on the fact of prevention, which is considered essential to combat trafficking. It also reiterates its call for the European Commission to present a legislative proposal to combat violence against women and addresses the crucial issue of identifying victims.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that it is extremely necessary we act against any criminal activity which involves disgraceful trafficking of human beings, their exploitation and abuse. Victims of these activities need to have a proper protection, legal and social, in all Member States and must be sure that there are organisations, both governmental and non-governmental, that stand by their side.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and call on the Member States to introduce strict criminal penalties for crimes of trafficking in human beings, modern slavery and human exploitation. In addition, we stress that prevention is crucial to tackling trafficking in human beings and that is why Member States must ensure that they make every effort to ensure that there are no victims in the first place.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the report on the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and on the protection of its victims on the basis of the gender dimension. It is obvious that such reports promote issues which are particularly important for the protection of European citizens. As the issue of trafficking in human beings continues to be a serious problem for humanity, Europe can and must seek to tackle it in the most effective way. That is why I supported this report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased with the adoption of this report because I think it is the right political position on a problem that is extremely important for Europe, namely trafficking in human beings. Indeed, with this political document, the Eu ropean Union is trying to combat this serious form of organised crime effectively by means of the various abuses of fundamental human rights and the personal integrity of the victim who is dragging his back. This report aims to establish stronger forms of control so that it is first and for all the individual Member States that ensure that they do everything possible to ensure that new people are not victims of it. I believe that prevention is essential if we are to tackle trafficking in human beings in a concrete way. As an MEP, it is my job to defend the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and I believe that this report is designed to combat these issues in practice. In addition, and this is very important, the document highlights the protection of gender and how girls and women are all too often victims of violence because they are objectively more vulnerable. For these reasons, I am extremely pleased with the adoption of this document.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The current refugee crisis has shown up the lack of proper tools at a European level for jointly combating Trafficking of Human Beings, especially when its aim is the sexual exploitation of women and children. A ‘one size fits all’ strategy is not efficient and the different forms of trafficking, such as trafficking for sexual exploitation, trafficking for labour exploitation and child trafficking, need to be addressed with specific and tailored policy measures.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour of clamping down on traffickers and criminal gangs who exploit the poor victims. However the EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking with the free movement of people across Europe. If we allow Turkey to join the EU or agree visa liberalisations this will only make trafficking much worse. UKIP cannot therefore support this report as it calls for more EU legislation and interference in criminal and immigration law. The only way we can deal a blow to the traffickers and save lives is to end the free movement of people and restore sensible and ethical border controls. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide criminal law, border controls and cooperation agreements with other countries, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The fight against trafficking in human beings is an absolute priority for the European Union. A scourge that knows no borders and has unfortunately become even more worrying about the so-called "refugee crisis".
