But the Union, and very much by the force of the European Parliament, not only looks at the scale of combat and repression, it is also concerned with prevention and about ensuring greater support for those who are victims of this crime. The Directive in this area has already been transposed by 27 Member States. It is clear that everyone should apply it, it is also important to ensure that it is transpositioncorrectly.  On the other hand, as the rapporteur acknowledges, there is still a lot of work to be done. In the field of prevention, Member States should use all means at their disposal, including Europol. At the level of victims, particular attention should be paid to those most affected - women - and to the most vulnerable, such as children.  I therefore support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the rapporteur's calls for further efforts. Unfortunately, despite the legal requirements, there is still an urgent need for action. Trafficking in human beings is a serious violation of human rights and human dignity and is considered one of the worst crimes in the world. We must not forget that behind every number there is a human destiny and that most of the victims are among the most vulnerable in our society. Only with coordinated joint efforts by all Member States in law enforcement, but also in prevention and victim support, will we achieve an effective fight against trafficking in human beings!

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour of clamping down on traffickers and criminal gangs who exploit the poor victims. However the EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking with the free movement of people across Europe. If we allow Turkey to join the EU or agree visa liberalisations this will only make trafficking much worse. UKIP cannot therefore support this report as it calls for more EU legislation and interference in criminal and immigration law. The only way we can deal a blow to the traffickers and save lives is to end the free movement of people and restore sensible and ethical border controls. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide criminal law, border controls and cooperation agreements with other countries, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011/36/EU aims to better protect victims of trafficking in human beings. Trafficking in human beings is considered one of the most serious crimes in the world and constitutes a serious violation of human rights. This directive lays down rules that apply throughout the European Union to address this horrific phenomenon and reduce the vulnerability of victims. Recruitment, transport, transfer, accommodation or the reception by force of persons for the purpose of exploitation shall be considered punishable. "Exploitation" means the exploitation of prostitution or other forms of sexual exploitation, labour or forced services, including begging, slavery, the exploitation of illegal activities or the taking of organs. With this directive, the Commission, by 6 April 2015, should have carried out evaluations and audits to examine the measures implemented by the Member States in transposing the directive. To date, the Commission has not carried out any evaluation or examination. I believe that particular importance must be placed in prevention in order to combat trafficking in human beings and in assisting victims. This report is a key step for the Member States in the fight against trafficking in human beings, and I am voting in favour of it.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – The adopted resolution aims to assess the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, in particular from a gender perspective. It is well known that approximately 80% of the victims of these networks are women, so specific measures should be studied in this regard. In this regard, the resolution is positive as it shows that the humanitarian crisis with refugees has highlighted the inability of measures to prevent trafficking in human beings and therefore calls for improvements in registration and means, requests that persons engaged in necessity prostitution be included among victims of trafficking, that specific training of staff in contact with victims, the financing of agencies and reception centres working with victims, or the inclusion of forced marriages as a possible form of sexual exploitation should be improved. Finally, I consider it very positive to adopt an amendment requesting Member States that victims of trafficking be entitled to a residence permit. For all this, my vote has been favourable.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking and exploitation of human beings, in all their manifestations, but above all in the field of work and sex, are phenomena still present in European societies. Victims of trafficking are already vulnerable groups, such as young women, children, asylum seekers and migrants. I am voting in favour of the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU for the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, because this is a transnational phenomenon and I believe that all Member States have the urgent need to fully and correctly implement the directive and to act in a coordinated manner. So far, Europol's capabilities have not been fully exploited for the exchange of information and the conduct of related investigations between the various Member States. Furthermore, I agree with the European Parliament's reading of the implementation of the directive, which underlines two dimensions, which I believe to be fundamental. EU anti-trafficking legislation must necessarily have a gender perspective in order to better protect the category of women. Finally, it is important to take into account the EU's internal and external action on trafficking in human beings, since non-EU countries are often the countries of origin and transit for trafficking within the EU.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights, as well as a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime that undermines the rule of law.  The vast majority of victims (80%) represented by women and girls. In their case, there are several factors that can contribute to this vulnerability, such as: barriers to access to education, the gender pay gap, unequal access to decent work opportunities, gender-like violence, unemployment or underemployment. I voted for better coordination in order to diminish the proportions of this crisis, but also to reintegrate victims into society.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights and serious organised crime within the meaning of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Directive 2011/36/EU aims to better protect victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims. Official statistics clearly show that a significant majority of victims, 80 per cent of them, come from women and girls. With this in mind, the EU institutions stressed in Article 1 of the Directive that Member States are obliged to integrate sex aspects into their anti-trafficking initiatives.  However, it should also be bearing in mind that trafficking in human beings can take many forms, including sexual exploitation, forced labour, forced marriage, domestic forced labour, organ trafficking, begging, illegal adoption and other activities. Statistics do not give an accurate picture of the real situation, which form of trafficking in human beings is most prevalent or who the victims really are. Due to different definitions, data are received which are not comparable. Prevention plays an essential role, so awareness-raising initiatives for the general public are of great importance.  Although the subject requires particular attention and targeted action, the report contains a number of wordings which either fall within national competence or go beyond its competence, so unfortunately I abstained from voting for this report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report provides an overall assessment of the measures taken to assess the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings as part of the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings. As the majority of victims of trafficking in human beings in the EU are women of different ages, the report focuses on determining their origin and the means of assistance and protection for them. It also deals with aspects related to combating forced prostitution and combating trafficking in human beings from a gender perspective, as well as recommendations for the future on how to prevent modern slavery. The report made references to LGBTI rights and access to abortion for victims of trafficking. I am aware of the importance of the subject, but I nevertheless believe that its content is far from sufficient and incomplete, which is why I abstained.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I support these efforts to tackle the serious issue of trafficking between EU Member States. The UK has also taken a strong stance on this issue, bringing the first Modern Slavery Bill in the EU into statute last year.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of this measure, which aims to promote the implementation of the directive on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims. It happens, in fact, that the victims of these traffickings are often criminalised and therefore become even more fragile and excluded, without any protection. This report proposes, in the drafting of the directive, to follow an integrated approach based on human rights, with a particular emphasis on the assistance and protection of victims. With the aim of making the standard truly effective, particular attention is also paid to the gender perspective. In fact, according to Eurostat data for the three-year period 2010-2012, 69% of registered victims of trafficking in human beings have been sexually exploited and 80% of the victims of these traffickings are women and girls. My vote is therefore intended to give full support to this report, for an increase in measures to support and defend victims, as well as for their recovery and reintegration into society. The European Union cannot be timid in the face of such phenomena, but it has a duty to develop effective policies that put the protection of human rights and dignity at the centre.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to assess the measures taken in the implementation of EU rules on the protection of victims of human trafficking. The directive was transposed into national law in 2013 by 27 Member States. The report focuses on the sexist dimension of human trafficking, knowing that 80% of victims are women, and identifies possible shortcomings in this implementation. Considering that the European Union must be exemplary in protecting victims of human trafficking, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the 2011/36/EU directive of 5 April 2011 on the prevention and control of human trafficking and the protection of victims from the perspective of gender equality. This report focuses on the gender dimension and notes that a large majority of victims are female. In addition, it is important to remember that many victims are not identified and that prevention is essential to effectively combat human trafficking.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Trafficking and trafficking in human beings are human rights violations. They are the source of sexual exploitation, but also forced labour and begging. These heinous crimes primarily affect the most vulnerable populations. 70% of the victims are women, 16% are children. If there is a European legal framework, with the 2011 directive on prevention and control of this type of trafficking, it is poorly applied by the Member States. Significant progress needs to be made in identifying and supporting victims. That is the purpose of this report.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the prevention and control of human trafficking and the protection of victims from the perspective of gender equality. Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental rights under Article 5 of the European Union Charter of Fundamental Rights, as well as an attack on the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime that threatens the state, including the rule of law. Furthermore, through this vote I wanted to draw attention to the issue of the fight against prostitution and the so-called Nordic model, which consists in penalizing the demand for sexual services. Indeed, I am in favour of this system of combating prostitution rings, which has become the norm in France thanks to a law passed at the beginning of the year in the French Parliament.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution making a series of recommendations on the implementation of the Trafficking in Persons and Victims' Protection Directive. Despite the Eu's efforts to combat this phenomenon, it is failing to be eradicated and is even on the rise by some estimates. The resolution urges Member States to better protect victims, especially women and children. It calls on them to ensure that the police, judicial staff and the medical profession receive adequate training, so that they can identify vulnerable victims as soon as possible and provide them with the support they need: access to housing, medical care, translation and legal advice. The resolution also stresses that Member States should grant victims residence permits and access to the labour market within the Member State in which they have been trafficked. Finally, the text regrets that the European Commission has failed to meet the timetable for the evaluation reports required by the directive and calls on it to do so as soon as possible.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, as this is a serious problem in the European Union, which is growing even more with incoming illegal immigrants from the south and east.  This report deals in particular with the increase in trafficking in human beings for prostitution, which can be defined as a modern type of slavery, and the free movement of persons within the Schengen area only facilitates this illegal activity. That is why measures must be taken to prevent trafficking in human beings, requiring common action and cooperation between the Member States of the European Union.  The report voted is a good step forward as it contains recommendations for future action, but also addresses the need to identify victims and provide assistance, support and protection.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a horrible violation of fundamental rights, and a violation of the human dignity and physical and psychological integrity of individuals. But we are voting against the report as it fraudulently tries to integrate immigrants into the society of European states and pays almost no attention to the real definition of trafficking in human beings and abuse, which has been hitting Europe since the great invasion of immigrants.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. As Directive 2011/36/EU states, trafficking in human beings is a serious crime, often committed within the framework of organised crime, which constitutes a serious violation of human rights and is explicitly prohibited by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. This report seeks to respond to this phenomenon from a multidisciplinary perspective, not only repressive-penal but also by taking a set of procedural and preventive measures The report represents an opportunity to assess the measures taken in the implementation of this Directive, focuses on the gender dimensions of trafficking in human beings and identifies possible deficiencies and other measures necessary to improve their effectiveness. In this regard, the Directive was to be incorporated into the national legislation of the Member States before 6 April 2013 and 27 Member States have done so, although the Commission has not yet reported on the measures taken by the Member States to comply with the Directive. In conclusion it is a positive report that deals with an issue on which the EU must be very committed

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights as well as a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime that compromises the State and the rule of law.  A 2011 Directive established a legal framework to facilitate prosecutions against traffickers and was recognised as a comprehensive legal instrument, with a commendable approach focused on human rights and clearly highlighting the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings. So far, 26 Member States have officially notified the commission of transposition, with only Germany missing. I also believe that adequate services and fair treatment of victims also play a role in prevention.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: a laudable but devious goal. The regularization of all women who denounce a prostitution or begging network would be tantamount to opening up an important legal source of immigration.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings, for various purposes and in its many forms, is one of the most serious ways of violating human rights. Women and children continue to be privileged victims. Situations of vulnerability are determined by several factors, in particular poverty and social exclusion, while the massive migratory flows have highlighted the transnational nature of the phenomenon and the lack of instruments to combat it. In the legal framework to be implemented for the prevention and repression of trafficking, the instruments relating to assistance, support and protection of victims, the cooperation of the authorities and the sharing of information aimed at investigating and discovering the financial flows resulting from the activity of organised crime networks play an important role.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Directive on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims aims at better protecting victims of trafficking in human beings and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims.  The report identifies that human trafficking is driven by the demand for high profits, which are estimated at about US$150 million per year.  It analyzes the root causes of trafficking and finds that trafficking in women, girls, men and boys for sexual exploitation has decreased in countries that criminalize demand, including both pimping and the client. It points out that the victims are overwhelmingly women. Note that, despite the Directive, victims still continue to fight for access to justice, information, access to specialised services, including access to short- and long-term secure accommodation, witness protection schemes, health care, including the right to termination of pregnancy, counselling, translation and interpretation services, judicial redress, compensation, access to education, language teaching in their country of residence, employment assistance, (re)integration, family mediation and resettlement. Despite the positive aspects, there are controversial aspects to which we have distanced ourselves (EUROPOL, EUROJUST, FRONTEX and CEPOL, among others).

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The huge migratory flows have led to a massive increase in human trafficking, which is one of the aberrant practices that has collected the most deaths in recent years, as well as representing a clear violation of fundamental human rights. Each state has the task of hindering and combating it. I voted in favour of this report because it brings to the attention of the EU Member States recommendations and useful tools to combat this international crime. The Directive lays down the obligation on Member States to set up mechanisms for the early detection, identification and assistance of victims. In this respect, public awareness-raising initiatives are essential, both in the countries of destination and in the countries of origin. In the latter, awareness-raising can help prevent trafficking, but in the countries of destination it can help to identify the direction in which victims and criminals are heading.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because, despite some aspects that we support, it focuses too much on uncontrolled pro-immigration policies.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a horrible violation of fundamental rights, and a violation of the human dignity and physical and psychological integrity of individuals. But I am voting against the report because it fraudulently tries to integrate immigrants into the society of European states and pays almost no attention to the real definition of trafficking in human beings and abuse, which has been hitting Europe since the great invasion of immigrants.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The majority of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and girls trafficked for the purpose of sexual exploitation, indicating clearly that there is a gender dimension in the trafficking of human beings that needs to be addressed correctly and efficiently. It is fundamental to establish a legal framework to better enable criminal prosecutions against traffickers, to protect the victims of trafficking and reduce vulnerability of potential victims. In line with the Anti-Trafficking Directive, Member States need to take measures to reduce the demand for trafficking. One way of doing this is to shift the criminal burden onto those who purchase the sexual services of trafficked persons. I believe we need better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires close cooperation across the EU.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU. The European Union is by its very nature, as enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the guarantor of the protection of human rights and dignity. I therefore consider it essential to promote the work of implementing the existing directive in order to continue european efforts against this dramatic phenomenon of violation of fundamental human rights, which is trafficking in human beings. I therefore agree with the urgent need for a more targeted legal framework, aimed at preventing crime, including through the criminalisation of those who purchase services (sexual, health or work) resulting from trafficking, and I call for the increased sentence for traffickers, calling for greater measures for the identification, assistance and protection of victims.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. As my group's shadow rapporteur, I voted today in favour of the report 'Prevention and combating trafficking in human beings', which also bears my lettering in many areas. Trafficking in human beings is a criminal crime that we cannot tolerate. Together with forced prostitution, it is necessary to combat it decisively across borders. I welcome more EU engagement here. I welcome the fact that we are explicitly referring to the 'Swedish model' and calling for this to be better protected for women throughout Europe. I regret that, due to the obstructionism of the other groups, it was not possible to give due consideration to the problem of surrogacy in this report.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights within the meaning of Article 5 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. It is also a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious organised crime that undermines the state and the rule of law. Directive 2011/36/EU has created a legal framework that Member States have not implemented sufficiently or at all. This must change in the foreseeable future.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The Bearder report was intended to address human trafficking, which particularly affects women and girls. They account for more than 80% of the victims. Pimping, clandestine domestic work, slavery, forced marriage or organ trafficking are all unacceptable situations.  However, the proposed solutions are likely to backfire on women and girls and to be exploited by illegal immigration networks. If we follow the recommendations of this report, it will be very simple and lucrative to force a woman into prostitution to ensure her subsequent regularization. She may also have already been forcibly married to take advantage of family reunification...  Moreover, this report deals only very superficially with the case of baby farms, modern slavery linked to the promotion of GPA. Yet this is a real subject of human trafficking, both for surrogate mothers and for children, who have become commodities. It is high time to take this into more serious concern.  In reality, the proposals in this report do not come to fight the traffickers, they come to support them. I have of course voted against this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. Since the European Commission has not been able to meet certain deadlines set out in Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective, the Bearder report calls for its effective implementation. It details measures to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims in the light of the following aspects: gender dimension, definition of trafficking in human beings, data collection for effective statistical treatment, prevention, identification and assistance to victims. It has a special impact on gender treatment, because we must not forget that 80% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and minors. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Writing. I fully supported the report 'Preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting their victims from a gender perspective' in the vote. Those parts of the text drawn up in the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Health and Human Rights, which call on the European Commission to "present guidelines on the punishment of customers on the Scandinavian model, while raising awareness of all forms of trafficking in human beings, in particular sexual exploitation, and making visible other forms of exploitation, such as serfdom," section 48 of the report. The report is about trafficking in human beings and, in this context, prostitution is characterised by the oppression of women and girls, who make up 80% of the victims of trafficking in human beings. It is my personal conviction that Scandinavian-style guidelines can be effective in the context of preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, and that punishment can have a deterrent effect on the use of sexual services by victims of trafficking in human beings. The report as a whole is a milestone in the fight against trafficking in human beings, especially women.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires close cooperation with our partners across the EU. Labour MEPs have led calls for better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Member States should do more to protect victims of human trafficking, especially women who make up 80% of trafficked persons, yet their specific needs are not being taken into account. EU legislation meant to protect victims of trafficking is not being properly implemented. Trafficked people must be treated as victims, not criminals, and given enough support to recover and return to a normal life.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report as I had no objections to its findings.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is a major problem that states must solve. However, the measures mentioned in the Bearder report do not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, as many areas are within the competences of the Member States. That is why I abstained from the vote. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU as a whole needs to tackle the issue of trafficking in human beings (THB). On one hand, there is a need for better identification and data collection on this matter. On the other hand, Member States must take action in enacting harsher penalties for those enabling, trafficking, or benefiting from THB.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from a gender perspective, as I believe that the Union and the Member States should focus greater efforts on protecting victims of trafficking, in particular women who make up 80% of victims. Some aspects of protection have not yet been taken into account and European legislation is not being adequately implemented. Victims of trafficking must not be considered criminals, and they need to be given stronger support to return to normal life as soon as possible. Therefore, I support this Report and believe that it is necessary to ensure that the fundamental rights of all individuals are respected.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks. However, the report calls for strong criminal sanctions to be implemented. With regard to clandestine work, "greater attention" is just requested to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies, but without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. The lax spirit that emerges from the text made me vote against him.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Diane James MEP and her fellow UKIP colleagues abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour of clamping down on traffickers and criminal gangs who exploit the poor victims. However the EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking with the free movement of people across Europe. If we allow Turkey to join the EU or agree visa liberalisations this will only make trafficking much worse. UKIP cannot therefore support this report as it calls for more EU legislation and interference in criminal and immigration law. The only way we can deal a blow to the traffickers and save lives is to end the free movement of people and restore sensible and ethical border controls. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide criminal law, border controls and cooperation agreements with other countries, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 2010 and 2012, the EU recorded over 30,000 victims of trafficking in human beings, in 80% of cases women were victims. Although visible progress can be seen in the fight against international smuggling gangs, legislation protecting victims of trafficking in human beings is unfortunately still under-implemented in the Member States. Victims of smuggling groups should not be taken as criminals, they need understanding access and compassion, they should have access to safe accommodation, legal aid and support in returning to normal life. Human trafficking has no place in our century, which is why I supported this report.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which concerns both the prevention of human trafficking, the fight against this phenomenon and the protection of victims, subjects to which I am particularly sensitive.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Member States are invited to identify existing loopholes in the law on trafficking in human beings and to adapt their policies accordingly in order to punish such crimes more effectively. In this sense, Member States are invited to ratify international treaties on trafficking in human beings and to incorporate them into their national legislation. However, the aim of the report is to promote lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender groups in the context of gender equality, and to grant citizenship to immigrants who are victims of human trafficking. I therefore do not agree with this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires close cooperation with our partners across the EU. Labour MEPs have led calls for better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. \u2012 Victims of trafficking in human beings must be helped and protected in the best possible way. There can be no doubt about this. When we abstain on how to ensure this in practice, it is because the area is covered by the opt-out. Therefore, the precise measures for protection and legal aid for victims of trafficking in human beings in Denmark cannot be laid down in EU law, but only in Danish law.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is a major problem that states must solve. However, the measures mentioned in the Bearder report do not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, as many areas are within the competences of the Member States. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. – Despite the provisions of the existing directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings (THB), human trafficking is still a reality. Statistics show clearly that the majority of victims are women and girls. I believe that in order to tackle this crucial issue, there is a clear need to identify the victims better and to offer them the support they need, having particular regard to refugees who are vulnerable to THB. The present report aims to strengthen the scope of the directive by combining criminal activities with a strong gender dimension. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my voice the Report on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims, as trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights, as well as a violation of the victim's privacy and a serious form of organised crime that undermines the foundations of the state and the rule of law.  Member States must vigorously fight impunity, criminalize trafficking in human beings and ensure that perpetrators face adequate sanctions. Member States must ratify all relevant international instruments, agreements and legal obligations, which would make efforts to combat trafficking in human beings more effective, coherent and consistent.  Prevention is essential in the fight against trafficking in human beings and Member States must ensure that they do everything they can to prevent people from becoming victims. Victims should be given the opportunity for legal advice and legal representation, including for the purpose of claiming compensation. The nature of the traffic suggests that the victim probably does not have the means to pay for this type of assistance, therefore it must be free of charge.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this resolution, Parliament reiterated that trafficking in human beings constitutes a very serious violation of fundamental rights and a violation of human dignity and the physical and psychological integrity of the victims. But it's not just that. Trafficking in human beings is also a serious form of crime, often organised, fuelled by strong demand and profits estimated at around $150 billion a year. The phenomenon is so complex and transnational that it can only be tackled effectively by coordinating the actions of the EU Member States, institutions and agencies. And also through effective measures to prevent and suppress trafficking and protect victims. About 80% of the victims of trafficking are women and girls and in most cases are victims of sexual exploitation. But there are equally abhorrent figures estimating up to 16% of the number of child victims of trafficking who mostly come from minority groups, are of Roma origin or are refugees or asylum seekers. We pay particular attention to asylum seekers, refugees and migrants who are victims of trafficking. We are calling loudly for humanitarian visas for women and children, and once they have arrived in Europe, we are calling for effective measures of economic and social integration.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a serious violation of human rights, but at the same time a lucrative business for traffickers. This cruel activity is not coincidentally defined as modern slavery for the exploitation of people who are treated as goods for sale. Usually victims are involved in various legal and illegal activities from agriculture and household chores to the sex industry, begging and dealing with human organs.  I believe that the transnational nature of the phenomenon requires a united effort of all institutions involved at national and regional level. It is important to note that the capabilities of the European Police Office (Europol) have not been fully used by the Member States. Sharing more information with Europol and other Member States can contribute to the creation of a broader information architecture that is key to tackling issues such as trafficking in human beings, drug trafficking and terrorism.  In conclusion, I would like to emphasise the fact that the training of legal practitioners and officials is essential for the early identification of potential victims and the prevention of crime. I therefore call on the Member States to exchange best practices, in particular when setting up training programmes for prevention and protection purposes.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Following various discussions and amendments, the draft law on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings has finally been adopted. Trafficking in human beings is a serious violation of fundamental human rights and we cannot fail to act to combat it. The report represents an opportunity to analyse the instruments used during the implemention of this directive and identifies its limits for improving its effectiveness. To date, 80% of the victims of human trafficking are women, and that is why we want to focus on protecting women and children in particular. Unfortunately, the Commission has not yet reported on the measures applied by the Member States to comply with this directive. Having considered what has been said and with the desire for new instruments to be put in place, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of human trafficking and the fight against human trafficking. This is a laudable goal in principle, but diverted from its purpose. There is a real need to combat trafficking in human beings and in particular against the various forms of exploitation of women: pimping, begging, clandestine domestic work, forced marriage, organ trade and illegal adoptions. Women and girls account for 80% of registered trafficking victims. The regularization of all women who denounce a prostitution or begging network would, however, open up an important legal source of immigration. This will be even more true for humanitarian visas. Lgbt victims are also referred to, so as to facilitate their regularization, which would be made necessary by discrimination against them.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I spoke out against this report. It is part of the fight against the forms of exploitation of women (pimping, begging, forced marriage, illegal adoptions). In fact, it seeks to encourage certain people, such as women who would be willing to report a prostitution ring or other people from the LGBT community, to facilitate their regularization. This is also the intention of the text, which calls for broad funding of NGOs for migrants. The initial humanitarian intentions are therefore overwhelmed by ideological proposals.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights, a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organized crime that undermines the rule of law. The EU established a legal framework aimed at strengthening criminal actions against traffickers of human beings, improving the protection of victims of trafficking and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims. The report carries out an assessment of the measures that have been implemented by Member States in order to address the gender dimension in human trafficking in the implementation of the Directive. The report notes that there are different types of trafficking: labour exploitation, organ extraction, sexual exploitation. It also emphasizes the urgent need to better identify victims, include gender perspective in preventing human trafficking and identifying, assisting and protecting victims of trafficking.  Finally, the report recommends new measures that should be implemented, the implementation of harsher penalties for traffickers and those exploiting victims and greater cooperation across the EU.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The resolution adopted aims to assess the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, in particular from a gender perspective. It is well known that approximately 80% of the victims of these networks are women, so specific measures should be studied in this regard. In this regard, the resolution is positive as it shows that the humanitarian crisis with refugees has highlighted the inability of measures to prevent trafficking in human beings and therefore calls for improvements in registration and means, requests that persons engaged in necessity prostitution be included among victims of trafficking, that specific training of staff in contact with victims, the financing of agencies and reception centres working with victims, or the inclusion of forced marriages as a possible form of sexual exploitation should be improved. Finally, I consider it very positive to adopt an amendment requesting Member States that victims of trafficking be entitled to a residence permit. For all this, my vote has been favourable.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Trafficking in human beings constitutes a serious violation of the fundamental human rights protected by Article 5 of the EIA. the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, as well as breaches of the victim's personal integrity and a serious form of organised crime endangering the state and the rule of law. Directive 2011/36/EU aims to provide better protection for victims of trafficking in human beings and to reduce the exposure of potential victims, and to establish a legal framework for better enforcement of the prosecution of perpetrators. The EU strategy considers violence against women and gender inequality to be one of the root causes of trafficking in human beings. Statistics clearly show that the majority of victims (80 %) women, girls and girls and that gender is a factor of exposure to the risk of trafficking in human beings. This is why it is important to adopt an approach that takes into account the gender perspective in the field of trafficking in human beings, as women and men are often trafficked for different purposes and in different ways. I supported this report because it highlights the necessity of better coordination and prevention, which is essential in the fight against trafficking in human beings.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is a major problem that states must solve. However, the measures mentioned in the Bearder report do not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, as many areas are within the competences of the Member States. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – Trafficking in human beings is currently a serious crime of a borderline nature, the detection of which is complicated and costly. In addition to fundamental violations of human rights, humiliation and harm to victims, it also has a significant economic dimension, as it is a source of illegal income. Trafficking in human beings has various and increasingly sophisticated forms of violence, from sexual abuse, forced labour and begging, various forms of discrimination to organ taking. It concerns weaker sections of the population, especially women and children. It is essential that the Member States and the Commission, by properly applying, monitoring and evaluating the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, eliminate the commission of these crimes, detect and punish them in a timely manner, and provide timely and effective assistance to victims.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU of 5 April 2011 on the prevention and combating of trafficking in human beings and on the protection of its victims on the basis of the gender dimension for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/5/2016 and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The report contains only empty phrases about the fight against trafficking in human beings. Human trafficking is regrettable and should be prosecuted by the police. However, this report will not contribute in any way. On the contrary, European policy, such as Schengen or visa-free travel for Turkey, will only further facilitate the volume of trafficking in human beings and children. I do not agree that states should take special account of the needs of "transgender" people in detecting human trafficking. The state should treat all adults equally, children deserve special treatment. Different groups of adults are vulnerable, there is no need for special access to "transgender" people.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. – Today we voted on a report dealing with an important issue, which is trafficking in human beings. This is a gross violation of fundamental rights as well as a violation of the human dignity and physical and psychological integrity of the victim, which often causes consequences for the rest of his life. It is mainly committed in the form of organised crime, which is driven by high demand and profits estimated at around USD 150 billion per year. An alarming fact is also the high percentage of children, up to 16 percent of the victims are just children. I welcomed the fact that the Commission has set up a website to combat trafficking in human beings, as it is the internet that is becoming a major challenge in the fight against this serious crime. International cooperation is needed to combat this phenomenon. I supported the report.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The prevention of trafficking in human beings is one of the key elements to be put in place, also in the light of the migration crisis. As the report mentions, 70% of the victims and 70% of the perpetrators are European citizens. Our solution must be directed towards the problem facing European citizens and not just the problem of international trafficking or the exploitation of migrants. Similarly, every person can be a victim of trafficking, but we know that this problem disproportionately affects women and girls, so we need to produce specific solutions geared towards women. We must provide specific support services for women and girls who are victims. In order to try to solve the problem, however, it is necessary to combat demand. This is the only way to end the trafficking, because there will always be victims who fall into the criminal group. The demand for prostitution, the demand for forced labour and the demand for illegal organs must be eliminated. I want to see the end of all these problems and my vote in favour today is a contribution to this cause.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings, regardless of gender, is a flagrant violation of the fundamental rights and human dignity of victims (Article 5(3) of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights). Victims of such actions suffer irreparable harm that often follow them for the rest of their lives.  Tackling the crime of trafficking in human beings must be a primary concern of the Union through targeted policies that are implemented directly and in practice. The need for immediate action has also been highlighted by the current refugee crisis, which has given impetus to such illegal actions. At the same time, it also revealed the lack of appropriate tools on the part of the Union to deal with and eliminate this crime. This resolution will make a positive contribution to improving the policy of tackling trafficking in human beings since it advocates the immediate implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU, which contains arrangements for both combating and protecting victims.  Of particular importance is given to women victims of trafficking in human beings, who make up 80% of the total number, as well as to the strengthening of their support services. Finally, the Directive imposes on the Commission the obligation to report on the control measures taken by States, as well as to criminalise the use of services exploited by trafficking in human beings.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. The purpose of this text is, and we welcome it, to combat trafficking in human beings and, in particular, against the various forms of exploitation of women. This objective, in full agreement with our desire to combat these forms of exploitation, masks a very different will: the regularization of all women who would denounce a network of prostitution or begging. This would mean opening up an important legal source of immigration, a phenomenon that would be amplified for humanitarian visas. Moreover, it would be of interest if the sentences imposed on criminals were deterrent and likely to effectively impede the activity of criminal networks. We regret that this is not the case. However, the report calls for stronger criminal sanctions, which we agree with. We condemn the laxity with which the issue of illegal labour is dealt with.  Indeed, only "greater attention" to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies is recommended, without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. What's the point? Finally, there is a call for an increase in funding for NGOs working for migrants, which we oppose.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on trafficking in human beings assesses the current situation, various EU initiatives to combat this problem. It is noted that there are no appropriate tools at European level to combat trafficking in human beings, especially those aimed at sexually exploiting women and children. The report calls for a wide range of assistance for victims of trafficking in human beings, such as legal assistance in court and for the prosecution and conviction of traffickers, and for redress.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The concept of human trafficking encompasses a wide range of activities: sexual exploitation, forced labour, forced marriages, domestic servitude, organ removal, forced begging, illegal adoptions... The report stresses that within the EU "asylum seekers, refugees and migrants are particularly vulnerable to trafficking" and therefore calls for the establishment of "channels for legal and safe migration" The report rightly points out that "trafficking in persons for the purpose of sexual exploitation has declined in countries that have penalised demand , including pimping and the purchase of sexual services" and also calls on Member States to set up 'safe abortion services'. I vote for this text regretting that it has no legislative value and is therefore only wishful thinking.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. There are many problems with this report. In particular, I believe that the provisions he advocates will not make it possible to identify or protect victims more effectively. Indeed, by applying for rights and residence permits for victims of trafficking, migrant women may be exposed to processes that are not human enough to obtain their regularization. Finally, human trafficking is already very much regulated in France, an unnecessary and harmful overload is unwelcome.  So I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While the text contained important measures to combat the deplorable act of trafficking of human beings, I could not support the final version as it included unacceptable references to abortion which are misplaced in the text.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on the gender dimension in human trafficking and the fight against human trafficking. Assessing the implementation of EU legislation in this area, this resolution reminds Member States of their obligations, particularly in the area of preventing trafficking and assisting victims. The text focuses in particular on trafficking for sexual exploitation, the majority of which are women and girls. In this regard, I would like to stress the crucial importance of properly taking into account the new trends linked to the development of the internet. The Internet offers new opportunities for criminal networks active in human trafficking and allows the emergence of new forms of trafficking, particularly in the area of sexual exploitation. In order to combat this phenomenon, which is progressing at an alarming rate, the Union cannot save effective action, coordinated between Member States and based on cutting-edge expertise in this area.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – Trafficking in human beings is considered a serious organised crime and victims are seriously affected by the personal integrity of man as a fundamental human right recognised by both the international and European systems of protection of rights. , unemployment and underemence, the feminisation of poverty and other factors. I consider it of the utmost importance that the Member States identify, treat and provide the greatest possible protection and support in their initiatives. Assistance services should take into account the gender aspect and take into account that different gender groups have different aid needs. As a precaution, it is also important to focus on education programmes and the empowerment of women, girls and marginalised groups. Given the seriousness of this probblmatics, the motion for a resolution has my full support.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Under the principled aim of combating human trafficking, the text is quickly diverted from its purpose. The regularization of all women who denounce a prostitution or begging network would indeed open up an important legal source of immigration. This will be even more true for humanitarian visas. Moreover, the penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks. However, the report calls for strong criminal sanctions to be implemented. With regard to clandestine work, "greater attention" is just requested to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies, but without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. For these reasons, it is therefore not possible to support this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of Article 5(3) of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, trafficking in human beings constitutes a serious violation of fundamental rights, as well as a violation of human dignity and the physical and mental integrity of victims, responsible for serious damage affecting them throughout their lives.  I would point out that Directive 2011/36/EU should have been transposed into the national legislation of the Member States by 6 April 2013 and that all Member States, except one, have notified the Commission of the transposition of that directive into national law. I believe it is essential that Member States speed up the correct and full implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting victims. I endorse the rapporteur's position in the recommendation that the gender dimension should be properly monitored in the implementation of EU law, and Member States should adopt gender-differentiated measures. Men and women, as well as girls and boys, have different forms of vulnerability, are trafficked for various purposes and prevention, assistance and support measures should therefore be gender-adapted.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks. However, the report calls for strong criminal sanctions to be implemented. With regard to clandestine work, "greater attention" is just requested to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies, but without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. That is why I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the prevention of human trafficking. While this phenomenon benefits criminal networks above all, it is essential to strengthen the arsenal at the disposal of the European Union in order to fight more effectively against all practices that violate human rights.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings, whether for sexual exploitation, forced labour, forced marriages, domestic servitude, forced removal of organs, illegal adoptions, is an unacceptable phenomenon that still plagues our society. With the adoption of this directive, the EU aims to prevent and effectively combat all forms of exploitation, putting victims and people at the centre, paying the necessary attention to differences in sex and age, as well as to different religious denominations. As a recent Caritas report shows, however, trafficking in human beings remains in third place, after drug and arms trafficking, as the most profitable 'business' for organised crime. A turnover of as much as $32 billion a year. A business in which the most affected victims are women and girls (80%), whose vulnerability can be attributed to obstacles in access to education, gender-based violence, unfair access to employment opportunities. As pointed out in the latest Migrantes report, the anonymity in which the victims often find themselves and the lack of coordination between states are important obstacles. I therefore hope that the directive will bring attention to the individual and coordination between states, international organisations and NGOs, both of which are necessary for the defeat of trafficking in human beings.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Bearder report on the prevention of human trafficking and the fight against human trafficking. Some points were proposed in free vote to MEPs, I decided to vote in favour of all these points which encouraged the help and protection of transgender people victims of violence, the protection of prostitutes and the penalization of their clients on the basis of the Nordic model in force, access to abortion in the case of pregnancies resulting from sexual and forced exploitation , to protect LGBTI people and finally to a draft law against violence against women. The European Union must continue to mobilise and act against all forms of violence, as well as to protect citizens.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. Whereas trafficking in human beings constitutes a serious violation of the fundamental rights of the European Union, an insult to human dignity and a threat to the physical and psychological safety of the individuals concerned; We are in favour of the Bearder report. Noting the phenomenon of sexual slavery, which is particularly serious for young people and women who, for reasons of safety or subsistence, are often forced to give in to blackmail by their tormentors, we therefore reiterate the importance of the gender dimension in all measures to prevent and prosecute the phenomenon. With this in mind, we stress the need for policies that ensure that those at risk have safe and privileged humanitarian channels and that, once they reach the country of destination, they are assured to the most vulnerable sections of integration instruments, such as language courses and residence permits, that prevent their subjugation to criminal groups. Given that the lack of coordination between Member States in this area favours organised crime, we regret the non-transposition of Directive 2011/36/EU by a Member State and the failure of the European Commission to comply with the timetable, which, by April 2015, should have presented a report on the measures taken by individual countries to adapt to this directive.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fight against trafficking in human beings. This heinous crime is a serious violation of human rights and we must take action against it by all possible means. Its victims are a significant number of women and children, who often also become victims of sexual exploitation. I think it is important that awareness-raising campaigns are an integral part of the fight, as hiding behind anonymity and taboos can make perpetrators work much more effectively. Trafficking in human beings is not only a problem for third countries, it is a global problem, which unfortunately also takes place in the European Union in many cases.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The definition of trafficking in human beings says it is a violation of fundamental human rights under Article 5 of the Charter on Fundamental Rights of the EU, as well as a violation of the victim’s personal integrity and a serious organised crime that undermines the state and the rule of law. I have voted for this report that will bring initiatives to tackle gender inequality and empower women and girls, thus reducing their vulnerability to trafficking.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ The report assesses how the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims has been implemented across EU Member States. Trafficking in human beings is a highly gendered phenomenon – 80% of victims being women and girls. The report stresses that Member States should, in accordance with this directive, introduce a gender perspective into anti-trafficking measures, but that there is a need for clarification of what this means in practice in order to do so effectively. Likewise, the report points to disparity across Member States in terms of collecting data on trafficking in human beings due to a lack of common definitions and, in some cases, lack of gender disaggregated data. Standardising data collection across the EU is essential for creating policies that can prevent such trafficking. Thus, the resolution outlines important gaps in the implementation of the directive which need to be addressed, and it is for this reason that I endorse it.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the implementation, fight against and protection of victims from the point of view of gender equality, which highlights the vulnerability of women and children and the need to take more effective action to protect them from this dangerous type of crime and its consequences in the context of a serious global and European problem. One of them should be the disclosure of legal aid in various types of proceedings, not only criminal, but also others in which they can seek legal protection. Member States should also ensure that victims of trafficking in human beings have adequate access to specialised services such as health and psychological care.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 Alternative ways of reducing prostitution and demand, as well as the protection of the human rights of sex workers, are topics that deserve separate parliamentary debate. The report on the prevention of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims aims to criminalise criminals profiteering by smuggling and exploiting people, not solving this issue. Criminalising the demand for prostitution has been in operation in Sweden for 15 years and in Norway for 8 years. However, after all this time, there is no conclusive evidence that this legal solution has reduced the number of sex workers and victims forced into sex work exploited by people smuggling.  However, there are many examples and studies showing that it has increased the vulnerability of sex workers, contributed to their stigmatisation and reduced their access to health and justice. Growing and prominent organisations are protesting against this solution, citing these studies, arguing for alternative solutions to reduce demand. Thus, criminalised demand has not only not achieved the desired objective, i.e. it has not reduced demand, but it has also made people who are now in need of a black market even more vulnerable, who are thus forced to work in a much more dangerous environment, subjected to abuse and harassment. This is particularly worrying, as these people already live on the margins of society. The European Parliament has a duty to protect the human rights of all people living in Europe, including sex workers.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. If I had been present at the vote, I would have opposed this report. I strongly oppose gender mainstreaming in all union policies and in the national policies that follow it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important that the Member States and the relevant EU institutions do everything to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings, reduce their vulnerability and effectively address the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. Trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious organised crime, spreading ominously in all regions of the world. Effective measures to combat trafficking in human beings, which include prevention, the protection of victims' human rights and the prosecution of traffickers, therefore need to be implemented. It is necessary to understand that the victim of human trafficking can become a person of any age, sex, social status. However, socially vulnerable people are most often victims. It is therefore essential that victims of trafficking in human beings have access to legal aid not only in criminal proceedings, but also in all civil, labour and other procedures. Victims of trafficking in human beings should also be systematically informed of the possibility of benefiting from the recovery and reflection period.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Over 30,000 victims of trafficking networks were recorded in the EU between 2010 and 2012, 80% of whom were women. Children make up about 16% of registered victims and girls make up 13%. Women and girls make up 95% of victims of sexual exploitation, while the majority of victims of labour exploitation are men (71%). efforts to protect victims of trafficking in human beings and to take measures to prevent and provide assistance and support. Vulnerable victims must be identified quickly and given the necessary support.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The resolution artfully obscures the root cause of the phenomenon, namely the capitalist mode of production which, using labour force as a commodity, also converts people into goods. It isolates "organised crime" as an exclusive cause, hiding that it works by the rules of the capitalist enterprise in the exploitative system, which recognizes profit as its only supreme value. It entrusts the solution of the problem to the unpopular repressive mechanisms of the EU and governments, such as Europol, recommends, in support of victims, more funding for NGOs often suspected of their action, rather than supporting state infrastructure and services. The policy of the EU and civil governments shapes the barbaric reality experienced by women in the grassroots. It establishes prostitution – the ultimate form of commercialization and exploitation of human existence – as a profession, and its separation into voluntary and coercive, uses forced prostitution to expand legal prostitution. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece was white, stressing that, in a world dominated by monopolies, there is absolutely no qualms about any commercialisation of human life of all kinds. That is why the people must overthrow them by abolishing the exploitation of man by man.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course is in favour of clamping down on traffickers and criminal gangs who exploit the poor victims. However the EU has created the perfect environment for trafficking with the free movement of people across Europe. If we allow Turkey to join the EU or agree visa liberalisations this will only make trafficking much worse. UKIP cannot therefore support this report as it calls for more EU legislation and interference in criminal and immigration law. The only way we can deal a blow to the traffickers and save lives is to end the free movement of people and restore sensible and ethical border controls. Only our elected and accountable national government should decide criminal law, border controls and cooperation agreements with other countries, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On my colleague's proposal, I would vote in favour. Trafficking in human beings is, without doubt, a violation of fundamental rights and human dignity and, since the Union's legal framework recognises trafficking as a gender phenomenon, I believe that the gender dimension must be a good approach to adopt and follow. In this respect, greater regulatory efforts by states to combat this social scourge, closer monitoring of the situation of women and transgender victims and the adoption of specific measures to provide assistance to the weakest groups would be desirable. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Trafficking in human beings is a serious crime and a gross violation of human rights, which can be classified as a modern form of slavery. It occurs all over the world and affects almost every country as an origin, transit or destination country or sometimes a combination of all. I vote for minimum common rules for determining offences of trafficking in human beings and punishing offenders. I strongly hope that this will provide measures to better prevent this phenomenon and to strengthen the protection of victims all over the world.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings in any form is a serious violation of the fundamental human rights that we must protect. The human trafficking industry knows no borders and has become a serious form of organised crime with profits of $150 billion a year. We are all united in the view that we must do everything in our power to stop these serious violations of human rights and dignity, but we disagree when it comes to the exact definition of human trafficking, which, in my view, should be comprehensive and include modern forms of human trafficking such as surrogacy, which this Parliament has already condemned, and the Council of Europe has recently opposed the legalisation of this practice that undermines human dignity because it treats both women and children facilities and goods to be bought and sold. I also disagree fully with the methods of protecting victims of trafficking outlined in this report. We know that human rights go back to violating another man's human rights, so I strongly oppose access to abortion as an instrument to help and protect victims of sexual exploitation. I believe that there is a lot of scope to create effective instruments to combat human trafficking and we need to focus on developing instruments, enforcing EU legislation on this issue and destroying the black market in human trafficking.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of human rights, as enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Although the target of those affected is composite, the statistics inform us that the majority of them are women. I voted in favour of this resolution because I support the need to step up the EU's efforts against this inhumane practice, which is part of a wide range of illegal activities. Putting into practice actions to protect victims of trafficking and jointly combating their continuation means fully implementing Directive 2011/36/EU establishing a common legal framework for criminal proceedings against traffickers. This rule also contains an obligation for Member States to establish mechanisms for the early detection, identification and assistance of victims; To this end, the Union must continue to develop methodologies and methods of data collection in order to produce comparable statistics. We also need to work on prevention through initiatives to tackle gender inequalities and empower women and girls. It is also necessary to provide assistance and support to victims of trafficking regardless of whether they want to testify or not, taking gender dimension into account, of course.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒in 2012, taking into account the Oviedo Convention on Human Rights and Biomedicine and the Hague Adoption Convention, the European Parliament noted that Directive 2011/36/EU should have been transposed into member states' national law by 6 April 2013 and that all Member States, except one, had informed the Commission of the transposition of this Directive into their national law. He also stressed that, in accordance with Article 11 of the Member States shall establish mechanisms to ensure early detection of victims and assistance and support to victims, in cooperation with appropriate support organisations. He also highlighted the need for an approach based on four key strategies: prevention, prosecution, victim protection and multi-level partnership. I welcome the European Parliament's decision, as it recognises, and consequently prevents, the risk of women and children being forced into sexual intercourse in exchange for protection, in order to survive, to continue on their migration route and to feed themselves. It also addresses the fact that trafficking in human beings is carried out not only by organised criminal groups, but also by members of the victim's family, friends, relatives, love partners and regular employers.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective aims at better protecting victims of trafficking in human beings and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims.  The report identifies that human trafficking is driven by the demand for high profits, which are estimated at about US$150 million per year. It analyzes the root causes of trafficking and finds that trafficking in women, girls, men and boys for sexual exploitation has decreased in countries that criminalize demand, including both pimping and the client. It points out that the victims are the overwhelming majority of victims who can be found in lawful and illegal activities, which include: prostitution, agriculture, the food industry, domestic work, the manufacturing sector, the care sector, cleaning, begging, crime, forced marriage, sexual exploitation of children online, illegal adoptions and trade in human organs. Despite an appropriate overall assessment, issues such as the response framework focused on structures such as EUROPOL, EUROJUST, or FRONTEX; the proposal of an independent national rapporteur; with which we disagree, justify abstaining.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights, the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime. I supported Mp Bearder's report calling for better coordination and more activities to prevent and combat trafficking in human beings. The Union should continue to develop its work on methodologies and ways of collecting quality data in order to obtain comparable statistics that will serve as a basis for the implementation of concrete measures.  Prevention is important and in this regard a legal proposal should be proposed to combat violence against women with a focus on awareness campaigns. Preventive initiatives should involve the most relevant stakeholders and Member States should work closely with social partners, civil society and survivors of this serious crime.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The report represents an opportunity to assess the measures taken in implementation of the Directive on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims and to identify any gaps and further steps needed to improve their effectiveness. Considerable progress has been made in recent years in the fight against criminal organisations dedicated to international trafficking in human beings but, all too often, victims are not given all the help they are entitled to. EU Member States should do more to protect victims of trafficking in human beings and take specific prevention, assistance and support measures for women and children. It is important that EU Member States provide adequate training for their police forces, the judiciary, medical staff and social workers, so that they can offer their professionalism and the necessary support to the victims. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.
