name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This own-initiative report provides an overall assessment of the measures taken to assess the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings as part of the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings. As the majority of victims of trafficking in human beings in the EU are women and girls, this report focuses on determining their origin and on helping and protecting them. It also deals with aspects related to the fight against forced prostitution and the prevention of trafficking in human beings from a gender perspective, and includes recommendations for the future on how to prevent modern slavery. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In Europe, 70% of victims of human trafficking are EU nationals. I voted in favour of a text that makes recommendations on the implementation of the directive to combat this phenomenon and above all to protect the victims, who are unfortunately mainly women and children. It is therefore important to remember that it is at the Member State level that the measures must be implemented, in addition to the Necessary European cooperation.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. I fully supported the report 'Preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting their victims from a gender perspective' in the vote. Those parts of the text drawn up in the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Health and Human Rights, which call on the European Commission to "present guidelines on the punishment of customers on the Scandinavian model, while raising awareness of all forms of trafficking in human beings, in particular sexual exploitation, and making visible other forms of exploitation, such as serfdom," section 48 of the report. The report is about trafficking in human beings and, in this context, prostitution is characterised by the oppression of women and girls, who make up 80% of the victims of trafficking in human beings. It is my personal conviction that Scandinavian-style guidelines can be effective in the context of preventing and combating trafficking in human beings, and that punishment can have a deterrent effect on the use of sexual services by victims of trafficking in human beings. The report as a whole is a milestone in the fight against trafficking in human beings, especially women.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is an atrocious form of organized crime, generating considerable profits and generally goes unpunished. It is also a serious violation of fundamental rights, affecting many victims. Through this text, MEPs call on the EU and Member States to act in a coordinated way to combat this worrying phenomenon. This requires a comprehensive approach, focused on prevention, prosecuting those responsible, and protecting victims; which also means gender-appropriate measures. Women and men are often victims of different types of trafficking, and do not have the same vulnerability to exploitation. In addition, the particular situation of some victims, such as children or LGBTI people, requires specific responses. This report focuses in particular on the needs related to identification, support and assistance to victims. This must be a priority: above all, it is about human beings who have suffered terrible traumas, which must be helped to rebuild. In this sense, it is essential to allow them to access a residence permit unconditionally, but also to ensure the recognition of their status throughout the Union.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. Trafficking in human beings is intolerable. It must be stopped, whatever its forms. This will include the effective implementation of EU legislation, including the 2011/36/EU directive. The fight against human trafficking must first be preventive. And where it could not be prevented, victims must be protected and supported, their rights must be respected, their return to normal life guaranteed, while a repressive component must also be properly applied. Impunity on this issue cannot be accepted. Trafficking in human beings is an affront to our societies based on respect for fundamental rights and for our values. Women and girls make up 80% of victims of human trafficking. Children account for 16% of the victims. These figures are all the more terrible, given that 10,000 unaccompanied children disappeared after arriving in the EU in 2015, according to Europol.  Trafficking in human beings is unacceptable. Appropriate action must be taken. This text supports this idea. That is why I supported him.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights, a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organized crime that undermines the rule of law. The EU adopted in 2011 Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, which established a legal framework aimed at strengthening criminal actions against traffickers, improving the protection of victims of trafficking and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims.  In view of the Commission's failure to comply with its obligation to submit two assessment reports in April 2015, Parliament has prepared this report, which I have supported, and which stresses the urgent need to better identify victims, to include the gender perspective in the prevention of trafficking in persons and in the identification, assistance and protection of victims of trafficking. It also recommends the application of harsher penalties for traffickers and those exploiting victims and greater cooperation across the EU. And it calls on the Commission for a new Strategy for the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of this report which calls above all on the European Commission to present a European strategy against gender-based violence, including a legislative proposal on violence against women, which also includes the "fight against human trafficking" dimension.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a disgrace to mankind. At the same time, however, trafficking in human beings is also a huge illegal business for some. It is difficult to deal with it, but the experience of the last couple of hundred years shows that it is possible. The start has already been made – trafficking in human beings is, in principle, criminalised and punishable by human trafficking around the world. The next steps are more complex. First of all, it is necessary to ensure that legislation that condemns trafficking in human beings is fully enforced. And this is not the easiest task, especially given the amounts that are turning in the area of trafficking in human beings. The next task ahead of us is to reduce demand, to educate society in order to gain the global perception that trafficking in human beings is a reprehensible thing that is not compatible with the modern world. And it is this education that needs to be given particular attention, both in supply and demand countries, as a preventive measure.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on Member States to take gender-based prevention, assistance and support measures, and to better protect victims of human trafficking. This text recalls that progress has been made in the fight against international trafficking in human beings. Nevertheless, it is crucial that EU victims' rights legislation is applied more optimally.  Women and children are the first victims of traffickers. In 2015, according to Europol, nearly 10,000 unaccompanied children have disappeared since their arrival in the EU. In the face of these alarming figures, measures are needed to ensure that children are registered at the time of arrival and their inclusion in child protection systems. It is also a priority to combat the sexual exploitation of women, a common practice of human traffickers.  Finally, I supported this text because it calls on Member States to provide adequate training for social and order services so that they can identify victims of trafficking as soon as possible and offer them adequate support.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. Since the European Commission has not been able to meet certain deadlines set out in Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective, the Bearder report calls for its effective implementation. It details measures to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims in the light of the following aspects: gender dimension, definition of trafficking in human beings, data collection for effective statistical treatment, prevention, identification and assistance to victims. It has a special impact on gender treatment, because we must not forget that 80% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and minors. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU of 5 April 2011 on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from a gender perspective, because trafficking in human beings is a growing global problem. The report rightly identifies a large gender gap and calls for action to be taken. Women and young girls in particular are particularly vulnerable and therefore need to be better protected. Member States must also cooperate more closely and exchange information more closely.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The resolution adopted aims to assess the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, in particular from a gender perspective. It is well known that approximately 80% of the victims of these networks are women, so specific measures should be studied in this regard. In this regard, the resolution is positive as it shows that the humanitarian crisis with refugees has highlighted the inability of measures to prevent trafficking in human beings and therefore calls for improvements in registration and means, requests that persons engaged in necessity prostitution be included among victims of trafficking, that specific training of staff in contact with victims, the financing of agencies and reception centres working with victims, or the inclusion of forced marriages as a possible form of sexual exploitation should be improved. Finally, I consider it very positive to adopt an amendment requesting Member States that victims of trafficking be entitled to a residence permit. For all this, my vote has been favourable.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective defines trafficking in human beings as a violation of human dignity, the physical and mental integrity of victims. This form of crime is based on the exploitation of victims which includes exploitation for the purposes of prostitution, for forced labour, such as begging, slavery, the exploitation of criminal activities, as well as the removal of organs in order to obtain very high profits. The report warns that trafficking in human beings acquires a gender dimension, for example 80% of victims exposed to sexual exploitation are women and girls. It also stresses that it is important to protect and identify victims belonging to socially vulnerable groups such as children, young people, LGBTI people and people with disabilities, who remain somewhat forgotten. I voted positively because the report calls on Member States to correctly transpose Directive 2011/36/EU on trafficking in human beings, further strengthens the rights of the most vulnerable, encourages greater coordination in data collection to identify victims and promotes exchanges of best practices to address the specific needs of those victims.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for the implementation of this Directive which aims to prevent and combat trafficking in human beings and protecting the victims of its victims. I also believe that it is particularly important that this is from a gender perspective, as the vast majority of victims of THB (Trafficking in Human Beings) are women and girls, primarily for the purpose of sexual exploitation. In line with the Anti-Trafficking Directive to which the report refers, Member States need to take measures to reduce the demand for trafficking. We need better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims. The fight against THB requires close cooperation across the EU.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU of 5 April 2011 on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from a gender perspective because the universal strategy is not effective and the problem of different forms of trafficking in human beings, such as trafficking for sexual exploitation, trafficking to exploit labour and trafficking in children, must be addressed through specific and tailor-made policy measures. Most of the victims were women, girls and girls. It is important to encourage the identification, treatment and protection of victims and the support at their disposal through the report. Despite the directive, victims of trafficking in human beings are still not recognised early and consistently enough and continue to have problems with access to justice and services and fair treatment to which they are entitled under EU law. In line with the Commission's study on the gender dimension of trafficking in human beings, there are gender-specific harms in the case of victims trafficked for sexual exploitation in relation to other forms of trafficking and this should therefore be reflected in the services and assistance provided to them. In order to reduce the demand that is leading to increasing trafficking in human beings due to sexual exploitation, higher penalties should penalise those who buy such sexual services, not just those who sell them.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is now already transcending the borders of individual Member States, which is why I consider this phenomenon to be one of the most serious crimes in the world. Although more attention has recently been paid to the investigation and prosecution of trafficking cases from EU level, I am concerned that the total number of cases prosecuted in the EU remains low. I am aware that identifying victims is very difficult, but I believe that in the next period we will strengthen the support and protection of victims, including the right of the victim to legally settle and work in the Member State to which the victim was sold. I supported the resolution because I believe that prevention needs to be stepped up in order to protect victims, taking into account the root causes of people's vulnerability to and the fight against trafficking in human beings. I expect that, in line with the measures taken, sufficient mechanisms will be put in place to protect, assist and socially integrate victims of trafficking. I also expect that we will find a way to improve coordination and cooperation between key actors active in this area.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights under Article 5 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and a violation of the personal integrity of victims and a serious form of organised crime that threatens the rule of law. Although victims may be of very diverse genders and all ages, statistics clearly show that the majority (as many as 80%) victims of women and girls from Central and Eastern Europe. Directive 2011/36/EU on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims established a legal framework for more effective prosecution of traffickers. The Directive calls on the Member States to include a gender dimension in their initiatives to combat trafficking in human beings and to provide assistance and support to victims on a case-by-case basis. The report on the directive highlights the inadequate reporting of trafficking in human beings, pointing to inadequate implementation and a lack of political will. Furthermore, the report calls on Member States to cooperate more in the field of trafficking in human beings, including the identification of potential victims, and highlights the role of EU agencies in the early identification of victims at the Borders of the European Union. I believe that the report contributes to an intensified fight against trafficking in human beings, which is why I supported it.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Today the European Parliament voted on the Bearder report, which looks at the implementation of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective. Although people of all gender types, ages and backgrounds are victims of human trafficking, statistics show that women and girls make up the majority (80%).  The Anti-Trafficking Directive focuses on prevention, victim protection and criminal prosecution. There is specific attention to gender and children. The Bearder report provides facts and figures on the implementation of that Directive in several Member States and examines measures that address the gender dimension in trafficking in human beings. It states that prostitution is a Member State competence, but does ask the European Commission to investigate links between sexual services and trafficking in human beings. It is also argued that the demand for such services can be reduced by criminalising the buyer instead of the provider. The refugee crisis is increasing human trafficking, with women and unaccompanied minors being the main victims. That is why it is important to ensure safe and legal migration channels so that we undermine traffickers.  It is important that we put pressure on the Commission and the Member States to eradicate trafficking in human beings. I voted for this report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. Trafficking in human beings is a major problem that states must solve. However, the measures mentioned in the Bearder report do not comply with the principle of subsidiarity, as many areas are within the competences of the Member States. That is why I abstained from the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a crime that belongs to the modern form of slavery and is mainly related to inequalities in our society. If we are talking about trafficking in human beings, we are talking about a complex transnational phenomenon that can only be tackled effectively if the European institutions and the Member States act proactively together. It is necessary to provide for harsh sanctions not only for criminal groups, but also for individuals involved in trafficking in human beings.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on this report.  The N-VA stands for an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to all diverse target groups. This applies to all genders and especially to women.  It goes without saying that trafficking in human beings and the sexual exploitation of men, women and children constitute serious criminal offences and a violation of fundamental human rights. They deserve the greatest police and legal attention at all levels of policy.  However, N-VA must note that gender equality is being used to expand migration-related rights. For example, this report aimed to establish European humanitarian visas as a miracle solution against people smuggling. A tourist visa is used to transfer asylum seekers by plane to Europe, without any maximum ceiling. For us, an open borders policy is not the solution we want to find against such criminal practices.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against trafficking in human beings requires close cooperation with our partners across the EU. Labour MEPs have led calls for better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Trafficking in human beings is defined as recruitment, transport, translation, concealment or admission of persons, including the exchange or transfer of control over such persons, by using a threat, force or other form of coercion, abduction, deception, fraud, abuse of authority or position of helplessness, giving or receiving payment or benefit to achieve the consent of a person in control of another person, for exploitation purposes (Directive 2011/36/EU). Trafficking in human beings is a grave violation of the fundamental rights, human dignity and physical and psychological integrity of the victim, causing serious harm to victims that can have an impact for the rest of their lives. Unfortunately, the current refugee crisis has highlighted the lack of appropriate tools at European level to jointly combat trafficking in human beings, especially where sexual exploitation of women and children is aimed at. Trafficking in human beings is of utmost importance and the effectiveness of preventing and combating trafficking in human beings must be at an all-time high.  I support this report, as I believe that such a level of efficiency requires Member States to make full use of Europol's capacity to strengthen information sharing with Europol and to recognise human trafficking, within the legal and political framework of the European Union, as a gender-specific phenomenon that requires gender-friendly measures.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation and combating of the Directive on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from the point of view of gender equality. According to the Eurostat report on trafficking in human beings, women and girls account for 80% of the recorded victims of trafficking. The alarming figures confirm the thesis that traffickers are choosing the most vulnerable groups of people for victims, who in most cases face a difficult socio-economic situation.  If we want to take a step forward in strengthening the prosecution of organised crime networks that serve in human trafficking, then we need to improve the cooperation of the institutions of the European Union and the Member States. I support strengthening the prosecution of trafficking in human beings in the Member States, but this is not enough.  In addition to the repressive measures, we also need prevention, assistance and protection of victims, the education of professional staff dealing with this issue and, of course, good cross-border cooperation not only with Member States, but also with countries outside the European Union. As a society, we must have zero tolerance for human trafficking.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings constitutes a horrible violation of fundamental rights, and a violation of human dignity as well as the physical and psychological integrity of individuals. However, this report aims to fraudulently integrate illegal immigrants into the society of European states, ignoring the real problem which is the rapid deterioration of the living conditions of European citizens following the huge invasion of the Member States of the Union.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 In order not to be self-contradictory because of my obligation as Vice-President of the European People's Party in relation to the decision, since the Fidesz PP delegation voted differently from the group, I did not directly take part in the vote. In other words, I did not press the voting button, but I indicated to the PP group with my hands the voting position that had been decided jointly.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, which gives a comprehensive, realistic picture of the state of implementation of the EU Directive on trafficking in human beings adopted in 2011, on the basis of the regular Commission reporting obligation contained in the Directive. I think it is important that the report examines the 'gender' aspects of the issue in a number of ways, the situation of women who are particularly vulnerable to trafficking in human beings. I also appreciate the report's response to current developments in the refugee crisis, pointing to overlaps between the dangers of trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings, where refugees and migrants in general are also the target group most exposed to the activities of traffickers.  On the basis of the assessment of the situation of the report, it is also necessary to give even greater attention to the aspects of victim protection and assistance in the future, among the objectives highlighted in the Directive. In accordance with the spirit of the decision, I am convinced that we must continue to pay close attention to the worrying spread of international trafficking in human beings on the part of the European Parliament and to combat these serious crimes by all political means at our disposal.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a terrible violation of fundamental rights, as well as of human dignity and physical and mental integrity. Unfortunately, due to the still high demand, this process is thriving, generating profits estimated at around $150 billion per year. In order for anti-trafficking legislation to be effective, it must be accompanied by a clear cultural change, which is to move away from a culture of impunity towards a culture of zero tolerance for trafficking in human beings. EU Member States should therefore take the necessary measures to properly implement Directive 2011/36/EU in this regard as soon as possible. A coherent approach to the prosecution of trafficking in human beings is also necessary, including by strengthening regional or international cooperation. The European Parliament's report rightly calls on Member States to create emergency numbers that victims of trafficking and exploitation could call to seek help. Furthermore, a step in the right direction is undoubtedly the creation by the Commission of a website dedicated to the fight against trafficking in human beings, containing a database on EU-funded projects within the Union and in other areas. The EP report is another of parliament's many calls for coordinated action at all levels to effectively prevent trafficking in human beings. That is why I have chosen to support this document.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted to prevent and combat trafficking in human beings and to protect victims of trafficking in human beings on 5 May 2012. Member States should do more to protect victims of trafficking in human beings. Victims of trafficking in human beings must be treated specifically as victims, not criminals, and they must be given sufficient support to recover and return to normal life. I also voted to delete paragraph 48, which contradicts paragraph 51, which states that the regulation of prostitution falls within the competence of the Member States.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. There is an EU trafficking legislation, but unfortunately not all the countries have implemented it completely. Member States have to deal with this issue in two settings. First at home, where they have to take measures to reduce the demand for trafficking, and outside their Member State, where they have to increase the collaboration with other countries in the fight against human trafficking. There are several perspectives in tackling THB – starting with measures to diminish the demand, and continuing with the harsh punishments for the traffickers of human beings. More measures have to be put in place for the identification of victims and the special treatment that they need.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Trafficking in human beings (THB) is a large transnational phenomenon that brings profits of approximately USD 150 billion a year. Although 80% of victims are girls and women, the majority of whom are being trafficked for sexual exploitation, victims of THB can also be found in other types of legal and illegal activities, such as domestic work, agriculture, criminality and forced marriages. THB is not only a gross violation of fundamental human rights and a crime that undermines the rule of law, but can also cause victims severe physical and psychological harm that could last a lifetime. I believe that the only way to tackle THB in the European Union is for Member States to better work together in order to prevent people from becoming victims. It is essential to raise awareness of this problem and to empower women and girls in order to reduce their vulnerability. Furthermore, I think that coordinated systems of victim identification and victim assistance are due and a common set of guidelines in all Member States is needed. I would like to express my support for this resolution as it takes us one step closer to ending trafficking in human beings.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Member States should implement the directive more fervently and seriously in this area. The EU's legal and political framework recognises that trafficking is a gender-specific phenomenon and requires Member States to adopt measures that take into account gender differences. Article 1 of the directive stresses the need for a human trafficking approach that takes into account gender issues of equality. Women and men, girls and boys are vulnerable in different ways and are often trafficked for different purposes, and prevention, assistance and support measures must therefore take gender into account. Finally, the EU strategy identifies violence against women and gender inequality as one of the root causes of trafficking, and introduces a series of measures addressing the generic dimension of trafficking.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Between 2010 and 2012, the EU registered over 30 000 victims of trafficking, 80% of them women. The 2013 EU Anti-Trafficking Directive was a great step forwards towards giving victims of human trafficking tailored support. Despite this legislative progress, however, the directive has been implemented only very poorly by Member States. This is why I voted in favour of this report which analyses the level of implementation today. The vulnerability of the newly arrived migrants in Europe is a reminder that human trafficking operates without regard to national borders, which is why we will be strongest if we combat this crime at the European level. I hope that this report will give a new impetus to accelerating the implementation of the directive, to better protect and support its victims, and diminish the level of trafficking of human beings in the EU.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. Trafficking in human beings constitutes a violation of fundamental human rights under the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and a violation of the personal integrity of the victim and a serious form of organised crime affecting the rule of law. Statistics clearly show that the majority of victims (80%) are women and girls. Their vulnerability can be attributed to a number of elements: barriers to access to education, gender pay gap, unfair access to decent employment opportunities, gender-based violence, unemployment, migration and gender-insensitive development strategies. In any support or financing action to third countries or developing countries, the European Union should take account of the gender dimension and make it its priority.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it is clear that trafficking in human beings is one of the greatest crimes against humanity, which is directly directed against human dignity, freedom and humanity. There is, of course, only one way to prevent this practice: consistent persecution of traffickers and the inevitability of punishment. Both of these measures will have not only the necessary impact at a specific time, but preventive action would also be a consequence of them. We, the European Parliament, must support these legal changes, which will contribute to the suspension of one of the most violent crimes that should not have been the case in the 21st century.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 In accordance with Article 5. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights, as well as a violation of the victim's personal integrity and a serious form of organised crime endangering the state and the rule of law.  Although the victims cover a wide range of people of both sexes, different ages and different social environments, statistics clearly show that the majority of victims are women, girls and girls. In my view, prevention is essential in the fight against trafficking in human beings, so Member States must do their utmost to prevent people from becoming victims. I also support the proposal for Member States to design preventive initiatives in cooperation with social partners, civil society and trading survivors, taking into account best practices. I am aware of the fact that many migrants and refugees are victims of trafficking in human beings, but I cannot support a solution that would combat this kind of organised crime by opening our borders even more. We must discourage traffickers by tightening rather than loosening our migration policy. That's why I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the debates on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law (Rule 135 of the Rules of Procedure) because EU countries must make progress in protecting victims of trafficking in human beings while taking measures to prevent, assist and support victims, especially women.  In order to help victims, it is necessary to ensure that both the judiciary, the health system and social services are adequately trained in the early detection of victims and their further care.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. Since the European Commission has not been able to meet certain deadlines set out in Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective, the Bearder report calls for its effective implementation. It details measures to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims in the light of the following aspects: gender dimension, definition of trafficking in human beings, data collection for effective statistical treatment, prevention, identification and assistance to victims. It has a special impact on gender treatment, because we must not forget that 80% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and minors. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I firmly support this resolution as this terrible phenomenon must be stopped as soon as possible. Trafficking in human beings is a terrible violation of fundamental rights, as outlined in Article 5(3) of the EU Charter on Fundamental Rights, and a violation of human dignity and of the victims’ physical and psychological integrity, causing severe damage that often affects them for the rest of their lives, as well as a serious form of, mostly organised, crime driven by high demand and profits , estimated at some USD 150 billion a year. We should reinforce our efforts and means to fight this crime.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is in principle laudable but diverted from its purpose. The regularization of all women who denounce a prostitution or begging network would be tantamount to opening up an important legal source of immigration. This will be even more true for humanitarian visas. Moreover, the penalties imposed on criminals are not particularly deterrent and are therefore not likely to actually impede the activity of criminal networks.  However, the report calls for strong criminal sanctions to be implemented. With regard to clandestine work, "greater attention" is just requested to employers, subcontractors and other employment agencies, but without mentioning their criminal and civil liability. I am voting against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The United Nations stresses that trafficking in men and women must be recognised and the similarities and differences between women's and men's experiences of vulnerabilities and violations are analysed. Trafficking in human beings is the result of global economic and social inequalities, with the absence of public awareness of the problems associated with trafficking in human beings perpetuating a permissive environment for this phenomenon, while being intensified by the inequalities of society. The gender dimension requires careful monitoring in the implementation of European Union legislation to combat trafficking in human beings, and a 'universal' strategy is not effective as different forms of trafficking, such as trafficking for sexual exploitation, trafficking for labour and child trafficking, must be addressed through specific and tailored policy measures. All services of assistance for victims of trafficking in human beings must be truly unconditional and guarantee the absence of greater victimisation, as victims frequently do not know their own rights or how to effectively exercise them. In this respect, I support the need to speed up the process of full and correct implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and combating of trafficking in human beings and the protection of its victims.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. Since the European Commission has not been able to meet certain deadlines set out in Directive 2011/36/EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims from a gender perspective, the Bearder report calls for its effective implementation. It details measures to improve the protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce the vulnerability of potential victims in the light of the following aspects: gender dimension, definition of trafficking in human beings, data collection for effective statistical treatment, prevention, identification and assistance to victims. It has a special impact on gender treatment, because we must not forget that 80% of victims of trafficking in human beings are women and minors. We voted in favour of the report.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it calls on states to do more to properly implement the anti-trafficking directive and calls for it to be implemented from a gender perspective. At the same time, the report also reminds states of their obligations in identifying and protecting victims and introduces important references on the protection of potential asylum seekers and the LGBT collective.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the Commission has set up an anti-trafficking website containing a database of EU-funded projects in the EU and elsewhere, as well as updated information on EU legal and policy instruments, measures to combat trafficking in human beings in the Member States, access to finance and EU initiatives.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Member States must do all they can to protect victims of trafficking in human beings, especially women and children, who are very vulnerable groups. We cannot allow data such as those of 2015 to be repeated, in which 10,000 un escorted children appeared under Europol. We are therefore talking about a text which rightly addresses these problems, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favour.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. \u2012 "Speak for those who are defenseless, protect the right of the trampled". This text from the Book of Proverbs fits well with this morning's debate. Thousands of women become victims of human trafficking every year and end up in prostitution in Europe. Their situation is clear: this is modern slavery. We speak for them today and we also want justice to be spoken. The Bearder report rightly focuses on the demand side of human trafficking and calls it the 'driving force'. In countries where the purchase of sexual services has been criminalised, the trade in women has declined. A new French law fines customers. In my own country, the Netherlands, my party is working on an initiative law, whereby clients who knowingly use a prostitute who is forced to do her job can be tackled. People are not commodities, and prostitution is not a normal profession! I supported this resolution because it contains many good elements. But I voted against the paragraphs that refer to abortion.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. The fight against trafficking in human beings requires better cooperation between all the Member States of the European Union. We must curb trafficking in human beings and identify and punish those responsible for it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report focuses on the implementation of the Directive on the Prevention of Trafficking in Human Beings and the fight against it.  The European Commission has not met the deadlines for the publication of a report assessing the implementation by Member States of the provisions of this directive.  Trafficking in human beings claimed more than 30,000 victims (registered) in the EU between 2010 and 2012: 80% were women and 16% were children, 13% of whom were girls. Women and girls account for 95% of victims of sexual exploitation and trafficking.  Trafficking in human beings is put forward by Member States to justify repressive policies towards migrants without implementing European texts. This report goes in the right direction by insisting on a ban on penalizing victims of trafficking. They must be able to receive protection and assistance by following a gender-differentiated approach with an increase in the number of shelters or by strengthening reintegration programmes for victims.  The report also stresses the importance of the systematic recognition by all Member States of the right to abortion for victims. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011/36 / EU on the prevention and fight against trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims aims at better protection of victims of trafficking in human beings and reducing the vulnerability of potential victims.  The report identifies that human trafficking is driven by the demand for high profits, which are estimated at about US$150 million per year. It analyzes the root causes of trafficking and finds that trafficking in women, girls, men and boys for sexual exploitation has decreased in countries that criminalize demand, including both pimping and the client. The report clearly identifies that women and girls are particularly vulnerable, as well as asylum seekers, refugees and migrants, and special attention should be paid to trafficking in women, children and other vulnerable groups. It calls on the EU Member States to provide adequate training for all actors in this process.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU of 5 April 2011 on preventing and combating trafficking in human beings and protecting its victims from a gender perspective. The text calls for special measures for transgender refugees, which I strongly reject. The resolution also calls for a residence permit for EU citizens and third-country nationals who have been victims of trafficking in human beings. I reject this, as it violates the sovereignty of Member States.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against trafficking in human beings requires close cooperation with our partners across the EU. Labour MEPs have led calls for better identification, treatment and support for victims as well as harsher penalties for traffickers and those who exploit victims. Women, girls and LGBTI persons are at particular risk so it is important to give special consideration to victims from a gender perspective.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Written. – I fully support Catherine Bearder's report on the implementation of Directive 2011/36/EU. Although Article 5 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union irreversible protects the integrity of the individual, these rights are still violated on a daily basis. The report discusses important aspects of the problem, such as the fact that women and young girls in particular are victims of human trafficking. In addition, we face a lot of difficulties, including finding representative data, identifying victims and linking the right actions to a particular violation.  The report provides very specific answers and recommendations, such as providing legal assistance to the victims involved and launching hotlines and information campaigns that lower the threshold for them. It also rightly calls for increased exchanges and better cooperation between Member States. Across the board, it also points out that there needs to be a general focus on women, children, refugees and LGBTI people in solving this problem.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – Since my election in 2004, I have also been involved in the problem of trafficking in human beings. This modern-day slavery, which flourishes even in countries that are proud of humanism and democratic regimes, is a disgrace to modern society. For many years, we have talked mainly about prosecuting trafficking and helping victims. I have always felt a deficit in prevention activities. I welcome the fact that this report also focuses on going through trade. At the same time, the report particularly highlights the growing market for children. I am very sorry that I could not support the report because the resolution supports abortion (points 71 and 75). We try to protect one life at risk in the report and we destroy the other. This, too, shows the weakness of our policies. Likewise, the report is ambiguous. In the French text, he talks about tackling the problem from the perspective of equality between men and women, in English and others from the perspective of gender. The problem is that we use the word 'gender' in the EU document dictionary, which is not defined in European or international legislation. This certainly does not help the victims of human trafficking.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution by giving my vote in favour. The safeguarding and protection of human rights, as well as the defence of human dignity, is non-negotiable.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2011/36/EU aims to better protect victims of trafficking in human beings and reduce their vulnerability, with clear evidence for the gender dimension. The own-initiative report we are debating today analyses a number of aspects, including the gender dimension, the definition of traffic, the availability of data and statistics. Particular emphasis is placed on prevention, which is considered essential to combat trafficking in human beings and to defend the women involved in particular. In order to take initiatives in the field of training and emancipation, Parliament's request to present a legislative proposal to combat violence against women has been reiterated. It also addresses the issue of victim identification, where member states are obliged to ensure that persons, units and services responsible for investigating and prosecuting traffic violations are properly trained. However, the report has found that this has not been implemented by the Member States themselves. Finally, the issue of victim care is highlighted, paying attention to the gender dimension. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 Trafficking in human beings is a problem that affects all the countries of the Union and to which the greatest attention and care must be paid. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution in order to consider the gender perspective in the fight against this crime. It is mainly the cover-ups of women and children, who account for 80% of exploited human beings, that are exploited by male traffickers. Of these, about 95% are placed on the prostitution black market. The resolution calls for greater effectiveness in the fight against trafficking in human beings and calls, in addition to this commitment, for policies to support women and children who are victims of abuse to be developed, adopting a perspective of defending individual rights and reintegrating them into society. I fully agree with the position taken by my political group: we have succeeded in criminalising trafficking in human beings rather than the victims of this trafficking.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The resolution artfully obscures the root cause of the phenomenon, namely the capitalist mode of production which, using labour force as a commodity, also converts people into goods. It isolates "organised crime" as an exclusive cause, hiding that it works by the rules of the capitalist enterprise in the exploitative system, which recognizes profit as its only supreme value. It entrusts the solution of the problem to the unpopular repressive mechanisms of the EU and governments, such as Europol, recommends, in support of victims, more funding for NGOs often suspected of their action, rather than supporting state infrastructure and services. The policy of the EU and civil governments shapes the barbaric reality experienced by women in the grassroots. It establishes prostitution – the ultimate form of commercialization and exploitation of human existence – as a profession, and its separation into voluntary and coercive, uses forced prostitution to expand legal prostitution. The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece was white, stressing that, in a world dominated by monopolies, there is absolutely no qualms about any commercialisation of human life of all kinds. That is why the people must overthrow them by abolishing the exploitation of man by man.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's report. This report is also important through the migration crisis. It is an indisputable fact that women and children can be forced into sexual services in exchange for protection in order to survive and progress on their migration journey and to ensure basic livelihoods. These victims must be assisted. Personally, I am concerned that the use of the services of victims of trafficking in human beings is not yet considered a criminal offence in all Member States, although I am aware of the fact that from a judicial point of view it is difficult to prove these acts. On the contrary, I positively welcome the fact that the Commission has set up anti-trafficking websites containing a database of projects financially supported by the EU in the EU and other countries.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The FEMM Report aimed to evaluate measures in the field of combating trafficking in human beings, in particular from a gender perspective. In the text, the rapporteur focused on the correct procedures for identifying victims of trafficking in human beings and on the various ways of support and assistance that we can provide them. In my opinion, the main idea and message of the whole report was very good and, especially in the light of the current migration and refugee crisis, very timely and important. However, I do not support a practice in which individual groups incorporate their agenda into a report of this type, which is controversial for many Member States. As a result, we cannot support reports that we would otherwise agree with. This is also the case with this report, when, due to certain negative aspects, I did not finally support the report and abstained from voting on the report as a whole.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported the report because I believe it highlights the key problems in preventing trafficking in human beings. It recalls that differences in member states' legislation facilitate organised crime activities, as the risk of law enforcement is still too low and sanctions to deter this crime are still insufficient compared to the potential high profits. Identifying victims, which can be found in various legal and illegal activities, remains one of the most difficult aspects of preventing trafficking in human beings. Therefore, enhanced cooperation between Europol and national law enforcement authorities, their additional professional training, the establishment of appropriate victim support and awareness among the general public of any new forms of trafficking in human beings are needed.

name: Nathan GILL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr. President, I am very grateful to have this opportunity to discuss the important issue of foreign currency loans.  Taking out a mortgage to buy a home is the single biggest financial transaction that most people undertake in their lives. So we need a vibrant and competitive mortgage market, one where people have choice, but also one where they know what they are buying and what risks they are taking on. One of the products that became popular in recent years was loans made in foreign currencies, and for many years they offered consumers low interest rates. But recent experience has shown that they can become a problem if they are offered to households that cannot protect themselves properly against sudden changes in exchange rates, and here I think loans in Swiss francs, provide a good example.  These have been popular in countries like Croatia, Poland, Hungary and Romania. But when the Swiss National Bank stopped pegging Swiss francs to the euro in January last year, the cost of servicing those mortgages shot up and that left households struggling to keep up with their mortgage repayments, which in turn put pressure on governments to take action to help those who were in difficulty. Some countries have already passed laws; others are considering doing so. In terms of what the Commission has done for the future, we have acted to ensure that risks associated with foreign currency loans are better managed by strengthening consumer protection in the Mortgage Credit Directive.  But that does not deal with the problem of the existing loans in foreign currencies, and here we are working closely with governments that are considering how best to respond. Of course, there is a need to protect the interests of consumers, but we also need to make sure that any measures taken are fully consistent with the single market and that they do not restrict disproportionately the free movement of capital or the freedom of European companies to do business anywhere in the EU. We also have to consider the potential damage that would be done to investor confidence if we were to undermine legal certainty.  Croatia has chosen to pass legislation that allows borrowers to convert Swiss-franc loans into euro-denominated loans at an exchange rate that pre-dates the franc's appreciation. It puts borrowers in the position that they would have been had they initially chosen a euro-denominated loan, but it places the cost of the conversion, a cost that I understand is some EUR 1 billion, almost wholly on the shoulders of the banks that issued the loans without regard to the different circumstances of the borrowers. The Commission was not consulted on the draft legislation, and the Croatian government was under no obligation to do so. Since its adoption, we have assessed whether Croatia's amendments to its Consumer Credit Act and the Credit Institutions Act are compatible with the principles of the single market. Let me give you our initial analysis. It is clear that the goal of protecting borrowers to avoid a debt crisis can justify restrictions to the free movement of capital or the freedom of establishment, but in our view, allowing borrowers to exchange their loans from Swiss francs into euros at an artificially low exchange rate and placing the cost almost exclusively on lenders goes beyond what is needed to avoid a crisis and protect those borrowers. There is clearly a problem that needs tackling, so we need to find a proportionate solution in line with Treaty freedoms and one that helps maintain investor confidence in Croatia.  The issue has been discussed at the Ecofin Council. We are monitoring the situation carefully in Croatia, but also in other countries that are currently considering passing legislation. We are keeping all options open, including of course opening an infringement procedure if that proves necessary. We are in close contact with the Croatian Government, who tell us that they are keen to find a way forward and they are talking to the banks concerned to find a more balanced approach that shares the burden of adjustment more fairly. I support that approach, but clearly there must be progress soon or we will have to take appropriate action. So, we need a solution that strikes the right balance, one that is consistent with EU legislation, that protects consumers but also investment and the single market. That is the solution that I will continue to push for, and that is what I want to see in every Member State where this is currently a matter of concern.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! For the time being, Commissioner Hill, thank you for answering our question. We asked this question because laws adopted and prepared to convert foreign currency loans in Romania, Poland and Croatia – sometimes even retroactively – are shaking the confidence of citizens and investors. Credibility, legal certainty and confidence are being undermined.  Recent steps have led to great concern about the reliability, predictability and stability of the legal framework, not only in these countries, but also in the European Union. And the European Central Bank has made it clear that these measures have a negative impact on financial stability, the banking sector and the real economy, as well as a great risk of contagion on the other Member States. I therefore say very clearly that Europe's populists – and there is a connection here – must not shake the foundations of our legal order when they are out for short-term votes.  The rule of law is one of the cornerstones of the common Europe! We must defend the community of law and the European Union community of values and must not allow confidence and credibility to be retroactively overridden in the deposition of trust and credibility, contrary to European law.  And, Commissioner, I would like to add a few additional questions to you in this context. You touched it, but you didn't answer it completely.  Which countries have informed the Commission in advance of the legislative proposals, as would be mandatory under EU law? What measures do you intend to take to make it clear to states facing such debates that this is contrary to EU law – namely the freedom of capital – and what dangers this envisad?  How do you see the central pillars of the common Europe, such as the free movement of capital and legal certainty, if rules are introduced in which loans are suddenly retroactively relocated to a historical interest rate?  Europe's economic strength has been, and still is, its rule of law and its entrepreneurial freedom. Let us therefore work together to ensure that short-term populist measures or risks do not jeopardise these strengths.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, of course, banks must be protected. Of course, the European single market is important. Predictability for investors is again very important. We are, however, talking about a commercial contract, a commercial contract between two parties that must also assume the benefits and risks equally. In a commercial contract, it is the banks that give the credit, they have interest, they receive insurance but, at the same time, they also have to bear certain risks. It must be very clear to everyone that we are still talking about the effects of the 2008 crisis. We are talking about loans taken by European citizens in the period 2007-2008 (when interest rates were 10-11%, when house prices were very high), customers who paid for years these loans, who gave advance of 20-30%. Basically, the banks recovered their credit all these years but, because these customers were no longer able to pay that credit, the banks also took their house and left them indebted.  It is a social phenomenon, it is a very great social tragedy in many countries, such as Croatia, such as Romania, which must be managed by all the stakeholders. We must bear in mind that at the heart of the financial crisis of 2008 were primarily banks which, overnight, turned from commercial banks into investment banks that gave mortgages, without taking any safety measures, to people who could not pay those loans in ten lifetimes, just because they could roll them over. This irresponsibility of the banks and this hunger for profit of the banking system has cost us all a great lot.  Guess what! Banks have been bailed out, bank executives, investment managers in those banks have retained their financial benefits, but people have been homeless after paying for years for those homes and not only have they run out of homes, but they still owe them. This situation cannot continue.  You are saying that in Croatia a billion is the "price" – I put quotation marks – that banks pay for this situation to be regulated and to assume some of the burden of this situation. But in addition to that figure, Commissioner, I would also be interested in putting in other figures, because a figure is never enough. What is the amount of credits given during that period? What is the profit rate of the banks during that period? What is the value of the housing assets that banks have recovered from customers who have not been able to pay their homes and how have they recovered it in the housing market?  There are a lot of negative phenomena related to this foreign currency credit crisis. There are, for example, situations in Romania where banks have taken the homes of those who have not been able to pay, have given them to so-called executors, who have capitalized on a black market, parallel, real estate at prices of nothing, and will return to certain people who had connections with the banks that had given the original credit. It's a phenomenon that's affected a lot of people. It is a negative phenomenon, which also distorts the market economy to which you refer.  This is not just about the free movement of capital. It is about the responsibility of the financial system, the responsibility of the banks and the measures they take when they have loans. No one prevents a bank from taking additional safety measures, from letting the customer choose, for example, as in Romania, for the law that has just passed, the Law on Payment, to opt to give the property back when it can no longer pay or to come up with additional guarantees. In Romania has now passed a very good law, from our point of view, the Law of payment, which says that a citizen, if he can no longer pay his mortgage, the real estate loan, give the real estate to the bank and close his debt. Of course there has been very high pressure: that it is not right, that investors will no longer have predictability, but the situation is a very simple one. In the loan agreement, the mortgage agreement makes it very clear that the mortgage covers the loan, the amount of the loan. Therefore, when the property returns to the bank, it is closed. The debt is closed. Say that banks suffer very large losses. What is the loss, when an ordinary person pays 30% in advance, pays interest and rates for years, which cover the difference in money and, at some point, can no longer pay, after a year, two, three? The bank remains with the advance, the bank remains with the rates paid and the bank remains with the real estate. What is the loss of the bank, it is not very clear to me. I believe that it must be a clear contract, in which everyone assumes the benefits and costs of this contract, and banks must remain commercial banks, never be investment banks again.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I cannot help but note the fact that foreign currency loans are extremely widespread in some Member States. In particular, loans in Swiss francs have been popular in the recent past in eastern Europe countries, where about 60% of outstanding loans are taken in foreign currency.  The data show that loans in foreign currency belong mainly to European households, the share of the corporate and government sectors is relatively small. It is also noticeable that only in the UK and Luxembourg a large percentage of loans in Swiss francs are granted to persons – citizens of other countries, which reflects the status of these countries as international financial centres. The attractiveness of loans in foreign currency lies in their immediate benefits, such as lower interest rates and a longer repayment period. However, they pose quite a few risks, as households do not expect to have income in the relevant foreign currency or to be protected from currency risk.  As I have already noted, a few years ago in Central and Eastern Europe the popularity of loans in foreign currency, in particular Swiss francs, increased as interest rates were much lower in Switzerland. People took advantage of such loans for the purchase of real estate. In 2008, however, the value of many currencies collapsed against the franc, resulting in borrowers being put in a situation where they had to repay in local currency an amount many times higher than the value of the loan.  According to data from 2008, Bulgarians are the world record-holder for borrowing in foreign currency, among the most popular are loans for buying homes. However, according to analyses conducted last autumn, 99% of bank loans are in BGN or EURO, as these currencies are considered stable and are not expected to be affected by the changes happening in international markets. While in the 1990s loans in dollars or francs were popular among my compatriots, after Bulgaria's accession to the EU, many businesses and households benefited from the integration of our country's economy into the European economy and increasingly used the euro and bgn.  In addition to the security of the euro, this is also due to the protection that European legislation provides to its citizens. In particular, the Unfair Terms Directive and the case-law of the Court of Justice of the European Union provide a set of rules to replace unfair terms on such credit agreements in foreign currency.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, it seems that we are talking about a very specific technical issue here, but in fact we are talking about a fundamental political problem, which is transversal to many other issues, and we end up playing it all the time.  I would like, however, to start with a note: it seems to me, from the outset, that the subject of this debate is wrong, because if we take into account the cases that are here, the loans that have been reported are loans that have been made in national currencies and not in foreign currency. But let's not be under any illusions. In fact, the purpose of the reported practices is to eliminate all risk on the side of financial institutions, discharging this risk, as always, on top of customers.  The only justification for the profitability of banking activity is that we assume that the risk is also taken on the part of banks — either in all or at least part of the risk. That is what should be taken into account when we talk about any credit agreement. But that is not the case in most mortgage contracts, and, moreover, every time we talk about this, we must remember the number of families who have had tragic situations, because they have not been able to repay their loans, have had to be left without a home and have yet to have to pay. Therefore, the risk was entirely on the side of families and the financial sector fully protected. In this regard, I would say that the response of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of this House on this particular matter is quite revealing. And it is revealing, I would say, of the attitude of the European institutions on the regulation of the financial sector. The European institutions have no problem interfering in the management of the national financial sectors, as they did very recently, and illegally, in the process of selling Banif in Portugal. But if there are citizens who denounce contracts that violate the principles of good faith, balance and justice, the response of the European institutions is very simple and it is almost always the same: put the banks in court and resolve themselves.  Therefore, the titanic Europe that we see in imposing budgetary policies or in the choice of buyers in national competitions always becomes, or almost always, a noist when it comes to protecting citizens against those who are the abuses of the financial sector. And it is for these and for other reasons, Commissioner, that the credibility of the European institutions and the European Union has fallen sharply across Europe. There can no longer be such a heavy burden on citizens and all excuses and some more to continue to protect the financial sector. And therefore promises are not enough; it is not enough to say that the Commission intends to protect consumers. Concrete action is needed, and I would like to see the same commitment by the Commission to protect the citizens of this European Union, as it is committed to protecting the internal market and the free movement of capital.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I have been looking forward to this debate today. I didn't want to believe my eyes when I saw on the agenda that it was going to be foreign currency loans. Well, I'm telling you, it finally looks like their hearts have opened. These Eurocrats have had enough of receiving hundreds of letters a day from relatives of foreign currency loan victims who have committed suicide. They have had enough of the fact that, while we live in Europe, like the most depressive countries, a lot of people who are enslaved by the debtor lose their homes, get sick physically and mentally, families are destroyed, human fates are ruined. They're finally trying to find a solution. They have a say in everything, they talk about everything, now they are determined to do something good for the people of Europe and they will be obliged to push for a solution. Turns out it's not!  They want infringement proceedings to be opened against Croatia because the Croatian state sided with the people and sided with the foreign currency loan victims against the banks. Go Croatia! What you, the European Union, are doing is a disgrace and a disgrace. They're intertwined with organized crime networks, economic criminals, you as political criminals are forming a total mafia. How dare you look in the mirror? Shame on you. And, Commissioner, make a statement about your vision for people, because we already know how you want to support and save the banks. I'm waiting to see what your intentions are with people.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, this debate is extremely interesting, it is a pity that we are unfortunately addressing such an important issue at the end of the meeting on Thursday afternoon. I have listened very carefully to your speech, Commissioner, and I am glad that the European Commission sees it as important to negotiate with individual national governments that are, say, labour-related, conversion laws, and that we are trying to find a solution that, on the one hand, will help people who have been put in a difficult social situation, but on the other hand that we are looking for a solution that will not harm the internal market of the European Union. that we are looking for a solution that is not retroactive, and that we are looking for a solution that does not conflict with the principles on which our integration is based. On the one hand, I sympathise with people who, by taking out credit in another currency, have put their credit in a difficult economic situation, on the other hand, the result cannot be the adoption of laws that are contrary to the principles of the European Union. I am very glad, Commissioner, that you are watching this and that you have reassured us that you are dealing with individual national governments.  In short, if some national governments want to help their fellow citizens who have taken risks and taken out favorable loans that have subsequently proved less profitable, then these governments and these countries cannot do so at the expense of business. And they should not do this at the expense of another group of borrowers. In short, if we help one group of borrowers, how do other borrowers who were more responsible take out less attractive loans and now they don't get into a difficult situation? Let us also note that the assistance of one group of debtors is always at the expense of someone else and that it is therefore also other debtors who have approached the matter more responsibly. I am, Mr Commissioner, from the Czech Republic, and just as there was a boom in these foreign loans in Swiss francs in Eastern Europe, which we are essentially talking about, I was in the Czech Government, which strongly warned Czechs not to make good promises and not to take out loans in Swiss francs. In the Czech Republic, too, we do not have this problem at the moment. We have strong banking, we have a strong crown, even though we are a relatively small country, and we do not solve the problems that our neighbors solve. And there is also the question of how governments in eastern European countries contributed to this at the time, and how they warned their citizens at the time that if they took out an attractive loan, they would increase their risk and that the risk might fall on them. So I am very much begging you not to be subject to populism here, and to really – and I feel that this effort is on your side – to have a debate with national governments and to look for solutions that do not harm the internal market, which for me personally is the main value of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, if one looks at the actual distribution of currencies around the world, then it is clear that an absolute majority rarely moves across native borders for the purpose of trade, investment or anything else – unless numismatics are involved. Therefore, in order to engage in trade relations, national currencies have to get exchanged for something else. For the most part that includes the US dollar, the euro, the Japanese yen, pound sterling, the Australian dollar, the Swiss franc, the Chinese yuan and the Russian rouble. The same situation applies to foreign currency lending: for example, according to the European Central Bank, in January 2016 most foreign currency loans within the EU itself were in euros, US dollars or Swiss francs. Households are usually the primary borrowers, with non-financial institutions coming next and financial institutions third.  Depending on the country, households and non-financial counterparties (NFCs) may change places. For example, most such loans in Bulgaria are by NFCs, while households constitute a majority in Poland. Interestingly enough, in Hungary and the Czech Republic household loans in foreign currency are virtually non-existent. At the same time in the UK, Cyprus, Ireland and Luxembourg, a majority of foreign currency loans are taken by financial institutions. Moreover, Swiss francs dominate in foreign currency lending in Austria, while in Poland and Greece their share is around half of all such loans. In other words, depending on each country, financial stability, economic growth and other factors, a choice is made in which currency it is more reasonable to take loans. A covered foreign currency loan, such as a loan denominated in a currency other than that of the borrower’s home country, for which repayment terms are prearranged through the use of a forward currency contract, means that an agreement is in place that obligates parties to exchange given quantities of currencies at a pre-specified exchange rate with a certain future date. However, not all foreign currency loans are covered, and this is precisely where an effective regulatory system is necessary in order to create an environment where, for instance, potential borrowers are fully aware of lending specificities, while banks cannot make unsubstantiated demands or change the lending conditions midway through. The principle risk of foreign currency (forex) lending is the potential volatility of the exchange rate involved. For example, since the Bulgarian lev and Danish crown are linked to the euro, if a Bulgarian or Danish national takes a loan in euros, the risk of rapidly increasing loan payments is rather low, so one of the only things a person would have to worry about is the stability of their income. If, however, a Russian or Ukrainian national decided to take a loan in a foreign currency – for example in US dollars or euros – a couple of years ago, the situation may have turned out differently, as is precisely the case now due to several currencies’ depreciation, including the Russian rouble and Ukrainian hryvnia, over the last two years. Of course, there may be serious issues arising from having a common currency, due to financial crises or internal financial instability taking place in one or more states employing the currency, such as Greece for example, where the question of the reinstitution of the Greek drachma was seriously considered some time ago. For the most part, however, having a common currency is quite beneficial. In the case of foreign currency loans, this is quite true if the common currency has a stable exchange rate in relation to the one in which the loan was made. A couple of months ago, questions for oral answers were submitted to the Commission on the matter of foreign currency loans, or more precisely retrospective conversion of foreign currency loans into local currency loans. The issue mostly concerns EU Member States outside the eurozone.
